webTitle: Ipswich 2 - 1 Man City

fields.headline: City tumble through trapdoor
fields.trailText: Manchester City will join Coventry and Bradford in the Nationwide First Division next season while Ipswich wait on the result of tonight's game at Anfield to see if they can still make the Champions League.
fields.body:
A year is a short time in football. On May 7 2000 Manchester City beat Blackburn to secure promotion to the Premiership after four years in the wilderness. Last night, exactly 365 days later, City were relegated back to the First Division, plunging their long-suffering fans into the grips of despair again.

Hearts sank and tears flowed as City failed to come up with the win they needed to keep alive their hopes of avoiding the drop. They fought gallantly and took the lead against the run of play with 15 minutes of the game remaining. But Ipswich, continuing the spirit of a wonderful season, hit back with two late goals to keep alive their hopes of securing an improbable place in the Champions League, which will be ended only if Liverpool beat Chelsea tonight.

The night was not only enjoyable for Ipswich but for Middlesbrough too. It was Terry Venables' team that City could have caught had they won. But the man brought in to rescue Boro will now earn his reported £400,000 for keeping them in the Premiership as City join Bradford and Coventry in relegation.

"Everyone's very low," said the City manager Joe Royle. "Nine times this season we have taken the lead and lost it. It's just concentration at the highest level. Generally the defence has not always been up to it. It is no coincidence that the bottom three are going down with the most goals conceded in the division. As for next season, it's not the time to talk about it. Let's all be miserable for a while first."

It is difficult to believe that these two clubs came up together last season - Ipswich actually via the play-offs - so different are their positions one year on. Royle believes that has a lot to do with City being in the Second Division only two seasons ago.

"Ipswich have had the continuity we lacked," he said. "They were four years in the making in the First Division whereas we had one season there. They added one or two players in the summer while we needed more radical changes and it takes time for everyone to settle."

Perhaps like Charlton they will return much stronger. Certainly the City chairman is thinking positive. "I'm sure we'll be back," said David Bernstein. "The club is in very strong shape."

City's plan on the night was to soak up the early pressure, secure a base and strengthen the attack in the second half by bringing on Shaun Goater as an extra attacker.

It worked up to a point. Despite the loss of their leading scorer Marcus Stewart, Ipswich pressed hard from the start, their flowing movement carving holes in City's defence.

Jermaine Wright, James Scowcroft, Matt Holland, Martijn Reuser and Alun Armstrong all went close before the break. When City managed to get the ball, they struggled to make progress as Ipswich closed them down.

It was no surprise that City's best early chance came on the break. But despite having a three-on-two advantage, the chance was fluffed by Paulo Wanchope, who shot tamely at Richard Wright.

At half-time, with City's plan working well, Shaun Goater came on and Royle's forward thinking almost paid dividends immediately.

A soft ball played into the Ipswich box was headed clear but only to the edge of the area where Wanchope executed an audacious overhead kick and hit the outside of the post with Wright scrambling to get anywhere near.

Suddenly City looked threatening and on 74 minutes they took the lead. Danny Tiatto's ball found Wanchope about 20 yards out. The big striker pivoted and unleashed a wicked shot which Wright could only parry, Goater beating the keeper's lunge to poke the ball home.

But Goater hobbled off following the collision and, just when City thought that a miracle was on the cards, Ipswich equalised.

Jamie Clapham's long ball forward was headed down by Scowcroft, Richard Naylor flicked it on and the captain Matt Holland nipped in to shoot past Carlo Nash. City's lead had lasted four minutes.

Worse was to follow. Five minutes from time Armstrong caught City pushing forward in search of a vital winner, crossed from the right and Reuser, unmarked, headed Ipswich ahead from close range.

City's dream was over but Ipswich's is still very much alive.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Comment: Whitehall voices more dissent under Labour

fields.headline: Disobedient servants
fields.standfirst:
Whitehall mandarins have disagreed with ministerial decisions and been overruled more often under Labour
Special report: Whitehall
Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Whitehall mandarins have disagreed with ministerial decisions and been overruled more often under Labour.
fields.body:
Senior civil servants have issued formal "notes of dissent" against ministers more frequently under Blair than they did under Major. By Whitehall convention, a department's permanent secretary can refuse to implement any ministerial decision if the official believes that that decision is unjustified, either because it is a waste of taxpayers' money or because it is improper. The minister then has to overrule this declaration of dissent from the top official by issuing a specific direction instructing officials to carry out the decision.

In this role, the permanent secretary is known as the accounting officer, since he or she is personally responsible for the expenditure of public money in the department. And the right to register dissatisfaction in this way is potentially a powerful tool for senior civil servants, created in 1866 to prevent abuses by politicians. Peter Hennessy of Queen Mary and Westfield College, London, calls it a "tactical nuclear weapon". Officials resort to them rarely. Since May 1997, Labour ministers have instructed their officials in this fashion on 13 occasions. By comparison, ministers used them seven times in the last four years of John Major's administration.

This raises two questions. Is this increase a sign that relations between ministers and senior civil servants have been worse under Labour? The second, wider question is about the constitutional position of civil servants who want to blow the whistle on ministerial abuses.

To the first, the answer seems to be no, to judge by the nature of the instructions. Many of the directions seem to be quite technical, more to do with following longstanding Whitehall procedures than real disputes. Details of ministerial directions stretching back to 1993 have been released to Liberal Democrat MP Matthew Taylor and to the Guardian under the open government code. They give a broad outline of these incidents, but not the actual documents relating to the directions.

The most explosive dispute of this sort in living memory occurred in 1991 when the foreign secretary Douglas Hurd, with the support of John Major, rejected the advice of Sir Tim Lankester, the permanent secretary at what was then known as the Overseas Development Administration, and decided to finance the construction of the Pergau dam in Malaysia with £234m of taxpayers' money.

Sir Tim had warned that the dam project was a very "bad buy" and "an abuse" of the aid budget. His judgement was later vindicated. The National Audit Office (NAO) condemned the decision which was also ruled unlawful by judges. The dispute had been kept secret within government for two years.

Following the controversy, the rules were changed so that each ministerial decision must now be reported immediately to the NAO, which usually informs the chairman of the House of Commons public accounts committee (PAC). The NAO and PAC make these directions public, but usually in a low-key way. In one case, information was simply placed in the Commons library which is not open to members of the public. There could be better ways of publicising them.

The most high-profile case under Blair concerns the Millennium Dome. On two occasions last year, Mike O'Connor, the chief official of the Millennium Commission, objected to giving grants of £29m and then £47m to bail out the hapless project. But he was overruled by the culture secretary Chris Smith, who argued that it would cost much more money and damage the country's image to close the dome early.

Ministers often overrule officials if there are wider considerations than just money. Two years ago it emerged that hundreds of disabled people were receiving welfare benefits to which they were not actually entitled, because of errors in the benefits system. The disabled people were not at fault, but were faced with having to repay the money, sometimes amounting to thousands of pounds. Alistair Darling, then social security minister, decided that this was unacceptable and ordered officials not to attempt to recover the overpayments, which totalled around £15m. Legislation was later introduced to correct the errors.

Ministerial directions come in all shapes and sizes, and some are quite minor. For instance, defence ministers wanted to spend £500 to allow the family of a dead serviceman to fly to Croatia for compassionate reasons. Civil servants pointed out last August that, strictly speaking, this sum fell outside the scope of expenditure that could be officially authorised.

Similarly, in the previous year, the Ministry of Defence sold off a property to a local childcare group for a slightly lower price than had been offered by a commercial company. Theoretically, the higher price should have been accepted by the MoD, especially since helping the childcare group was not a stipulated function of the MoD. However, defence ministers approved the sale to the group as it helped to promote the government's overall childcare strategy and "contributed to the wider community".

The convention of ministerial directions exists in some thing of a constitutional vacuum. During the Thatcher era Robert Armstrong, the head of the civil service, issued his much-criticised doctrine that civil servants are employed merely to execute the wishes of ministers and have no wider responsibilities. It seemed to leave no room for whistleblowing.

Tony Blair has done little to modernise the doctrine, although a civil service act to put official activity on a statutory footing has been promised. The Commons public administration committee noted recently that in the new constitutional climate shaped by devolution, the Human Rights Act and the Freedom of Information Act, the time was ripe for such legislation, to put the civil service on a "clearer and firmer constitutional footing".

 Rob Evans is a Guardian reporter.

webTitle: Help me fire my assistant

fields.headline: Help me fire my assistant
fields.trailText: May 8: I am an administrator in charge of two secretaries: one does not do any work and is carried by the other. I now stand to lose the best one - is there anyway I can get her colleague the sack?
fields.body:
The problem

I am an administrator in an office of three people looking after 15 project officers but Sheila, our secretary, is a real drama queen. The other, Michelle, is a real gem and she carries Sheila work wise.

But Michelle has had enough and is looking for another job, which means I am losing the best assistant I have ever had. Every time we tell management about it they have Sheila in the office - but she soon starts to cry and blames it on her hormones.

Management have not got the backbone to fire her and I have not got the power. What should I do?

The solution

The only way Sheila can be fired is for actually doing things that warrant warnings or dismissal. Unfortunately, this is unlikely to include being a "drama queen" - unless her behaviour is resulting in, say, lost customers, is offensive to colleagues or is in some other way detrimental to the company. If she is not carrying her weight and does not perform a piece of work that is in her job description (and is thus breaching her contract of employment), then you might have a stronger case.

Michelle may need to stop carrying her in order to prove that Sheila has been negligent in her duties. At this point, you should write to management with evidence of the misdemeanour and suggest that Sheila be given a verbal warning.

It does not matter how much she cries - the verbal warning must still be written into her files. Should she repeat her actions, up to two written warnings can be given (which will not require management to witness her tears at all) and then she can be fired on her next 'crime'.

These last actions can be done in writing, so avoiding the risk of Sheila's tears exerting their influence.

You cannot force the management to fire Sheila, but you can help them to see how the company is suffering because of her.

If you can document the effect she is having on colleagues, customers and work output, and present your case in writing, as well as suggest an action plan as described above, it would take a very unwise manager to continue to prevaricate on this issue. Good luck!


Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

webTitle: Classical review:  Antarctic Symphony

fields.headline: Antarctic Symphony
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Peter Maxwell Davies's eighth, and he says last, symphony has had more advance publicity than the other seven put together. It was commissioned by the British Antarctic Survey, as a sequel to Vaughan Williams's Sinfonia Antartica, with the condition that Davies must visit Antarctica before writing it. That he did in 1997, and the Antarctic Symphony was finished last December. Sunday night's premiere by the Philharmonia Orchestra and conducted by Davies was part of the Festival Hall's 50th birthday celebrations.

Davies says his single-movement work, lasting about 40 minutes, is "abstract", but uses sound images derived from his experiences in Antarctica. Certainly it does not seem at all programmatic and, without foreknowledge, it would be very difficult to guess the inspiration. There are some explosive climaxes interrupting long periods of stasis that could be construed as avalanches or ice breaks, and some glassy, wide-spaced textures that might conjure up an icy landscape. But otherwise the symmetrical structure, with a rather pawky scherzo at its centre flanked by two slow sections, and faster music on either side of those, seems totally self-contained.

The heart of the work, and the most impressive invention, is contained in those slow processions, with sequences of woodwind solos unwinding over static chords and evaporating in flurries of activity. That is where Davies's scoring is most lucid; the faster music is congested and lacking in focus. Its seesawing dynamics tend to dissipate the tension that has been so carefully built up.

On Saturday evening the London Philharmonic played a distinctly uncelebratory work: Britten's War Requiem. The performance under John Eliot Gardiner was certainly purposeful, and Ian Bostridge's contribution as tenor soloist remarkable for its verbal detail, but the piece came over as dated as the decor of the Festival Hall.

On Saturday afternoon the London Sinfonietta and the Orchestra of the Enlightenment joined forces for a more appropriate hybrid programme. Simon Rattle conducted the OAE in Mozart's G minor Symphony, and Martyn Brabbins took the Sinfonietta through Knussen's exquisite Two Organa and Adams's clarinet concerto, Gnarly Buttons, with Michael Collins as the superb soloist. The two orchestras combined under Brabbins for the London premiere of Mark-Anthony Turnage's About Time, sounding more purposeful in the RFH acoustic than at its first performance in Ely Cathedral 18 months ago.

 A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: Theatre review:  Mince?

fields.headline: Mince?
fields.standfirst:
Dundee Rep Theatre
****
fields.trailText:
Dundee Rep Theatre
****
fields.body:
It is very strange to see the cast of Dundee Rep's recent superb production of A Winter's Tale transposed to Mince?, a new musical of fabulous lunacy set in the mind of a TV ad jingle writer. All credit to them that they can switch from dark tragedy to a camp pastiche of easy-listening sounds and styles so smoothly.

Written and composed by actor Forbes Masson, it follows Stiff!, his first musical, set in the world of a mortician. Mince? is as unlikely a proposition: a therapist gets a mobile phone connection into the mind of Donald Johnstone, the troubled star of Scottish advertising. He may have won an award for his McKinnon's Mince campaign, but his life is in shreds. His relationship with Rhona Boak (an abattoir worker who gets a makeover for the campaign into Marilyn Montrose) is over; his father is slipping into dementia; his friendship with business partner Hunter Cunningham (beautifully played like Liam Gallagher by Billy Mack) is damaging him. These details sum up the play's mood - madly, deeply funny at times, darkly sombre at others.

The pace slackens slightly in the second act, but this is a fine evening's entertainment - popular but not populist, smart (film-type credits are projected on to the stage) but not pompous. Tom Piper's set moves from therapist's office to easy-listening lounge, meat processing works and claustrophobic family home, each set to lush lounge sounds by Gordon Dougall.

"What's nearly fact and what's clearly fiction" is what Johnstone has to find out for himself. For all the madness of Mince? and its glorious pantomime tomfoolery - think Rocky Horror Show meets Burt Bacharach - this is the serious issue that the play tackles: how we all have to work that one out as we grow up.

 Until May 19. Box office: 01382 223530.

webTitle: Co-op Bank profits from morality

fields.headline: Co-op Bank profits from morality
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The Co-operative Bank is benefiting from the promotion of its ethical stance and claims to be making a profit, writes Roger Crowe.
fields.body:
The Co-op Bank has for the first time put a price on its ethical stance - and claims to be showing a profit.

Its positions on issues such as the arms trade and renewable energy made it £16m better off last year. That is about 16% of pre-tax profit, and comes after extra costs of more than £2m.

The figures are published today in the bank's fourth annual "Partnership report", which details financial, ethical and environmental performance in 2000.

Introducing the report, chief executive Mervyn Pedelty says the bank's distinctive position had been important in producing a seventh successive year of increased profits. Mr Pedelty says ethics are just one aspect of the bank's brand. But in the first cost-benefit exercise of its kind, marketing and finance specialists have estimated that these values are responsible for between 15% and 18% of the £96m pre-tax profit.

The figures are based on detailed analysis of the Co-op brand value, and market research findings from Mori that more than a quarter of current account customers cited ethics or the environment as the reason for opening their accounts.

Paul Monahan, the partnership development manager, said the results demonstrated the business case for sustainable development. "People often claim that ethical business is good business, but nobody has had hard numbers before."

The extra profits are despite turning down 105 of the 270 referrals to the bank's policy unit, mostly because of the ecological impact of the applicant's business. This is estimated to have cost the bank £1.7m in lost profits. On the other hand efforts to reduce the use of paper have saved nearly £3m.

Mr Monahan said the bank's energy bills show that many businesses overestimate the cost of going green. Using renewable energy in all the main office locations has added an annual cost of just £41,000. This has allowed the bank to achieve its target of cutting the carbon dioxide emissions it is responsible for by 60% since 1997 - three times the government's 20% reduction target.

In the current year the bank will benefit from national insurance savings following the introduction of the climate change levy. Mr Monahan said this would cancel the extra energy costs.

"It means we will have gone green and saved money."

The report details progress against 68 targets set last year. Of these, 47 have been completely achieved but no progress has been made on 10. Most significant is the failure to persuade staff that their salaries and benefits are good enough.

The bank has missed its target of getting 70% of staff to agree that salaries are at least "quite good".

Mr Monahan said this was partly due to a different approach to measuring staff attitudes, but new efforts will be made to boost staff satisfaction levels.

webTitle: Pop review: Beachbuggy

fields.headline: Beachbuggy
fields.standfirst:
The Leadmill, Sheffield
**
fields.trailText:
The Leadmill, Sheffield
**
fields.body:
When hip Texan noiseniks And You Shall Know Us By The Trail of Dead appeared in Leeds recently, traffic was temporarily brought to a halt as the entire city centre was filled with noise. This had nothing to do with the Americans, but was a mischievous prank courtesy of Doncaster hopefuls Beachbuggy. It is one thing to be blown off stage by an unknown band, quite another when the challengers are playing outside your venue on the back of a lorry.

Ironically, Beachbuggy's spirit has thus far been recognised mostly in America. Noise/production guru Steve Albini even flew them over to make an album. But the fiery four-piece are determined to make inroads in their homeland. A launch do for their new Kickin' Back single provides a rare chance to see them on a stationary stage, without the "assistance" of city centre policemen.

They have certainly made an effort. Clad in white boiler suits that reflect their 1950s racing car obsession, the band look like a cross between Kraftwerk, Devo and Stirling Moss. They have two drummers, and when they get going in unison the effect is wonderfully eerie, rather like Kraftwerk's robots if they had been allowed to grin. Unleashing enormous Glitter Band grooves with clinical precision, the pair play exactly the same beats, although occasionally one of them will slip in something different and smirk at the other knowingly.

Sadly, though, the drummers' magnetism is not yet reflected in the rest of the band. The bassist has an impressive air of disdain, but singer-guitarist Jack Straker - a kind of sci-fi Mark E Smith on disc - has difficulty transferring his impressive recorded presence to the stage. With Straker skulking in the corner and his barking voice drowned by echo, his rapier wit is almost inaudible and their marauding Fall-ish surf punk lacks the wallop of the forthcoming Sport Fury album, or their lorry appearances. But they still enjoy conceptual jokes, and end the evening by standing perfectly still, like showroom dummies, and then walking off one by one.

This hasn't quite been Beachbuggy's night, but we won't have heard the last of them. They may well put in an impromptu appearance on a housing estate somewhere on their way home.

 Beachbuggy play the Camden Palace, London NW1 tonight (020-7387 0428), then tour.

webTitle: World music: The Drummers of Burundi

fields.headline: The primeval power of the Burundi drums
fields.standfirst:
The Drummers of Burundi
The Lowry, Salford
****
fields.trailText:
The Drummers of Burundi
The Lowry, Salford
****
fields.body:
Heard the one about the African tribesmen who changed the sound of pop? The Drummers of Burundi have. These master percussionists have played with Echo and the Bunnymen and inspired everyone from the Clash to Joni Mitchell. Perhaps most famously, they bequeathed the Adam and the Ants tribal drum sound that lit up the charts in the 1980s. Making a rare British visit, they are greeted with hero-worship, and respond with a performance worthy of their status.

The drumming starts even before they hit the stage, as vast waves of rolling thunder emanate from their dressing room. When the 12 masters walk on barefoot, in colourful robes, playing their drums on their heads, you can just about hear gasps above their tribal magic, which, unamplified, is louder than Deep Purple.

Over the next 50 minutes, none of the performers speaks (although there are plenty of whoops and cries), which adds to the mystique, and emphasises the beat as star. That beat has been handed down for generations, originally accompanied the Burundi king on his travels, and is rooted in agricultural ritual. The drums themselves are great hollowed-out logs covered in cow skin, each a different size and tuning, and beaten with sticks the size of an arm.

With all the drummers smiling away, despite one of them carrying a spear, they launch into the rhythm of Kings of the Wild Frontier by Adam and the Ants, complete with "heyoh-heyoh"s and clacking stick sounds. This is probably the mythical "perfect beat", which makes it a wonder that it hasn't been further pillaged by the dance generation. There is simply so much to marvel at: the spectacle of flailing limbs; the repetitive, primeval power; the beat's intricate construction; and the sheer physical exertion that must be necessary to play it.

As the pounding reaches a peak, band and audience reach something like a trance state, which may explain why the former are able to leap repeatedly into the air without missing a beat. Finally, they put their instruments back on their heads and depart as they arrived, leaving a piece of Burundi in the heart of Salford and a near riot at the CD stall.

 The Drummers of Burundi play the Hexagon, Reading tonight (0118-960 6060), then tour.

webTitle: Pop review: Ryan Adams

fields.headline: Ryan Adams
fields.standfirst:
Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith
***
fields.trailText:
Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith
***
fields.body:
As frontman of quasi-legendary "alt-country" band Whiskeytown, Ryan Adams found excitable listeners likening him to Gram Parsons or even Bob Dylan. Comparisons like these have killed many artists stone dead, but Adams's solo album, Heartbreaker, released last autumn, was strong and varied enough to enhance his burgeoning mystique still further.

Adams is treating this solo tour like a performing laboratory and songwriter's workshop, trying out the new songs that seem to teem through his brain, and lobbing in highlights from his back catalogue as helpful signposts. In between, he sustains a rambling montage of jokes, asides and anecdotes.

As he wandered off on sarcastic monologues about Britney Spears, Radiohead and Smashing Pumpkins, and essayed a prolonged sketch in which his uncontrollable mop of hair became a character in its own right and threatened to steal the show, you could begin to believe that Adams was preparing for a career in stand-up in case the songwriting should run dry.

There's no danger of that yet, though, as he seems to be experiencing that hair-trigger creative condition where any fleeting thought or passing observation instantly prompts another song. Slow songs, quick songs, sad songs, songs on guitar or piano -there were so many that Adams couldn't decide what to play next, taking long pauses to leaf through his notebook while absent-mindedly smoking three cigarettes at once.

Yet when he stops clowning around and starts to sing, the shambolic facade instantly vanishes. A rapt silence descended on the house when he sang Oh My Sweet Carolina, while My Winding Wheel derived its impact from its folksy simplicity. Duets with Corina Round on The Idiot Dance and the Neil Young-ish Come Pick Me Up were spellbinding, even if somebody is bound to accuse him of emulating Gram Parsons and Emmylou Harris. Although not Bryan Adams, fortunately.

 Ryan Adams plays the Y Theatre, Leicester (0116-255 6507), tomorrow and the Hop and Grape, Manchester (0161-832 1111) on Saturday.

webTitle: Jazz review:  Cheltenham jazz festival

fields.headline: Thrash and big band at Cheltenham
fields.standfirst:
Cheltenham jazz festival
Various venues
****
fields.trailText:
Cheltenham jazz festival
Various venues
****
fields.body:
The moment when Billy Higgins interrupted his band's suspiciously guileless sway through The Girl From Ipanema with a nerve-splintering thrash of abstract guitar noise will have been for some among the piquant memories of this year's excellent Cheltenham jazz festival. But for those whose idea of jazz this is not, the festival also included intelligently creative expanders of the tradition such as pianist Brad Mehldau and American saxophonists Joe Lovano, Bob Berg, Greg Osby, Mark Turner and Chris Potter.

Starting the six-day event's last weekend, Potter explored the material dedicated to past sax giants from his new Universal album. The only negative surprise was its slightly restrained respectfulness on disc. But live performance suggested it might be a slow-burner, with pieces such as the Lester Young dedication The Visitor and the ruggedly Michael Breckerish High Noon seeming far more urgent.

If Potter was a shade cerebral for some, Don Weller's big band was the straight-swinging antidote. Though they took a while to warm up, Weller's Basie-like arrangements, with their cross-sectional banter, train-hooting trumpet cadences and exuberant shouts, made this a fine example of big band bravura.

British pianist Nikki Yeoh's trio had Saturday afternoon's audience standing to shout bop riffs behind drummer Mark Mondesir's dazzling closing solo. And though Yeoh's own improvising is going through a tentative phase, her multilayered, melodically wayward, probingly unjazzy themes grow increasingly fascinating. New York drummer Jim Black's AlasNoAxis played laptop computers as well as more regular hardware. Although its thrashing, guitar-led blasts of free-funk noise dislodged some listeners, and its minimalist melodies could have had a little more substance, the set was often exhilarating.

A different kind of thrash, mixing traditional Vietnamese music with the Hendrix-Scofield-Stern line of headlong guitar wailing, came from Nguyen Le on Sunday. His astonishingly virtuosic set, a brilliant compositional and ensemble performance as well as a showcase for the leader's guitar, was a triumph.

Meanwhile, the heavyweight US hornmen, Osby, Turner and Lovano, highlighted the general sax move from muscular Breckerish Coltraneism towards a cooler, contrapuntal, interweavingly linear manner. On Saturday night Osby and Turner played a superb set of intricate melodies reminiscent of Lennie Tristano, but with an unexpectedly funky diversion into The Sidewinder. Lovano's versatile Sunday-night quartet (three of them, including Lovano, took turns on drums) preferred Ornette Coleman's scuttling themes, sudden pauses and long, clamorous blues wails, mixed with the Chet Baker/Gerry Mulligan contrapuntal approach. The impact may seem more preoccupied on disc but, as a distinctive and theatrical festival band, it can't miss.

webTitle: Retail therapy out of fashion

fields.headline: Retail therapy out of fashion
fields.trailText: Retail therapy is losing its allure as shoppers opt to spend more on trips abroad or eating out, according to a new report.
fields.body:
Retail therapy is losing its allure as shoppers opt to spend more on trips abroad or eating out, according to a new report.

Average income is on the up, but little of this extra cash is being spent on clothing or furniture as people become bored with going to the shops.

Retail consultancy Verdict said many high-street chains now face a challenging future unless they can inspire customers to come to their local store.

Just below one-third - 32.9% - of all consumers' spending goes on the retail sector today, compared to 47% in 1980.

Verdict chairman Richard Hyman said: "There are now lots of other things we can spend our money on now compared to 10to 15 years ago and retail is losing out as a result of that.

"Retail sales are not diminishing, they are not going backwards, but they are growing very slowly, more slowly than its costing these companies to stay open."

webTitle: Theatre review: Tantalus

fields.headline: Triumphant Tantalus
fields.standfirst:
Tantalus
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Tantalus
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
"When the legend becomes fact, print the legend," says the newspaper editor in John Ford's The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance. But one of the prime purposes of the nine-play Tantalus - adapted from John Barton's original cycle and getting the first of three all-day showings at the Barbican on Sunday - is to make us re-examine the myths surrounding the Trojan War. You think you know the story of Agamemnon and Priam, Helen and Hecuba? After seeing this "epic cycle of the lost bits" you think again.

I praised the concept and the execution by Peter and Edward Hall when I saw the show at the Denver Center last October. But a second viewing clarifies key themes and gives one a chance to dwell on the acting. Starting on an Aegean beach with David Ryall's trinket vendor as a downmarket Robert Graves explaining the Greek myths to a group of bikini-clad girls, Tantalus is clearly a show about storytelling. But it is also a metaphor for modern times: about fluidity of gender, ambiguity of character, the preference for war-war over jaw-jaw, women as eternal victims and the hollowness of presumed victory. It trades in the Greek myths but could equally be about the modern Balkans.

Barton's original vision has famously been compromised in the interests of pragmatic necessity. But the plays also make an uneven impact. Some are capable narrative drama; others audaciously brilliant. On Sunday it was the seventh play, Cassandra, that overwhelmed me. This was partly due to a triumphant performance from Ann Mitchell, who, despite a throat infection, conveyed the feral rage of the exiled Hecuba as she prepared to blind the Thracian king. But when someone asked why the sightless king was dancing and was told "to be free of his pain" we were into the absurdist world of Beckett. And the final moments, when Greg Hicks's Agamemnon and Alyssa Bresnahan's Cassandra strip off their masks, shows tender, human eroticism breaking through the carapace of post-war conflict.

Masks, which I normally resist, here serve to express character and enable the six main actors to play multiple roles. Hicks, in particular, is outstanding as a dryly ironic Agamemnon, a towering Priam and a Menelaus who explains that Paris's Helen was a doppelganger. He has a great ability to caress the language, so his explanation of the first cocked-up expedition to Troy - "Oh yes, we landed, but in the wrong place" - gets a legitimate laugh. But the whole Anglo-American cast, including Alan Dobie as a morally equivocal Odysseus and Annalee Jefferies as an impassioned Clytemnestra, do a sterling job. Hall père et fils and designer Dionysis Fotopoulos also ingeniously reinvent the basic circular sandpit so each play makes its own visual statement.

A marathon day passes easily, leaving you questioning the received truth of classical myth. The only tragedy is that Barton feels unable to share in its collaborative success.

 Until May 19. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

webTitle: Rugby League: Great game, such a shame it has to die

fields.headline: Great game, rugby league, such a shame it has to die
fields.standfirst: Why the code's finest are voting with their feet
fields.trailText: Why the code's finest are voting with their feet
fields.body:
The Army played the Royal Navy on Saturday, and good ol' rugger was itself again and so was Twickers. Who cared that the two platoons of chaps enacted their private war to reverberating echoes bouncing round the cavernous concrete suburban emptiness. They have done so annually in one of Christendom's oldest sportin' fixtures - first played at The Oval in 1878 when the matelots won by a goal and a try to a goal, probably because they had an extra man as the Khakis' skipper, the nicely named Captain RA Ballantyne RA, had been posted to garrison Sudan that very morning.

Saturday's match - for the Willis Carroon Trophy, wouldn't you know - might have offered spiritual balm for the diehard old union ghosts which had been wafting around in anguish only the Saturday before when their tabernacle of righteousness was used to stage the celebrations of their blighted enemy, in the shape of the rugby league Challenge Cup final.

Such purgatorial distress will be temporary, anyway. Soon those reactionary wraiths of rugby past will realise they have secured the future, and totally routed their traitorous antagonists of more than a century. To my mind, these last few months have seen rugby league totally doomed. It is only a matter of time - and not much of that, either - before rugby league in Britain is forced to merge with a voracious union. I give it five years, and that is being generous.

While the Challenge Cup final plays odd herald these days for the game's summer Super League to get into its stride, the spiteful and bickering committee rooms of the English union club game is wrapping up its season with a barmy series of championship play-offs, as if no one knew who the out-and-out uncontested champions are. Then in high summer union's touring British Lions will hog all Fleet Street's attention, as well as television's largest audiences.

It is unfair, for the wretched irony is that of the two codes, league is the more sharply organised, is far more at ease with itself, is run by more charming and imaginative folk and is played by more amenable fellows with not only more resplendent skills but with a more touching affection for, and pride in, their game.

Union's administration, in contrast, is beset with a corrosive enmity - yet within five years it will have gobbled up its north-country cousins.

The Twickenham season which ended, except for Saturday's Navy lark, with league's cup final had opened with another revolutionary "sacrilege" in the shape of league's autumn World Cup curtain-raiser, England v Australia. On a sorry Saturday, union's huge stadium was less than half full. A week later, in Cardiff's new 73,000-seater, only a few more than 15,000 turned up to watch Wales's national league team. A ruinously disappointing World Cup put league on the back foot, and once its leading players began to be poached by the union - ruthlessly tit-for-tat after a century the other way - any reasonable and unbiased forecaster could sense the game was as good as up.

In a blink, English league's supreme star, Jason Robinson, was playing union for England and, in another, for the Lions.

How many former league men will be union Lions when they next tour in 2005? Plenty. How many fellows who played in that league World Cup, come to that, will enjoy their next World Cup as union players in 2003? Even more.

And don't curse about the power of money in all this. That does not come into it: as long as television is coughing up there is plenty on the table for both codes, oodles of it.

No, the central point here is this. What players want is the thrill of the big time, the genuine international up-front occasion in packed-out stadiums, the experience of being watched by millions the world over.

It means that low-key, dismal, unwatched World Cups on the back of mundane club contests against the same blokes you played a fortnight ago, and three weeks before that, and for local reporters in northern editions, are no use any more for top sportsmen desperate for the incentive of genuine glory. That is what rugby union can deliver and the good old, insular, homely league cannot. And once global television twigs it, well, bye-bye league. In England anyway.

Last week was league's centenary cup final. Union's centenary was way back in the mists of 1971. For it Twickenham published an attractive little booklet, Touchdown, in celebration. As a wheeze, the editors canvassed predictions for rugby 30 years hence, heading the chapter with a science-fictionary razzmatazz: AD 2001. Thirty years on, but more like eons really, so steeped in aspic still was union and its expectations then.

The Twickenham eminence Lord Wakefield forecast a game played on artificial surfaces, its teams boasting "greater professionalism - but only, of course, purely as an attitude of mind" (of course, milord), and a midwinter break which these amateurs could "devote to other strenuous activities like skiing".

He also saw in his vision of the future "hoisting or lifting at the lineout - two men combining to obtain the ball, and I see nothing wrong with that". On the whole, his lordship prophesied, "the more time he has to devote to his hobby, the more Rugbyman will strive to attain greater efficiency".

The former Wales player and writer, Vivian Jenkins, foresaw the outrageous possibility of a World Cup for rugby - "though I, for one, hope it never happens. A World Cup is quite enough of an ordeal for our soccer players, whose living it is. For rugby players it would introduce a much too demanding complication into their daily lives."

Mind you, he added: "If every other country approached the game as we do it might be a different matter - but these are the days when sport is so often a vehicle for political propaganda ... I would prefer to see by 2001 our rugby having reverted to its time-honoured domestic format with as few commitments outside the British Isles as possible."

Which last thought, I reckon, will be one for British rugby league. Doodling at the same party game today, it is utterly inconceivable that rugby in 2031 will be anything other than a single code. Did I say 2031? Make that 2006, more like, and alas for league.

webTitle: Simon Schama's A History Of Britain returns

fields.headline: Fighting talk
fields.standfirst: Simon Schama's A History Of Britain returns this week, opening with the traumas of the Civil War. But will he have anything new to tell us?
fields.trailText: Simon Schama's A History Of Britain returns this week, opening with the traumas of the Civil War. But will he have anything new to tell us?
fields.body:
Britannia - cool, tolerant and pragmatic. An island embarrassed by enthusiasm and sceptical about ideology - its inhabitants more interested in gardening than politics. The national myths of self-esteem are part of the mental landscape. Blairist, technocratic and apolitical, is only the latest chapter in that tome of what it means to be British.

But the book of British history needs endless rewriting and revision for successive generations. And the earliest chapters in the section on what it means to be modern shows a different, unsettling account of the matter. This, after all, is the country that went to civil war for the sake of ideas about law and obe dience. We invented republicanism in modern politics and, behind Philadelphia in 1776 and Paris in 1789, there stands the scaffolding on which a short man born in Dunfermline was beheaded in 1649.

Macaulay's leather-jacketed heir is back on the screen to explain to us why Britain collapsed into very un-British anarchy. The camera work is as beautiful as ever; all swooping and tracking shots over a landscape by turns pastoral and dramatic, elysian and craggy. This is a series whose richness of imagery is also a landscape of the mind.

But Simon Schama's resumption of his narrative (The British Wars) is elegiac and compassionate rather than triumphalist. In his history of the French revolution, Citizens, he took no hostages in his bleak view of the event that for the liberal-left invented democracy. For Schama it was a school for tyrants, a regressive catastrophe which invented new refinements in political cruelty. 1789 was a mistake that impeded the evolution of a society that had been doing rather nicely thank you in the 1780s. And here again there's a tolerance towards Britain's own ancien régime.

Schama is no early Stuart apologist. Charles I, in one of his many happy phrases, was "constitutionally incapable of being a constitutional monarch". But both camera and language collude elegantly in explaining what Charles I was about: the dream of unity. The fact that it was a vision so rooted in aesthetics makes the visuals work. Cartography guides the viewer too. John Speed's 67 maps of Britain show the early Stuart optimism about a united Kingdom - and it was an inspiration to pick up on Speed's description of Edgehill as another Eden. The Eden that turned into Golgotha.

All history - bathetically - is contemporary history. How could it be otherwise. The word itself means enquiry - and enquiry is rooted in the here and now. In taking us to the there and then, Schama is showing us that there is a unity in British history, but only in the sense of there being recurring questions - rather than a constitution set in stone and a national character that keeps on singing "there'll always be a Britain".

The Stuarts had three thrones to fill: in Ireland, Scotland and England. What the English claim as their "civil war" was also a conflict between the three countries. And those tensions remain even in a post- devolutionary age. Behind the poll tax first visited on the Scots by Thatcher there stands Charles's imposition of the Prayer Book on a resistant Calvinist race. Ireland in this story erupts with a melancholy-on-cue quality, with wars of propaganda and atrocities - real and imagined.

Schama's history shows that events suck and character determines. His civil war builds on some revisionist work that maintains that this catastrophe started as a quarrel among the toffs. There's no embryonic class consciousness of revolutionary agents visible, waiting anachronistically to be born into bourgeois life. What we have is a collection of country gentlemen who happened to be very stubborn about law, had a few hand-me-down truisms to hang on to about the Magna Carta - and a deep distaste for European Catholicism

Charles was the real revolutionary - the one who seemed to have the little bits of Britain in his hand. He was at the heart of Europe, where the most dynamic model of government was that of absolutist kingship. Those silly myths about the king as father of his people were rooted in pre- democratic reality.

In a way Schama's is a very conservative view of what happened in a half-century of constitutional conflict He shows that Euro-scepticism was not born at Maastricht and that the arguments have never gone away.

There's a great sense of drama and involvement as the series' second half gets into its stride - involving though Schama's first instalment had been as he swooped down to squint at the sceptred isle from the Picts to Elizabeth. And it comes through in the compassion charged with understanding. The war was about allegiance - and so the diptych (one of many) is created on screen of the Verneys - the father being Charles's standard bearer at Edgehill while the son swore an oath to Parliament.

Psychology is here in abundance, and it all works because this is something at which television - that stripper of the persona - is adept. We see the suit of armour that had belonged to Prince Henry, Charles's elder, more glamorous brother who had been more of a jousting-jock than the aloof aesthete. Charles tried it on for size after his brother died but found it too big. There's Henrietta Maria, our own Marie Antoinette - less sexy but just as silly - a sallow-skinned airhead airbrushed into glam by Van Dyck's deceitful palette.

And there are eyes everywhere - the soulful ones of the court which history tends to romanticise because they were born to rule but now seem born losers. But we also see the harder ones of Black Tom Stafford, the earl of Wentworth, the man Charles betrayed by approving his execution, the man who would have been the king's man of iron, the gauleiter to rule a united kingdom.

Puritans come in for some roughing-up. And there's a touch of Merrie-England romanticism at work in Schama's criticism that these anti-ritualistic people of the Book "deprived the ordinary of colour and ceremony". But he's excellent in his assessment of the appeal of being one of the elect. The charm of minority status when you're an avant-garde ideologist is that it means you must be special, chosen and therefore right simply because there aren't many of you. It's good to be in Gideon's army as a small, self-justifying band on the march. As right and as authoritarian as that piggy-eyed dogmatist Archbishop Laud.

It all looked good for Charles's "playground of the gods" for a while in the 1630s says Schama, looking up to camera, and then he had to come down to earth. The expense of war on the continent meant that taxation had to be raised and approved by parliament. Parliament and the pound are twin brothers, then as now. What emerged out of the struggle was for a long time confused. Schama's is no Whiggish inevitability and morality tale of a parliament that was always rising and planning initiatives. Charles could have got away with it - and Britain could perhaps have had good art rather than marginal water-colourists, decent food rather than convenience fodder, and a House of Commons only occasionally summoned, rather than our regular feast of delights by the Thames.

There was no script of inevitability saying "go forth and be democratic". The men who died holding those pikes that advance so darkly in the melée of the battlefield wrought more than they knew. History as poker player has more than one hidden hand. Pym Hampden and the rest were not proto-democrats but cross and rich, the products of deference. A world turned upside down was not what they were about.

Afer 1660 it all seemed over, "the good old cause" dead and buried. It seemed to survive only in the tragic cadences of Milton the blind poet hearing "the sons of Belial all flushed with wine" on London's Restoration streets as men in tights came back to play.

As a historian, Schama has always shown that the division between analysis and narrative is a researcher's contrivance. Here he fuses both tools with a matchless skill. His insistently nodding head (which goes against the tired canons of on-screen delivery) communicates the zeal that led to war in the isles and on the hearth, in the courts of law and in the court of silks and taffeta.

And in the final moments we see him on Edgehill, the battlefield where Edmund Verney's body was never found. How green and pleasant a land the killing field looks now. So British and National Trust. But beneath it all as the images blur, blend and cross over, the mind's eye can see the blood that has seeped into the turf, sense the suffering of those who fulfilled a role in a terrible British tragedy, and weep. This is how it should be done. Sometimes there's more to telly than meets the eye.

 A History Of Britain, Tuesday, 9pm, BBC2

webTitle: Speaking out about Prozac

fields.headline: Bitter pill
fields.standfirst: David Healy claims that Prozac, the bestselling drug of all time, can drive people to suicide - even if they aren't depressed. The company that makes the drug (and earns £1.8bn a year from it) says that's rubbish. So have his views just cost him a job? Sarah Boseley investigates
fields.trailText: David Healy claims that Prozac, the bestselling drug of all time, can drive people to suicide - even if they aren't depressed. The company that makes the drug (and earns £1.8bn a year from it) says that's rubbish. So have his views just cost him a job?
fields.body:
David Healy was looking forward to moving to Canada. For the British psycho-pharmacologist, author of the definitive history of antidepressant drugs, the invitation to take up a post at the prestigious University of Toronto made absolute sense. Apart from the academic advantages, his claims that the cult drug Prozac and its copycat sisters can make some people commit suicide were taking him to the US increasingly often to testify on behalf of bereaved families against the drug companies.

It wasn't to happen. Healy's move across the Atlantic, closer to the field of battle over some of the bestselling drugs of all time, has been scuppered in what some see as just the latest skirmish in a dirty war to stop him and others speaking out.

The stakes are huge. The pharmaceutical group Eli Lilly made $2.6bn (£1.8bn) from Prozac last year alone and is pulling out all the stops to register the drug for new uses now that its patent is at an end. It has just succeeded in getting it renamed and repackaged as Sarafem, for severe premenstrual tension, which will keep the profits rolling in until 2007. But if Healy is right, there is a risk that a minority of people on Prozac will take their own lives. He calculates that a quarter of a million people worldwide have tried to commit suicide because of Prozac and that 25,000 have succeeded. For the manufacturers of the SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors as this class of drug is called) Healy's work is enormously damaging.

Eli Lilly claims there is absolutely no evidence of a link between Prozac and suicide but, within academic circles, Healy, who is director of the North Wales department of psychological medicine, has a high reputation. Two years ago, he began to be courted by the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH) at Toronto University. He spent three days there in July 1999. Afterwards, Paul Garfinkel, the chair of the department, wrote an appreciative letter, anticipating the chance to "discuss more specifically the arrangements for you in Toronto" and talking of meeting Healy's wife so that "she too might look forward to a good opportunity in Canada".

On January 28 last year, Sidney Kennedy, another professor in the department, wrote with full details of the position Healy was being offered, including rank and salary. In August, the formal offer was made by David Goldbloom, physician in chief at CAMH - and Healy formally accepted it in September. Only the immigration hurdles remained.

Then in November, Healy was invited to speak at a two-day conference at CAMH. Everything seemed to be going smoothly. The day before, he received a handwritten note from Goldbloom, giving him the names of colleagues who could advise him on schools for his children. He was urged by the professor to give one month's notice to his employer in the UK instead of three. He was told: "We need to get you here within weeks rather than months."

The talk on November 30 appeared to go down well - the same talk received acclaim in the US a few days later and again earlier this year in Paris. But in Toronto, Goldbloom showed signs of distress. At a dinner that night, Healy said in a subsequent letter to the ethics committee of Toronto University's board of trustees, "he was too livid to engage in any constructive dialogue". According to Healy, Goldbloom was worried that the main thing people would take away from his talk was the claim that Prozac can cause suicide.

Within a few days, Healy received an email from Goldbloom, saying he had something urgent to discuss. Healy's travel schedule made a telephone conversation impossible, so Goldbloom finally broke the news by email on December 7. "Essentially, we believe that it is not a good fit between you and the role as leader of an academic program in mood and anxiety disorders at the centre and in relation to the university," he said. "This view was solidified by your recent appearance at the centre in the context of an academic lecture. The University of Toronto denies that the Prozac issue was connected with the change of heart over Healy. But Healy points out that the attitude of everybody at Toronto towards him was very positive until the talk, and that the day before he spoke he was even asked to sit on an interview panel for a post that would be under his supervision when he moved to Canada.

However, Andy Vickery, of Vickery and Waldner, a law firm based in Houston, Texas, which has retained Healy as an expert witness in a number of SSRI cases, says he has no doubt that what happened to Healy was connected with the litigation. "It is either to try to keep him out or to punish him for having the audacity to speak up on behalf of families."

Healy, he says, is a problem for those who want to "perpetuate the myth that there's no problem with these drugs".

webTitle: Drug firm wakes up to sleeping sickness

fields.headline: Drug firm wakes up to sleeping sickness
fields.standfirst: Campaign persuades Aventis to give five years' worth of medicine and help World Health Organisation research
fields.trailText: Campaign persuades Aventis to give five years' worth of medicine and help World Health Organisation research
fields.body:
One of the world's major pharmaceutical companies, which stopped making the only safe medicine for the late, fatal, stage of sleeping sickness because it could not make a profit from it, has agreed to donate the drug, following a public outcry over shortages of medicines in Africa.

In a dramatic turnaround, Aventis has signed a deal with the World Health Organisation to supply a five-year global need for eflornithine and two other drugs used to treat the parasitic disease. It will also provide funding for the WHO's sleeping sickness treatment and research programmes.

The decision has been greeted with euphoria by campaigners and doctors who currently have only an arsenic derivative - which can kill the patient - to treat the late stages of the disease.

Aventis dropped eflornithine in 1995 because there was no market for it in the wealthy west. Médecins Sans Frontières, the Nobel prize-winning volunteer doctors' organisation, and other campaigners have long pressed the company to reconsider.

Then last year, a second pharmaceutical giant, Bristol Myers Squibb, found a new and potentially lucrative use for eflornithine in the west - as an ingredient in hair-removing cream, under licence from Aventis. Campaigners believe that the accusations of favouring profit over lives that this attracted, together with the furore over the court case brought by 39 pharmaceutical companies against the South African government over access to cheap drugs, are behind Aventis's decision.

Sleeping sickness, or African trypanosomiasis, is spread by the tsetse fly and is a scourge of sub-Saharan rural areas. Left untreated, the parasites spread to the brain and the patient suffers neurological damage, falls into an irreversible coma and eventually dies.

It affects 500,000 people in 36 African countries, and 60m are at risk of its spread. In some villages in Angola, Democratic Republic of Congo and southern Sudan, it is the biggest cause of death, ahead of Aids.

The drug melarsoprol, discovered in 1949, has been the only available medicine that can cross the blood-brain barrier to reach the parasite in the later stages of disease. It is the last arsenic derivative in existence and its side-effects are dire. "In the field we are forced to use melarsoprol and when we put it into people's veins, they often scream," said Daniel Berman of MSF. It kills 3-10% of patients, and others suffer brain damage.

Eflornithine was licensed in 1990 and seemed like the an swer, but production stopped in 1999. Last year Aventis offered the licence to the WHO, but the organisation could not find anyone to produce the drug. Now the company has offered as much eflornithine as is needed, together with melarsoprol and the early-stage drug pentamidine, for five years, and will give $25m (£17m) to support the WHO's activities.

MSF thinks public opinion has been crucial to the move. "We feel that the growing public awareness about this and the publicity in the newspapers was a pivotal factor in bringing this drug back into production," Mr Berman said.

MSF, which will distribute the drugs to the places they are needed, is delighted by the company's generosity. "This agreement is excellent news for patients and a major step in the struggle to control sleeping sickness", said Bernard Pécoul, director of MSF's campaign for access to essential medicines. But he said that more money - more than £25m a year - would be needed from international donors.

Gro Harlem Brundtland, the WHO's director general, said: "We can now look forward to halting the spread of sleeping sickness. We are deeply gratified by the commitment of Aventis to this cause. We hope others, inspired by our work, will join us, as much remains to be done."

Richard Markham, chief executive of Aventis Pharma, said the company was "committed to playing an important role in improving the quality of human life and contributing to the sustainable development of our world."

webTitle: Down to Earth

fields.headline: Down to Earth
fields.standfirst:
Safe landing for the first space tourist

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The world's first space tourist made a textbook landing on the steppes of Kazakhstan yesterday and declared that he had just returned from paradise.
fields.body:
The world's first space tourist made a textbook landing on the steppes of Kazakhstan yesterday and declared that he had just returned from paradise.

The Soyuz capsule, carrying Dennis Tito, 60, and two Russian cosmonauts, returned on schedule from its week-long trip to the International Space Station.

"It was great; best, best, best of all. It was paradise, I just came back from paradise," an exhilarated Mr Tito said as he emerged unsteadily from the capsule.

The American tycoon reportedly paid the hard-up Russian space agency $20m for the flight, despite fierce opposition from Nasa, which said that the presence of a tourist jeopardised station safety.

Mr Tito, who had to be taken by wheelchair to a field hospital for a check-up, is expected to stay in Russia for about 10 days.

On landing, the three men were given apples, a Kazakh national symbol. Mr Tito tried to juggle them but failed."You see, I'm still used to weightlessness," he said. "I was worried that I might not feel well in space. But I turned out to feel the best I felt in my entire life." Reuters

webTitle: Briefing

fields.headline: Public debate swamped by racists
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: The row over racism which led to William Hague disciplining two rebel backbenchers last week is unlikely to go away in the heated atmosphere of the next few weeks.
fields.body:
The row over racism which led to William Hague disciplining two rebel backbenchers last week is unlikely to go away in the heated atmosphere of the next few weeks.

Disturbing new economic research suggests that many people share the views of the two silenced MPs.

Mr Hague made John Townend apologise for comments about immigration turning Britain into a mongrel race, while Laurence Robertson was forced to retract his warnings about the dangers of "cramming" in different ethnic groups.

Some senior Tories blame the commission for racial equality and the government for suppressing a legitimate debate about immigration and asylum under the guise of banning racist or inflammatory electioneering.

Unfortunately, it appears the public opposition towards further immigration, either legal or illegal is driven largely by racism rather than fears the new arrivals will take jobs away from locals or be a burden on the welfare system.

Using several waves of the British Social Attitudes survey, researchers Christian Dustmann and Ian Preston find that two-thirds of the public are opposed to further immigration by ethnic minorities, and their hostility associated with racist views about ethnic minorities. More than 66% of those questioned in the BSA survey would prefer fewer immigrants from the West Indies and more than 70% would prefer fewer immigrants from Asia.

The BSA also asks respondents about whether they consider inter-ethnic marriage acceptable, what they would think about having a boss from an ethnic minority and if they consider themselves to be prejudiced. It also asks if they worried about losing their jobs or about the strains on the welfare system.

Dustmann and Preston find that opposition to further immigration is heavily correlated to racist attitudes as revealed by the BSA questions about ethnic minorities. Worries about immigrants taking jobs or welfare benefits are a less important factor.

The fact that only a minority oppose immigration from ethnically similar countries such as Australia and New Zealand is further proof of entrenched public hostility towards people of Asian or Afro-Caribbean origin.

The research uses data from large-scale surveys to show that people who are most hostile towards immigrants hold strongly racist views. "Racial prejudice is by far the most important, explaining negative inclinations towards immigration of ethnically different populations," the researchers say.

Low-skilled workers, who might be thought to worry about competition for jobs, are in fact more likely than more highly skilled workers to be hostile to immigrants because of racist views, according to the report.

The research demonstrates why hardline anti-immigration speeches by politicians play well with the public. As the CRE suspects, whatever excuses are made about discussing issues like jobs and welfare spending, the debate is really about race.

Dustmann and Preston argue that European countries are going to have to change their hardline on immigration because they are running out of workers. To keep its working population stable between now 2050, the European Union needs to import 1.4m immigrants a year. To stop the ratio between workers and retired people falling, it needs a net inflow of 12.7m immigrants a year.

"Addressing the antipathy towards immigration at the lower end of the spectrum of skills and education requires engaging the stereotypes that underlie the racial antagonisms driving these attitudes," Dustmann and Preston argue.

The British government has recognised the need for immigration to attract skilled workers in some sectors and has changed work permit rules to allow in a limited number of immigrants.

But there are few signs that the government is preparing to try to turn around the large scale public hostility to immigrants revealed by the survey data.

Some commentators argue that by taking a hardline stance on asylum seekers, Labour is secretly exploiting the same racist attitudes it accuses the opposition of fomenting.

Racial and Economic Factors in Attitudes towards Immigration, by Christian Dustmann and Ian Preston; Centre for Economic Policy Research

webTitle: Church initiative after Oldham stand-off

fields.headline: Church initiative after Oldham stand-off
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: A pastoral letter praising racial diversity and the "overwhelming desire of local people to live peaceably and justly" was read yesterday in every Anglican church in Oldham, after a tense stand-off between police and rival groups.
fields.body:
A pastoral letter praising racial diversity and the "overwhelming desire of local people to live peaceably and justly" was read yesterday in every Anglican church in Oldham, after a tense stand-off between police and rival groups.

The Bishop of Middleton, Michael Lewis, issued the strongly worded letter following claims of racial no-go areas in the town which attracted outside demonstrators from the National Front and a counter-protest from the Anti-Nazi League at the weekend.

Sporadic fighting broke out on Saturday evening as an overwhelming show of strength by Greater Manchester police wound down, and 16 people were arrested for alleged public order offences.

Only some 30 rightwingers mustered in defiance of a three-month ban on demonstrations in Oldham, and they spent most of the day penned into a garage forecourt by police.

But an angry reaction from some Asian youths led to scuffles, window-smashing and three home-made petrol bombs being thrown.

A police spokesman said that "some racially motivated damage had been done to houses" and that detectives were investigating the stabbing of a white man in the Hathershaw area.

The bishop said in his letter that recent violence in Oldham had been disturbing but did not justify the picture painted in some quarters of outright hostility between racial groups.

He stressed the desire of local communities to live peaceably. He praised Oldham Muslims for promoting "peace and neighbourliness" and concluded: "Racial diversity is a cause for celebration rather than fear."

Police in Bradford, meanwhile, are hunting two racist gangs after four men were treated for concussion and bruising from unprovoked attacks.

Two Asian youths were set upon by up to 30 Middlesbrough football supporters outside Bradford City's ground at Valley Parade, and two white brothers, aged 28 and 26, were kicked and beated by up to 12 Asian men in the city centre.

webTitle: Total Meltdown, Royal Festival Hall, London

fields.headline: Total Meltdown
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating****
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating****
fields.body:
When a rock band plays one of London's classical venues, it's frequently a signal that said rock band are taking themselves very seriously indeed. The audience must sit in rapt silence while the band purvey their art, the grandeur of the surroundings is at odds with a rock gig's visceral thrills, and the outcome is dry and bookish, like attending a dull-but-worthy lecture.

Yet Meltdown, the Royal Festival Hall's annual concert series picked by a left-field rock dignitary, regularly surprises. The catholicism of the directors' tastes often leads to genuinely wayward moments. Last year, Scott Walker was curator. Among his choices was an Austrian industrial band called Fuckhead, who concluded their set by stripping naked, sticking a washing line up their bums and hanging clothes off it. That has to be the most memorable finale the Royal Festival Hall has ever seen.

Sadly, Fuckhead are absent tonight, which celebrates the venue's 50th birthday by gathering former Meltdown curators. In their absence, erstwhile Pere Ubu frontman David Thomas provides the evening's most startling sight, his notable girth squeezed behind a red plastic apron. Thomas's voice remains as bizarre as his appearance, jumping from whisper to deafening bleat mid-phrase. While Pere Ubu's wit was darkly mordant, Thomas is positively avuncular. Through a dense mesh of treated guitar and trumpet, one song appears to be a complaint against BBC weatherman Michael Fish.

Even by their own sombre standards, Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds' current album, No More Shall We Part, is a remarkably bleak affair, yet tonight Cave too is in playful mood. He chuckles and teases the audience between songs, but his set is affecting and strangely intimate. As they run through a selection of the new album's highlights, Cave's wracked voice and the restrained, stately rumble of The Bad Seeds overcomes the impersonality of the Festival Hall's 1950s interior.

But it is Elvis Costello's shambolic appearance that embodies Meltdown's appeal. Performing alone, he experiments with tape loops and drum machines, thrashes a distorted guitar, encourages singing from a startled audience, plays an aged and heartbreaking American folk song and encores with an unsettling reading of his 1986 track I Want You. "I haven't a clue what I'm doing," he says, smiling, to appreciative applause. Freed from the standard conventions of a rock gig, he's clearly having the time of his life.

webTitle: Rugby League: Bruising Broncos hurt Horne but Hull maintain momentum

fields.headline: Bruising Broncos hurt Horne but Hull maintain momentum
fields.standfirst:
Hull 19
London Broncos 14
fields.trailText: A despicably late tackle by Marvin Golden took Hull's brightest prospect Richard Horne out of this game, but it did not stop the home side reclaiming second place in the Super League.
fields.body:
A despicably late tackle by Marvin Golden took Hull's brightest prospect Richard Horne out of this game, but it did not stop the home side reclaiming second place in the Super League.

On the evidence so far, these two sides should be thanked for making this the most competitive season in the league's short history. Hull, who enjoyed a brief spell at the table's summit last week until results elsewhere went against them, and London, the conquerors of Wigan, were certainly competitive with each other in last night's bruising meeting.

Horne was the biggest casualty. The versatile young centre departed with bruised kidneys following Golden's crunching tackle, well after the 18-year-old had touched down for the game's opening try.

Golden soon followed Horne to the sidelines, victim of an uncompromising Tony Smith tackle, but the Broncos drew level when Dennis Moran reclaimed his own kick and sent Nigel Roy over. They were quickly six points behind again, however, aftersloppily allowing Hull's re-start to bounce into the path of Deon Bird.

Brett Warton's penalty just after half-time kept London involved, but by then Hull were in the ascendancy and they scored a crucial try soon after, Bird swooping for another opportunistic effort. Crowther's brilliant touchline conversion gave Hull a 10-point cushion.

This was always a bad-tempered game, despite the attractive veneer, and it erupted five minutes later. As the Hull substitute Paul King's decisive drop goal sailed over, London's Justin Dooley was assaulting Steve Prescott. Dooley was lucky only to be sin-binned, Prescott just as unlucky to join him.

A fiery final quarter was made all the more frantic by a late Broncos try from Michael Gillett. "We just needed an ounce of luck," said his coach Tony Rae. Rae's opposite number, Shaun McRae, was happier. "There are more than just a top four clubs now," he beamed. "And that's good for the game."

London Broncos: Barnett; Warton, Martin, Roy, Golden; Tollett, Moran; Mestrov, Hetherington, Cram, Toshack, Retchless, Dymock. Substitutes : Millard, Gillett, Dooley, Clarke.

Referee: S Ganson (St Helens).

webTitle: Rugby Union: Bath roar into final with one Voyce

fields.headline: Bath roar into final with one Voyce
fields.standfirst:
Zurich Championship semi-finals
Callard's team fight back to earn return to Twickenham
Wasps 31 Bath 36
fields.trailText: Zurich Championship semi-finals: Callard's team fight back to earn return to Twickenham
fields.body:
Enough domestic rugby has been played in the last nine months to satisfy any glutton's appetite but yesterday's sparkling encounter here in west London proved as compelling as any. If Bath can now look forward to meeting their old rivals Leicester in Sunday's Twickenham final, their first visit to headquarters for five years, the way they got there will be hard to improve on.

Six Bath tries, in the end, were enough to settle a contest in which they trailed 24-7 only six minutes before the interval. Entering the 80th minute, though, the sides were locked at 31-31 when an attempted clearance kick from Josh Lewsey sailed invitingly into the hands of Matt Perry.

The England full-back ran it back cleverly enough to elude three defenders before inviting his winger Tom Voyce to ignore the famously narrow confines of the Loftus Road pitch and gallop around Martyn Wood for his second score of a memorable afternoon.

The 20-year-old Voyce, it later emerged, was almost substituted at half-time such was his coach Jon Callard's opinion of his first-half performance, but the decision to persevere with the young Cornishman ultimately proved as decisive as the knee injury to Lawrence Dallaglio which caused him to depart at half-time. The Wasps director of rugby Nigel Melville later insisted Dallaglio's injury was "nothing serious" but confirmed two further Lions, Rob Henderson (knee) and Phil Greening (ribs) had also been withdrawn for their protection.

Melville chose to blame a loss of composure for his side's collapse after a first half in which they could have put 40 points on the board instead of a mere 24.

Callard preferred to praise his young team's sense of adventure but Wasps did have two touchdowns ruled out for fractional forward passes, the first by Dallaglio to Shane Roiser in the second minute appearing legal to almost everyone in the ground bar the touch judge Robin Goodliffe.

For a while it seemed unlikely to matter. Bath had snatched an unlikely lead with a try from the prop David Barnes but Perry's conversion, deflected over the bar off the hands of the onrushing Logan, was the signal for two free-running sides to start running amok.

Wasps' second try, by Roiser, after Henderson had rampaged over for a trademark try on his final home appearance before moving to Munster, summed up the almost schizophrenic cut-and-thrust nature of the game to perfection. One minute Alex King was bearing down on the Bath line with Perry and Iain Balshaw scrambling desperately to gather a loose ball, the next Balshaw had instigated a raid deep into the Wasps' half only for Voyce to fumble a loose pass from his fly-half Gareth Cooper and allow Wasps to hack the ball upfield and score themselves.

Voyce soon redeemed himself with a breakway score after Paul Volley's pass had gone to ground and Bath were back to 24-21 two minutes after half-time when Henderson tugged back Steve Borthwick and the referee Brian Campsall correctly awarded a penalty try.

The Irish Lion in waiting also coughed up the turnover which allowed Balshaw to score another superb counter-attacking gem. Dan Lyle scored Bath's fifth from Catt's long ball, only for Logan's conversion of Fraser Waters' try to level the scores. The Scottish winger, though, could not land a 74th-minute penalty against the breeze and it was Bath who finished up, one might say, in full Voyce.

Bath: Tries: Barnes, Voyce 2, penalty try, Balshaw, Lyle. Conversions : Perry 3.

Referee: B Campsall (Yorkshire).
