webTitle: Rugby Union: Reserve Tigers rise to task

fields.headline: Reserve Tigers rise to task
fields.standfirst:
Leicester 17
Northampton 13
fields.trailText: With 12 minutes remaining Leicester wheeled on their big gun Martin Johnson as Pat Lam came on to take a final bow for the visitors, reserves that would make Sir Alex Ferguson envious.
fields.body:
As impact substitutions go, this was pretty useful. With 12 minutes remaining Leicester wheeled on their big gun Martin Johnson as Pat Lam came on to take a final bow for the visitors, reserves that would make Sir Alex Ferguson envious.

Three minutes later, and with Northampton pounding away at the enemy line, Lam spun off the back of a scrum on Leicester's 22 only to run straight into the Lions captain. At that moment Leicester sensed they would be heading for Twickenham next Sunday.

Dean Richards, Leicester's director of rugby, must now marshal his reserves in an equally astute way as the Tigers prepare for two finals in seven days. On Sunday Bath will be attempting to prevent the Premiership winners from adding the play-off final while the players of Stade Français can relax with a glass of red wine as they wait for the Heineken Cup final the following Saturday.

Leicester played a barely recognisable team here and still preserved an unbeaten home record against English teams that stretches back for some 3 seasons.

The likes of Steve Booth, Ollie Smith, Louis Deacon and Peter Short may not be given leading roles in Paris but as understudies they were word-perfect here. The diminutive wing Booth has only started three Premiership games but he scored the try just before the break that underpinned the victory, a score that Richards, not a man given to hyperbole, called "awesome".

Booth's weaving run down the left touchline after a counter-attack by Tim Stimpson took him past Nick Beal and Ben Cohen. Stimpson's touchline conversion gave Leicester an eight-point lead that the Saints were not able to claw back.

"I wouldn't hesitate to play some of these boys in the Zurich final," said Richards, hinting that the likes of Johnson, Austin Healey, Martin Corry, Dorian West and Leon Lloyd, all rested here, might only be given walk-on roles at Twickenham.

Northampton, who themselves were going for a treble a year ago, desperately needed a return to Twickenham to compensate for their feeble defence of the Heineken Cup last winter.

Their director of rugby John Steele for one sees no reason why Leicester cannot win two trophies next week. "They may have plateaued out in terms of intensity in recent weeks but once you reach finals the games take on their own momentum. We had chances to win today but it comes down to a battle of minds and that's where Leicester are so strong."

Northampton might have won but for two missed penalties. An early chance from Leicester's 22 that Paul Grayson would normally have converted in his sleep was struck wide. And a second kick on the half-hour appeared, at least to all the spectators in the Crumbie stand, to have gone inside the uprights.

The Saints toiled away and after the interval Luca Martin cancelled out Pat Howard's early try but they were not helped when Allan Bateman's career at Franklins Gardens came to a painful end when the Wales centre injured his ankle in a tackle on the halfway line.

The great Samoan warrior Lam left the field with a tearful wave and Leicester trooped off to the sounds of REM. Shiny Happy People at least made a change from We are the Champions.

Leicester : Stimpson; Booth, Smith, Howard, Stanley; Goode, Hamilton (O'Reilly, 74min); Rowntree (Freshwater, 59), Cockerill (Chuter, 59), Garforth (Nebbett, 76), Deacon (M Johnson, 68), Kay, Short (Gustard, 67), Back (capt), W Johnson.

Referee : E Morrison (Bristol).

webTitle: Rugby Union: Swansea secure silverware

fields.headline: Swansea secure silverware
fields.standfirst:
Swansea 54
Glasgow 10
fields.trailText: Swansea will be presented with the Welsh-Scottish league trophy when they entertain Bridgend here in midweek after being confirmed champions while they sat in the clubhouse here watching television on Saturday night.
fields.body:
Swansea will be presented with the Welsh-Scottish league trophy when they entertain Bridgend here in midweek after being confirmed champions while they sat in the clubhouse here watching television on Saturday night.

The Whites' eight-try demolition of Glasgow in the afternoon meant that for Cardiff to retain their title, they had not only to win their remaining two matches, the first of which was at Llanelli that evening, but also score at least 32 tries.

That mission improbable came to grief at the first hurdle with Llanelli winning 34-25 at Stradey Park to gain a mod icum of revenge for their 65-16 humiliation at home by Cardiff in the Principality Cup two months ago.

"We knew going into Saturday that Cardiff would only catch us if we lost our last two games," said the Swansea coach John Plumtree.

"The league is a true measure of a side's worth throughout a season, far more so than cups, where you rely considerably on the luck of the draw. It was disappointing not to get beyond the quarter-final of the Heineken Cup, but we will have another crack at it next season.

"Considering that we have been without players like Scott Gibbs, Mark Taylor, Arwel Thomas and Garin Jenkins for parts of the season, winning the title is a tribute to our strength in depth and, in the most competitive league season I can remember, being the Welsh-Scottish champions definitely means something."

Cardiff will finish runners-up and empty-handed, with Neath and Newport contesting the Principality Cup final on Sunday. They are also looking for a new coach following the resignation of Lynn Howells. "Whoever takes over from me will need to be a strong person," said Howells. "He has to be able to stand up to the board of directors and chart his own course."

Bridgend secured Wales' fifth berth in next season's Heineken Cup by defeating Caerphilly 31-23 at Virginia Park. They join Swansea, Cardiff, Llanelli and Newport in the tournament, which has never been won by a Welsh club.

It was disappointing not to get beyond the quarter-final of the Heineken Cup, but we will have another crack at it next season. "Considering that we have been without players like Scott Gibbs, Mark Taylor, Arwel Thomas and Garin Jenkins for parts of the season, winning the title is a tribute to our strength in depth and, in the most competitive league season I can remember, being the Welsh-Scottish champions definitely means something." Cardiff will finish runners-up and empty-handed, with Neath and Newport contesting the Principality Cup final on Sunday. They are also looking for a new coach following the resignation of Lynn Howells. "Whoever takes over from me will need to be a strong person," said Howells. "He has to be able to stand up to the board of directors and chart his own course." Bridgend secured Wales' fifth berth in next season's Heineken Cup by defeating Caerphilly 31-23 at Virginia Park. They join Swansea, Cardiff, Llanelli and Newport in the tournament, which has never been won by a Welsh club.

webTitle: Rugby Union: Leicester's long-term view breeds new type of rugby club

fields.headline: Leicester's long-term view breeds new type of rugby club
fields.trailText: Now their place in the final of the Zurich Championship is assured, it's time to ask if Leicester can win the treble of the Premiership, Championship and Heineken Cup?
fields.body:
Now their place in the final of the Zurich Championship is assured, it's time to ask if Leicester can win the treble of the Premiership, Championship and Heineken Cup? I'm not sure. I feel they will win the play-off final, but the European Cup final may be a different matter.

They are probably the most consistent team in Europe, but a one-off game against Stade Français in Paris could be hard for them. I'd give them a 50-50 chance in what is bound to be their biggest challenge of the year.

Whether or not they do become European champions, I think they are the best team of the last 10 years in England - the rugby equivalent of Manchester United. They set a standard of their own: they have lost only two league games this season, which is just incredible.

The biggest thing they have going for them is that Leicester is a city which lives for rugby. It's the most important thing up there, and that means lots of tradition and local support, which in turn means they can fill a big stadium every week. It's a good financial foundation.

On the pitch, they have a good mix of players, both young and experienced. And in Martin Johnson they have a big captain - in every sense - even if sometimes he loses his head. He's a hard man, very charismatic.

Even so, I think Pat Howard has been their best player this year, and perhaps the best in the league. One of the most important things for Leicester this season has been the fact that he hasn't had any injuries and hasn't missed many games.

Howard just gets better every year - there is no way they can fully replace him even if they do sign Rod Kafer.

Howard is a good organiser on the pitch, and has done a lot on the coaching side. He's managed to make the players think differently: they have realised that they can do a lot more with the ball. He's a nightmare to defend against: every time he has the ball, you think he's going to pass it then he breaks through you.

As for Tim Stimpson, I can't understand why Newcastle got rid of him. He had huge potential there, and in a confident state of mind he is just unbelievable. What they have done is put him in a team with quality players around him and watched him move forward.

The pack is legendary, but they will have to replace their front row. Graham Rowntree, Richard Cockerill and Darren Garforth aren't getting any younger and although they're still at a really high level, in a couple of years they may have trouble finding players to equal them. Garforth has had a super year. He plays like Neil Back, runs around everywhere - he runs like a prop, which is funny to watch, but he isn't funny to tackle. It's like trying to stop a train.

They've recruited well, with a lot of thought. They've bought players, but they seem to know exactly what players they need and where they fit in. They are always thinking three or four years ahead. This is where Dean Richards comes in: he was a legend as a player, and seems to have a better feel than anyone for the team and the city. There is so much continuity in what he has done.

What's interesting is the way they have changed their game in the last five years. I played against them in Toulouse in 1996 and saw them in the European Cup that year, and when I played them this season I was surprised by the skills among their backs. You can put that down mainly to Howard and Geordan Murphy, but you can't ignore Austin Healey either.

The final thing with Leicester is the spirit. The players seem proud to play for the team. They've got to a really high level a few times, and they want the feeling again. When you see Johnson play an international on Saturday, then turn out on Tuesday for a Premiership game, you see the spirit, and when a player like that shows the way, the others have to do the same.

Playing against them is like taking on a machine. You can't relax or it will break you. If they get six or seven points ahead, it's hard to come back. You have to lead them, as once they have a lead, they get on a roll and are impossible to stop. One mistake, and they'll kill you.

webTitle: Young pretender catches the eye of the real McEvoy

fields.headline: Young pretender catches the eye of the real McEvoy
fields.trailText: Richard McEvoy won the Lytham Trophy here yesterday with some golf that was worthy of the man who may be his captain in a few months' time, But the winner is no relation to Peter McEvoy who won this event in 1979 and later this year will take the Walker Cup team to the United States.
fields.byline: David Davies at Royal Lytham St Annes
fields.body:
Richard McEvoy won the Lytham Trophy here yesterday with some golf that was worthy of the man who may be his captain in a few months' time, But the winner is no relation to Peter McEvoy who won this event in 1979 and later this year will take the Walker Cup team to the United States.

McEvoy R made a strong case for selection yesterday with some compelling play on a course over which the Open will be played in July. Realising towards the end of the final round that he was allow ing his challengers to get rather too close, he played Lytham's infamous and widely feared finish from the 14th onwards in three-under par, sinking birdies on the last three holes - something for which the professionals would give millions come the Open.

It gave him a final round of 66, the lowest of the event and an aggregate of 276, 11 under, the lowest ever in the event, which beat the 279 recorded three years ago by the Scot Graham Rankin and in 1979 by the man who is in danger now of becoming known as the other McEvoy.

He won by eight shots from Marc Warren of East Kilbride and Paul Bradshaw of Gainsborough with notables like Lancashire's Nick Dougherty and David Dixon of Cornwall, last year's winner, trailing by 12 and 14 shots respectively.

McEvoy P masterminded arguably the greatest of all Walker Cup victories when, at Nairn in 1999, Great Britain and Ireland came back from 7-5 down after the first day to win 15-9.

He had been, he reflected yesterday, "hyper-confident" his team would win, and that confidence palpably transmitted itself to his team.

This year the match is in the United States and McEvoy expects it to be "more challenging". He said: "We won at Nairn despite one poor day's golf and we will not be able to afford that this year. We will have to perform. But there is absolutely no reason why we should not.

"I've done some research on the Premiership in football and two-thirds of the points are won by home teams.

"The funny thing is that the pitch dimensions are all the same within a few feet, the surface is always the same and the only real factor against you is the crowd. But crowds should only affect the head, not the feet, so that means that the reason home teams win most of the time is that they are expected to.

"So we have to prevent that expectation from prevailing. It shouldn't exist but, as it does, we will have to get round it and the great thing is that it has been identified."

McEvoy acknowledges that the South Carolina weather in August, which will be both hot and humid, is likely to be a factor but points out that there should be a number of members of the team that play regularly in college golf in America and will be accustomed to those conditions.

Finally he dealt firmly with the intimidation factor. "It doesn't exist any more," said the captain of the defending champions. "It's not just the fact that we won last time; it's all the other cup winners - the Curtis Cup, the Solheim Cup, the Ryder Cup teams - they've done away with that. And so have people like Luke Donald, who was in our team at Nairn and may be again.

"He has just won three college events in succession in America and to go over there all on his own and become their No1 shows everyone that there's no need to be afraid."

webTitle: Olazabal rides out the storm

fields.headline: Olazabal rides out the storm
fields.standfirst: Spaniard breaks barren run to take French Open
fields.trailText: Jose Maria Olazabal was not the only man smiling after his first victory for 12 months in the flood-blighted French Open here yesterday.
fields.body:
Jose Maria Olazabal was not the only man smiling after his first victory for 12 months in the flood-blighted French Open here yesterday.

On the eve of the defence of his last win, in the Benson & Hedges International at the Belfry, the 35-year-old Spaniard moved up from 16th to sixth in the Ryder Cup qualifying table with closing rounds of 66 and 67 for a 12-under-par total of 268.

His 19th European Tour success, worth some £135,000, in a championship which lost more than 13 hours to the wet weather, substantially eases the pressure on the Ryder Cup captain Sam Torrance, who is allowed only two personal picks in his 12 to face the Americans back at the Belfry in September.

Olazabal has been campaigning across the Atlantic, where the best of his eight finishes so far is a tie for 12th in the Players Championship, and missed the cut on his first European outing of the season in last month's Spanish Open.

His solid 15th place in the US Masters counted towards a Ryder return but it was important for Torrance's peace of mind that Olazabal got some more points under his belt.

Olazabal and the Italian Costantino Rocca had started the final round as joint leaders on nine under after completing the third round in the morning, Rocca carding a superb 64 to outscore Olazabal by two shots.

Rocca, second in the Ryder rankings before the off but dramatically back on form, then set the target with a closing 69 for 270, and his total was matched by a spectacular eagle three at the last by New Zealand's Greg Turner, who hit a five-wood 235 yards from the soggy fairway to 12 feet for a 67.

But a safety-first long iron off the tee at the 18th by Olazabal, who struggled with his driver all week, underlined the Spaniard's ability to keep his nerve under the strongest pressure as he pitched to six feet for a clinching birdie.

The diminutive Lancastrian Paul Eales may lack length but he is not short of determination and birdies at the 11th, from 20 feet, and the long 15th got him to 10 under.

But Eales had to settle for a share of second with Rocca and Turner after a 68, finishing two behind Olazabal.

In the morning Rocca, after opening rounds of 68 and 69, shot a third-round 64 to show he has at last rediscovered the scoring form which earned him five tour victories and three Ryder Cup outings in the 90s. His 64 was sprinkled with six birdies but there was to be no repeat of his 1993 victory at the same Parcours des Sangliers venue in the Lyon Open.

Olazabal swiftly found himself three shots clear of Rocca early in the final round. But the Italian, after nervously opening his second round of the day with a brace of bogeys, bounced back to draw level again with birdies at the 5th - a 571yd hole turned into a par three because of the flooding - and the 6th plus a birdie three from 15 feet at the 12th.

 Australian Karrie Webb shot a one-under-par 71 to go six clear of the field and win the Nichirei Cup World Ladies title in Japan for the second consecutive year.

webTitle: Tennis: Storming Williams has eyes on Berlin and Paris

fields.headline: Storming Williams has eyes on Berlin and Paris
fields.trailText: Venus Williams issued a typically vivid warning that she is capable of adding the French Open to her triumphs at the US Open and Wimbledon by capturing the third clay court title of her career here yesterday, demolishing her steadily improving 21-year-old American compatriot, Meghann Shaughnessy, 6-3, 6-0 in the final of the Betty Barclay Cup.
fields.body:
Venus Williams issued a typically vivid warning that she is capable of adding the French Open to her triumphs at the US Open and Wimbledon by capturing the third clay court title of her career here yesterday, demolishing her steadily improving 21-year-old American compatriot, Meghann Shaughnessy, 6-3, 6-0 in the final of the Betty Barclay Cup.

A giant tarantula of sprawling braids and four-inch long pendulum ear-rings was matched by an almost as eye-catching way of dealing with the sport's slowest surface. Increasingly Williams stepped forward to finish rallies off from mid-court with swinging drive volleys which made the ochre dust look anything but slow and the opposition anything but respectable.

"I am a little bit upset: I felt a bit hopeless today," admitted Shaughnessy, who has just climbed into the world's top 20. "Even if I had played really well I don't know how long I could have held her up."

In fact the WTA Tour event final lasted only 54 minutes and there were only about 20 of those when the outcome was in doubt. Shaughnessy risked a hit-or-bust policy to break back for 2-2 but immediately lost her service again and, by dropping serve for a third time at the start of the second set, trying to do too much and double-faulting on break point, she allowed herself to run into the eye of a storm.

That was because it gave the world No2 a cushion to have a whirl at almost anything and when she did it usually came off. Whether Williams can prevail against the best clay-courters on the biggest occasion is unproven, but she talks as if she can.

"I dreamed about winning Roland Garros. I dreamed about it a little bit more than my dream of winning Wimbledon," she claimed. "And I think I have as good a chance as I do on hard or on grass."

Not everyone agrees. However, Williams completed the week by conceding a mere 12 games in eight sets, and 10 of the last 14 Hamburg finals have produced at least one of the Paris finalists. The crux may be whether she has the hang of sliding into the shot on the loose top without undue stress to the knee which caused the furore in Miami when she withdrew.

This week in Berlin, Martina Hingis should provide tougher opposition. If Williams wins again, she will be within striking distance of another big goal - only a couple of hundred ranking points behind the world No1.

webTitle: Snooker: Rapt attention as the Rocket lifts from the launch pad

fields.headline: Rapt attention as the Rocket lifts from the launch pad
fields.trailText: In the lobby of the Crucible the world championship trophy was made available for pictures. There was brisk business as fans paid a modest £5 for the privilege of being photographed in an appropriately triumphant pose
fields.body:
In the lobby of the Crucible the world championship trophy was made available for pictures. There was brisk business as fans paid a modest £5 for the privilege of being photographed in an appropriately triumphant pose. If they had been offered the ability to play like Ronnie O'Sullivan as well, the price would have been a fair bit higher - a right arm, say.

Busier still before the final began was the bookmaker, laying odds of 2000-1 against the best-of- 35-frames championship being decided 18-0. The tobacco company sponsoring the event would have felt cold turkey if that was ever in prospect. John Higgins, at least, dispelled any such fear by winning the second frame.

Extraordinarily, the pre-final odds were exactly the same against O'Sullivan and Hggins for every possible winning margin. This was almost certainly based on the belief that, while O'Sullivan may be the better player, he is as likely to blow himself away as Higgins.

The silence during play at the Crucible is compelling; no sport is conducted in a more reverential tone. A cathedral is raucous by comparison. The hush becomes hypnotic, so when "shot" is whispered by a member of the audience, say, as Higgins makes a difficult red, it breaks the spell, dropping noisily in the arena, like a pin.

Higgins is a perfect fit for the silent stage, the 25-year-old Scot bearing more than a passing resemblance to Stan Laurel. He does not scratch his head but his hair is tousled in just such a way that one could believe he just has. Like Laurel, he has a clown's face. The eyes, when he is not laughing (and this was no laughing matter), are sad and the frown, like a shadow, passes across his brow when things go amiss.

O'Sullivan is different. Silence is never noisier than when he is at the table. It is not simply the expectation of the 980-strong audience, their collective will engaged in O'Sullivan's cause. It is that he has such a charged presence that, even when he is simply measuring the shot, one can feel the atmosphere crackle with intent. He is not a man whose hand one would choose to shake after walking on a synthetic carpet.

O'Sullivan goes on the attack with relish. One wonders if, somewhere deep in his distant past, balls or tables did something to upset him, and ever since he has wreaked his revenge. That taste for the battle makes O'Sullivan a sensational shot-maker. This makes it almost impossible to stop watching him. One dare not look away.

"I look on snooker as an art and it should be made to look beautiful," O'Sullivan said recently. He may have recalled those words as the pink, in a decidedly ugly mood in frame three, refused to go down despite the simplicity of the shot.

It had begun to look one of those finals which O'Sullivan would either win or lose, on his own. It still does. Higgins will just have to wait and see which.

One wonders if, somewhere deep in his distant past, balls or tables did something to upset him, and ever since he has wreaked his revenge. That taste for the battle makes O'Sullivan a sensational shot-maker. This makes it almost impossible to stop watching him. One dare not look away. "I look on snooker as an art and it should be made to look beautiful," O'Sullivan said recently. He may have recalled those words as the pink, in a decidedly ugly mood in frame three, refused to go down despite the simplicity of the shot. It had begun to look one of those finals which O'Sullivan would either win or lose, on his own. It still does. Higgins will just have to wait and see which.

webTitle: Snooker: O'Sullivan slips into the rhythm

fields.headline: O'Sullivan slips into the rhythm
fields.standfirst: Higgins forced on to back foot in final
fields.trailText: Higgins forced on to back foot in final
fields.body:
Ronnie O'Sullivan's 6-2 lead over John Higgins after the first of the four sessions which comprise their best-of-35-frames final yesterday of the Embassy World Championship at the Crucible Theatre, Sheffield, was just the start that all his opponents fear.

"Ronnie is not the sort of player you can get back at," said Joe Swail, his 17-11 semi-final victim. "He's a very good front runner."

He is a genius too, according to both the Northern Ireland No1 and Peter Ebdon, beaten 13-6 by O'Sullivan in the quarter-finals. "His game is a joy to watch," said Swail. "There were times when I was just sat there laughing."

The draw, other results and the order of play have conspired in his favour. "I've had some good space between each game," said O'Sullivan. "I've managed to make light of my matches. I've had a bit of a smoother run through."

Safely through, with media commitments dealt with before the tension of Saturday's football results, O'Sullivan was able to rest and prepare while Higgins was digging deep into his mental reserves to beat Matthew Stevens, last year's runner-up, 17-15.

Higgins, who had trailed 13-11 going into their final session, prevailed through a monumental 61-minute clinching frame and said that he had learned a lesson from last year's semi-final in which he led Mark Williams 15-11 only to be knocked out after a six-frame losing streak.

"It's strange because when you're in front I think you're actually more nervous," said the 1998 champion. "You're trying to protect a lead whereas, if you're behind, you know you've got to play well and you're just going for your shots. It's tough because, when the pressure is on, you can't even see the pocket sometimes."

The first four frames of the final occupied only 42 minutes. Higgins, unlucky to go in-off on 37, yielded the opener to O'Sullivan's 88 clearance but kept him scoreless in the second with runs of 47 and 45.

No ball was potted by the 25-year-old Scot in the third or fourth, though, in which he sat out breaks of 81 and 46 respectively, and the after noon's only tactical frame, one of 31 minutes, went to O'Sullivan on the black with a 34 clearance as he led 4-1.

A total clearance of 135 from Higgins, his 10th century of the championship in pursuit of his record 14 in his title year, accounted for the sixth and, from 0-48, he had a chance to clear up in the seventh only to falter on 28 with a rest shot, an unreliable feature of his performance against Stevens.

O'Sullivan pounced with 42 and with a dashing 70 secured his 6-2 interval advantage, one he had also enjoyed against Swail and of which he said: "With a four-frame lead you can relax a little bit more. The other player is playing catch-up and you know he's got to take a few more chances than he'd like to."

Real life has often impeded O'Sullivan's snooker since his father was jailed for life for murder nine years ago. "I'm not being big-headed but I know how good I was," he says. "If I'd kept up my form I had at 15 and 16, I believe I would have won the championship by now."

He felt the wrench of separation from his chief supporter keenly, sometimes seeking relief in the pursuit of pleasure, sometimes sinking into black depressions.

"There are a lot of things I would like to change and do differently but I've just got to accept it and get on with it. I'm trying my hardest. I see and feel a different thing out there than you see on TV. Your adrenalin kicks in when you're playing big matches. It just takes over. "

webTitle: Horse racing: Kentucky blues for Godolphin

fields.headline: Kentucky blues for Godolphin
fields.trailText: Godolphin's latest assault on the Kentucky Derby was wide of the mark at the Churchill Downs on Saturday night when Express Tour finished eighth of 17 starters behind Monarchos.
fields.body:
Godolphin's latest assault on the Kentucky Derby was wide of the mark at the Churchill Downs on Saturday night when Express Tour finished eighth of 17 starters behind Monarchos.

The Saeed bin Suroor-trained Express Tour made a promising move halfway down the far side and rounding the bend into the straight the colt was disputing third place. But when jockey David Flores asked the chestnut to pick up, the response was muted. Express Tour was beaten almost 15 lengths.

The Dubai team, out of luck with Tobougg in the Sagitta 2000 Guineas, were not disappointed with Express Tour, who could well be pointed at the Preakness Stakes, the second leg of the American Triple Crown, at Pimlico, Baltimore on May 19.

Racing manager Simon Crisford, after talking to Flores, said: "David felt the last eighth of a mile found us out. He was in a good enough position and enjoyed a clean run. He will remain in the States and be dropped back to a mile and an eighth (the distance of the Preakness)."

Flores also blamed lack of stamina, saying: "I was right there on that last turn, right there with Point Given. I thought I was in heaven.

"I saw Congaree go early and thought I'd follow him and Point Given right to the front. He gave me a little turning for home but then he was empty. He'll be tough back in the Preakness."

Monarchos ran out the impressive winner in front of the second-biggest Derby day crowd of 154,210, a figure bettered only for the 100th running in 1974 (163,628).

The John Ward-trained colt drew clear in the home straight under Jorge Chevaz to beat the outsider Invisible Ink by four and three-quarter lengths with Congaree a nose back in third. Thunder Blitz was fourth.

webTitle: Horse racing: Horse and jockey survive horror fall

fields.headline: Horse and jockey survive horror fall
fields.trailText: Racegoers at Hamilton were left fearing the worst after the opening race yesterday when Societe Generale, ridden by Kevin Hodgson, suffered what appeared an horrific fall.
fields.body:
Racegoers at Hamilton were left fearing the worst after the opening race yesterday when Societe Generale, ridden by Kevin Hodgson, suffered what appeared an horrific fall.

However, relieved officials were later able to confirm that both horse and jockey escaped serious injury.

The two-year-old was in the rear of the field and running green when he swerved violently to his right after about two furlongs of the five-furlong contest and crashed through the running rails and down a steep bank into the centre of the course.

Hodgson was thrown to the ground by the impact with the rails, but was able to walk back to the weighing-room with nothing more than bruising.

Hamilton chief executive Morag Gray said: "It is an enormous relief as it looked terrible. But I gather that Kevin is okay and that the horse was caught, although he might be slightly lame."

A stewards' enquiry held into the incident warned Societe Generale's trainer Alan Bailey that any similar behaviour from the gelding might render the horse to be reported to the Jockey Club, who could ban him from taking part in future races.

The race was won by hot favourite Zinging.

webTitle: Golan on the path to glory

fields.headline: Golan on the path to glory
fields.standfirst: Stoute colt hot favourite to follow in footsteps of Nashwan
fields.trailText: As many questions that Saturday's Sagitta 2,000 Guineas answered, it finally posed an even bigger one. Can Golan become the first horse since Nashwan in 1989 to complete the Guineas-Derby double?
fields.body:
As many questions that Saturday's Sagitta 2,000 Guineas answered, it finally posed an even bigger one. Can Golan become the first horse since Nashwan in 1989 to complete the Guineas-Derby double?

Predictably, the bookmakers are taking no chances and the colt is now a best-priced 5-2 with Ladbrokes for Epsom, while Coral's and the Tote go as short as 2-1.

Golan certainly has the breeding to suggest he will stay a mile and a half and if he can combine that with the sustained speed he showed here, he will be very hard to beat in the Derby.

An analysis of the sectional times on Saturday indicated that Golan ran the fastest four consecutive furlongs of any horse in the race - from the six-marker until the two-pole.

That is truly remarkable. For an animal to sustain this sort of speed - he was averaging just over 40mph - for that length of time in the middle section of a mile race is little short of sensational and it puts him in a different league to last year's winner King's Best.

The latter appeared to produce stunning acceleration in the final quarter mile to win the Guineas, but it was more a question of those in front stopping. This was not the case this time and Golan could be a superstar.

Raced only once as a two-year-old when he won a maiden at Chepstow in September, he is further proof of the training skills of Sir Michael Stoute, who was able bring him to a peak without a prior outing in the worst spring anyone can remember.

Not over-racing your best two-year-olds in their first season, or even giving them a perfunctory couple of runs, is now becoming standard practice for the top English trainers, al though it is not a method favoured by Aidan O'Brien.

The Group One races for juveniles in the programme are now beginning to look of financial and academic interest only; a startling statistic being that the Dewhurst Stakes winner has gone on to win the 2,000 Guineas just three times in the last 30 years - El Gran Senor, Zafonic and Pennekamp.

Golan is a very fresh horse and in the long term this must be of immense benefit to him. Stoute does not intend to give him another run before the Derby so his stamina must be taken on trust. But being by the Champion Stakes winner Spectrum out of a mare by Generous he has a middle-distance pedigree.

If Golan was the equine hero on Saturday, then Kieren Fallon's effort must not be underestimated. Like a cat with nine lives Fallon keeps coming back. Sacked by Henry Cecil two season ago, his world fell apart. But there was worse to come and by mid-summer last year, after a horror-fall at Royal Ascot, he was wondering whether he would ever ride again.

How he overcame the loss of use in his left arm has been well-documented and looking back, the Cecil sacking can be seen as a blessing in disguise. Indeed, you could put it even more strongly and say that is was the best thing that could have happened.

Picked up by the powerful Stoute stable, Fallon's career has suffered not one jot. He has now won the 2,000 Guineas in successive years and stands on the threshold of gaining his second Derby triumph to follow Oath in 1999.

Compared to Stoute, Cecil has strugged. Beset by personal problems and the loss of form of his horses, he is not exactly a back number. However, he has had to take an unaccustomed back seat.

Cecil's Derby colt, Curtain Time, seemed aptly named after failing in the opener on Saturday and the main danger to Golan at Epsom could turn out to be his stable companion Dilshaan, who beat Tamburlaine in the Racing Post Trophy at Doncaster last season.

Apparently Dilshaan, a 12-l chance for the Derby, worked well on Saturday morning and is on target for the Dante Stakes at York Wednesday week.

O'Brien's Galileo, quoted at 8-1, is due to take the Sinndar route and will go for the Derrinstown Stud Derby Trial at Leopardstown on Sunday.

webTitle: Horse racing: Davids Lad gives Murphy a National celebration

fields.headline: Davids Lad gives Murphy a National celebration
fields.trailText: Davids Lad gave trainer Tony Martin and jockey Timmy Murphy the biggest successes of their careers when landing the Powers Gold Label Irish Grand National at Fairyhouse yesterday.
fields.body:
Davids Lad gave trainer Tony Martin and jockey Timmy Murphy the biggest successes of their careers when landing the Powers Gold Label Irish Grand National at Fairyhouse yesterday.

Davids Lad, a course winner on April 25 and 3lb out of the handicap, came fast and late to take the IR£81,500 first prize in the colours of the four-man Eddie Joe's Racing Syndicate.

Successful at Cheltenham last November, Davids Lad (10-1) was ridden with restraint and great judgment by 26-year-old Murphy to tackle the 25-1 chance Rathbawn Prince going to the final fence and score by a length and a half.

Murphy said: "I was told to make sure he settled, get him jumping and come late on the scene. All credit to Tony Martin for producing Davids Lad in the form of his life."

Murphy, who comes from Kilcullen, Co Kildare was runner up on Smarty in the Grand National at Aintree and was particularly pleased to gain compensation in the Irish equivalent.

He added: "This is brilliant after missing out at Aintree on Smarty. I never really had a moment's worry because we met no trouble in running and we went round on fresh ground on the inner."

Well-backed favourite Foxchapel King and the top-weight Commanche Court were both vulnerable when the pace suddenly quickened at the third last, where the long-time leader Sheltering was being challenged by Rathbawn Prince with Murphy still sitting pretty on Davids Lad.

Sheltering, who jumped better than when winning a hunter chase here last week, did not settle for Norman Williamson but still took third place.

Martin, who trains not far from the course outside Trim, has done a marvellous job with Davids Lad considering the gelding has risen 48lb in the ratings since opening his account over fences at Navan last autumn.

The winner's dam Cool Nora remarkably gave Martin his first winner as a trainer when taking a modest maiden hurdle at Downpatrick, and Davids Lad was her only foal.

webTitle: Ameerat ends long

fields.headline: Ameerat ends long
fields.standfirst: Classic wait for Jarvis
fields.trailText: They say that everything comes to those who wait, and following the victory of Ameerat in yesterday's Sagitta 1,000 Guineas trainer Michael Jarvis will vouch for the wisdom of those words.
fields.body:
They say that everything comes to those who wait, and following the victory of Ameerat in yesterday's Sagitta 1,000 Guineas trainer Michael Jarvis will vouch for the wisdom of those words.

Jarvis has held a licence since 1968 and although he saddled the runner-up in the Oaks and the St Leger (Meadowville behind Nijinsky) he had never won an English Classic.

"It's a wonderful feeling - I would have hated to have retired never having won one," said Jarvis. "I've won the French Derby and the Arc, but there's nothing like winning one of the big ones on your home soil."

Jarvis, 62, is one of the most popular members of the training fraternity, and although a low-key operator, seldom fails to exploit the potential of his horses. The same could be said for jockey Philip Robinson, although this was his third English Classic victory following Pebbles in 1,000 in 1984 and Bob's Return in the 1993 St Leger.

"I've always rated this filly and she's got to be up there with the best I've ridden, including Pebbles, Katies and Crimplene," said Robinson, who rode his first winner in 1978.

Jarvis was full of praise for Robinson, who came late to snatch the verdict by a neck after Frankie Dettori had tried to make all on Muwakleh.

Of the runner-up, Dettori said: "She tried very hard and I couldn't fault her performance - she should stay a bit farther. But I'm not sure about a mile and a half."

Aidan O'Brien's Toroca was a length away third with Crystal Music fourth, but the 9-2 favourite Karasta, trained by Sir Michael Stoute, finished 13th of the 15 runners.

With Jarvis uncertain whether Ameerat will run in the Vodafone Oaks, most bookmakers have Stoute's Flight of Fancy, owned by The Queen, favourite at 6-1.

webTitle: Ronnie Biggs in prison again

fields.headline: Ronnie Biggs in prison again
fields.trailText: The great train robber Ronnie Biggs touched down in the UK today after 35 years on the run, only to be sent  back to jail to serve the remainder of his sentence.
fields.body:
The great train robber Ronnie Biggs touched down in the UK today after 35 years on the run, only to be sent back to jail to serve the remainder of his sentence.

Biggs flew back into Britain from his home in Brazil aboard a private jet stocked with lager and curry and paid for by the Sun newspaper. He was immediately rearrested and appeared at a west London magistrates court three and a half hours after the plane landed.

After a brief hearing, Biggs, 71, was sent back to jail to serve his time at Belmarsh prison in south east London. Biggs immediately vowed to appeal. A statement issued through his lawyer said he would seek a hearing before the Court of Appeals to have his original sentence overturned.

At today's hearing, Biggs was not charged with any offence, District Judge Tim Workman merely having to be satisfied that he was the person named in an arrest warrant issued following his prison break in 1965.

About 60 police officers were awaiting his arrival at the entrance to RAF Northolt in northeast London this morning. Seven police vans and at least three police cars welcomed the frail and penniless Biggs, who has suffered three strokes and can no longer speak properly.

Biggs left Rio de Janeiro, his home for most of his time on the run, last night amid chaotic scenes as reporters and photographers sought to get a glimpse of one of the world's most famous fugitives.

Biggs, who long ago spent his £147,000 share (worth about £1.6m in today's money) of the 1963 mail train robbery haul, hopes to receive vital medical treatment, which he could not afford in Brazil. The fugitive, who escaped from Wandsworth prison in 1965 after serving 15 months of his 30 year sentence for robbery, returned to Britain in a Dassault Falcon 900 executive jet stocked with curry, Marmite and cans of beer.

Biggs has 28 years of a 30-year prison sentence still to serve for his role in the 1963 robbery of the Glasgow-to-London mail train, which yielded £2.6m.

At Northolt, waiting press were kept outside a perimeter fence and RAF police patrolled with dogs.

He said he had spoken to the train robber's son Michael, 26, in Brazil who had told him that "the old Biggs sparkle had appeared in his eye".

The train robber's return from exile has sparked a row over what should happen to him.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, called for a "hard-headed" attitude, saying he should spend the rest of his life behind bars.

But friends said the authorities should treat him with compassion as he was in poor health after his third stroke. Unable to speak, Biggs now communicates through written notes.

Last week Biggs sent an email to the head of the Flying Squad, Detective Chief Superintendent John Coles, the officer in overall charge of the Met's Serious and Organised Crime Group, saying he wanted to give himself up. There have been suggestions that he has run out of money and wants to return home to get free medical treatment on the NHS.

But the home secretary, Jack Straw, said any individual unlawfully at large from prison was liable to immediate rearrest and return to prison as soon as it came to the notice of the police.

In Brazil Biggs made money by inviting people into his home and selling T-shirts and souvenirs on his own website.

webTitle: Cricket: Unctuous Aussies damn Nasser with faint praise to begin phoney war

fields.headline: Unctuous Aussies damn Nasser with faint praise to begin phoney war
fields.trailText: The blighters from Down Under have begun the phoney war even before England's starters with Pakistan beginning on Thursday week.
fields.body:
 The blighters from Down Under have begun the phoney war even before England's starters with Pakistan beginning on Thursday week. It was cringemaking to hear the two mischievous former Australian Test players, Ian Healy and Greg Matthews, so unctuously talking up England's cricketing rebirth on the radio the other day - particularly their smarminess about the England captain Nasser Hussain and how he is "a Mike Brearley worth his place for his leadership alone". You could almost see their eyes glinting, hear them rubbing their hands, as they said it - thinking "if Hussain is in at No3 then how much more quickly is McGrath going to turn 20 for one into 20 for two."

Hussain's 63 on Saturday was his highest score in England in 43 matches. The England captain really is in desperate need of big runs against Pakistan. That memorably brave 109 against Sri Lanka at Kandy was wholly played on guts and sandwiched between series scores of 3, 1, 15, 8, and nought. The Australians will pile into him mercilessly if he looks still vulnerably out of sorts in midsummer.

In fact, the Australians were wrong - Brearley as captain never dropped himself for any lack of form. It was Mike Denness who did in Australia in 1974-75. On the following tour, Mike was certainly considering it in 1978-79 after Test scores of 17, 0, 1, 0 - when Tony Greig dropped into his Sydney hotel room to commiserate (gloatingly). "Blimey, what an amazing coincidence, Brears," hinted the blond beanpole, "yours is room 145, which is the very same room where Denness decided to fall on his own sword four years ago!" Brearley stuck it out - and weeks later he discovered that Denness's team had stayed on the other side of the city. Of course, Greigy by then was an out-and-out Aussie, wasn't he?

Ah, the FA Cup, definition of Englishness - "that band of gold in the fabric of our sporting nation," as the late Bryon Butler proudly preened in his official history of the competition, whose "pageant has sprinkled stardust through the drip and chill of English winters ever since Stanley found Livingstone and Gladstone introduced Bank Holidays". Not this Bank Holiday it doesn't as England looks forward to a 2001 final when 22 players, 15 or 16 from faraway places with strange sounding names, will be led into a Welsh stadium by two Frenchmen.

From Mrs B Gilmartin, Hayes, Middlesex: "Dear Mr Keating, Your observation that Irish rugby captain and Lion, Keith Wood, 'is as bald as a Donegal granny' I find objectionable as well as inaccurate. Being a Donegal grandmother myself with a copious head of hair, and being acquainted with many more, each with luxuriant locks, we demand to know on what facts you base your assumptions. You have obviously written this codswallop off the top of your head. My grandson - who plays rugby - is hurt and confused by your remark."

Apologies all round.

webTitle: Cricket: Beefy and beef fat on the menu as Chilly gets cooking

fields.headline: Beefy and beef fat on the menu as Chilly gets cooking
fields.standfirst: Rachel Cugnoni on a brief encounter with a sporting hero
fields.trailText: Rachel Cugnoni on a brief encounter with a sporting hero
fields.body:
Gucci, Boycks, Willey, Dilley and, of course Beefy, just a few of the names there back in 1981 at the Headingley Test, the one that everyone remembers, the one when our boys fought back against incredible odds (the bookies put it at 500-1) and reclaimed the Ashes.

I am not quite old enough to remember the events of 1966 but 1981 is clear in my mind and, as far as I am concerned, anyone who took part in that historic victory is on my A list of people I would like to meet.

So, happy day, here I am sitting in a chintzy chippy seven miles outside Penzance chatting to Chilly - Chris Old to you. Things are going quite well. We have done the weather (amazingly the sun is beating down), we have done golf - well, it is only polite, all men of a certain age do it. We have done the Test - he scored a crucial 29 and took out Border's middle stump. And now I find myself asking: "So what do you cook the chips in then?"

It was not a question I ever expected to be asking Chris Old but the sad thing is there was no avoiding it. After all how does a great swing bowler end up running what is essentially an up-market fish-and-chip shop on a beautiful beach in Cornwall?

I wish I could tell you it was the great links courses that brought him down here, or that the thing Chris Old loves best after Geoffrey Boycott is a seafood platter but that, unfortunately, would not be the truth of it.

Cricket is still Chris Old's major addiction but the problem is cricket's not bothered one way or another about Chris Old. It is a straight-up-and-down case of unrequited love. Since he retired as a professional in 1985 he has been trying to make a living out of the game and failing. Don't call us, Chris; we'll call you.

A sportsman's life is a brief and, for the lucky, glorious one. By the time a footballer reaches his late 20s he is approaching his sell-by date and on the reduced counter. At thirtysomething he is in the "everything must go" league. And then, pretty soon after that, he might find Ron Atkinson passing him by at a car-boot sale. It is enough to send the sanest of men running screaming to the Priory or perhaps the pub.

Never mind the high-profile breakdowns of Tony Adams, Paul Merson and Stan "the mad man" Collymore. What about the rest of them - the ones the tabloids are not interested in? If they cannot pass on their experience and expertise in a coaching position and Radio 5 Live will not have them - and they have Peter Beardsley after all - they have to be thinking a sports shop somewhere in the home counties, a pub in Essex or, I suppose, catering in Cornwall.

Chris Old's life had a trajectory most professional sportsmen would recognise. The first half of his life was gilded. He was naturally gifted. As a boy he excelled at both cricket and rugby and in his teens had to decide which he was going to specialise in. He was clearly capable of reaching international level in either.

He went for cricket, he says, "for the money" and so his career began: 1966 - selected for Yorkshire; 1972 - called up for England; 1979 - voted Wisden cricketer of the year; 1981 - no need to go on about that again. It is the stuff of a schoolboy's dreams.

It was when he was in his mid-thirties and nearing the end of his useful life that things became more complicated and nothing he had experienced in his first three-and-a-half decades had prepared him for the trials ahead. One minute he was being paid to muck around on playing fields and sign his autograph. The next he finds himself washed up on a beach.

There is no obvious answer to the problem, of course. Worrying about it will not help. And in any case it is not that different from the lives of us ordinary mortals. We have our time, we either waste it or use it until we get too old to waste it or use it any more. It is just more brutal ifor those who happen to make their living from sport.

But if, like me, you are delighted at the prospect of meeting a real live sporting hero, book a holiday in Cornwall and drive over to Praa Sands. You will find Chris Old's Clipper Restaurant. The chips are great. He cooks them in beef dripping. He is a Yorkshireman after all.

Rachel Cugnoni is editorial director of Yellow Jersey press

webTitle: Cricket: Ranatunga hits out at ICC

fields.headline: Ranatunga hits out at ICC
fields.trailText: The former Sri Lanka captain Arjuna Ranatunga yesterday dismissed as "patently ridiculous and unworthy of consideration" the allegations contained in an Indian police report into the match-fixing inquiry.
fields.body:
The former Sri Lanka captain Arjuna Ranatunga yesterday dismissed as "patently ridiculous and unworthy of consideration" the allegations contained in an Indian police report into the match-fixing inquiry.

His comments in a letter to a newspaper came at the end of a week in which he refused to answer questions from two ICC investigators when he was called before the Sri Lankan inquiry under the lawyer Desmond Fernando.

"The allegations against me are based on the unproven evidence of a self-confessed rogue. I should have thought that the BCCSL (Sri Lanka cricket board) would have rejected them with the contempt they deserve," said Ranatunga.

Ranatunga was surprised to see Jeffrey Rees and Alan Peacock, the ICC investigators, sitting in Fernando's room, said Kalinga Indatissa, his attorney.

"We protested and said we had come for only one inquiry.

"We asked the ICC to send us the charges in writing. Thereafter, they can call and we will come for questioning any day.

"Our objective is not to run away from answering questions, but the rules of natural justice demand that a person should be made aware of the charges against him."

Pakistan cruised to an easy win over British Universities yesterday but coach Richard Pybus had to defend new fast bowling "sensation" Mohammad Sami after the youngster struggled with the conditions.

"He's got exceptional pace but you haven't seen that yet," he said. "I didn't want him going full tilt as he got his first feel of English conditions."

Sami will be put under more pressure by the arrival of Shoaib Akhtar, who will finally arrive in England today. Spokesman Khalid Butt said last night: "the Pakistan Cricket Board panel of doctors are satisfied that Shoaib can proceed to England. He will be leaving by the earliest flight available."

webTitle: Cricket: Shah goes off like the clappers

fields.headline: Shah goes off like the clappers
fields.trailText: Middlesex 225-5 Hampshire 200-8 Middlesex won by 25 runs
fields.body:
Middlesex 225-5 Hampshire 200-8 Middlesex won by 25 runs

Those who choose to spend a bitter Sunday watching B&H south division zonal matches pretty much know what they are going to get. Cold: yes. Tea: yes. A smug satisfaction at spending the day outside rather than loafing around watching Dawson's Creek: most definitely. They do not dare to fantasise about the tingle factor.

So the crowd here fell on their feet, albeit frozen ones. They came, they saw and they were treated to 142 minutes of unbuckled exhilaration and swagger from Owais Shah. He made an unbeaten 118 with nine fours and three sixes - including one huge sweep to take him to 99 - and powered Middlesex to an easy victory.

It was an innings that shone all the more because over the past year or so Shah has been pigeon-holed as an idle waster - talented but too cocky, all the strokes but don't-give-a-damn careless. It was quite a haul for a player who had been f ted almost since he picked up a bat. He made his county debut in 1995 aged 16 and led England to victory in the under-19 World Cup in 1997-98.

And in the late summer of 1999 he scored three centuries for Middlesex in just over a month. But since then there has been almost nothing. He averaged 24 in the championship last year, scored only three 50s in any cricket and by mid-July was dropped.

This innings showed what Middlesex have been missing. Shah does not look particularly gainly; he sticks his bottom out so far that his 6ft 1in frame seems squatter than it is and his feet sometimes look to be one step ahead of his brain.

But the speed of his bat through the air and his immaculate timing make every stroke look effortless. And he does not lack nous; he let Neil Johnson and John Stephenson know their places by dispatching the first balls of their spells to the boundary.

He walked off to a standing ovation from those in the pavilion wearing the type of beige mackintoshes favoured by TV detectives, as well as from the fluorescent anoraks in the grandstand. At some points one suspected they were clapping to keep body temperatures above zero. But not for Shah; his innings was special.

webTitle: Cricket: House is where the Sussex heart is

fields.headline: House is where the Sussex heart is
fields.trailText: Kent 175 Sussex 180-5 Sussex won by five wickets
fields.body:
Kent 175 Sussex 180-5 Sussex won by five wickets

Spike Milligan lives just up the road from here and for much of yesterday the suspicion lingered that Sussex and Kent were being captained by Eccles and Bluebottle. It was that sort of match.

On a flat pitch Kent could muster only 175 in this South Division Benson & Hedges Cup tie, and succeeded in being bowled out 10 balls short of their 50 overs. This should have been a doddle for Sussex, particularly when they were 134 for three in the 40th. But they allowed pressure to encroach.

With three overs to go they still needed 14 and Kent were contemplating victory. Then one Martin McCague over went for nine, with a two, a four and a wide coming from successive deliveries. It was all over.

Sussex can be excused for making a meal of it. They were without their two most experienced batsmen, Chris Adams and Tony Cottey. And if this platoon of virgin soldiers get through to the quarter-finals, which they certainly will if they beat Hampshire today, it will be a considerable achievement.

Yesterday's result gave particular pleasure to Will House, who played for Kent between 1997-99 and joined Sussex last year because of a lack of opportunity at Canterbury.

At Hove last season he played the sort of innings that will probably have him waking up in a cold sweat for the rest of his life. In a floodlit National League match against his old Kent muckers, Sussex needed five to win from the final over, with six wickets in hand; they lost by three runs. House blocked four deliveries before scrambling a single to return the strike to an in-form Michael Bevan. He swung the last delivery straight to deep midwicket.

Yesterday House scored only 35. But in the context of a low-scoring match it was a vital contribuion and along with Bas Zuiderent (42) he was responsible for raising the tempo after a ponderous start. Twice he hit Min Patel for six, first over midwicket and then straight.

The Dutchman Zuiderent is tall, clean-hitting and impressive. Yesterday it was a partnership of 61 in 13 overs between him and House that put Sussex in charge before both faltered. Zuiderent was run out by Matthew Walker's direct throw from point and House chopped a Mark Ealham delivery onto his stumps.

Robin Martin-Jenkins, an old hand in this company, saw Sussex home and swung David Masters for six over midwicket to win the match. Kent's batting had been awful, apart from Walker's tenacious 52; they lost their last six wickets for 51 runs. But on a slow pitch Mark Robinson bowled admirably for four for 29. No goon he.

At Hove last season he played the sort of innings that will probably have him waking up in a cold sweat for the rest of his life. In a floodlit National League match against his old Kent muckers, Sussex needed five to win from the final over, with six wickets in hand; they lost by three runs. House blocked four deliveries before scrambling a single to return the strike to an in-form Michael Bevan. He swung the last delivery straight to deep midwicket. Yesterday House scored only 35. But in the context of a low-scoring match it was a vital contribuion and along with Bas Zuiderent (42) he was responsible for raising the tempo after a ponderous start. Twice he hit Min Patel for six, first over midwicket and then straight. The Dutchman Zuiderent is tall, clean-hitting and impressive. Yesterday it was a partnership of 61 in 13 overs between him and House that put Sussex in charge before both faltered. Zuiderent was run out by Matthew Walker's direct throw from point and House chopped a Mark Ealham delivery onto his stumps. Robin Martin-Jenkins, an old hand in this company, saw Sussex home and swung David Masters for six over midwicket to win the match. Kent's batting had been awful, apart from Walker's tenacious 52; they lost their last six wickets for 51 runs. But on a slow pitch Mark Robinson bowled admirably for four for 29. No goon he.

webTitle: Cricket: Notts undone by old boy Dowman

fields.headline: Notts undone by old boy Dowman
fields.standfirst: Nottinghamshire 231-5 Derbyshire 233-4 Derbyshire won by six wickets
fields.trailText: Mathew Dowman was once hailed by Nottinghamshire's manager Clive Rice as a potential England batsman, but he made a surprising switch to Derbyshire after his dissatisfaction with the standard of Trent Bridge pitches hastened his release.
fields.body:
Mathew Dowman was once hailed by Nottinghamshire's manager Clive Rice as a potential England batsman, but he made a surprising switch to Derbyshire after his dissatisfaction with the standard of Trent Bridge pitches hastened his release.

That will have made Dowman's satisfaction all the sweeter yesterday as his 75 not out brought Derbyshire victory with four balls to spare in a Benson & Hedges Cup tie that they had seemed determined to throw away at the last.

The Nottinghamshire captain Darren Bicknell had manipulated his bowlers intelligently but the decision to leave the final over with the inexperienced Gareth Clough proved fatal as Dowman, with nine needed for victory, hoisted him for a leg-side six and a four off successive balls.

Bottom of the North Division overnight, Derbyshire's first victory had seemed assured with 80 needed from the last 15 overs and nine wickets intact. But Rob Bailey fell to a marvellous diving catch by Guy Welton at square leg and then Luke Sutton dallied 10 overs for 13. The run-rate required had risen to eight an over by the time Dominic Cork appeared and he fell for nought as he heaved at Greg Smith's inswinger and was bowled.

Nottinghamshire could have been forgiven for assuming that the target they had set was adequate, so flimsy has been Derbyshire's batting this season, but from 88 for one in the 22nd over, their ambitions might have stretched to a total of 250-plus.

Two neat stumpings by Karl Krikken deserved much of the recognition for Derbyshire's resistance. Richard Illingworth defeated Greg Blewett's sneaky leg-side push and Paul John son failed to launch Adrian Pierson over long-off, with Krikken on each occasion supporting the contention of Cork, his captain, that he has the quickest hands on the circuit.

Nottinghamshire's careworn approach in mid-innings also owed something to a mix-up between Bicknell and Usman Afzaal, who refused his captain's call for a single and bore his error heavily as illustrated by a sheepish raise of the bat to mark his half-century.

Kevin Pietersen's late flurry improved their prospects but Derbyshire's reply was surprisingly blissful, with both Bailey and Michael di Venuto in commanding form.

webTitle: Cricket: Cricket at the sharp end

fields.headline: Gloves off
fields.standfirst: Cricket at the sharp end
fields.trailText: Darren Lehmann, Yorkshire's overseas player from South Australia, played a very strong knock against us at Headingley the other day, but seems to have trouble counting to six.
fields.body:
Darren Lehmann, Yorkshire's overseas player from South Australia, played a very strong knock against us at Headingley the other day, but seems to have trouble counting to six.

All through his innings, he would ask the square leg umpire after four balls of every over, "How many balls left please?"

It's obviously a superstition or concentration thing, but we cottoned on to it and tried to disturb him by asking the umpires ourselves. In the end there would be three people asking them, and they'd find themselves saying "two" three times on the trot.

They're good blokes, the umpires. You build up a rapport with them over the years and I can't say there is a bad one on the circuit. I know a couple of our lads, Illy - friend of the stars (or at least the Minogues) - and Rob Bailey are looking to get into it when they finish playing.

Our efforts to put Lehmann off didn't work, anyway, because he won Yorkshire that game. The Benson & Hedges Cup is a funny competition coming so early in the season. If you get on a roll you're through, but we haven't and we're out.

It was a different story against Glamorgan in our first Sunday League game when we played really well as a team and Welchy, our new signing from Warwickshire, got a career-best five wickets - so he had to get the beers in.

I had a couple of ducks early in the week but I managed to hang around and towards the end I was starting to hit the ball a bit stronger. And I also had some good news from the Derbyshire committee this week - they have given me a benefit for next year after 15 years with the club.

I know the benefit system has been criticised, and it must be difficult for someone who has worked all their life and not got a jot. I could have gone to university but I wanted to make cricket my career. I realise I am very lucky to get a benefit like this next year, and I'd like to thank Derbyshire for that.

webTitle: Cricket: Flintoff sidelined by fresh injury

fields.headline: Flintoff sidelined by fresh injury
fields.standfirst: Yorkshire deliver the knock-out blow to Lancashire's hopes in Benson and Hedges Cup
fields.trailText: Yorkshire deliver the knock-out blow to Lancashire's hopes in Benson and Hedges Cup
fields.body:
Lancashire 170-9 Yorkshire 171-5 Yorkshire won by five wickets

Andy Flintoff will be absent for at least two weeks, and could be forced out of contention for England's triangular one-day series against Pakistan and Australia next month, after suffering a torn side muscle as Lancashire crashed out of this competition yesterday. His loss may also prove to be a substantial blow to Lancashire's championship hopes.

Flintoff should have been celebrating when he had Darren Lehmann, Yorkshire's Australian linchpin, caught at backward point to give his team a glimmer of hope in this North Division match. But as Bob Simpson, the Lancashire coach, explained, the 23-year-old, who remodelled his bowling action during the winter to ease the strain on his troublesome back, already had an inkling that his injury curse had struck again.

"He felt it with the ball that got Lehmann," said Simpson. "He's done a muscle and at this stage he will probably be out at least two weeks." England play Pakistan in the first game of the NatWest series on June 7.

Flintoff was always an outsider to take the vacant seventh batting place in England's team for the first Test against Pakistan at Lord's on Thursday week, especially as he has struggled so far this season, failing again yesterday. But he remained a regular in England's one-day team in Sri Lanka and Pakistan last winter even though his back problems prevented him from bowling.

With Flintoff back in the pavilion, Michael Lumb steered Yorkshire to victory with more than three overs to spare, maintaining their hopes of reaching the quarter-finals. Another win today against Durham at Headingley in the last round of group matches will probably be enough.

Lehmann took his second Gold Award of the week, as much for figures of 6-1-13-1, including the crucial wicket of John Crawley, as his typically belligerent 35 which included two fours and a straight six off Muttiah Muralitharan.

David Byas, who has suffered more than prospered in one-day games against Lancashire in his six years as Yorkshire's captain, also played a substantial part in this satisfying victory, steering his team to 135 for two in the 36th over with 55 from 107 balls until he was bowled by Joe Scuderi.

Lancashire's innings had illustrated how much they rely on Neil Fairbrother, who was again missing because of a hamstring injury. Crawley and Michael Atherton had established an excellent platform with a second-wicket stand of 110 in 30 overs, the England opener gliding to his second consecutive half-century from 81 balls with five boundaries out of the textbook.

But after he had fallen in unorthodox fashion, top-edging a waist-high full toss from Gary Fellows to Lehmann at long leg, Lancashire lost wickets regularly, and momentum completely. Crawley, who had reached a 90-ball 50 as he battles for early-season form, was bowled trying to cut Lehmann's arm ball in the next over, and Flintoff scratched around for 10 overs without hitting a boundary before lofting the first ball of Ryan Sidebottom's second spell to long off.

Sidebottom had already combined with Craig White, who bowled his 10 overs straight through and tidily enough, to put the squeeze on Atherton and Crawley, and rivalled Lehmann as the pick of the Yorkshire attack. But Chris Silverwood claimed the best figures, adding two late wickets to his early dismissal of Chilton to end with three for 30.

Darren Gough, who like White was making his first appearance of the season, eased back with one for 33 from nine uneventful overs. "Once again our batting has let us down," lamented Simpson. "At two for 120 you should be looking at a comfortable 220."

webTitle: Baby killed in Israeli reprisal attack

fields.headline: Baby killed in Israeli reprisal attack
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli troops shelled a Palestinian refugee camp today in response to mortar fire on Jewish settlements, killing a four-month-old baby girl and wounding 24 Palestinians.
fields.body:
Israeli troops shelled a Palestinian refugee camp today in response to mortar fire on Jewish settlements, killing a four-month-old baby girl and wounding 24 Palestinians.

Palestinian doctors said 10 children were among the injured.

The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, expressed regret, saying that Israeli troops did not intend to harm children.

In a speech to parliament after the attack, Mr Sharon accused the Palestinian Authority of active involvement in attacks on Israelis and weapons smuggling and said he would not resume peace talks under fire.

In the West Bank, Israeli troops briefly entered two Palestinian towns in pursuit of gunmen - part of a new policy that gives field commanders the authority to decide on such forays on the spot, without waiting for government approval.

The Palestinians consider such forays a major violation of interim peace accords. The United States has sharply criticised the incursions.

Today's fighting began when Palestinians fired four mortar shells at two Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip, without causing injuries.

In response, Israeli tanks shelled buildings in the Khan Yunis refugee camp and troops fired large calibre machine guns.

One shell hit the shack of the Hijo family in the camp, instantly killing four-month-old Iman Hijo, with shrapnel tearing an orange-sized hole into the infant's back.

The girl's 19-year-old mother and three other children belonging to the extended family were wounded. One of the children,18-month-old Mahmoud, was in intensive care at Nasser hospital with extensive shrapnel wounds, doctors said.

In the emergency room, four children were treated, including the baby's seven-year-old aunt, Dunya, who sat on a bed with a dazed look on her face, her frilly white-and-green dress pulled up above scraped and bandaged legs. "They killed the baby," Dunya said, then burst into tears. The Israeli army confirmed the shelling, but said it had no details on damages and injuries. Mr Sharon said that "children and babies should not be involved in this terrible war that we would like one day to finish."

Meanwhile in the West Bank town of Bethlehem, about 2,000 Palestinians buried Mohammed Abayad, a militiaman killed yesterday in an Israeli army raid of the nearby community of Beit Jalla.

Monday's deaths brought to 436 the number of Palestinians killed since the latest wave of violence began in late September. Seventy-two Israelis have been killed.

Amid the latest fighting, Israeli and Palestinian officials gave mixed reviews of the US-led Mitchell Commission, which issued its draft findings on the causes of the violence.

Israeli cabinet minister Danny Naveh said the report's call for a halt to construction at Jewish settlements conflicted with peace accords that state the fate of the communities will be worked out in a final agreement.

Palestinian information minister Yasser Abed Rabbo said the Palestinians "accept the findings... in as much as they point directly to Israel's continued occupation of Palestinian land."

But the report did not support the Palestinian call for an international force, which Abed Rabbo described as one of several "oversights."

webTitle: US resumes reconnaissance over China

fields.headline: US resumes reconnaissance over China
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: An air force plane today flew the first US reconnaissance flight off China's coast since the April 1 collision between a Navy spy plane and a Chinese fighter jet.
fields.body:
An air force plane today flew the first US reconnaissance flight off China's coast since the April 1 collision between a Navy spy plane and a Chinese fighter jet.

A US defence official confirmed that the RC-135 reconnaissance plane, flying from Kadena air base on the Japanese island of Okinawa, flew a routine track along the northern portion of China's coastline.

The unarmed plane, which is used routinely for surveillance flights off China's coast, drew no response from the Chinese military and returned safely to base, the official said.

The Bush administration has previously stated its commitment to resuming surveillance flights off China's coast, but today's flight was the first since last month's incident over the South China sea.

The pilot of the Chinese jet was lost in the collision and the 24 crew members of the EP-3E were held by on Hainan for 11 days.

The US plane was badly damaged in the incident and officials say the Chinese likely harvested valuable intelligence from the craft, although the crew apparently managed to destroy the most sensitive information.

Defence secretary Donald H Rumsfeld yesterday said that he believed China would allow the United States to get the EP-3E back, and he said it appeared that the plane could be repaired sufficiently on Hainan to fly it out. "We'll know later this week," he told NBC.

A US defence official today said the Lockheed Martin technicians who inspected the plane last week determined that it could be repaired, but that it probably would take several days.

President Bush is expected to make the final decision on whether to press China for permission to repair it. An alternative would be to partially disassemble the plane and ship it out.

National security adviser Condoleezza Rice said yesterday that the president believed a "productive and fruitful relationship with China; is possible."

But she added: "Clearly, the way that the Chinese handle the fact that we have a plane on the ground will have an effect on how we see US-China relations."

China last week criticised Bush's proposal for a national missile defence program, insisting it could spark a new arms race.

Bush said the United States would work with its allies and seek to protect them as well from ballistic missile attacks from rogue nations.

Prominent Democrats yesterday said such a program could be seen as a violation of the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.

Senate minority leader Tom Daschle said: "I think that's another major concern, and then obviously losing our relationship with our allies and fracturing the very fragile relationship with China are also issues we've got to be very concerned about. "

But Rice said the treaty, "belongs to another era, when we had an implacably hostile relationship with the Soviet Union."
