webTitle: Straw reveals plans to get tough on repeat offenders

fields.headline: Straw reveals plans to get tough on repeat offenders
fields.standfirst:
Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: A "totting up" system under which persistent offenders will face more severe penalties for a wide range of minor crimes is expected to form part of a package of measures to be unveiled tomorrow as the launch pad for Labour's campaign for a second term.
fields.body:
A "totting up" system under which persistent offenders will face more severe penalties for a wide range of minor crimes is expected to form part of a package of measures to be unveiled tomorrow as the launch pad for Labour's campaign for a second term.

The package is the outcome a year-long review of sentencing policy. It will sound the death knell of the liberal philosophy behind the 1991 criminal justice act of making the "punishment fit the crime" and which was introduced to keep down prison numbers.

Mr Straw will show he is prepared to drive up the 68,000 prison population when he announces to the Commons new sentencing powers to tackle the hard core of about 100,000 persistent offenders who are said to be responsible for half of all recorded crime.

He will tell MPs that it is not good enough that there is no guarantee at present that a persistent offender will receive a more severe penalty when he appears before court for the fifth time than on his second appearance. He believes the focus of judges and magistrates on the specific offence for which the offender is before the court is "too narrow" and should reflect the needs of crime reduction and reparation as well as punishment.

Currently, persistent offend ers with 10 or more previous convictions still have a one in three chance of being given a community sentence when they next come before the court. Some 80% of persistent offenders are reconvicted within two years of leaving prison.

Mr Straw believes that such offenders should not be able to continually flout the law: "Persistent offenders need to know that if they persist in their crimes they will receive increasingly severe punishment," the home secretary told the Justice Clerks' Society in a speech trailing this week's announcements.

The sentencing shake-up is the result of a review under the chairmanship of John Halliday, a senior Home Office civil servant. Among changes expected to be announced are:

 A "totting up" system for a wide range of minor offences similar to the current penalty points system for motorists under which they lose automatically lose their driving licence once they hit a specified number of points. The review promises "a different and more sophisticated system" but one which will ensure that persistent offenders with recent and relevant previous convictions will face increasingly severe punishments which they will be able to predict.

This reform will be linked to proposals later in the year to deal with an extra 500,000 mi nor offences each year by fixed penalty fines to free up the time of the courts for more serious crimes.

 A "custody plus" system for the 44,000 prisoners a year who serve sentences of 12 months or less who are currently automatically released halfway through their sentences. webTitle: Gore Vidal accepts McVeigh invite to execution

fields.headline: Gore Vidal accepts McVeigh invite to execution
fields.trailText: Relatives of the victims of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing reacted with outrage yesterday to news that the novelist Gore Vidal has been given permission to attend the execution next week of the convicted bomber Timothy McVeigh.
fields.body:
Relatives of the victims of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing reacted with outrage yesterday to news that the novelist Gore Vidal has been given permission to attend the execution next week of the convicted bomber Timothy McVeigh.

Vidal was invited by McVeigh as a "friend" to watch him die by lethal injection at a federal prison in Terre Haute, Indiana, on May 16. The "fanatically anti-death penalty" author intends to write an article about it for Vanity Fair magazine.

The decision has been denounced by relatives of some of the 168 people who died.

A media circus already surrounds the execution. Six US networks are squabbling over which of them will get the two witness seats allocated to national television. A decision to show the execution to the relatives of victims on closed circuit television has raised fears that hackers will capture the pictures to show on the internet.

McVeigh, who has said he has no regrets about carrying out the bombing and regards himself as a martyr for the cause of American freedom, is entitled to choose six witnesses to the execution.

Vidal said yesterday that he had begun corresponding with McVeigh in 1998 after the bomber wrote to him about an article in which Vidal said the FBI's actions in breaking the sieges at Waco and Ruby Ridge in the early 90s had shredded the US bill of rights.

McVeigh has said he bombed the Alfred P Murrah Federal Building on the second anniversary of Waco as revenge. He described his victims as "collateral damage".

"The boy has a sense of justice," Vidal said at the weekend. "That's what attracted me to him. We've exchanged several letters. He's very intelligent. He's not insane."

webTitle: Hague to unveil 'blue belt' conservation plan

fields.headline: Hague to unveil 'blue belt' conservation plan
fields.standfirst:
Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: William Hague will today unveil a Conservative "blue belt" strategy to protect Britain's rivers, wetlands and coastline from the intrusive building threats which the historic green belt policy has held at bay in the countryside for 50 years.
fields.body:
William Hague will today unveil a Conservative "blue belt" strategy to protect Britain's rivers, wetlands and coastline from the intrusive building threats which the historic green belt policy has held at bay in the countryside for 50 years.

The Tory leader will couple the blue belt scheme with other more eye-catching policies when he announces the Tory manifesto for the local elections on June 7 - knowing they will be swamped within 24 hours by confirmation of a general election the same day.

Despite the gloom which engulfs Tory MPs across the ideolgical spectrum about their party's prospects, Conserva tive central office points to steady gains in council byelections as proof that a surprise may be in store, locally and nationally. They hope to gain 500-plus council seats out of the 2,476 up for election on June 7.

Blue belt areas would allow local councils to restrict development on river or canal banks, wetlands or coastal areas and let local people determine the rate of housing development in their local area.

 Tory MP Andrew Tyrie will tomorrow seek an emergency Commons statement on Tony Blair's private meeting with the Hinduja brothers at Downing Street in June 1998, when the Indian multi-millionaires lobbied him to soften US hostility to renewed nuclear testing by Delhi.

webTitle: Blair fears stayaway voters

fields.headline: Blair fears stayaway voters
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today urge his cabinet colleagues to turn the June 7 election campaign into a crusade to revitalise public faith in the role of the state - and to reverse the slide into apathy which threatens to undermine the legitimacy of a re-elected Labour government.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today urge his cabinet colleagues to turn the June 7 election campaign into a crusade to revitalise public faith in the role of the state - and to reverse the slide into apathy which threatens to undermine the legitimacy of a re-elected Labour government.

On his 48th birthday yesterday, Mr Blair confirmed that a special cabinet meeting will be held this afternoon. It will formally ratify Labour's manifesto and hear him say that ministers must fight as if this election is on a knife edge.

The more likely possibility - that Labour could win by another landslide - is unmentionable option in both major party HQs. Far from rejoicing at William Hague's prospective meltdown, No 10 is fearful that an abysmal turnout coupled with a second Tory collapse would drag the political system down with it.

Labour stalwarts like Roy Hattersley are openly warning that "the near extinction of Her Majesty's opposition would be bad for Britain and for Labour". It is a view privately shared by some senior ministers.

Mr Blair has been desperately seeking a campaign formula that will engage the imagination of a sceptical electorate by winning the big arguments on public services.

Voters now appear satisfied that Labour can safely manage the economy, so Mr Blair wants to persuade them that the future of their schools, hospitals and public transport is at stake - and prevent a widely predicted turnout of below 70%.

This apathy could be Mr Hague's best hope, if he can mobilise the Tories' 30%-plus core vote. Yesterday the party chairman, Michael Ancram, said that the key to victory is 3,000 swing votes in 180 marginals. "I am going into this election looking at only one possibility, and that's going to win it," he told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost.

Labour is using similar tactics. A magazine version of its manifesto is being sent to a million targeted voters in marginals - including some who voted Tory in 1997.

Mr Blair is aware that the election, already postponed because of the foot and mouth crisis, is not widely welcomed. However, he blames this on media cynicism and "the soundbite world" rather than timidity or the shortcomings of Labour's four years in power.

"We want to enthuse people," a senior adviser said last night. Peter Mandelson, who remains an insider despite his return to the backbenches, made a similar appeal for a "compelling vision" in the Observer. "Britain needs more than competence from its government," he wrote.

Mr Blair also intends to reject a "play safe" campaign, aides insist, though the evidence so far remains slender.

On his travels he will meet as many people as he can, given the present security conditions, a calculation made harder by the bomb in north London yesterday.

Labour's manifesto will include a renewed version of the five pledges on the economy, the NHS, crime, jobs and education which have caused grief to ministers since they were made in 1997. However, the 2001 version may be less specific. "We're damned if we have pledges and damned if we don't," a cabinet minister admitted.

Mr Blair will try to "rebuild public faith in the public services" and warn that the Hague-ite right "is always there to move in and dismantle them" if Labour's investment-and-reform package fails.

But the uphill task he faces was underlined yesterday by outbursts of candour from two Westminster heavyweights which both he and Mr Hague could have done without.

The former Tory prime minister, Sir Edward Heath, said his party might lose the 2005 election as well, while Labour's ex-deputy leader Lord Hattersley warned that if Labour wins another landslide, "democracy in Britain will be suspended for almost a full decade".

Privately some senior ministers agree. One said: "I don't want a bigger majority, it's probably too big now. We need an effective opposition. I lived through the 80s when the Tories had huge majorities and the government suffered as a consequence."

Internal Conservative polling, leaked yesterday, suggests both sides know a Labour landslide is a real option. According to the latest ICM poll for the Guardian, Labour is ahead by 47% to 33% with the Lib Dems on 14%.

webTitle: Hague launches Tory local election manifesto

fields.headline: Hague launches Tory local election manifesto
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Conservatives
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader, William Hague, today accused the Labour government of being "all spin and no delivery" and said his party is ready to win the local elections on June 7.
fields.body:
The Conservative leader, William Hague, today accused the Labour government of being "all spin and no delivery" and said his party is ready to win the local elections on June 7.

Setting out his party's local government manifesto, Mr Hague accused Labour of masterminding a 31% increase in "stealth" council taxes and of using local government as a tool to push through a central government agenda rather than taking the views of local people into account.

Mr Hague said: "It makes no difference where Labour is given the chance to govern, the story is the same: higher taxes for those who can least afford them and poorer services for those who need them."

He promised to give parents and teachers greater control of schools, local councils greater powers to evict "neighbours from hell" and local communities lower council tax burdens.

He said that within weeks of taking office, the Conservatives would abolish Labour's centrally planned homebuilding agenda, giving local people the power to decide how many new homes should be built and where they should be put.

The Conservatives also pledged to introduce doorstep recycling for all households, to renovate rundown council housing and to give councils new resources to remove litter, graffiti and abandoned cars.

Mr Hague, who knows he will be facing a general election announcement within days, took the opportunity to point out Conservative successes in recent local elections. The party hopes to add over 500 council seats out of the 2,476 possible.

The party also released its election theme music today, an instrumental composition called "Heartlands" written for the party by Michael Batt, the man behind The Wombles' theme tune, Remember You're a Womble.

webTitle: Roma breathe again

fields.headline: Roma breathe again
fields.trailText: Roma emerged from their second bout of hyperventilation in eight days looking as healthy as ever. After recovering from 2-0 down to Juventus with 11 minutes to go at the Stadio Delle Alpi on Sunday to gain a 2-2 draw, they lead Serie A by five points with five games to go.
fields.body:
Roma emerged from their second bout of hyperventilation in eight days looking as healthy as ever. After recovering from 2-0 down to Juventus with 11 minutes to go at the Stadio Delle Alpi on Sunday to gain a 2-2 draw, they lead Serie A by five points with five games to go.

After Alessandro Delvecchio and Zinedine Zidane had given Juventus what should have been a decisive lead, Hidetoshi Nakata rescued a point - and possibly the scudetto - with two fierce drives in the last 11 minutes. Edwin van der Sar was beaten by the first - from 30 yards out - and could only parry the second into the path of Vincenzo Montella, who knocked in the equaliser with seconds to go.

"I just followed in instinctively," said Montella, who had replaced Marco Delvecchio at the break. "I hope that turns out to be the most important goal of my career."

As Lazio beat Bari 2-0 with two goals from Juan Veron, Juve dropped to third - six points behind Roma.

"Roma had two shots on goal and they scored twice," the Juventus coach Carlo Ancelotti claimed. "Mistakes happen in a match but I think we paid too dear a price tonight."

Roma's coach Fabio Capello was left looking like a genius after goals from two of his substitutes.

"Nobody in this team is untouchable," he said, explaining his decision to take off his captain, Francesco Totti. "That helps to make my decisions much easier."

Three of Roma's remaining five games are at home, but they are all against teams who are still attempting to qualify for European competition - Atalanta, Milan and Parma.

"This point has the value of a victory," Montella said, "but nothing is decided yet."

Parma kept up their distant pursuit of the top three - and their bid for Italy's fourth Champions League place - with a 4-0 win over Napoli. There were two goals for Marco Di Vaio and one for Savo Milosevic. Milan lost 2-1 at Perugia, for whom the Greek striker Zisis Vryas scored twice, and lost fifth place to Internazionale, who beat Atalanta 3-0 with the help of two early goals from Christian Vieri.

Vicenza put some distance between them and the bottom four with a 2-1 win over their fellow relegation strugglers Reggina. Both their goals were scored by a defender, Marco Zanchi.

Vicenza lead fourth from last Napoli by three points. Verona are a further point back after their 2-1 win over Fiorentina.

Andriy Shevchenko scored a penalty for Milan to give him 21 league goals for the season, the best in Serie A. But Roberto Baggio performed the scoring feat of the weekend with a hat-trick in Brescia's 3-0 win at Lecce.

webTitle: Macedonia renews assault on Albanian insurgents

fields.headline: Macedonia renews assault on Albanian insurgents
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Using artillery and tanks, Macedonian military and police forces restarted their offensive against ethnic Albanian rebels this morning, prompting fears among international officials that Macedonia is descending into the next Balkan conflict.
fields.body:
Using artillery and tanks, Macedonian military and police forces restarted their offensive against ethnic Albanian rebels this morning, prompting fears among international officials that Macedonia is descending into the next Balkan conflict.

A Macedonian military spokesman said today that the army is engaged in "clean and sweep operations" near the northern city of Kumanovo.

Late yesterday, Albanian insurgents opened fire on a Macedonian army patrol in the nearby village of Lojane. The army returned fire and "neutralised" the rebels, said the spokesman.

He couldn't say whether there had been casualties among the Albanians. No government soldiers were injured in the attack.

The new fighting underlined the government's increasingly tenuous control of areas near the border with the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

European Union officials have urged Macedonia not to declare a state of war, sending their top diplomatic envoy to push for an end to the fighting.

Javier Solana, the EU's security affairs chief, was to ask the Macedonian prime minister, Ljbuco Georgievski, to work harder at creating peace with ethnic Albanian rebels, who insist they are denied equal rights under the country's constitution.

Yesterday, Macedonian forces lobbed shells into villages seized by rebels north-east of the capital, Skopje, pounding militant strongholds just hours after the expiration of a deadline set for civilians to evacuate.

The government claimed the rebels were holding hundreds of civilians as human shields.

A delegation from the International Committee of the Red Cross visited the villages of Vaksince and Slupcane yesterday to assess the conditions of civilians there, spokeswoman Annick Bouvier said today. About 2,000 civilians, including women and children, have been huddled in basements for four days.

"The situation is very confusing," she said. "We could feel a sense of solidarity. They don't want to be excluded from their relatives. But we can't exclude the possibility that they're being held against their will."

The organisation evacuated 13 people, including two pregnant women and two children, Ms Bouvier said.

The push by Macedonian forces on the ground follows a pledge by Macedonia's prime minister to pressure parliament to declare a state of war - a move designed to give the government a freer hand in attacks against militants hunkered down near the border with Kosovo.

"The integrity of our country is threatened," government spokesman Antonio Milososki said at a news conference yesterday, only a few miles from the site of recent attacks.

Bolstering his claims, rebels opened fire on soldiers near the country's second largest city, Tetovo, the site of clashes and a massive government offensive in March. No injuries were reported.

The push by Macedonian forces on the ground follows a pledge by Macedonia's prime minister to pressure parliament to declare a state of war - a move designed to give the government a freer hand in attacks against militants hunkered down near the border with Kosovo. webTitle: Comment: Political debate

fields.headline: Playing by boys' rules
fields.standfirst:
Political debate is all about conflict and argument. No wonder many of us just don't want to know
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Political debate is all about conflict and argument. No wonder many of us just don't want to know
fields.body:
Two days to go. The politicos are on the starting line, quivering with expectation for the long-awaited starting gun. The eerie pre-election campaign can finally be replaced by the real thing. Instead of smoking pyres of animals on the news every night, we'll get politicians hopping in and out of helicopters. Yet the prospect of an election campaign fills me with gloom. And it's not just me.

Outside the intense, self-referential world of Westminster, it's hard to find evidence of interest, let alone burning enthusiasm, for this election. Indeed, this will be a curious non-election - because the single biggest and by far the most compelling debate is about why so many people have gone off politics. Given that a Labour victory is a dead cert, the most interesting figure on polling day will be the turnout and, in particular, how many under 25 bother to vote. The predictions are grim: perhaps a third won't vote, and the figure could be much higher among younger age groups. A 1998 survey found that 71% of 16- to 21-year-olds thought that how you voted made little difference. The turnout will be only a rough guide to the levels of frustration, as many more will vote but with no sense of conviction and little interest.

Already, this issue has become the centrepiece of this election as we plunge into a sense of crisis about the health of our democracy - its institutions, our civic responsibilities (or lack of) and the national political culture. Take, for example, Channel 4, which is boldly launching its election coverage with a series titled The End of Politics. This raises the obvious query as to what election coverage there can be if politics is finished.

There's no shortage of excellent theories as to the causes of our low political morale. There's the "corporations wield power, not governments" theme as expounded by Naomi Klein, George Monbiot and now Noreena Hertz, who is to present The End of Politics series. Colin Crouch makes an interesting argument in a Fabian Society pamphlet that the aberration is not our current lack of interest but the unusual civic-mindedness of the postwar generations - now we are just reverting to type. Or, there's the more straightforward explanation that there's not much of a choice at this election, given the shambolic state of the Tories.

Here's another explanation: that the aggressive argumentativeness that now characterises political debate intensely irritates a sizeable section of the population, particularly women and those under 25. It amounts to a kind of polarised squabbling that leads droves of us to conclude "a plague on all their houses" and switch off.

This phenomenon of Anglo-Saxon political culture is analysed brilliantly by Deborah Tannen in The Argument Culture. An American socio-linguist, she made her name studying the different ways men and women communicate, and now turns the same skills of analysing how language moulds (and reflects) our attitudes to public debate. Her conclusion is that the dominant metaphors are about aggression and competition: "It is a pervasive warlike atmosphere that makes us approach public dialogue and just about anything we need to accomplish as if it were a fight."

Effective political participation requires an "adversarial frame of mind" so, for example, the "best way to show you're really thinking is to criticise" and "all intellectual inquiry is a game of attack, counterattack and self-defence". Our perception of politics is frozen into a false dualism as we unquestioningly accept such assumptions as "there are two sides to every question" (why always just two?) and that the best way to explore an idea is to get people together who completely disagree with each other. As Tannen succinctly points out, "smashing heads together does not open minds".

If you like watching heads being smashed, you turn to boxing or The Weakest Link, not Newsnight. As Tannen concludes, "when a certain type of interaction is the norm, those who feel comfortable with that type of interaction are drawn to participate and those who do not feel comfortable with it recoil and go elsewhere". The recoil factor is affecting the under-25s and women.

How can a generation reared on tolerance as its most strongly held principle participate in the argument culture? If you believe that "everyone is entitled to their own opinion", or in an even more relativistic position such as everyone's opinion is equally valid and there's no such thing as objective truth, then what's the point of arguing? At best, it seems a pointless exercise; at worst, it's positively offensive - it smacks of a one-upmanship and an old-fashioned impulse to establish a pecking order.

This tolerance ethic is often parcelled up with a powerful impulse to connect with people. In place of models of civic solidarity, we have an emotional solidarity - a democratic friendliness. We may not believe in the same things but we can feel the same things. The 18-year-olds who would have been on demos in the 70s (thriving on a culture of political confrontation), now have an army of friends with whom they are in virtually 24/7 contact, through text messaging, email or phone. It's the phenomenon that has given us up-speak, the intonation that requires the listener to provide constant encouragement; conversation becomes a collaboration rather an exchange, and certainly not a confrontation.

The model is the sort of fun-loving amiability typified by Jamie Oliver. This emotional solidarity is partly an Americanisation, partly feminisation (yet another contemporary trend that, as the US writer Thomas Frank points out, is a legacy of the 60s). This ethic of tolerance clashes with English political culture that appears stuck in a time warp, using the style and format of attack and defence of the English public school abetted by an aggressive media culture.

The second consequence of the recoil factor is that the spectacle of "smashing heads" not only puts people off following politics, it puts them off participating. Tannen breathes new life into the familiar feminist debate that women's political style is different. Everyone argued that Thatcher scotched that theory, but she simply proved what any office demonstrates: that some women are happy playing by the boys' rules, just as some boys hate it. The general and extraordinarily persistent rule is that women are not as comfortable with public speaking, let alone public confrontation.

Tannen's observations of children demonstrated how boys fought, physically and verbally, while girls negotiated and manipulated but avoided open conflict. Both preferred to play with their own sex, and when girls and boys played together, the girls were often furious at the aggression of the boys.

Until you have a critical mass of women participating in and reporting on politics, you won't know whether there is another way to discuss ideas. And, as this election is likely to see the first drop in the number of women MPs in decades, such a possibility is as remote as ever. Meanwhile, the gap between an adversarial political elite and how, increasingly, people prefer to negotiate conflict will yawn wider and wider.

webTitle: SOS for Canada's H20

fields.headline: SOS for Canada's H20
fields.standfirst: As a spate of fatal contamination cases show, Canada's abundant fresh water supplies are being mistreated, says Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: As a spate of fatal contamination cases show, Canada's abundant fresh water supplies are being mistreated, says Anne McIlroy.
fields.body:
Canadians have always taken clean drinking water for granted, but the second outbreak of a deadly waterborne disease within a year has experts calling for an overhaul of the system and ordinary citizens wondering if a drink from the kitchen faucet could kill them.

Three people are dead after an outbreak of the intestinal parasite cryptosporidium in North Battleford, Saskatchewan, where the sewage is dumped into the river upstream of the water filtration plant. The parasite lives in the intestines of humans and animals and is deadly mostly to those with weakened immune systems.

Hundreds may have been infected, and have reported to hospital with cramps, diarrhoea and flu-like symptoms. Last summer, seven people died in Walkerton, Ontario, after a lethal form of the bacteria E Coli invaded the town's water system. Thousands were made seriously ill.

Walkertown was a political scandal that made headlines for weeks after it was revealed that municipal officials ignored warnings of danger and doctored safety reports. In North Battleford, it appears the municipal officials checked water days after learning there was a problem.

Standards vary from province to province, but environmentalists say they are generally far too lax. In Ontario, for example, an industrial solvent called trichloroethylene has been detected at levels that would not be permitted in the United States.

That has environmentalists in towns and cities across the country calling for urgent action by the federal government, including a review of the patchwork system now in place and the establishment of national standards. Clean water has become a hot political issue.

"There is a dramatic need for a new federal water policy," said Paul Muldoon, executive director of the Canadian environmental defence fund.

Canada has 9% of the world's fresh water, and that abundance has led to complacency. Increasingly intensive livestock farming has led to more runoff into streams and groundwater. Farmers are permitted to spread human sewage on their fields. Wetlands that naturally filter water are being destroyed to make way for new roads, housing and commercial developments.

The problem of contaminated drinking water is nationwide, with dozens of communities at any one time being ordered by local officials to boil water before drinking. In Ontario, Canada's richest and most populous province, a review recently found that half of the water treatment plants don't meet provincial standards.

The poorest Canadians have the most dangerous water. One in five aboriginal communities have water that may be unsafe. Outbreaks of gastrointestinal disorders are common on reserves, which all too often have no running water or sewage treatment.

In one native reserve in Quebec, pets had to be given bottled water because the local stuff was too dangerous even for them.

Matthew Coon Come, the elected chief of Canada's natives, says that newborns and the elderly regularly die on reserves because of waterborne diseases. "These deaths don't make the front pages of Canadian newspapers," he says.

webTitle: Brown's 'hands off' warning to Brussels

fields.headline: Brown's 'hands off' warning to Brussels
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will today deliver a strong warning to the European Commission to stop meddling in the handling of the British economy, quashing any hopes of UK supporters of the single currency that Labour would adopt a strong pro-European line in the election.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today deliver a strong warning to the European Commission to stop meddling in the handling of the British economy, quashing any hopes of UK supporters of the single currency that Labour would adopt a strong pro-European line in the election.

The chancellor intends to tell Brussels it has "no business" making recommendations concerning the level of taxes and spending in the UK.

Mr Brown's aides said he was "angry" at criticisms of his fiscal policy in the broad guidelines for economic policy issued by the commission 10 days ago, and would use today's meeting of European Union economic and finance ministers (Ecofin) to express "serious concerns" about the approach taken by Brussels to macro-economic policies.

They denied the chancellor had "picked a fight" with Europe for reasons of domestic politics, saying"real points of substance" were at stake, and the commission had made "a serious error of judgment".

To the anger of pro-single currency cabinet ministers, Mr Brown is insisting the government concentrate on domestic issues during the election, and his determination to push Europe to the sidelines has been strengthened by the weakness of theeuro and the performance of the European Central Bank (ECB).

A report today from Oxford Economic Forecasting predicts bringing Britain's 2.5% inflation target in line with the 2% in the rest of Europe would cost£11bn in lost output and 50,000 jobs. Treasury sources said the prime minister was aware of the line Mr Brown would take during his brief visit ahead of this afternoon's cabinet meeting. The chancellor was said to be particularly irritated by the commission's findings, because they chime with the Conservatives, who also argue Labour's proposals for spending and borrowing may be financially imprudent.

The commission said the government's plan for the public finances to go into the red in coming years to fund capital spending on the nation's infrastructure was inconsistent with Europe's stability and growth pact, designed to prevent countries from running lax fiscal policies. In addition, officials in Brussels said public spending in the UK should not rise above the 37.3% planned by Mr Brown for 2002-3.

Mr Brown, who last week voiced concern at the ECB's failure to join the worldwide move to lower interest rates, intends to tell Ecofin the commission needs a more sophisticated approach. He will say that the Treasury's golden rule - allowing borrowing only for investment in the infrastrcture - is consistent with the stability pact.

Britain's debt is the EU's lowest apart from Luxembourg and Ireland, he will say: "Member states whose underlying public finances are sound should not be discouraged from increasing investment in public infrastructure where there is a clear need to do so."

He was said to be angrier at the 37.3% formula. The commission "has no business making recommendations concerning the level of public spending in individual member states. For a given deficit level, the balance between tax and public spending is entirely a matter for elected national governments."

Suggesting Britain had been targeted for its refusal to join the single currency, the chancellor will say the 37.3% ceiling is "arbitary" and"it is not clear why the UK and Denmark [which rejected monetary union in a referendum last year] have been singled out".

webTitle: Dot.coms and the porn industry

fields.headline: Pulling the porn
fields.standfirst:
Dot.coms may be collapsing but there's still one sure-fire winner on the internet - sex. So why are companies opting out of 'adult products'? Amy Vickers reports

More internet news
fields.trailText: Dot.coms may be collapsing but there's still one sure-fire winner on the internet - sex. So why are companies opting out of 'adult products'? Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
It is not easy to make money from the internet. It's even more difficult for an internet business to make a profit - unless, that is, you are in the porn business. The news last week that unseated dot.com employees were falling over themselves to get jobs in the porn industry was more than just a sign of the times. Disillusioned dot.commers, hacked off with constantly being bounced around from one failed outfit to the next, reasoned that the only fail-safe solution was pornography.

It wasn't such a big surprise. Porn is one of the few profitable industries on the internet, and "sex" has long been the most popular online search term, closely followed by "porn", "nude", "XXX", "Playboy" and "erotic stories".

While the rest of the net is reeling from crumbling ad revenues, the sex industry has not even taken a hit because its main revenue stream is subscriptions, not advertising. It's that old adage again: Sex always sells. No amount of economic downturn will affect this phenomenally successful industry that is becoming increasingly acceptable, especially among young professionals.

Yet companies such as Yahoo! are opting out of the porn industry. Given the demand, the big business and the job security,this seems like a mad decision. Why?

It all boils down to a public outcry, and a feeling that one of the biggest and arguably one of the most influential internet companies in the world shouldn't be dealing in the business of porn. Despite the fact that Yahoo! has sold X-rated products for more than two years, when the Los Angeles Times ran a piece suggesting it was expanding its collection a month ago, a huge debate ensued. A few days later, Yahoo! backed down and said it would cease selling adult products, stop accepting banner ads from porn sites, cut out classifieds and auction adult-type items, and pledged it would clamp down on sex-related message boards and clubs. The misconception, however, is that it will outlaw porn on its site, which it insists is not the case. A search still throws up 671 sites for "porn" and if Yahoo! users want to buy porn videos, they are redirected to an external site.

To make the changes Yahoo! is currently introducing what has been described as "pretty extensive filtering software" but teething problems are expected. The reduction of porn on Yahoo.com won't spell the death of Yahoo!, but it could derail its profit projections. Despite the new porn exclusion software, though, the company is still making its mind up. Last week, faced with a barrage of criticism from web users, it came back and said no decisions had been taken on whether the changes to its adult porn section would be permanent. "It's the internet, so lots of things are possible," said Yahoo! spokesman Jackson Holtz, insisting it was just a re-evaluation of adult content across the network.

Clearly, Yahoo! is playing it by ear. It doesn't want to alienate users or conservative forces, nor does it want to rule out forever a guaranteed moneyspinner. Yahoo! has been put in a glaringly uncomfortable spotlight. It has now publicly back-peddled on a plan to expand its adult materials and caused a flap among other big internet portals, concerned about public approval. Terra Lycos, which operates a number of Lycos portals around the world, has now chipped in and announced it is re-evaluating its own porn policy, while MSN has reaffirmed that it has a strict policy on porn.

Of all the bigger players in the portal market, AltaVista is one of the few that seems to offer no-holds-barred access to pornographic material. A quick search using the term "porn" brings up an array of hardcore images, video clips and links to sites that are advertised using very explicit language.

MSN has already gone the whole hog and removed any evidence of adult-related merchandise. It moderates chatrooms and has a tough policy on links to porn. In fact, after entering the term "porn" in the search engine, the user is immediately warned: "You have entered a search term that is likely to return adult content." There are no adult videos to be found on the site, but if users want that kind of material, they are sent out of MSN confines into the unrestrained web where technically they are no longer the responsibility of MSN.

Therein lies the great irony. A significant proportion of web users want access to porn and to this end will locate porn and buy it, with or without the help of Yahoo!. Censorship of this kind doesn't work. If Yahoo!, the second biggest website in the world, doesn't take a piece of this action, it will lose out. Pundits and users alike believe Yahoo! has got itself into unnecessarily uncomfortable territory because of its willingness to purge itself of adult materials, instead of forcing families to install filter software on their computers.

Yahoo! members spoke out last week, saying they felt betrayed and were planning to petition the portal after it quietly reconfigured its adult-themed clubs, message boards and chatrooms. Yahoo! has now made these areas much more difficult to find and even disabled some search links so that in order to find a club, users have to know the correct internet address and type it in directly. List members argue angrily that this tactic will ultimately lead to them disappearing altogether.

Ken Bradman, a 23-year-old web developer in Phoenix, has spoken out on the issue and is organising a protest club. "If they completely eliminate adult material from the site, they're going to lose a lot of members who are interested in that. I can guarantee you it's going to be a huge chunk of Yahoo!'s user base," he proclaimed last week.

Already some club members have reposted links to their clubs in different sections of the site to show they won't be silenced.

Yahoo! refuses to comment further on the porn issue, but the UK office is happy to point out its tight policy. "We have a different position to the US. We've already taken steps to reduce adult content on the site [last year] and we've tightened up chatroom controls," says a spokesman.

The UK office of MSN says much the same: "MSN.co.uk has a zero tolerance policy toward retailers on the shopping channel distributing pornographic material from its site. Since 'top shelf pornography' is not illegal for consenting adults over the age of 18 material of this nature is categorised in communities as 'adult' on the MSN site. Users searching under adult terms on MSN Search will be asked to confirm that they are wanting to access adult material and if they answer positively will be diverted on to a separate site - Nightsurf."

The issue has become much more than the removal of pornographic videos, the blocking of under 18s, and links to child porn sites; it has opened up a whole can of worms about freedom of speech on the internet. For a harassed Yahoo! though, it is damned whatever it does. This one could run and run.

The news last week that unseated dot.com employees were falling over themselves to get jobs in the porn industry was more than just a sign of the times. Disillusioned dot.commers, hacked off with constantly being bounced around from one failed outfit to the next, reasoned that the only fail-safe solution was pornography. It wasn't such a big surprise. Porn is one of the few profitable industries on the internet, and "sex" has long been the most popular online search term, closely followed by "porn", "nude", "XXX", "Playboy" and "erotic stories". While the rest of the net is reeling from crumbling ad revenues, the sex industry has not even taken a hit because its main revenue stream is subscriptions, not advertising. It's that old adage again: Sex always sells. No amount of economic downturn will affect this phenomenally successful industry that is becoming increasingly acceptable, especially among young professionals. Yet companies such as Yahoo! are opting out of the porn industry. Given the demand, the big business and the job security,this seems like a mad decision. Why? It all boils down to a public outcry, and a feeling that one of the biggest and arguably one of the most influential internet companies in the world shouldn't be dealing in the business of porn. Despite the fact that Yahoo! has sold X-rated products for more than two years, when the Los Angeles Times ran a piece suggesting it was expanding its collection a month ago, a huge debate ensued. A few days later, Yahoo! backed down and said it would cease selling adult products, stop accepting banner ads from porn sites, cut out classifieds and auction adult-type items, and pledged it would clamp down on sex-related message boards and clubs. The misconception, however, is that it will outlaw porn on its site, which it insists is not the case. A search still throws up 671 sites for "porn" and if Yahoo! users want to buy porn videos, they are redirected to an external site. To make the changes Yahoo! is currently introducing what has been described as "pretty extensive filtering software" but teething problems are expected. The reduction of porn on Yahoo.com won't spell the death of Yahoo!, but it could derail its profit projections. Despite the new porn exclusion software, though, the company is still making its mind up. Last week, faced with a barrage of criticism from web users, it came back and said no decisions had been taken on whether the changes to its adult porn section would be permanent. "It's the internet, so lots of things are possible," said Yahoo! spokesman Jackson Holtz, insisting it was just a re-evaluation of adult content across the network. Clearly, Yahoo! is playing it by ear. It doesn't want to alienate users or conservative forces, nor does it want to rule out forever a guaranteed moneyspinner. Yahoo! has been put in a glaringly uncomfortable spotlight. It has now publicly back-peddled on a plan to expand its adult materials and caused a flap among other big internet portals, concerned about public approval. Terra Lycos, which operates a number of Lycos portals around the world, has now chipped in and announced it is re-evaluating its own porn policy, while MSN has reaffirmed that it has a strict policy on porn. Of all the bigger players in the portal market, AltaVista is one of the few that seems to offer no-holds-barred access to pornographic material. A quick search using the term "porn" brings up an array of hardcore images, video clips and links to sites that are advertised using very explicit language. MSN has already gone the whole hog and removed any evidence of adult-related merchandise. It moderates chatrooms and has a tough policy on links to porn. In fact, after entering the term "porn" in the search engine, the user is immediately warned: "You have entered a search term that is likely to return adult content." There are no adult videos to be found on the site, but if users want that kind of material, they are sent out of MSN confines into the unrestrained web where technically they are no longer the responsibility of MSN. Therein lies the great irony. A significant proportion of web users want access to porn and to this end will locate porn and buy it, with or without the help of Yahoo!. Censorship of this kind doesn't work. If Yahoo!, the second biggest website in the world, doesn't take a piece of this action, it will lose out. Pundits and users alike believe Yahoo! has got itself into unnecessarily uncomfortable territory because of its willingness to purge itself of adult materials, instead of forcing families to install filter software on their computers. Yahoo! members spoke out last week, saying they felt betrayed and were planning to petition the portal after it quietly reconfigured its adult-themed clubs, message boards and chatrooms. Yahoo! has now made these areas much more difficult to find and even disabled some search links so that in order to find a club, users have to know the correct internet address and type it in directly. List members argue angrily that this tactic will ultimately lead to them disappearing altogether. Ken Bradman, a 23-year-old web developer in Phoenix, has spoken out on the issue and is organising a protest club. "If they completely eliminate adult material from the site, they're going to lose a lot of members who are interested in that. I can guarantee you it's going to be a huge chunk of Yahoo!'s user base," he proclaimed last week. Already some club members have reposted links to their clubs in different sections of the site to show they won't be silenced. Yahoo! refuses to comment further on the porn issue, but the UK office is happy to point out its tight policy. "We have a different position to the US. We've already taken steps to reduce adult content on the site [last year] and we've tightened up chatroom controls," says a spokesman. The UK office of MSN says much the same: "MSN.co.uk has a zero tolerance policy toward retailers on the shopping channel distributing pornographic material from its site. Since 'top shelf pornography' is not illegal for consenting adults over the age of 18 material of this nature is categorised in communities as 'adult' on the MSN site. Users searching under adult terms on MSN Search will be asked to confirm that they are wanting to access adult material and if they answer positively will be diverted on to a separate site - Nightsurf." webTitle: British Interactive Broadcasting closes

fields.headline: Bang! The door slams shut on Open
fields.trailText: For the selective few of us who remember the launch of BiB - British Interactive Broadcasting - it will come as little surprise that Open has shut.
fields.body:
For the selective few of us who remember the launch of BiB - British Interactive Broadcasting - it will come as little surprise that Open has shut. At a time when the threat of the internet seemed pressing and the lure of e-tail revenues inviting, BiB offered a stunningly dull opportunity to shop at WH Smith and bank at the Midland. And however much huff and puff the unholy alliance of BT and BSkyB gave it, there never really seemed to be a future for the Open product which evolved from the BiB initiative.

For anything which provided such a limited range of products, compared to the endless smorgasbord of services from retailing websites, the future always looked cloudy. Its fate was effectively sealed when Tony Ball took over from Mark Booth as chief executive of BSkyB. Coming to the project from the outside, Ball soon realised that an interactive service which did not allow access to the internet had little future.

But Open's problems were even more fundamental than this. For a start, the services could only be accessed when you were not watching television. This may seem a trivial point, but to the supine surfer the idea of tuning out of surfing and into a whole new protocol is laborious and deserves a reward.

Open failed to deliver on this point too. There are those whose lives were enriched by the interactive games such as Beehive Bedlam and Corporal Cluck - an exciting game which involved detonating chickens - but they were few and far between. The retailing services were devised in a counter-intuitive manner which meant that a great deal of attention had been paid to production values and almost nothing spent on customer service.

Even the most rudimentary internet retailers offer a confirmation of order, a tracking service and a post-purchase hand-holding email service, which however imperfect are more reassuring than the void which followed an Open purchase.

The metrics on Open are about as appalling as they could possibly be. To lose £116m on a money-making no-brainer which is an add on to your core service is fairly sobering. For the service to have generated only 650,000 transactions is a testimony to the magnitude of the product's flaws.

But, for BSkyB, the dissolving of the partnership with BT will come as a blessed relief. For a start, it can simplify the installation of its mini digital dishes - the requirement that you must have a BT phone line drilled into the wall behind your TV will presumably cease. Though not if BSkyB wants to pursue other interactive services. For instance, the Sky News interactive bulletin is one of the genuinely valuable features of Sky's service.

The success of interactive news and the failure of Open teach broadcasters a valuable lesson about interactive TV. First, that consumer expectations have been massively raised by the net; and, second, that interactive TV only works if it does exactly what it says on the tin. Something which is interactive but not TV and not the internet is going to unsettle an audience.

What is also interesting is that the demise of Open is coming at a time when iTV (interactive TV) is once again being talked about as the big new thing. Just as those trendy Blackberry gadgets, currently sweeping through trendy Manhattan, revive pager technology, so iTV is threatening to become the hot platform of tomorrow after being consigned to interim technology death several years ago.

The infamous TimeWarner interactive TV trial in Florida proved a gigantic, costly lemon, whose party was pretty much pooped by the advent of the internet. The new challenge is to incorporate the features of the internet into the set-top box. But the range of services which will be optioned by viewers must also be carefully selected if they are not to suffer the fate of Open. Detailed transaction is much better suited to the intimate confines of a PC screen with fully functional keyboard. Enhancing viewer services is about adding content and functionality rather than hindering the viewer with unwanted sales messages.

But, most of all, interactive television is still awaiting its killer application, and, looking at Sky TV's "interactive revenues", it is clear that gambling comes pretty high up the list, as it constitutes more than 80% of the £26m earnings. The Government would like to believe it will be filling in your tax return or claiming your pension, hence the breathless efforts to turn the country digital as soon as possible, but TV needs an email or text messaging equivalent if any of this costly technology is ever going to be viable. One thing is certain - the future does not lie with an exploding chicken.

 Emily Bell is editor-in-chief of Guardian Unlimited

webTitle: Medical scandals leave trust in doctors unshaken

fields.headline: Medical scandals leave trust in doctors unshaken
fields.trailText: Doctors are still viewed as the people the public most trust, research has revealed, despite a wealth of recent adverse publicity - from Harold Shipman, the GP-turned-serial-killer, to the Alder Hey organ retention scandal, and the Bristol babies' hearts tragedy.
fields.body:
Doctors are still viewed as the people the public most trust, research has revealed, despite a wealth of recent adverse publicity - from Harold Shipman, the GP-turned-serial-killer, to the Alder Hey organ retention scandal, and the Bristol babies' hearts tragedy.

The Mori poll - which deliberately drew the public's attention to controversies such as Alder Hey, where some 3,000 childrens' organs were stored without their parents consent - found 89% of the public trust their doctors to tell the truth. This was a rise of 2% on last year when Harold Shipman was found guilty of murdering 15 female patients, and 7% on 1983 when Mori began polling on the issue.

Their trustworthiness rating, which comes as a national audit office (NAO) report revealed the NHS owes £3.9bn in compensation for medical negligence, places them above teachers, on 86%, and judges and the clergy, the latter of which have seen public trust slide from 85% in 1983 to 78%.

The police are trusted by 63% of an increasingly cynical public, but, at 17%, the least trusted of all remain politicians.

Perhaps surprisingly, given the second resignation of former Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson, government ministers are viewed as more trustworthy than back benchers, at 20%, and are seen as more credible than journalists, trusted by 18%.

The research, conducted for the British Medical Association (BMA), drew on interviews with nearly 2,000 people aged 15 and over in England, Scotland and Wales, which took place in late March - before the NAO report, or a hospital audit which last week revealed a third of all cervical cancer cases were undetected.

But the face-to-face interviews did occur against a backdrop of increasingly high-profile media coverage of medical blunders, including the harm wreaked by disgraced gynae cologists Rodney Ledward and Richard Neale, and the recent hospital deaths of 18-year-old Wayne Jowett - who died in February when a junior doctor injected a powerful drug into his spine instead of his vein - and three-year-old Najiyah Hussain, who died in January when a consultant gave her a fatal dose of laughing gas instead of oxygen.

Commenting on the results, which also found 89% of the public were fairly or very satisfied with the way doctors carried out their jobs, the BMA's chairman, Ian Bogle, said they belied fears of a crisis of public confidence in doctors.

"This shows that you should trust the public to make mature judgments based on their own experience," he said. "Patients read about high profile cases and they want action taken against individual bad doctors but they do not make false links between very different kinds of problems and they know that doctors are doing a good job in difficult circumstances.

"Doctors will take great heart from this evidence, and I hope that politicians, commentators and doctors themselves really do absorb the lessons of this poll.

He added: "There is a danger that if you keep saying that public confidence is eroded, it will become a self-fulfilling prophecy. That is not good for patients, for doctors or for the NHS."

% in 1983 2001

Doctors 82 89

Teachers 79 86

TV newsreaders 63 75

Professors n/a 78

Judges 77 78

Clergy 85 78

Scientists n/a 65

Police 61 63

Man on the street 57 52

Pollsters n/a 46

Civil servants 25 43

Union bosses 18 39

Business leaders 25 27

Government ministers 16 20

Journalists 19 18

Politicians 18 17

webTitle: Roy Greenslade on Suzanne Goldenberg

fields.headline: 'I came here to write about peace'
fields.standfirst:
Guardian journalist Suzanne Goldenberg last week won a prestigious award. Roy Greenslade says it is a victory for her on two fronts

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Guardian journalist Suzanne Goldenberg last week won a prestigious award. Roy Greenslade says it is a victory for her on two fronts.
fields.body:
Journalists are too often given awards they don't deserve. Indeed, there are awards that no longer deserve to be received. But last week a good award went to a good woman who won it on merit.

I must declare two interests: the recipient was Suzanne Goldenberg, the Guardian's correspondent in Jerusalem, and I was one of the London Press Club judges who awarded her the Edgar Wallace Trophy for reporting of the highest quality.

Neither of these factors should cloud a wider appreciation of Goldenberg, who has been subject to intolerable pressure in the last seven months. Journalists are often derided for what they write. It goes with the territory. They come to accept that however much people cry out for them to be neutral observers it is impossible to satisfy everybody. Impartiality, like beauty, is always in the eye of the beholder.

For journalists whose daily work is to report on conflicts from within divided communities, the problem is far greater. Nowhere is this more obvious than in Israel/Palestine. The Israeli state has been particularly prickly about reporting of the current intifada, believing that it has been on the end of negative press coverage. That view is endorsed by many Jews outside Israel who carefully monitor newspapers and then set out to pressure editors they think guilty of publishing material they deem to be pro-Palestinian.

Spinning must be expected in such circumstances. But since October last year there is evidence that it has taken a sinister turn, with attempts to stifle any objective reporting of events. The main target in Britain has been the Guardian and, more specifically, Goldenberg.

A shadowy ultra-orthodox Jewish group has organised a campaign of vilification and denigration against her, attempting to undermine her. Along with editor Alan Rusbridger, the foreign desk and the letters editor, Goldenberg has received waves of emails, many of them highly insulting and defamatory, which call into question her professionalism and her commitment to telling the truth.

Hundreds of complaints arrived in February following her article, A Museum Fit for Martyrs, about an exhibition of relics of Palestinians killed in the uprising - all claimed she was guilty of bias.

In March, the Jewish Tribune, a weekly published in London for an ultra-orthodox audience, carried an article accusing the Guardian of biased reporting. It quoted an anonymous "experienced British foreign correspondent" who claimed that "part of the problem" was Goldenberg, who was described as "extremely inexperienced, young, leftist, Jewish and over-compensating because she's Jewish".

For the record, Goldenberg regards herself as a secular Jew. Now 38, she was born in Canada and, after leaving university in Montreal, she worked for Canadian media groups and freelanced from India before joining the Guardian in 1988 as a foreign sub-editor. Between 1988 and 1995, she carried out several reporting assignments for the Guardian, spending six months in the former Soviet Union.

She later spent five years as the Guardian's south Asia correspondent, reporting on one occasion in 1998 from Israel. A fluent Hebrew speaker, she became full-time Middle East correspondent in February last year. That hardly justifies the claim of inexperience, but Goldenberg believes that much of the criticism directed at her "is because of my surname". In other words, Israelis view her as a traitor to the cause.

Though she does not believe herself to be in any physical danger, her car has been vandalised on several occasions and she has been subject, like many other reporters, to petty restrictions.

She believes her articles are fair and balanced but that many Israelis are "in denial" and unable to accept any criticism. In the citation for her Press Club award, the judges pointed to two articles she wrote in October last year which are typical of Goldenberg's work: detailed reporting of observed events with political analysis and some historical context.

Hostile reaction to Goldenberg, and attacks on the Guardian, prompted Rusbridger to write a defence of the paper's coverage in the Jewish Chronicle three weeks ago. He argued that the Guardian has presented a "a mosaic of news, features, analysis and comment from all sides" in recent months, praising Goldenberg as "courageous".

Back in Jerusalem after receiving her award from Tony Blair, Goldenberg is determined to carry on reporting as before. "I came here to write about peace," she says. "I still hope that one day I can."

webTitle: Witness appeal on Anna death inquiry

fields.headline: Witness appeal on Anna death inquiry
fields.trailText: Lord Laming, head of a public inquiry into the killing of eight-year-old Anna Climbié, last night appealed for witnesses to provide evidence that could lead to a fundamental overhaul of child protection in England.
fields.body:
Lord Laming, head of a public inquiry into the killing of eight-year-old Anna Climbié, last night appealed for witnesses to provide evidence that could lead to a fundamental overhaul of child protection in England.

In an interview with the Guardian, he opened up the possibility that her murderers might be invited to give public evidence on their perception of the service offered by social workers, doctors and police before her death.

And he disclosed advice from ministers that the girl's death could not be blamed on the misjudgment of individual staff, but looked as if it may have been the result of "a gross failure of the system".

The girl - named in trial reports as Anna, but known to the inquiry as Victoria Climbié - was murdered in London last year after months of abuse went unheeded by staff from the agencies that came into contact with her.

Her aunt, Marie Thérèse Kouao, 44, and her lover, Carl Manning, 28, were convicted of murder at the Old Bailey in January and jailed for life.

The girl had been brought to the attention of social services three times and was discharged from hospital twice since coming to Britain from the Ivory Coast in 1999. After her death, the marks of 128 separate injuries were found on her body.

Lord Laming, a former chief inspector of social services, said he was heading an unusually complex statutory inquiry into the lessons to be drawn. Although the terms of reference instructed his team to reach conclusions on "how such an event may, as far as possible, be avoided in the future", he would not be able to comment on defects in the system unless they were thrown up by the evidence of this case.

For that reason, he said, he was about to advertise an appeal for witnesses.

Lord Laming, a former chief inspector of social services, said he was heading an unusually complex statutory inquiry into the lessons to be drawn. Although the terms of reference instructed his team to reach conclusions on "how such an event may, as far as possible, be avoided in the future", he would not be able to comment on defects in the system unless they were thrown up by the evidence of this case. For that reason, he said, he was about to advertise an appeal for witnesses.

webTitle: Snack scheme aims to cut NHS wastage

fields.headline: Snack scheme aims to cut NHS wastage
fields.trailText: A 24-hour service of free snacks in NHS hospitals will be launched by ministers this week in a £40m programme to improve the quality of patients' food.
fields.body:
A 24-hour service of free snacks in NHS hospitals will be launched by ministers this week in a £40m programme to improve the quality of patients' food.

Alan Milburn, health secretary, will also unveil recipes for main meals that have been prepared by Loyd Grossman and other celebrity chefs. The minister ordered that meals must be tempting enough to cut the NHS bill for wasted food, which accounts for nearly 10% of its £500m annual culinary budget.

The snackbox service will be provided for patients who do not feel like a main meal or who miss one because of treatment or tests, and for patients arriving at any hour of the day or night when kitchen service is not available.

The choice will be:

 a standard snackbox of fresh fruit, crisps, cheese, butter, crackers, chocolate bar and fruit drink;

 a sandwich snackbox with a choice of white or wholemeal bread sandwiches, yoghurt, fresh fruit and fruit drink;

 a children's snackbox of fromage frais, cheese triangle and breadsticks, fresh fruit, milkshake, chocolate bar and crisps.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said the snackbox service would be "rolled out" to all NHS hospitals in England by the end of the year. It would not be available to patients who had a full meal and still felt peckish.

The NHS provides 300m meals a year at an average cost of £1.67 per meal.

"Our aim is to improve the standard and quality of hospital food. We want patients to have better food with less waste," she said.

webTitle: Pope makes history in Syria, and angers Israel

fields.headline: Pope makes history in Syria, and angers Israel
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II, who yesterday made history by becoming the first pontiff to visit a mosque, sided with the Palestinians by calling indirectly on Israel to withdraw from the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II, who yesterday made history by becoming the first pontiff to visit a mosque, sided with the Palestinians by calling indirectly on Israel to withdraw from the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

The Pope, on his first full day in Damascus, also found himself caught up in a row between Israel and Syria over accusations of anti-semitism.

The Israeli foreign ministry claimed that the Syrian president, Bashar Assad, was using the Pope as "a platform to wage an anti-Jewish campaign, raising anti-semitic accusations that have led to much bloodshed over the ages" and called on the Pope to dissociate himself from them during his visit.

For the first time in 1,400 years of Muslim history, a pope entered a mosque. The Pope was greeted at the Umayyad mosque in the centre of Damascus's old city by Syria's leading Muslim cleric, Sheik Ahmad Kuftaro, who said before the meeting that he hoped the visit "will result in serious common action to save the Palestinians - Christians and Muslims - from the massacres being carried out by Israel".

As required by Muslim custom, the Pope removed his shoes and put on white slippers before entering the mosque. He stumbled several times on his way to the tomb in the mosque believed to contain the head of John the Baptist.

His trip has been billed as a journey in the footsteps of St Paul, whose conversion occurred on the way to Damascus.

On arrival at Damascus airport, the Pope called on Israel to abide by international law: "It is time to return to the principles of international legality: the banning of the acquisition of territory by force, the right of peoples to self-determination, respect for the resolutions of the United Nations organisation and the Geneva conventions."

The Pope did not name Israel, but it has consistently refused to implement UN resolutions calling on it to withdraw from occupied territory and to stop expanding Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza, in contravention of international law.

The Israeli government refrained from publicly criticising the Pope, but an official said in private: "It is unfortunate that he has allowed himself to be dragged into this."

The Pope will upset Israelis further today by visiting the Syrian ghost town of Kuneitra, on the Golan Heights, a place Syrians regard as a symbol of Israeli brutality. The Israelis demolished it house by house as they withdrew after the 1973 war.

Israeli ministers queued up to condemn an anti-semitic diatribe from Mr Assad.

At a welcoming ceremony for the Pope, Mr Assad said: "We see them [Israel] attacking sacred Christian and Muslim places in Palestine... They try to kill the principle of religions in the same mentality in which they betrayed Jesus Christ and tried to kill the prophet Mohammed."

The Israeli president, Moshe Katsav, said it was "surprising that the Pope did not find it appropriate to correct Assad's statements".

The deputy foreign minister, Michael Melchior, said he had hoped that after the Holocaust such remarks would not be heard again and called on world and church leaders to condemn them.

A Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said: "The Pope will absolutely not intervene. We are guests of this president and he has expressed his opinion."

webTitle: All change in the Indian assembly?

fields.headline: All change in the Indian assembly?
fields.standfirst: Early indications suggest the out-of-favour Congress party may mount a comeback in the upcoming assembly elections, says Luke Harding
fields.trailText: Early indications suggest the out-of-favour Congress party may mount a comeback in the upcoming assembly elections, says Luke Harding.
fields.body:
Just how well will the once-mighty Congress party do in India's assembly elections later this week? Though it is too early to talk about a renaissance in the party's now dismal fortunes, the signs are that Congress will perform better than expected.

There are regional polls on Thursday in four important areas of the country - in West Bengal, where the ruling left front is hoping to cling onto power, and in the states of Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Assam. According to the latest polls, the Congress and its coalition partners appear to be ahead in three states. The party, in alliance with the Trinamool Congress, is also not far behind the communists in West Bengal.

It is too early to say whether a strong showing in this week's elections means that the Congress's wilderness years are coming to a close. But with India's ruling Hindu nationalist-led coalition government appearing increasingly shaky, Congress strategists may at least be able to console themselves that the party has turned a corner.

Like most Indian elections, the assembly polls are as much about personalities as politics. The most intriguing contest is in West Bengal, where the mercurial Trinamool Congress leader Mamata Banerjee is trying to drive out the incumbent Left Front, which has run West Bengal for decades.

Ms Banerjee dramatically resigned from the government and the National Democratic Alliance coalition six weeks ago, after an Indian website exposed corruption in both the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and India's defence ministry. Her resignation was largely tactical.

By distancing herself from the Hindu nationalist BJP, Ms Banerjee is hoping to cash in on West Bengal's significant Muslim vote bank, and thus improve her chances of becoming the state's chief minister. The fact that the Congress Party's leader, Sonia Gandhi, has allied herself with Trinamool is also important.

Having previously insisted that the Congress would only return to power nationally in its own right, the party is increasingly waking up to the reality that India is now firmly in the era of coalition politics. To gain power even at regional level requires compromises.

The prospect of any party - whether Congress or BJP, left or right - ever being able to secure an absolute majority in its own right seems increasingly improbable. If Sonia is ever to become prime minister, a prospect most observers feel is still unlikely, more such tactical alliances will be needed in the tricky months ahead.

This week's election also confirms a trend rife in politics across South Asia: that the principle of dynastic succession is alive and well. In Tamil Nadu, for example, the incumbent chief minister M Karunanidhi is trying to cling onto power in the face of a massive challenge from his larger-than-life arch-rival Jayalalitha.

Now in his 70s, Mr Karunanidhi has been openly grooming his memorably named son Stalin to succeed him, despite grumbling from within his own DMK party. But the latest polls put Jayalalitha and her AIADMK party ahead, despite the fact she has been disqualified from standing in the election because of alleged corruption. Whether Stalin's coronation as Tamil Nadu's new chief minister takes place remains to be seen.

There is little appetite, meanwhile, among Delhi's political classes at the moment for a general election. But after the assembly polls in three days' time, all bets are off. India's prime minister Atal Behari Vajpayee seems a demoralised figure these days. After 18 months in power, his NDA coalition is beginning to sink under the weight of its own contradictions. A general election next year seems distinctly probable.
