webTitle: Jail death that marked a watershed

fields.headline: Jail death that marked a watershed
fields.standfirst:
Twenty years on, the legacy of IRA hunger striker Bobby Sands is still steeped in controversy

Special report: Northern Ireland

66-day drama created modern martyr
fields.trailText: Twenty years on, the legacy of IRA hunger striker Bobby Sands is still steeped in controversy
fields.body:
Twenty years ago last Saturday, the death of IRA hunger striker Bobby Sands in the Maze prison, outside Belfast, marked one of the biggest watersheds in the history of Irish republicanism. By late summer, nine more men were dead, six of them IRA men, three from the Irish National Liberation Army, before the families of the remaining 13 hunger strikers began to intervene to end their protest.

The battle of wills with the then British prime minister Margaret Thatcher brought turbulent times for Northern Ireland, plunging it into a cycle of riots, paramilitary and security force shootings, which claimed more than 60 lives, over half of them civilian, outside the jail.

On the face of it the prisoners lost, but in the long term they won. In the ensuing months their demands for better conditions were granted, including political status in all but name, and they gained unprecedented sympathy for their cause.

Unionists, who viewed the hunger strikers as deluded, terrorist fanatics, forced to die by the IRA leadership, looked on in disbelief as the international spotlight focused on the province.

Brendan "Bik" McFarlane, IRA leader in the Maze in 1981, who now works for North Belfast Sinn Fein assemblyman Gerry Kelly, categorically rejects any suggestion the hunger strike was not voluntary. "Scores of people volunteered," he said. "Our problem was not lack of people but choosing which ones. The IRA army council was actually opposed to the hunger strike but we won the argument. Of course, it was about much more than prison rights. By picking the jail as her battleground, the Iron Lady though she was attacking the underbelly of republicanism. But she found it was made of steel. There is no question it was one of Britain's biggest mistakes."

The election of Sands as Fermanagh/ South Tyrone MP, weeks before he died, was to set the bulk of the republican movement, with Sinn Fein at its helm, on a new path to political strength. Rapid progress, albeit as former Sinn Fein publicity director, Danny Morrison, put it "with the ballot box in one hand and the Armalite in the other", led to the IRA ceasefires and eventually the Good Friday agreement.

Violent struggle

Two decades on, as republicans commemorate the hunger strike, the legacy of the 10 men elevated as martyrs to the cause of Irish freedom is bitterly disputed. Many former hunger strikers and their families now support Sinn Fein and the peace process. webTitle: Sixty-six day drama created a modern martyr

fields.headline: Sixty-six day drama created a modern martyr
fields.standfirst:
To begin with he was a little known activist, but 100,000 people turned out for his funeral

Jail death that marked a watershed
fields.trailText: To begin with he was a little known activist, but 100,000 people turned out for his funera
fields.body:
On March 1 1981, when Bobby Sands embarked on hunger strike in the Maze prison outside Belfast, he was a little known west Belfast republican.

But when he died 66 days later, aged just 27, he was a Westminster MP, and the shockwaves spread around the world.

More than 100,000 people came to his funeral, and now, two decades on, his long hair and pale features are among the most recognised faces of our time.

Born in 1954, Sands encountered religious bigotry early in life when his family was driven out of the loyalist Rathcoole housing estate.

A few years later sectarian harassment forced him to give up his first job as an apprentice coachbuilder.

He joined the IRA at 18 and soon became leader of a west Belfast unit. He was jailed twice for possession of firearms, first in 1973 and again in 1977, when he was arrested after a bomb attack and gun battle at a warehouse.

He and other republican prisoners took part in the blanket and "dirty" protests, in an attempt to get the British government to restore political status, which had been gradually phased out in the early 1970s.

The ante was upped to a hunger strike in 1980 but this was called off amid confusion after a couple of months, with no deaths but no demands met.

But in 1981 the prisoners decided they would have to go the distance with a second hunger strike.

Brendan "Bik" McFarlane, head of the IRA in the Maze at the time, who first met Sands in the notorious H blocks in 1979, said: "There was an electricity about Bobby."

Mr McFarlane, convicted for the murder of five Protestants blown up in a bomb in a Shankill Road bar, now works for Sinn Fein Stormont assemblyman and fellow ex-prisoner, Gerry Kelly.

"Bobby was a poet, songwriter, storyteller, an all-round entertainer, but a deep thinker too. He wasn't overtly religious but there was a spiritual side to him."

The republican prisoners were incredibly well organised, he said. They painstakingly wrote a huge number of comms [communications] to the IRA army council, in tiny letters on cigarette paper, wrapped in clingfilm and smuggled out via visitors in all manner of body orifices. And education and political discussion were an important part of the daily routine.

Mr McFarlane last saw Sands about a week before his death, when European commission officials came to the prison in a failed attempt to visit him and try to resolve the situation. It was a shocking sight he will never forget.

"Bobby was propped up in bed on loads of pillows, gaunt, with sunken eyes and cheeks," he said.

"Even though I was right beside him, he couldn't see or hear me properly. I had to bend close to hear what he was saying. But mentally, he was still alert and his resolve was solid as a rock."

By then, most republicans felt the protest was heading inexorably toward Sands' death, but it was still a massive shock when it happened. He died at 1.17am on May 5 and Mr McFarlane heard the news at 2am on a tiny crystal radio set in his cell.

webTitle: Blast sparks poll alert

fields.headline: Blast sparks poll alert
fields.standfirst:
Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Dissident Irish bombers could be planning a campaign designed to wreak havoc during the run-up to the general election, anti-terrorist police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Dissident Irish bombers could be planning a campaign designed to wreak havoc during the run-up to the general election, anti-terrorist police said yesterday.

The warning came after a suspected Real IRA device exploded outside a post office sorting depot in north London, the second time the building had been targeted in three weeks.

Alan Fry, the head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, said contingency plans were in place to combat an election bombing campaign.

Describing the task of stopping the terrorists as a "major challenge", Deputy Commissioner Fry said: "We have seen sustained activity in election campaigns both in 97 and 92. We take note of that and we will be doing everything possible to secure the safety of those taking part in the election and the general public."

Before the 1992 election the IRA warned it would force its way on to the agenda by stepping up its terror campaign on mainland Britain. As the Tories celebrated victory a bomb rocked the Baltic Exchange in the City, killing three people.

In the run-up to polling day in the last election, the IRA caused massive disruption by falsely claiming it had planted devices on motorways and at airports.

But it was thought that the terrorists were reluctant to endanger lives as deaths could have had an adverse impact on the chances of Sinn Fein candidates. One worry now must be that the Real IRA will not be so careful because it has no such direct aspirations to power in Westminster.

The bomb at the Hendon sorting office went off at 1.40am yesterday. It had been placed at the same spot on the pavement that a similar device was detonated on April 14. Only one passerby was slightly hurt but Mr Fry said enough high explosive - half a pound - had been used to cause "serious injuries or even death".

There was only minor damage to the building, which was empty because of the bank holiday. Though no warning was given and nobody claimed responsibility, the blast was thought to be linked to the 20th anniversary of the death of IRA hunger striker Bobby Sands. The previous bomb coincided with the anniversary of the 1916 Easter Rising.

In March a bomb that detonated in a taxi as experts tried to carry out a controlled explosion outside the BBC TV Centre in west London was taken as a signal of an escalation of the Real IRA's campaign on mainland Britain.

webTitle: Justice bill 'endangers press freedom'

fields.headline: Justice bill 'endangers press freedom'
fields.standfirst:
Straw under attack with claims that 'protection' clause would criminalise media investigation
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Straw under attack with claims that 'protection' clause would criminalise media investigation
fields.body:
Investigative journalism and peaceful protest are threatened by a clause in Jack Straw's criminal justice and police bill, members of the House of Lords will argue this week.

Clause 41 was added to the bill with the aim of protecting scientists and staff at Huntingdon Life Sciences and other animal testing laboratories from the frightening tactics of some animal rights activists. However, its provisions have been drawn so widely they threaten to criminalise more than intimidation, it is claimed.

Opponents argue a future Robert Maxwell or General Pinochet could call a passing police constable, who would have power to force anyone -including a journalist - to leave the vicinity of their home; the officer merely has to believe the outsider's presence is likely to cause harassment, alarm or distress to the victim.

Non-compliance would be a crime punishable by up to three months in jail or a £2,500 fine - even though there was no intention to harass or distress, and even though no threatening or insulting words or behaviour were used.

Andrew Phillips, the Liberal Democrat peer and solicitor, who unsuccessfully argued in the Lords last week for amendments, said the clause amounted to "by far the most draconian restriction of peaceful protest ever contemplated for our law". He also predicted it would join the libel writ in the armoury of those with crookery and corruption to hide.

"Where you've got people who are powerful and in the know, there is going to be a real risk that they are going to ring up the local cop shop and say 'Look, we're getting real hassle from these fellows outside and we expect you to do something about it'."

Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister, conceded during Commons debates on the bill that the clause would apply to journalists but insisted that it would not affect doorstepping. The "classic doorstep", he argued, "can sometimes be difficult and problematic for the people concerned, but would obviously not be unlawful - because harassment, alarm and distress would not arise." Others disagree: as Lord Phillips noted in the Lords debate, someone guilty of a concealed fraud might well be alarmed or distressed to find a determined journalist camped on the pavement outside.

Mr Clarke's reassurance also overlooked the wording of the clause, which does not require actual harassment, alarm or distress. It would be enough if police believed an interloper's presence "amounts to, or is likely to result in, the harassment of the victim" or is likely to cause the victim alarm or distress.

The rights organisation Liberty said: "The nearly automatic reaction to a problem is to get out the statute book and pencil in a few more powers for the police and create a few more criminal offences. The powers are not carefully crafted to deal only with the current 'problem' but are much more wide-ranging in their effects."

The government seems not to have realised quite how far these powers stretch. Last week in the Lords, the Home Office minister, Lord Davies of Oldham, dismissed the idea police would interfere with the rights of journalists. In the Commons, Mr Clarke, accepted police had the power, but insisted they would not interfere with legitimate journalism.

Lord Phillips asked: "Is the copper going to sit there carefully weighing up the difference between vigorous, determined, won't-take-no-for-an-answer journalism, and alarm and distress? Of course he won't. You don't take risks with basic freedoms. This power is a sitting duck for misuse by the very people who are most in need of being dogged by the press."

The home secretary has warned liberal peers he would portray them as soft on burglars and paedophiles if they were to block key elements of his bill. He gave his verbal threat at a private meeting of peers a fortnight ago.

The Liberal Democrats believe other parts of the bill would conravene the human rights act, put millions of innocent people permanently onto a police DNA database, and improperly deprive citizens of their passport.

Lord McNally, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, said yesterday: "Parliament has to hold its nerve against Jack Straw's threats, and demand proper scrutiny.

"It may not be fashionable to defend the liberties of an alleged criminal, but we cannot go on giving the police more and more powers."

webTitle: Endpiece: It's still my party right or wrong

fields.headline: It's still my party right or wrong
fields.standfirst:
Labour remains our best hope of achieving an equal society

Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Labour remains our best hope of achieving an equal society
fields.body:
Last Friday evening I met, for the first time in 20 years, a man who - when we knew each other well - was the distinguished headmaster of a north of England comprehensive school. No sooner had we shaken hands than he told me that he had voted Labour in every general election since the second world war.

I have learned from recent hard experience that, these days, protestations of previous loyalty almost all lead to announcements of imminent desertion. So he did not need to say that, thanks to Alastair Campbell's reference to "bog standard comprehensives", he would never vote Labour again. Nevertheless, he did. He then suppressed mild surprise that I continued to support a party that had abandoned so many of the principles that had attracted us both to it 50 years ago.

Nothing he said made me even consider changing my allegiance. But it did cause me to wonder if I clung to the party of my youthful passion for reasons that have become rationally indefensible. After all, I had not even considered any of the alternatives since I had been forced to stand as Conservative candidate in the Sheffield city grammar school first-form mock election in 1945. And then, I had argued the Tory case so badly that I lost my notional deposit. So I felt a sudden urge to ask the heretical question. Am I still what I would once call "a Labour man" because of sentiment, the comfort that comes from imagined familiarity, or because the Tories are so much worse? Whatever happened to glad confident morning?

Sentiment is certainly part of the explanation. I was brought up in the Labour party and long before I had even heard of TH Green or RH Tawney I knew that I was part of a "movement" that struggled to build a more equal society. The loyalty came first and the ideology came afterwards.

I felt no embarrassment about that. Families, regiments and countries hang together in difficult times because their members are united by common memories. If I had no better reason for hoping for a Labour victory on June 7, I would want Tony Blair back in Downing Street because he leads my tribe. I know the prime minister despises tribal politics even though they secure his vote among the neglected urban poor. I do not.

Those feelings make the other tribes my natural enemies. But I'm sufficiently objective to realise that they are sometimes not as absolutely ghastly as we make out. But at the moment the Tory party is even worse than Labour propaganda suggests. Even with Jack Straw replicating Michael Howard's legal "reforms" and David Blunkett breaking his promise to extend comprehensive education, the ideological gulf between the parties is vast. Labour has been dragged to the right. But it is the Tories who did the dragging. It is worth getting Tony Blair in just to keep William Hague out.

But for people like me, the old contemptibles of egalitarian socialism, there has to be a positive reason for our continued support of Labour. It exists. However, it is only marginally related to the record of the past four years - even allowing for the minimum wage, the social chapter and new nursery schools. And, if rumours of renewed immobilism prove correct, it will be equally unconnected to this year's manifesto.

I remain unequivocally Labour in the hope that one day the party will reclaim its destiny for, despite all its pathetic timidity and its current admiration for the values of the meretricious society, it remains the best prospect of building a new society - one day. Blairism is a temporary phenomenon. Democratic socialism abides. There is still a chance that one day Labour will be the party that it would have been had John Smith lived and the government it might have become had Neil Kinnock won in 1992.

To sacrifice that chance would be no different from the craven capitulation of the Gang of Four 20 years ago. They flinched from the fight to save Labour from the wildest shores of politics. Those of us who stayed and fought won. We now have to open a second front against a different sort of infiltration. I was not driven out by the militants and I do not propose either to leave or sit on my hands because a different sort of cuckoo has invaded our nest.

A political party - however strong the attraction of its name and idea - is never more than an organisation for putting an idea into practice. I leant that long ago when the excitement of red rosettes and noisy public meetings was replaced by the conviction that equality is the hallmark of a good society. Labour remains the best hope of keeping that idea alive. The prospect may be remote. But I am a long way from desperation and despair. As long as we battle on, the egalitarians have not lost. Victory on June 7 ought to be the beginning, not the end, of socialism's campaign.

fields.headline: Blindfolded sentencing
fields.standfirst: Britain has more inmates than Burma
fields.trailText: An election is on the brink of being called. Right on cue, Jack Straw - according to leaks in yesterday's Observer - is due tomorrow to unveil a new punitive package to deal with criminals. What could be more cynical?
fields.body:
An election is on the brink of being called. Right on cue, Jack Straw - according to leaks in yesterday's Observer - is due tomorrow to unveil a new punitive package to deal with criminals. What could be more cynical?

On one of the few issues where Labour is performing badly in the polls, it produces a last-minute crime package to reassure Middle England. In fact, to be fair, the sentencing review being carried out under John Halliday, a senior Home Office policy-maker, has always been due to report in May. It will be much more sophisticated than yesterday's headlines, as our home affairs editor explains today, but do not expect spin doctors to set out the complexity of dealing with crime.

There are serious shortcomings with the present sentencing system, with too little attention paid to tackling re-offending. Supervision on release is restricted to heavy sentences; resettlement programmes, which can reduce re-offending, are extremely patchy; and there is far too little feedback to the courts about the effectiveness of different sentences. Within the system, too little progress is being made to improve literacy and numeracy skills, even though two-thirds of all inmates are ineligible for 90% of job vacancies because of inadequate skills.

A progressive government should be seeking to create a more effective system of short-term prison sentences. But it should also be seeking to make more use of alternatives to prison. Skills-training courses are even more effective in the community than behind the prison wall. Remember the Lord Chief Justice's address to the Prison Reform Trust in February, setting out the fundamental failure of the system: overcrowding.

Remember the chief inspector for prisons, interviewed in the Guardian in the same week, on how that challenge could be achieved: diverting 20,000 current inmates - women, boys, the elderly, the mentally ill, petty offenders - from the system. And remember the prison director's response one week later, that unless management and staff became more committed to reforming the current "hell holes", he would find "an easier way of earning a living".

What would be desirable tomorrow - although it is not going to happen - would be a reminder by ministers of the limits of sentencing in a criminal justice system in which 98 out of every 100 crimes does not end with a conviction. Detection has always been a much bigger deterrent than length of sentence, but the clear-up rate has been going down not up.

Contrary to Joe Public's beliefs, the government has succeeded in continuing to cut crime: a 20% fall in car crime and a 28% drop in burglary. But this drop was the result not of the tougher prison sentences endorsed by ministers, but of two other more constructive approaches. First, carefully designed crime-prevention programmes - better locks on cars and a £400m project to make 2m homes of poor and elderly people more secure. Second, true to Labour's last election mantra of being "tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime", its multiple anti-poverty programmes that have played their part in drastically cutting unemployment.

What is more likely tomorrow is another depressing debate on the need for more prisons. We already send more people to prison than any other European state except Portugal. More, in fact, than the most hardline overseas regimes - Saudi Arabia, China and Burma. The prison population is already more than 50% higher than a decade ago. When will someone have the courage to say stop?

webTitle: How firebrand Milburn became a model manager

fields.headline: How firebrand Milburn became a model manager
fields.standfirst:
Search for 'real solutions' put health secretary on road to power

Special report on the NHS plan
fields.trailText: Search for 'real solutions' put health secretary on road to power
fields.body:
It is difficult to believe now that Militant Tendency was once considered a serious threat to British democracy. Indeed if you are under 40 there is a good chance you do not know what it was. But in the early 1980s there really were people who conspired to take over the Labour party for Trotskyite ends, stealthily securing their majorities on the general management committees of local parties so they could send like-minded MPs to foment revolution at Westminster.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, was part of the "hard left" in those days. He had a quarrel with Militant, but as he described it to me it sounded like a quarrel about means, not ends. "I didn't like their methods; I thought they were pretty crude and unsophisticated."

Slipping into the ideological vernacular of the day, he said: "I didn't instinctively like the making of impossibilist demands that could never be met. Some" - this said rather defensively - "would regard that as pragmatism, but I like to think that, coming from somewhere that had real problems, I see the need for real solutions."

Somewhere in there lies the key to the journey Alan Milburn has made from revolutionary firebrand to the archetype of the New Labour manager - a cabinet minister - a journey he describes as a symbol of what has happened to his party.

His memories of a Co Durham childhood are without any hint of the intense emotion or the delicate north-eastern light that made the film Billy Elliot blaze so brightly in our imagination ("I went to see Billy Elliot. I thought it was fantastic, but it wasn't me." Why not? "I was never interested in dance").

But that childhood had many of the elements that feed the southerner's stereotyping: a single mother, a town built around a long dead mine, and reflex Labour loyalties. Labour "was in your guts and in your heart". So far, so much standard stuff. There was a first political love affair that went wrong. Milburn was captivated by the romance of leftwing history spun in EP Thompson's The Making of the English Working Class, and began research on 18th century radicalism in the north-east.

The PhD, at Newcastle University, ran into the ground. "I was riveted by the idea that there was a fine tradition of radicalism in various parts of the country connected with the burgeoning of a new form of ideology, which was expressing itself in Europe with the Enlightenment, with the French revolution and in America too. But I found it pretty hard to unearth much of this in the north-east of England; sadly, there wasn't a red Tyneside to match the red Clydeside."

Clarity

Milburn packed it in - an early sign that he is more doer than thinker. For him the history you make matters more than the history you learn. Something odd happened to his speech patterns when he described the next phase of his life: a certain imprecision of memory that sat uneasily with the intellectual clarity of the man who had so confidently outlined his wholesale restructuring of NHS trusts the day before we talked.

Milburn worked in Days of Hope, a leftwing bookshop in Newcastle, and he did not deny the suggestion that he had been a "Trot". He had been a member of the International Marxist group, the British section of Leon Trotsky's Fourth International, but he conceded that some of his political beliefs in those days were "crackers". He said: "I probably thought that the best solution for any economic problem was for the state to run it."

World revolution and all those other things? "I was never that mad. I wasn't an anarchist _ I was rather more structured than that - probably. I wasn't for sort of building barricades and so on - I don't think. But I probably thought at the time that parliament was pretty much an irrelevance in terms of changing people's lives."

There is one intriguing clue to the Alan Milburn of today in his account of his Days of Hope life. "I personally developed the badge market on Tyneside," he said. Shortly after he left the shop it went bankrupt. "I don't know whether that's a reflection on how I ran it or on how those who succeeded me ran it." Even then, competence mattered.

The decisive moment on his road to Damascus came when, as a trade union official, he led a campaign to stop the closure of the Sunderland shipyard, announced in 1986. "Here was a modern industrial facility with a lot going for it: a skilled workforce, hundreds of millions of pounds of investment had gone into it, lots of orders."

He insisted that the decision to shut it down was made for political reasons. A deal had been done with the European commission to reduce Britain's ship building capacity, and Sunderland had to go so that the politically sensitive Harland and Woolfe in Belfast could be kept open.

Milburn lost his battle. He is not a politician with a reputation for forging fine phrases, but his comment on the lesson he drew is often quoted: "It taught me," he said, "that life's a bitch."

In fact, he learned something more profound than respect for the harsh realities of a global economy: he learned that "political decisions matter". If there is such a thing as Milburnism that lesson lies at its heart. He is driven by a deep conviction about the importance of the political process itself.

It lends a puritanical cast to much of what he says; indeed puritanism is a consistent thread that links today's secretary of state with the revolutionary of two decades ago. "The thing about that form of politics, which people who haven't been in it find difficult to understand," he said of his Newcastle bookshop days, "is that it is an extremely puritanical form of leftwing politics. We believed in the cause to the detriment of any other form of life, including the wages that we were paid."

Today the puritanism shows itself in the occasional flash of irritation at what he obviously sees as the fripperies of political life - including interviews like this one. Milburn runs one of the biggest public services in the world and has been talked of as a future prime minister. Yet his personality remains largely hidden behind seven terse lines in Who's Who.

Soap opera

He conceded that "if you've got a position of responsibility people want an insight to what motivates you and what sort of person you are, and fair enough," but "what I resent about the way that modern politics is sometimes portrayed [is that] it's portrayed as soap opera."

His Whitehall office is not far from where the scaffold was erected for King Charles I. The health secretary could have written a fine manifesto for Roundheadism. And yet there are flashes too of the US Democrat and the quintessentially American belief in the pursuit of happiness as a legitimate political goal. He roadtested one of those anecdotes politicians like to use to make a point. He was hailed on a plane journey from the north-east by someone he had scarcely seen since they had been at school together. "He said, 'I make pop videos for Elton John and U2 and people like that'. I said that sounds interesting. He said, 'Yes and it's very lucrative' - he'd made a fortune." The anecdote was told to illustrate his commitment to a way of ordering things that allows everyone to fulfil their potential. But his chuckle on the word "lucrative" provided a glimpse of the share option-owning chief executive he could undoubtedly have been.

When Milburn restructured the health service last week - cutting back on bureaucrats and decentralising decision-making - the Tories accused him of stealing their clothes. I asked him to define what was distinctively Labour about the plan, and he said it was inspired by a determination to give people power over their own lives. "I remember as a kid coming back to my house on a council estate and finding that the door was yellow, and when I'd left it in the morning it was red. Somebody had done that to me, or to my family, without even asking me. Well that's a bad thing" - the suspicion of nanny state power that inspired so many libertarian Thatcherites in the 1980s.

Push him a little and Milburn is prepared to admit what a long way his political journey has taken him. He called it simply a question of "growing up" and coming to terms with the fact that "the world has changed".

"There was huge pain that the Labour party had to go through and people like me had to go through," he said. "I had to look at what I believed in, what I thought was right, and realise that not only was it not acceptable to people out there, but that it was probably wrong in many ways."

He is acutely sensitive to the perception that ideology has been replaced by managerialism. It has been said of his generation of ministers - Geoff Hoon and Stephen Byers - that they never "coined a memorable phrase or thought a dangerous thought".

"I think people of my generation, because we've grown up with 24-hour media, have a sense of what is the right thing to say. It depends what you think people want of their politicians. I don't think politics is a circus, I don't think it's theatre. I think it's a pretty serious business."

I did not directly raise the suggestion that he and his generation of ministers might be a little _ well, dull, but he worried away at it none the less. "If interesting is mad," he said finally, "then I don't want to be interesting."
Fast track Route to cabinet  Born January 27, 1958, in Birmingham.

 Raised by his unmarried mother, a secretary in the NHS, in the old coalmining village of Tow Law in County Durham.

 Educated at John Marlay school, Newcastle, and Stokesley comprehensive, North Yorkshire; Lancaster University (BA Hons in history).

 Married Barbara "Mo" O'Toole, now a Labour MEP. Marriage broke up and long-term partner is Ruth Briel, a consultant psychiatrist. They have two children.

 Worked for the Trade Union studies information unit, Newcastle 1984-90, and as a senior business development officer for North Tyneside council 1990-92.

 Elected MP for Darlington in 1992, ousting Michael Fallon, a government minister.

 Quickly promoted, becoming opposition spokesman on health in 1995 and Treasury spokesman in 1996. Became health minister in 1997. He was seen as winning his spurs by facing down strong trade union and party opposition to the use of private finance to build new hospitals.

 Chief secretary to the Treasury in 1998 and health secretary on October 11, 1999, replacing Frank Dobson.

 Interests include cricket, football, music (rap and soul), cinema, cooking.

webTitle: Farcical scenes at airport as Biggs heads home

fields.headline: Farcical scenes at airport as Biggs heads home
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The fugitive Ronnie Biggs was last night set to fly back to Britain and to certain arrest, as scenes of farce dogged his departure from Brazil.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro and Vikram Dodd
fields.body:
The fugitive Ronnie Biggs was last night set to fly back to Britain and to certain arrest, as scenes of farce dogged his departure from Brazil.

A Falconer 900 EX jet hired by the Sun newspaper spent most of yesterday waiting on the tarmac at Rio de Janeiro's international airport.

Scotland Yard said the great train robber, debilitated by three strokes and reportedly nearly penniless after more than 30 years on the run, would be arrested on arrival in Britain, expected to be today.

The prison service has started making plans for where the 71-year-old should resume serving the remaining 28 years of his 30-year sentence, after his audacious escape in 1965 from Wandsworth prison in London.

After numerous reports over 30 years that Biggs was on his way back, one sign that this time was genuine came when the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, intervened to ensure that the convicted crook would get an emergency passport allowing him into Britain.

At 2pm Brazilian time two airport staff placed a wheelchair in the disabled parking space at terminal two of the airport. They said Biggs's people had asked for it to be provided. Half an hour later a dozen armed security guards appeared to clear the 50-strong British press pack from the area. Geoff Cowling, the British consul general in Rio, and Michael John Holloway, the vice-consul, were also at the airport monitoring developments.

The Brazilian federal police said that before Biggs left he would be interviewed by officers and would have to sign a document saying he was leaving of his own free will.

There were farcical scenes as the press descended on every taxi arriving at the airport in the vain hope that Biggs was in it, until they were told he would arrive in a white minivan. Finally the van drew up with Biggs, wearing a cowboy hat and a glazed expression, one of 20 people inside. With him was his fellow great train robber, Bruce Reynolds.

But the minivan, sporting the logo of the Sun and a local hotel, quickly drove off as the press pack thronged around it. Later Biggs and his entourage slipped into the airport unnoticed.

The Sun is believed to have paid £60,000 for the hire of the private jet which flew to Rio to collect the fugitive for the 6,000-mile return flight to Britain. It did not comment on a report that in addition to the cost of the plane it would pay Bigg's son Michael £20,000 in "expenses", with Bruce Reynolds and his son Nick getting £12,000 each. Press complaints commission rules forbid payments to criminals.

If the figures are correct it would mean the Sun had paid almost £100,000 for the right to say it was the paper that brought back Britain's most notorious fugitive.

If Biggs is returned to prison straight away, it is thought likely he will be placed in a London jail. An assessment of his health needs will be made and also of the risk he poses. A police source said it was unlikely Biggs would be taken to court to face charges for escaping prison.

Biggs has told the Sun of his desire to have a pint of beer in a Margate pub, and on board the plane was reported to be a curry and other reminders of home.

webTitle: My new media interview: Tony Livesey

fields.headline: My new media
fields.standfirst:
Tony Livesey

More internet news
fields.trailText: Interview: Tony Livesey
fields.body:
What are your favourite websites?

Alastair Campbell and me share a passion, and it's not Tony Blair. It's the Burnley FC website (claretflag.com), where I spend half my time insulting Blackburn Rovers fans. All my favourite websites are football related, which is quite sad, but I also like MediaGuardian.co.uk so I can keep track of the impending demise of the Express newspaper.

What was your last online purchase?

A book by James Ellroy from amazon.com. I work in a very rough part of Manchester, so the less time I spend shopping outside the better.

Ever been in a chatroom?

Yes, but only on a professional basis through work. I find that people aren't educated enough to enthral me in a chatroom. In any case, I crave peace and quiet, not chat.

What was your last technological faux pas?

I ordered a £5,000 water feature for the reception area of my office, but it had to be destroyed because water was leaking out of it and nearly blew up our computer system.

What news source do you use on the web?

I'm more of a Teletext man. Most news websites aren't organised enough for me.

What is the most useful website?

ananova.com which puts a lot of Press Association material out, which in turn gives me ideas of what to put in the paper, or not. Generally we like pictures of topless women and football results. Too much news puts the readers off.

What kind of website is least likely to succeed?

Anything without sex or gambling.

What is the least useful site?

purple.com which is just a purple page for people who like purple.

Do you use a screensaver?

Yes, the Burnley Football club badge.

What do you find the most irritating thing about the net?

The time it takes to look at anything. Ultimately that's the problem so I'd just rather watch television. Simple as that.

Do you still use old media?

All the time, but I don't get a lot of pleasure from newspapers because I'm in the business and most of them bore me to tears. There's not enough invention. The Sun is so dull and predictable - if I had half their promotional budget, I'd be selling millions! Nowadays, if newspapers were musicians, they'd be Elton John and Cliff Richard. I'm waiting for punk to arrive.

 Tony Livesey is managing director of Sport Newspapers Ltd which recently launched stripnews.co.uk

webTitle: New media diary

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: And so Sophie Wessex's big dot.com adventure comes to an end - not that she ever devoted much time to it, Diary hears.
fields.body:
 And so Sophie Wessex's big dot.com adventure comes to an end - not that she ever devoted much time to it, Diary hears. It was clearly an accident waiting to happen - if only because Sophie's involvement in 5at6.com, which planned to launch the snappily titled Ladsaway, hinged on her high profile and ability to sweet-talk investors. The rest is history, but Diary learns that Ladsaway got "very close to launching" before being "postponed" because of the Concorde crash in July. Odd reason, but presumably "lads" using the site were to be whisked "away" by Concorde, or something like that. Still, how refreshing in this day and age - when everyone fatuously blames "market conditions" - to hear someone come up with such an original explanation for a dot.com failure.

 The Ministry of Truth has been at work at AOL and Freeserve. First, reports emerged that Freeserve's new marketing maestro, Keith Hawkins, was responsible for the horrendous Connie ads that have plagued our screens for years. Only Diary's spies, who were there at Connie's birth, tell a different story: the blame rests with none other than AOL's UK MD Karen Thompson. Meanwhile, Freeserve's Ajaz Ahmed has spent years hinting that Freeserve was his idea (it was) only to have this contradicted by Freeserve bosses. To set the record straight, Ajaz, who now happens to be leaving Freeserve, started talking about his consumer internet product in 1995 with Packard Bell and Dixons and, according to partners at the time, was the original instigator. Now let that be an end to it all.

 Techies have questioned the 45m page impressions in three weeks claimed by ITV.co.uk's Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? game. Could ITV be using that old trick of confusing hits with impressions? Consider: 1) the site is a bunch of flash movies in a series of frames, which makes it almost impossible to count impressions; and 2) given that 300,000 registered to play, they would have had to play almost every day to rack up an average of 150 page impressions each over the three weeks. Sure, it's feasible - and Diary isn't saying it isn't - but it does stretch the imagination.

 How nice when old colleagues are reunited by acquisitions - as happened last week when Sports.com bought United Business Media's consumer internet albatross, MegaStar, for a knockdown £100,000. Since United spent millions on MegaStar last year, Lord Hollick should be thanking his lucky megastars that he found an exit. Anyhow, the reunion at Sports.com is a Mills and Boon-like tale with Dennis Greene and Brad Rees, former MegaStar men themselves, leading the welcoming party. But rumours of a happy ending are still greatly exaggerated in these uncertain times.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of MediaGuardian.co.uk

webTitle: The death of TV shopping?

fields.headline: Closing time
fields.standfirst: BSkyB is set to close Open, the interactive TV firm, in order to boost its own business. But has the market lost its taste for TV shopping? By  David Teather
fields.trailText: BSkyB is set to close Open, the interactive TV firm, in order to boost its own business. But has the market lost its taste for TV shopping? By David Teather.
fields.body:
It is set to be an anxious few days at the Farringdon Street offices of Open, the interactive television firm. Ever since BSkyB announced its intent last July to take full control of British Interactive Broadcasting, Open's parent company, the writing has been on the wall.

Open has 420 staff, while BSkyB has another couple of hundred working in new media. Open is based in an expensive, swanky central London location, the rest are behind barbed wire in Isleworth. With regulatory approval set to be given for BSkyB to buy its partners out, the broadcaster is planning to announce the inevitable job losses with its third quarter results on Wednesday.

"There was always an integration strategy in place which would naturally mean some rationalisation," said one BSkyB executive.

John Florsheim, managing director of Open, is expected to move across to run a combined Sky interactive operation, neatly brushing aside BSkyB's new media chief John Swingewood, who is to be scapegoat for the broadcaster's disastrous investments in the internet. Swingewood was at home on Friday.

It is difficult to gauge how successful Open has been. BSkyB has been reluctant to divulge figures since a triumphant press release 18 months ago said sales were running at £1m in the run-up to Christmas 1999. At the time of BSkyB's interim results the company said the system had received 650,000 retail orders for its content partners including Domino's Pizza and Woolworths.

Open racked up losses of £116m in the first six months of BSkyB's financial year and analysts expect that to reach £150m in the full year. What BSkyB doesn't break down is how much of those losses come from the operation of Open and how much is from set-top box subsidies - BiB was set up to keep the price of set-top boxes at less than £200.

The Open brand is likely to survive in the short to medium term although the future of the stand alone "walled garden" shopping portal is uncertain. Rivals at the cable companies delight in telling anyone who will listen that Open is in fact closed - an inferior technology offering only a relatively small number of services within a "walled garden". The content partners report mixed results. "Predicting the complete demise of Open is a little premature," says one source. "But that's not to say it will be there forever and it is unlikely to be there in its existing form."

There are rumours that Accenture, the management consultants used by BSkyB, told the company it needed to cut 80% of Open's staff to make it viable.

What is more apparent is that BSkyB had little choice but to take full control of Open. It is buying out Matsushita and HSBC and is in discussions with British Telecom to acquire its 20% stake. As long as Open remained a joint venture, BSkyB was forced to adhere to a non-compete clause, which meant it could not launch interactive services across its other channels - something it needs to do as a matter of urgency.

BSkyB is coming under intense pressure to increase revenues per subscriber. This year the company will have made revenues of some £2bn but will lose around £120m at the pre-tax profit level. Marketing costs are huge in an increasingly competitive market, set-top box subsidies continue and there are fears BSkyB might need to replace them to keep up with new technological developments.

The price of programming rights reached eye watering levels when the company agreed to pay £1.1bn for three years of Premier League football, while Channel 4 pushed Friends and ER to a level even BSkyB was no longer prepared to play at. Audience shares on some of its prime channels continue to fall, with Sky One, denuded of some of its highest rating imports, dropping from 5.3% in multi-channel homes last May to 4.6% in August and just 3.7% in March. It can only be a matter of time before the slide begins to have an impact on advertising revenues.

There is little more to be squeezed from customers in subscription revenues and interactive services are viewed as the new paradigm. BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball has agreed to pay £225m for the 20% held by HSBC and £169m for the 15% stake owned by Matsushita. Taking full control of Open also means BSkyB will bear the full brunt of subsidising set-top boxes on its own balance sheet for the first time. But it will have been deemed worth the cost.

At the interim results in February, Ball outlined aggressive targets to increase the average revenue per subscriber from the current £286 to £400 a year by 2005. Of that increase, Ball said almost half would come from new interactive services. "We have had a big growth period. Now we have to show where the money is," he added.

Services such as email have already started to migrate from the Open channel to other parts of Sky. The Open platform is robust enough to handle e-commerce and the plan is to add an interactive element to a wide base of content. In some cases, that would redirect back to Open, in others to a tailormade site layered behind the show. Viewers will watch the Simpsons and be able to click on an icon in the corner of the screen giving them a chance to buy a Bart mug or Homer tie, Ball enthused at a recent presentation to the City.

The latest service is Sky Movies Active which shows previews of upcoming films. Open's back end technology will allow viewers to buy CDs, videos and DVDs with BSkyB taking a cut. "All they need to do is to get every home to spend an extra £1 a week and they are starting to have a great business," says one analyst.

The bigger opportunity is perceived to be for online betting. Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation owns a 37.5% stake in BSkyB, told a conference recently that he expected the broadcaster to generate £700m a year from online betting by 2005. Plans for Sports Active include email, shopping, betting, news and profiles appearing on a bar on screen.

Much of the difficulty for BSkyB is that models for use of the internet and other interactive services are in a constant state of flux.

Some of BSkyB's deals in the internet only give grist to Murdoch's cycnicism about the business model of new media. The acquisition of Sports Internet, endorsed by the BSkyB board, for more than £300m is the prime example. Analysts value the company today at little more than £10m.

Some of the early enthusiasm among investors for TV shopping has similarly waned. At the time of the deal to buy Matsushita and HSBC out of Open, some analysts were valuing the business at £2.75bn because of the potential for commerce over the TV set. That valuation has also clearly moved on.

In the meantime stripping out costs where they double up with BSkyB's existing interactive services is the obvious commercial route to take. But the uncertainties at Open have caused a growing sense of resentment. "It's astonishing the way people at Open have been kept in the dark. They've really just been hanging on since July without knowing what would happen," says one former employee. Only a couple of days to go.

webTitle: The libel case with far-reaching implications for the net

fields.headline: Position impossible
fields.standfirst:
Times editor Peter Stothard says a libel case against his paper could result in publications with internet sites facing eternal damnation by the courts

More internet news
fields.trailText: Times editor Peter Stothard says a libel case against his paper could result in publications with internet sites facing eternal damnation by the courts.
fields.body:
The editor of the Guardian, Alan Rusbridger, and I do not agree on everything. But we do agree on one big thing: that talking about your libel actions is only one social step up from talking about your chilblains, your charity work, or your children's prowess on the recorder.

Both of us have fought difficult cases. But, as Rusbridger told readers of the Times last week, most of our fellow journalists see libel cases as some unfortunate disease, one which any of us might catch at any time but which the sensible suffer in silence.

For many reasons the case of the Times v Loutchansky, now on its way to the court of appeal, demands more than the usual media inattention. It is the story of a Russian whom Time magazine once referred to as ... well, I won't give the quote because as a result of our case it would have to worry the Guardian lawyers ... and a newspaper that published what a senior Interpol source said about him.

Under new procedures, the journalistic procedures of the Times were vindicated in front of a high court jury. But a judge rejected the newspaper's claim that it had "qualified privilege", a form of immunity from libel actions, which we were claiming under House of Lords guidelines on the story's public importance and professional handling set out in 1998. Various issues of journalists' rights and duties, including how we publish stories based on security sources who cannot come to the witness box, are now set to be decided by higher courts.

But the case has also raised issues of an immediately practical kind. These affect every newspaper with an internet edition. The archive section of a newspaper's website could now be open to libel actions forever, with no defence being available.

In December 1999, Loutchansky sued the Times over two articles published in print the previous September and October. But a year later he also sued over the continued availability of the articles in the archive of the online edition of the Times. His lawyer argued that, since we had no witnesses able to testify to the truth of the disputed stories, we were not entitled to keep them on the internet edition once we had failed to mount a justification defence.

The first question was a technical matter. A claimant suing on the "hard copy" does not need to prove that anyone read or saw the defamatory material. The action must, however, be brought within the limitation period of one year from the date of original publication. What about internet archive material? Would publication of such material be similarly treated? Could the publisher be sued years after the material was first posted?

The Times argued that the courts in this country should adopt the American "single publication" rule. This says that publication takes place on the day the material is posted on the website. Thereafter, if it remains untouched by the hand of the publisher, there is no subsequent "publication". Thus the limitation period would run out a year after the date on which the material was first posted.

Mr Justice Gray, relying on Duke of Brunswick v Harmer (1849), ruled that the single publication rule could not be introduced in this country. He went on to rule that, provided the claimant could show that someone had read the article, he could bring an action for years to come, regardless of when the original article was posted.

Can even defences that were available on the original day of publication be relied on later? If the original publication enjoyed qualified privilege, should subsequent publications on the internet be protected as well? The judge in our case said no. On each publication the defendants had to show that it had immunity. He rejected our contention that the archive was automatically entitled to have the original privilege. He held that the defence of qualified privilege would have to be made on each occasion that the article was read online.

Thus, even had we won our qualified privilege, we would have lost. This decision places publishers which maintain an archive in an impossible position. If a newspaper, defending a "hard copy" action, failed to justify an article, or if its qualified privilege defence failed, no one would suggest it had to cut out the article from all library copies of the newspaper. But, internet archives would be censored in this manner - unless the defendants could prove the truth of what they published, or a continuing duty on their part to publish and a continuing interest on the part of the public to read the articles. This could mean redefending the allegations years later.

A clearly better course for the law, rather than altering the first draft of history, would be to link any corrections to the relevant web pages. The only other alternative, short of internet publishers employing armies of lawyers to reconsider daily if they are justified in continuing to publish every single item on their websites, is for publishers to stop publishing their full newspaper on the net. The law has taken an enormous backward step.

He held that the defence of qualified privilege would have to be made on each occasion that the article was read online. Thus, even had we won our qualified privilege, we would have lost. This decision places publishers which maintain an archive in an impossible position. If a newspaper, defending a "hard copy" action, failed to justify an article, or if its qualified privilege defence failed, no one would suggest it had to cut out the article from all library copies of the newspaper. But, internet archives would be censored in this manner - unless the defendants could prove the truth of what they published, or a continuing duty on their part to publish and a continuing interest on the part of the public to read the articles. This could mean redefending the allegations years later. A clearly better course for the law, rather than altering the first draft of history, would be to link any corrections to the relevant web pages. The only other alternative, short of internet publishers employing armies of lawyers to reconsider daily if they are justified in continuing to publish every single item on their websites, is for publishers to stop publishing their full newspaper on the net. The law has taken an enormous backward step.

webTitle: Media monkey's diary

fields.headline: Media monkey's diary
fields.trailText: Could Vanni "Three Jobs" Treves, the suave lawyer and Channel 4 chair, be harbouring hopes of succeeding Sir Christopher Bland?
fields.body:
 Could Vanni "Three Jobs" Treves, the suave lawyer and Channel 4 chair, be harbouring hopes of succeeding Sir Christopher Bland? He was taking an uncommonly close interest in the succession process at last week's annual report launch, and was overheard describing front-runner Gavyn Davies's Goldman Sachs reports as impenetrable "rocket science". Treves's first term with Channel 4 expires at the end of this year, and though currently also sorting out Equitable Life he's clearly bitten by the broadcasting bug. His chief executive Michael Jackson, meanwhile, seems very taken with the prospect of Gerry Robinson as BBC chairman. The subtext here? Well, since Robinson booted out Bland and Dyke when Granada took over LWT - leaving the zillionaires even richer but nevertheless resentful - a cosy Dyke/Robinson cohabitation is distinctly unlikely. Which could make Dyke a one-term director-general, opening up an opportunity for the former BBC high-flier to return to the Corporation.

 Interesting complaint from commercial radio following last week's Sony awards, a walkover as usual for the BBC. The judges included three members of the Radio Authority, which is known to be increasingly concerned about computerisation eroding quality. The authority says its members have traditionally been asked to judge, and that judges are also drawn from the BBC. But the difference is that none of them are governors, or act as judge and jury when it comes to handing out new licences or issuing fines. Come to think of it, can't remember seeing an ITC member on the Bafta juries either.

 Soon there'll just be editor Rebecca Hardy and the cleaners left: last week saw Andrew Neil's right-hand-woman Sue Douglas leaving the Scotsman, plus features editor Nicola McCormack and two of her writers.

 Moving up to chairman of TBWA/London last week, former Media Guardian columnist Trevor Beattie said his promotion "sent out a signal that creativity is our top priority". Bad timing, Trev, as it coincided with punters getting their first sighting of TBWA's dire latest posters for the Labour party, for which the agency now run by the man behind the Wonderbra and FCUK ads came up with the astonishingly uninspiring slogan "The work goes on". With a month still to go before the poll, have they run out of ideas already?

 BBC Worldwide boss Rupert Gavin is fed up with Broadcast's coverage of his divergence of opinion with Greg Dyke over the BBC commercial arm's direction. Broadcast says it's a row; he says it isn't. Now Gavin has cancelled all Worldwide's subscriptions, saving £10,000 a year and telling managers "it's not our policy to spend money on drivel". Has he seen Star recently? Luckily, relief is available for Worldwide staff who need their weekly fix of Broadcast - check out MediaGuardian.co.uk's trade press round-up.

 Worldwide staff will of course continue to receive the BBC's staff weekly Ariel, providing them with a far more acceptable perspective on industry developments. Though not exactly an independent one: Monkey hears that the headline ("BBC Listens to Staff") for the "Pravda" report on the Beeb's u-turn on expenses was personally suggested by Dyke, showing that his old local newspaper skills have not deserted him. Nor has his conviction that commercial ways are best - he's rumoured to have moaned in a memo that Pearson's in-house propaganda sheet is much better.

webTitle: Is Jon Gaunt the future of talk radio?

fields.headline: Local hero
fields.standfirst: Is Jon Gaunt the future of talk radio - or just a gobby chancer?  Jason Deans  and  Maggie Brown  take a look at the man who has just walked off with three Sony gongs
fields.trailText: Is Jon Gaunt the future of talk radio - or just a gobby chancer? Jason Deans and Maggie Brown take a look at the man who has just walked off with three Sony gongs.
fields.body:
"Either say I'm the future of British radio or slag me off." This parting shot neatly sums up the speech radio philosophy of Jon Gaunt, the BBC local radio breakfast show host who last week beat off competition from Radio 4 and 5 Live's finest to snatch an unprecedented three Sony Radio Academy Awards.

Gaunty, as he is known to colleagues and listeners, is a 40-year-old working-class lad made good who's not short of an opinion or two. Nor is he afraid to share them with listeners on the BBC Three Counties Radio show he has been presenting for four years.

"This is my opinion - not the BBC's opinion - this is what I think," is his starting point, the Luton-based broadcaster says. "Then I develop things by having guests with opposing views. It's not the kind of radio you find on Radio 4 or 5 Live, where you've got to have balance. I believe you should just open the lines, let people speak, and balance things with other callers."

Gaunt is not everybody's cup of tea. His "just talk about life and yourself" philosophy leads to discussions about everything from his kids' nits to piles and abortion, which he is against. "I'm not a devil's advocate. I'm not like that idiot James Whale, who takes a different stance every night."

He has been up before the broadcasting standards commission five times, with three complaints upheld, including one incident when he threatened to go round to a listener's house with a baseball bat. But three separate Sony juries agreed that the Three Counties Radio coverage of Vauxhall's decision to close its Luton car factory, which he presented in December, was outstanding live radio.

After his BBC colleague Stephen Rhodes had broken the story, on December 12, that Vauxhall was to cease car production in Luton after 95 years, Gaunt was hauled out of a panto rehearsal to present a drive time special in which the phones were thrown open to get the furious local reaction. "I was interviewing Vauxhall UK chairman Nick Reilly and there was an electric moment when this person called in and said: 'You bastard, you betrayed us', and called him a 'Judas'," Gaunt recalls. The next morning, Gaunt hosted his 6am breakfast show from a BBC radio van parked outside the Vauxhall factory gates. Listening to the tape of that broadcast you understand why someone who is not a national name walked off with three Sony golds.

Live radio is a stressful business, where every bungled cue or sloppy question shows. But in the course of this lengthy show, when even regular news bulletins were dropped in favour of a huge local story, Gaunt never missed a beat. He switched between Toby Friedner and Steve Swann, two reporters mingling with the protesters, as if they were in the van with him. He interviewed workers direct, handled phone-in calls and talked to Vauxhall managers. In the course of two hours, furious workers stormed Vauxhall's headquarters and demanded that Reilly address them. The programme's climax is the broadcast of this speech, heckles and all.

At the Sonys last Monday, Gaunt won a gold award in the news broadcaster category, and his programme and production team picked up two more golds in the news coverage, talk and breakfast news categories.

Gaunt says he is "very grateful" to get this industry recognition, but "ambivalent" about it, because "like a lot of great journalism it's based on other people's misery". He also reckons his broadcasting style of letting people speak meant there is a relationship with Three Counties Radio listeners that allowed him and his team to operate at the heart of the action when the Vauxhall story was breaking.

The fact he had "lived a bit" before starting his radio career in 1993 at the age of 31, rather than joining the industry fresh from a media course, is another advantage for a broadcaster, according to Gaunt. Moz Dee, now at BBC Radio 5 Live, gave him his first break. "Moz told me 'Just say something opinionated or controversial. Then the old dears phone up and you either put the phone down or flirt with them'," Gaunt says.

He is no fan of the "polished" packages turned out by BBC Radio 4 and 5 Live. "The BBC is superserving the middle classes. Radio 5 Live should be a tabloid station, serving the masses - they've left local radio to fill the gap." And of BBC Radio 1's Chris Moyles he says: "A prime example of somebody who's on the radio and has got nothing in his head." Gaunt is adamant that he will only consider offers on his own terms. "I'm too old to compromise. But if somebody wants to put the Jon Gaunt Show on a national station, that's fine." So, is he the future of British radio, or a gobby chancer? Let's throw the lines open.

webTitle: Why May Day protestors are spurning the media

fields.headline: Why Wombles won't speak to journalists
fields.standfirst:
May Day proved to many protesters that it's not worth trying to talk to mainstream media - they ignore any agenda but their own. Jessica Hodgson reports

Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: May Day proved to many protesters that it's not worth trying to talk to mainstream media - they ignore any agenda but their own. Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
A couple of weeks ago I got ejected from a meeting of anti-capitalist group the Wombles. My opening gambit, very foolishly, was saying I worked for the Guardian. I may as well have said I worked for Special Branch. The man I approached beamed at me like a beneficent vicar presented with a pot of geraniums by an elderly lady at a flower show and muttered something incomprehensible about journalists, sacks of cement and the bottom of the river Thames. Fearing the worst, I turned to a woman for clarification. "You're all liars," she said.

Following last year's May Day demonstrations, relations between the media and the various organisations and direct action groups that make up what is broadly called the May Day coalition reached their nadir. Images on the front page of every national newspaper of Winston Churchill with his turf Mohican put paid - the protesters claimed - to any remaining illusion of pluralism in the media. From that point on, almost any attempts by the "mainstream" media to contact protest groups have been stonewalled.

If you refuse to play ball with the media, can you expect to get a fair hearing? Many members of the movement argue that whatever they say to the media, the movement will be presented as a bunch of violent anarchists. Guy Taylor, of Globalise Resistance, one of the few groups who do still speak to the media, says the movement has been "stitched up" so many times that the majority of protesters don't bother.

After last year's demonstrations, protest group Reclaim the Streets issued a press release in an attempt to correct what it saw as overly negative media coverage of the event. It pointed out that the media's claim that daubing the Cenotaph with graffiti was an insult to the memories of soldiers in the first world war was misplaced, given that soldiers were in open revolt against the war.

The stance was monstered in the press - some would say predictably - and at that point many anti-capitalist groups threw in the towel and refused to have any dialogue with the media. "It's extremely frustrating," says Taylor, "to spend the whole day talking to the media about third world debt, only to find when you do get hauled in front of a camera you just get asked questions about violence."

Welcome to the real world, say detractors, claiming that any organisation that becomes the subject of media attention has to learn to take the knocks. But the protesters argue that the media are now so used to being spoon-fed stories that journalists have lost the ability to seek out contacts. Emily, a protester with Reclaim the Streets, says the media's reliance on official spokespeople for a dialogue goes to the heart of the problem. "Yes, it is hard to contact the protesters," she says. "But you can do it if you want to badly enough. If journalists are saying they can't do their job because there are no spokesmen, perhaps they should be taking a closer look at how they do their jobs."

Unofficially, journalists working for the main news networks say that violence is always the bottom line in coverage of protests. The BBC's head of newsgathering, Adrian Van Klaveren instructed journalists to give equal weight to the protesters' arguments. But one news producer said on the day: "If it all goes off in central London, all the pictures of peaceful protest will go out of the window." ITN and Sky insiders say it's the same story there.

Key to the protesters' strategy of circumventing the mainstream media is a proliferation of new grassroots media organisations that are supportive of the movement. One of the most striking things about the mass incarceration at Oxford Circus on May Day was the number of people carrying cameras, both stills and video. Much of the material will appear on websites such as Squall, Schnews and Indymedia, which show video and carry reports sympathetic to the protest. Protesters claim that journalists from these alternative news sources are excluded from police briefings.

Jim Carey, who works for Squall, says that the pro-protester bias in these sites is a legitimate antidote to the negativity in the mainstream media. "The media works properly when it's putting opposing cases to the viewer/listener as the jury," he says. "But the supporters of capitalism are widespread and the opposing case is not stated. So yes, some alternative media are less pluralist than the true ideal."

Globalise Resistance's Taylor agrees. "You can't avoid the mainstream media," he says. "If you've gone to the bother of seeking out the alternative voices you will already have heard the corporate media perspective, so it's not like there's a danger that it's going to be extinguished."

Many of the protesters think May Day 2001 was something of a watershed in the media's attitude towards anti-capitalism protests. Although the vast majority of papers led either on violence or on the police's "successful" containment, there were cracks in the edifice. Reclaim the Streets' Emily said lots of the TV news bulletins - faced with little violence - were left with enduring images of overzealous police with riot shields.

As journalist John Pilger put it: "These demonstrations on May Day are a demonstration of the worldwide outrage at the widening gulf between the rich and the poor, euphemistically called globalisation and to simply be reporting the hype of the Metropolitan police and a few politicians climbing on to their bandwagon is unbecoming to true journalists."

For many journalists the discrepancies last Tuesday between the endless cliches about violent anarchists and dogs on strings and the reality - of several thousand people from all walks of life held against their will for seven hours by riot police - must have been painfully apparent. If watching a Dalek-like policeman tell two schoolgirls that they couldn't leave the enclosure to use the toilet didn't do it, surely there's no hope for us.
