webTitle: Sitcom writer on taking it to America

fields.headline: A player - for a week
fields.standfirst: Sell a sitcom to the US TV networks and you'll probably never have to work again. CBS liked a comedy called Blind Men - originally broadcast by ITV - enough to make a pilot show. Writer  Chris England flew to Los Angeles to watch his baby acquire a US accent
fields.trailText: Sell a sitcom to the US TV networks and you'll probably never have to work again. CBS liked a comedy called Blind Men - originally broadcast by ITV - enough to make a pilot show. Writer Chris England flew to Los Angeles to watch his baby acquire a US accent.
fields.body:
A couple of months ago I got a phone call out of the blue from a man I had never met. He told me that the US network CBS had commissioned a pilot of an American version of a sitcom I wrote four years ago. It was a bit like getting a call from a complete stranger saying: "You don't know me, but I've taken the liberty of buying you a lottery ticket. I'll let you know if you win anything ..."

My sitcom was called Blind Men. It was about the rivalry between two extremely competitive interior furnishings salesmen and it ran for one series on ITV. The cast were uniformly excellent, with Jeremy Swift and Sophie Thompson especially splendid, and Granada USA have used the tapes of their performances to sell the show to CBS.

Sitcoms in the US are the big moneymakers. Once a show has played on one of the major networks for something approaching 100 episodes, it can be sold into syndication and repeated forever, at which point it is worth an absolute fortune. Seinfeld is reputed to have made no less than $1.6bn for NBC in this way.

US television is constructed on an efficient annual cycle. The spring is pilot season, when new shows that are trying to make it on to the fall schedule are tried out. Each network makes around a dozen sitcom pilots, of which maybe three or four will be picked up in May and put into production over the summer. A successful show will run from September to March, then be repeated over the following summer, leading up to the start of a new batch the following fall.

Three years ago Granada USA made a pilot of Blind Men for NBC, which was not picked up, although I did get the opportunity to swank about in Los Angeles pretending to be a player. The prospect of doing so again proved irresistible, so I packed a bag and flew over.

Sunday: I have arrived in LA, but my bag hasn't. It arrives at the hotel seven hours after I do, having been found lodged on the conveyor belt behind the plastic curtain.

Monday: I have a breakfast meeting with Bill and AJ from Granada USA. AJ has been canvassing the executives at CBS, and she is quite positive about Blind Men's chances. Of the 11 pilots commissioned by the network, apparently, only five have so far been cast, so there is a good chance of some of the competition being held over to next year.

One of the other CBS pilots is The Kennedys, an American version of The Royle Family, also being produced by Granada USA. After breakfast Bill goes off to supervise the single-camera filming of this, which is taking place over three days, while AJ takes me to meet the Blind Men people on our set at Studio City.

There are 20 huge sound stages on the lot at CBS Studio Center, and many of them have the logos for successful and long-running series painted large across huge double doors - Spin City, Third Rock From the Sun, Malcolm in the Middle. The streets are named after TV shows, and we drive down Gunsmoke, take a right on the Mary Tyler Moore Show, and park on the New York street set from Seinfeld.

Rehearsals are in progress, and between scenes I meet the director, Will, a friendly veteran of Taxi and WKRP in Cincinnati, and the star, French Stewart from Third Rock.

US TV is a notoriously ruthless environment and the lead character's wife has been recast over the weekend. When I am introduced to the new actress, who is Sherilyn Fenn from Twin Peaks, I am completely unprepared and step backwards in amazement with my mouth open.

The writers, Andrew and Michael, who have reworked my first two episodes into their pilot script, are what is called show-runners, which means they are effectively writing and producing the show, hiring the director, the staff and the cast. They have spent four years as staff writers on Third Rock, and two on Malcolm in the Middle, but this would be their first time in charge.

They are worried about the imminent Writers Guild of America strike, which is due to begin on May 1. If it goes ahead, then the networks may be reluctant to pick up any new shows for their fall schedule, not knowing whether they will be delivered or not. Indeed, CBS has announced that it has a contingency schedule in place, with wall-to-wall reality shows, news magazines and game shows, while NBC has threatened to go with Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, all night every night.

Along with the power of running the show comes the hassle of dealing with the various studio and network executives, each of whom can demand changes to things he or she doesn't get. My own knowledge of what actually goes on in meetings between the writers and the network is limited. Three years ago, on the NBC pilot, I did try to sit in on a script conference, as an observer, but the head of the network pointed at me and demanded that I leave. Not least amongst the pleasures of this trip was discovering that this fellow was sacked recently, and is now unable to "get lunch in this town".

Tuesday: I drive up from Santa Monica to Studio City, and sit in on the rehearsals. Today they are doing what is called "block and shoot". They will stage a scene for the four film cameras, and then shoot it just to have it in the can as a safety measure, in case there is a disaster on the audience night. Not that they are anticipating one, particularly, but there have been power cuts all over LA recently, and the major electricity utility has just declared itself bankrupt after dividing $50m-worth of assets among its own executives.

I sit at the back of the audience seating for a while, goggling at the sheer opulence of the production. There is a huge fancy set for the showroom where the blinds salesmen work, another huge home set for the Stewart and Fenn characters, and round the corner a living room for a customer visit scene.

A woman comes over and asks if I am an extra. When I say no she suddenly claps her hands to her face and squeals: "Oh, my God! You're the creator!"

The cast are blocked through their moves, then allowed to retire to their dressing rooms to relax while the camera moves are plotted. Each character has a stand-in, an out-of-work actor - not exactly in short supply in LA - who takes up position with a sign around his neck saying who he's meant to be, and a sullen resentful look on his face that says: "I could do this. I should be doing this."

I watch all this going on - the budget, I'm told, is $2m, enough to make 10 Blind Men episodes in the UK. To think that if it wasn't for me none of this would be here.

Dinner at an old friend's house, and we watch Who Wants to be a Millionaire?. They have started increasing the big prize by $10,000 every time someone fails to win it, so we are able to watch some milk-bottle-shouldered mummy's boy walk off with $2,180,000.

Wednesday: The audience recording. It is commonplace here for a show to be recorded in front of a studio audience, which will be released at around 10.30pm. Then the network and studio executives can give their notes about things they didn't like, and the actors can be brought back for retakes, new reaction shots, new lines and even new scenes, for as long as it takes. We hear a rumour that another pilot's recording went so badly last night that the writers started completely rewriting the script at midnight, and were still taping retakes at 7am.

By the time the audience are let in, Will has a whole non-audience version of the show in the can from yesterday and today's "block and shoot". During the evening he will have four film cameras recording every second, so no glances, takes, lines or looks will go astray.

A warm-up man, from the "What's your name, where are you from?" school, starts to build the atmosphere, and then the show gets under way. Happily the crowd seems to get it straightaway, and it is clear that we have a very strong leading man.

French Stewart has a way of delivering every line as though it's the finest joke he has ever heard, which is quite a knack. The announcement that he had signed to do Blind Men made the front pages of the trades, because it was the first official confirmation of the rumour that Third Rock was ending. He clearly has plenty of fans out there, and is an extremely pleasant bloke, which makes it all the more awful that I keep referring to him, inadvertently, as French Saunders.

The recording ends more or less on time, and the warm-up man calls the cast out for a curtain call. French gets a standing ovation from the Third Rock fan club, which is nice, and then we wait for word from the executive lounge. Mercifully there are no notes from the audience at all, which is either a good sign - that the show was great - or a bad sign - that they've given up on it already. Relief and champagne all round.

Friday: Home safely, with fingers crossed that CBS will like the pilot, and that if so, there is no writers' strike to sabotage its chances of getting on air.

webTitle: Kit manufacturers' media grip on football stars

fields.headline: No logo, no story
fields.standfirst: 'Psssst - wanna quick interview with Giggsy or Coley? No problem, just slip them into this rather attractively designed shirt ...'  Michael Hann  on the iron grip exerted by kit manufacturers over media access to star footballers
fields.trailText: 'Psssst - wanna quick interview with Giggsy or Coley? No problem, just slip them into this rather attractively designed shirt ...' Michael Hann on the iron grip exerted by kit manufacturers over media access to star footballers.
fields.body:
It's strange how events justify decisions one has already made. Not long after I chose to leave the editorship of FourFourTwo magazine, one of my colleagues received a call from a marketing assistant at one of the big multinational sportswear manufacturers. FourFourTwo's profiles of young players were great, he said, and he'd love it if his company could get involved. My colleague asked how. Well, suggested the marketing monkey, what if FourFourTwo notified him whenever the magazine was to interview a player without a kit sponsorship deal? That way he could get down to the interview, give the player a pile of free branded gear to wear in the photoshoot, and slip our writer fifty quid for the favour.

A few days later another of my colleagues took a similar call from an agent. Could we notify him if we ever interviewed any players who didn't have agents? And perhaps we could whisper his name in the player's ear? Again, there would be money in it for us.

Both times the suggestions were refused. And although they involved an almost cartoonish level of spivvery, they both serve to illustrate the perils faced by football magazines. Both, too, made me feel I was getting out at the right time.

For a sector that was once presumed to be a cash cow for publishers, the football titles have had a hard time of it recently. Match of the Day has now published its final issue, an outcome that was inevitable given the BBC's loss of its flagship football programme. Total Football's circulation shows no signs of approaching 30,000 and Future, its publishers, have been facing financial difficulties, so there appears little hope for greater editorial investment. The kids' titles, Match and Shoot, are dying slowly, and even the once mighty Manchester United Magazine has seen its circulation slump.

Only two titles - IPC's World Soccer and Haymarket's FourFourTwo - have withstood the ravages of the market.

The problems have come with increased competition from every section of the media. When FourFourTwo launched after the 1994 World Cup, the newspapers carried a fraction of the football coverage they now run, Sky Sports was still a minority interest channel and football websites were just an idea some technogeeks were kicking around. FourFourTwo, in that environment, had no difficulty attracting readers and offering them something they could not find elsewhere.

Increased competition, however, upped the ante for magazines. If punters could read interviews with footballers on websites and in newspapers, or watch more of them on television, why would they bother reading magazines?

At the same time, the transformation of footballers from sportsmen to celebrities was taking place. Players who were paid extraordinary amounts of money, who went to nightclubs with glamour models, who were cossetted and mollycoddled by clubs eager to hang on to their principal assets, stopped seeing the need to do anything so demeaning as talking to a magazine.

Which was where the kit manufacturers came in. Nowadays, if a football magazine wants an interview with any reasonably big name footballer, the journalists does not phone the club. He will not even bother with the agent. He goes straight for whoever makes that player's boots. You want to interview Ryan Giggs? You phone up Reebok and ask if it can set up an interview. Yes, it will be a five-page interview, yes, you will be sending along a photographer. And when you turn up a representative of Reebok will be there, bearing armfuls of ostentatiously branded clothes for Ryan to wear. And when the feature appears in the magazine, there will be three large pictures of Ryan wearing those clothes - and the quid pro quo is that the maker's logos must be visible.

I don't blame the kit makers. They are doing football magazines a favour. The best young footballers expect to be paid for virtually all media duties. They are not musicians with an album to promote or actors with a film to plug. They are sportsmen with little to say and even less interest in the questions being put to them. Interviews are a chore, and if there is no benefit from them, why do them? The kit makers supply the benefit by signing up players to sponsorship deals. In return for a sizable sum of money, the players make themselves available for a few days of promotional duties each year. Those duties encompass magazine interviews, product launches and the production of print and TV advertisements.

To get the big stars, however, a magazine might have to give up more than it wants to. Maybe, in return for the star, you might have to agree to a piece with some other young no-mark whom the company sponsors. And Diadora, for example, had a brief phase of demanding layout approval, in order to ensure their logos were given due prominence.

Even TV has suffered as the process of securing interviews has become more dependent on the middle men. Though the post-match interviews remain logo free, the one-on-one chats for BBC's Football Focus and ITV's On The Ball are often now set up by kit manufacturers. That's why you'll see players on TV with logoed baseball caps pulled low over their eyes. It's for the money, not the style.

That, of course, creates problems for the producers. One source at BBC Sport told me he and his colleagues were well aware they were breaking all sorts of BBC rules every time they broadcast interviews set up by a kit maker, but what could they do? It was break the rules or miss the interview, and given that choice they were happy to break the rules and carry what amounts to free advertising on the BBC.

Sports features programmes suffer the worst from the dependence on sponsors. Take Alan Hansen's various one-off shows on footballers. Did you see Football's Foreign Legion, with Leeds United's Harry Kewell wandering about in Adidas gear? Unsurprising, really, given that he was interviewed at the Adidas headquarters outside Manchester. Or perhaps you saw the trailer for Football Millionaires, which featured Andy Cole, clad head to toe in Nike kit - not his Manchester United strip - dribbling a Nike ball round some posts. That amounted to a free primetime TV ad for Nike on BBC. Which is exactly what Nike would have wanted when they agreed to supply Cole to the BBC.

But even when the kit companies have delivered the players, agents can still almost destroy the interview. The cover story of my first edition of FourFourTwo featured Cole and Dwight Yorke together, talking about their partnership at United. Cole's agency, Paul Stretford's Pro-Active Sports Management, faxed through a form - after Nike had set up the interview - demanding copy approval. I amended the form to grant quote approval and returned it (many agents like to see quotes, not to interfere with editorial comment, but to ensure their client has not in a moment of weakness accused his club manager of being a rent boy, or a tactical halfwit).

I heard nothing more about the request until several days after the interview had been conducted and written up, shortly before it was due to go to press, and even then the call did not come from Stretford (whose company is shortly to float on the stock market). One of FourFourTwo's Nike contacts called up, in a state of high panic, saying Stretford was furious he had not seen the full copy. Nike did not threaten the magazine. In fact, all those I spoke to at the company were desperately apologetic about the affair. But its representative made it clear Nike would greatly prefer us to send Stretford the copy, and FourFourTwo could not afford to alienate the world's most powerful sportswear manufacturer. So I swallowed my pride and phoned Pro-Active, where one of Stretford's assistants (at no point in the following days would Stretford speak to me directly) demanded the full text. Once we had sent off the copy, the demands began; and we had to accede, or lose our cover story with two days until press day and no replacement to hand.

We were to delete all references to Cole's difficult early days at United (Andy wanted to put that behind him). We were to delete all references to the fact that successive England managers had not, in football parlance, "fancied" Cole (Andy wanted to put that behind him). We were to delete all references to the rough ride Cole had been given by the media (Andy wanted to put that behind him). We were even asked to change one of Dwight Yorke's quotes. Even Pro-Active were forced to accept that Yorke's agent might not be terribly happy about that. The result was a frankly unbelievable piece about St Andrew Cole of Assisi.

Thank goodness we hadn't also written about what a surly and uncooperative interviewee Cole had been.

There is no way out of this bind. Access to footballers and football is becoming more and more tightly controlled. Although players on their way up and on their way down are usually happy to grant interviews, those players at the zenith of their profession are now even more lofty and inaccessible than Hollywood stars (curiously, this is not the case on the continent. If you want to interview, say, Raul, you just phone up the Real Madrid press office and wait. You might have to wait a few months, but it will happen). Press officers at English clubs are no help; they see their duties as overseeing the distribution of tickets for the press box and saying no to pretty much anything else.

Only when football catches up with the media model of American sport, where journalists are granted formalised and regular access to players, will the British sport media be able to stop giving free advertisements to the likes of Nike, Adidas, Puma, Diadora and the like.

Sadly, our footballers are not grown up enough to let that happen.

 Michael Hann was editor of FourFourTwo from September 1999 to March 2001

I heard nothing more about the request until several days after the interview had been conducted and written up, shortly before it was due to go to press, and even then the call did not come from Stretford (whose company is shortly to float on the stock market). One of FourFourTwo's Nike contacts called up, in a state of high panic, saying Stretford was furious he had not seen the full copy. Nike did not threaten the magazine. In fact, all those I spoke to at the company were desperately apologetic about the affair. But its representative made it clear Nike would greatly prefer us to send Stretford the copy, and FourFourTwo could not afford to alienate the world's most powerful sportswear manufacturer. So I swallowed my pride and phoned Pro-Active, where one of Stretford's assistants (at no point in the following days would Stretford speak to me directly) demanded the full text. Once we had sent off the copy, the demands began; and we had to accede, or lose our cover story with two days until press day and no replacement to hand. We were to delete all references to Cole's difficult early days at United (Andy wanted to put that behind him). We were to delete all references to the fact that successive England managers had not, in football parlance, "fancied" Cole (Andy wanted to put that behind him). We were to delete all references to the rough ride Cole had been given by the media (Andy wanted to put that behind him). We were even asked to change one of Dwight Yorke's quotes. Even Pro-Active were forced to accept that Yorke's agent might not be terribly happy about that. The result was a frankly unbelievable piece about St Andrew Cole of Assisi. Thank goodness we hadn't also written about what a surly and uncooperative interviewee Cole had been. There is no way out of this bind. Access to footballers and football is becoming more and more tightly controlled. Although players on their way up and on their way down are usually happy to grant interviews, those players at the zenith of their profession are now even more lofty and inaccessible than Hollywood stars (curiously, this is not the case on the continent. If you want to interview, say, Raul, you just phone up the Real Madrid press office and wait. You might have to wait a few months, but it will happen). Press officers at English clubs are no help; they see their duties as overseeing the distribution of tickets for the press box and saying no to pretty much anything else. Only when football catches up with the media model of American sport, where journalists are granted formalised and regular access to players, will the British sport media be able to stop giving free advertisements to the likes of Nike, Adidas, Puma, Diadora and the like. Sadly, our footballers are not grown up enough to let that happen.  Michael Hann was editor of FourFourTwo from September 1999 to March 2001

webTitle: Media monitor

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.trailText: For political journalists, the past month's delay posed a serious challenge. With the election campaign put off, how were they going to fill their pages and programmes? They needn't have worried.
fields.body:
The starting gun is about to be fired. For political journalists, the past month's delay posed a serious challenge. With the election campaign put off, how were they going to fill their pages and programmes? They needn't have worried. They were handed on a plate the easiest stories of all - the internal rows.

The final week of the non-campaign began, as the other weeks had done, with trouble for William Hague. Of all the sets of cuttings landing on his desk, few could have been worse than Monday and Tuesday. The tale of the two Ts, Townend and Taylor, following on from the debacle over the Commission for Racial Equality's pledges, ensured that Tory disarray over race dominated, day after day. Most of the broadsheets led on it on Monday, all of them did so on Tuesday. While the two remaining loyal organs, the Mail and the Telegraph, produced supportive leaders, ("William Hague has come through late but splendidly" - Telegraph), the Sun put the boot in, in inimitable fashion, with its "Hague just doesn't get it" editorial.

Most damaging for the Tories, the race row ensured that potentially difficult stories for Labour didn't get going in the way they could have done. There was plenty of scope for damage to Labour. The proposal by Germany's Chancellor for a more federalist European government could have rebounded terribly on our Euro-twitchy government. Instead, no matter how hard some papers tried to keep it going, the story died after 24 hours. The fiasco over Wembley also had only limited political impact, reinforcing the perception that this government isn't very competent in handling grand infrastructure projects. The accusation that Alastair Campbell was single-handedly setting defence policy, in common with other policies, was slightly troublesome. But any problems over spin were, for once, outweighed by the bigger question - should Britain join the US plans for a missile defence shield? And, lastly, sleaze reared its head again, this time Geoffrey Robinson's business dealings being denounced by the Commons standards committee. The papers had a good run with it from Thursday on.

But none of this matched the damage the Tories had inflicted on themselves. As Conservative strategists were lamenting late last week, they had been given a lifeline of five extra weeks to make inroads into Labour's lead, and, according to all the polls, had instead gone backwards.

There is no surer sign that the election is upon us than the fevered response to every opinion poll. During the rest of the parliamentary cycle, psephology is left to the psephologists. But the Sun's Mori survey on Wednesday, predicting a Labour majority of 227, had huge impact. At Millbank Tower, Labour operatives had a good chuckle, before being issued the perennial warning of "no complacency". Over at Tory Central Office some were wondering if the unimaginable actually could happen. Not only was Rupert Murdoch's red top dictating the terms of political engagement, but so was Channel 4's Powerhouse programme, a midget by comparison. Its NOP poll predicted an even bigger landslide.

So much is the result seen as a foregone conclusion, that many lobby hacks - when not feeding on the Tories' little local difficulties - have been looking beyond the election, to the next Labour term. Ministers in line for promotion have been putting their best feet forward - Patricia Hewitt in the FT, Peter Hain in the Times. The Sun carried out its own reshuffle, sidelining "two Jags" Prescott and promoting Lord Macdonald. The Express depicted David Blunkett as a "working class hero" and wondered whether he might not be the next Prime Minister - not the kind of thing Gordon Brown's camp wants to read.

And with all the machinations that come so naturally to numbers 10 and 11 Downing Street, there was no shortage of stories that, perish the thought, appeared to emanate from the chancellor's detractors. On Monday, the Independent put on the basement of its front a report that Brown had told Labour MPs the party would increase its majority - breaking the golden rule of "no complacency" - while the Times said on page two that Blair was making sure his post-election reforms to Whitehall departments would shrink Brown's empire. Meanwhile, Brown was entertaining Rupert Murdoch on Thursday. After the election, Blair versus Brown will be the real battle. Until then, everything is just a skirmish.

webTitle: My media: Lord Taylor of Warwick

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Lord Taylor of Warwick
fields.trailText: Lord Taylor of Warwick.
fields.body:
Newspapers: My staple diet is the Times, the Daily Telegraph, the Daily Mail and the Express. I do read Media Guardian because I used to work at the BBC. Saturday's papers are always disappointing. I don't read tabloids. I want informed information not sensationalist headlines.

Magazines: The best in the world is the Economist. I'll also pick up Hello! and OK! which are escapist and fun. In my youth I loved football magazines, but I don't get them now.

Television: I almost feel physically ill when I see Carol Smillie. Programmes such as Changing Rooms and the Naked Chef drive me mad. The BBC has built these people up as the anointed ones and we have them in everything. As a black person, there is an issue here, because black presenters also want to be on TV. A report showed that black people hardly feature on lifestyle programmes and it's a disgrace.

Radio: The Today programme, which sets the agenda. There's almost no point having the 10 o'clock news - all they do is repeat headlines you heard at 7am. I also like Premier Radio, the Christian station.

Books: Autobiographies of legendary figures such as Abraham Lincoln, John F Kennedy and Nelson Mandela. I had lunch with Mandela and it was the most incredible three hours of my life. I also dip into the Bible every day.

Films: I enjoyed Gladiator and thought it amusing that Russell Crowe was this beefcake hero wearing a skirt. I tend to like old-fashioned films, but hate anything by Tarantino. Pulp Fiction was a disgrace.

Ads: Ferrero Rocher's Ambassador ad was clever, but we are getting too near soft porn with Häagen-Dazs and the Boddingtons one with the cartoon cow.

New media: On average I get 70 emails a day, but this week I've had 200 a day. You've got to utilise it for good and there's a downside - you could spend all your time on the net and not relate to people.

 Lord Taylor of Warwick is a Conservative peer. He has been at the centre of a row with William Hague over comments on race made by Tory MP John Townend.

Interview by Nicola Norton

webTitle: How Richard and Judy got away

fields.headline: Laughing all the way to Channel 4
fields.standfirst: The defection of Richard and Judy to Channel 4 means that daytime will never be the same for a certain group of people - ITV execs.  Janine Gibson  and  Matt Wells  examine how the network could let their biggest bankers slip through the net
fields.trailText: The defection of Richard and Judy to Channel 4 means that daytime will never be the same for a certain group of people - ITV execs. Janine Gibson and Matt Wells examine how the network could let their biggest bankers slip through the net.
fields.body:
Richard promised not to dress up as Ali G and Judy insisted she would not be investing in a wardrobe of leather, but the mere appearance of the king and queen of daytime television at Channel 4's Horseferry Road headquarters on Friday was enough to send the sales of smelling salts soaring. Never in the short history of television has there been a defection quite as dramatic as the departure of Richard and Judy from ITV.

The husband-and-wife team have been responsible for the import of a US format that critics said would never work in Britain, turned it into a ratings-winning phenomenon, and spearheaded ITV's drive to dominate the daytime schedule with the number one show for 13 years.

Now, with its afternoon performance in freefall and without Richard and Judy winning the morning, the prospects for ITV look bleak.

As the news swept the industry on Friday, the enormity of the situation sank in. How had ITV and the show's producers at Granada let their two biggest live television stars slip through their fingers when the alarm bells started to ring at the beginning of the year? In February, a carefully sourced story in the Sunday People revealed that the pair were in negotiations with Sky and the BBC about a possible deal. The story was never denied, yet it seems that Granada and ITV were powerless to keep the couple.

The Sky deal collapsed with the departure of the programming chief David Bergg - indeed, there are informed suggestions that it may even have been the cause of his departure - and the the BBC never seriously considered poaching them.

But no one reckoned on the nuclear option, and in a clandestine week of negotiations that did not even involve the couple's agent, Madeley and Finnigan concluded a deal with Channel 4 that took their employers completely by surprise.

In another blow for Granada and ITV, the couple confirmed at the Horseferry Road press conference that they had never even considered staying with Granada beyond the end of their contract in July. In the space of a few hours, ITV had lost the linchpin of its daytime schedule, and a frantic search for replacements began. "It's just careless," said Jane Lush, the gleeful controller of daytime at the BBC.

But while the ITV network and Granada put brave faces on their loss, recriminations began almost as soon as the announcement was made. Madeley and Finnigan publicly stated that money was not the motive for their move, so questions turned to their relationship with their bosses at ITV and Granada. Madeley denounced the stories as "crap", and said the couple enjoyed a close personal relationship with ITV executives such as David Liddiment. Pointedly, he did not mention the controller of daytime programmes at the network centre, Maureen Duffy.

The leopard-print and leather wearing ex-BBC marketing executive has been causing ructions with ITV's daytime schedule since arriving last year. Focus group research showed that Loose Women, the title of ITV's daily chat show fronted by Kaye Adams, was mildly offensive to some women. Instead of sticking with the title, which matched the show's irreverent style, she decided it should be changed to the anodyne Live Talk.

The first sign of trouble at This Morning was her insistence on a revamp of its title sequence, a move which went down badly with the presenters. She had a tough act to follow - her predecessor Dianne Nelmes was the couple's first producer and enjoyed a close working relationship with them. Whenever Madeley and Finnigan have thrown a wobbler behind the scenes - and the tales of tearful former researchers testify to a stormy history - Nelmes was always able to make peace.

But from the moment Duffy arrived at ITV, say those close to the show, she has attempted to assert "micro-management control." Madeley and Finnigan are not known to accept changes quietly: "It has been a constant battle with Maureen," said one member of the programme's staff. Complaints were circulating as early as Judy's appearance at the National Television Awards - when she won the hearts of the nation all over again by revealing a rather grey M&S bra underneath her glamorous halter neck gown. Behind the scenes, executives were murmuring about Duffy's insistence on researching every aspect of a 13-year-old programme with focus groups.

Sources say she has waged a six-month campaign to split the pair up onscreen, arguing that they would be better deployed presenting the show's disparate items separately. This strategy angered many on This Morning, who believed the bickering and flirting of a married couple was the secret of their success.

But tensions came to a head recently with This Morning's big competition. Madeley and Finnigan, who are closely involved in the development of editorial ideas for the show, had come up with the idea of offering a dream seaside retreat as a prize. Duffy disagreed, and insisted a town house in Birmingham would appeal more to the programme's viewers. The presenters, apparently, were livid.

David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, was placed in an awkward situation. As a former Granada chief, he oversaw the development of the programme and was ultimately responsible for soothing the bruised egos of the high-maintenance stars. But he was also responsible for bringing Duffy to ITV, and feels a strong sense of personal loyalty to the daytime controller.

So when he entertained Madeley and Finnigan recently, he attempted to assure them they were loved and appreciated. But Liddiment was not the problem: they were at war with Duffy and he was unable to negotiate a truce.

Duffy had been determined to play hard ball with the pair: in talks over the renewal of Granada's contract to produce This Morning (due to start in the autumn), she refused to offer a deal for more than a year, determined to keep them under her thumb.

Enter Amanda Ross, whose production company Cactus makes the Soap Awards for ITV, which is presented by Madeley and Finnigan. Ross had already been in discussions with Jo McGrath, Channel 4's daytime commissioner, who said she wanted to develop a new entertainment and chat programme to compete with BBC2's The Weakest Link in the early evenings. Knowing that Madeley and Finnigan were unhappy at ITV, Ross suggested the couple would be the perfect presenters.

Unknown to ITV, Madeley and Finnigan had also taken their frustrations elsewhere: besides Sky, tentative feelers had been put out to the BBC. Chrysalis - which owns Cactus - is said to have approached Greg Dyke directly to gauge the corporation's interest in a big money transfer. Ross denies that any formal proposal was made: whatever happened, Lush passed on the pair, probably fearing a repeat of the Vanessa Feltz debacle when BBC1 found itself locked into a multi-year contract costing millions with another former ITV daytime star.

Ross's negotiations with Channel 4 began in earnest only last Monday. Finnigan and Madeley, who net £1.5m between them for their ITV show, settled on a similar fee from Channel 4 but will also receive a cut of the new show's production budget. It was a deal negotiated without their agent, Annie Sweetbaum, who was still in the south of France on Friday.

Madeley and Finnigan appeared in the office of Grant Mansfield, Granada's director of programmes, on Friday morning to break the news. Granada Media chairman Charles Allen, chief executive Steve Morrison and programme editor Karen Smith received faxes. Finnigan became emotional in Mansfield's office and began to cry. "Do you think we're doing the right thing?" she asked him. Mansfield's reply goes unrecorded.

Channel 4 insists that Madeley and Finnigan are the right choice for the channel. There is speculation that they want to boost their troublesome 5pm slot, which is performing dismally against Ready, Steady, Cook and the Weakest Link on BBC2. But Lush believes her Channel 4 counterpart, Jo McGrath, has made a big mistake. "I'm not surprised that Richard and Judy have left ITV, but I am astonished that Channel 4 thought they were an appropriate booking," she said.

For Granada, the loss of Richard and Judy is far more significant than the end of a 13-year relationship. Along with Coronation Street, This Morning is a company flagship. A two-hour programme, five days a week which has consistently won its slot for over a decade is a huge business in itself - the contract is worth £8m a year to the company.

ITV sources suggest that Duffy rang Granada on Friday to assure the nervous executives that This Morning had been recomissioned for the year through to 2002. But she and Liddiment have not yet discussed the long-term future of the programme. "It seems impossible that This Morning can survive without Richard and Judy," said a senior ITV source on Friday. "So the slot might have to be put out to tender. If Granada loses that contract it'll be the biggest pitch British television has ever seen."

The show's demise would leave ITV with a gaping hole in its schedule, but would blow a crater in Granada's bank balance. The advertising revenue attracted by a slot-winning show is Granada's bottom line.

Either way, the confusion shows how urgently ITV needs to act as one united force. Granada's top executives will not suffer being held over a barrel because of a breakdown in relations between its stars and the network centre for much longer. Neither should the network be reduced to blaming the producers for losing their talent. Honestly, it's the kind of behaviour you expect from the BBC.

"So the slot might have to be put out to tender. If Granada loses that contract it'll be the biggest pitch British television has ever seen." The show's demise would leave ITV with a gaping hole in its schedule, but would blow a crater in Granada's bank balance. The advertising revenue attracted by a slot-winning show is Granada's bottom line. Either way, the confusion shows how urgently ITV needs to act as one united force. Granada's top executives will not suffer being held over a barrel because of a breakdown in relations between its stars and the network centre for much longer. Neither should the network be reduced to blaming the producers for losing their talent. Honestly, it's the kind of behaviour you expect from the BBC.

webTitle: Eta kills regional leader of ruling party

fields.headline: Eta kills regional leader of ruling party
fields.trailText: Gunmen from the Basque separatist group Eta were last night being blamed for the killing of Manuel Jimenez, regional leader of the Popular party of the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, in the north-eastern Spanish city of Zaragoza.
fields.body:
Gunmen from the Basque separatist group Eta were last night being blamed for the killing of Manuel Jimenez, regional leader of the Popular party of the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, in the north-eastern Spanish city of Zaragoza.

Jimenez, 53, was gunned down as he walked to the football stadium in Zaragoza to watch a match. He was president of the centre-right Popular party (PP) in the Aragon region.

He was shot in the head twice by a gunman who fled on foot. Radio reports last night said the killing had been witnessed by his 16-year-old son, who was with him.

Eyewitnesses said a man of about 25, with long hair and a baseball hat, had fired the shots at point blank range. The assassin was accompanied by a young woman.

Cartridge shells from a 9mm pistol, the weapon usually used by Eta gunmen, were found nearby, police said.

Jimenez became the twelfth PP politician to be killed by Eta since it began a campaign against its officials six years ago.

That campaign has been intensified since Eta called off a 16-month ceasefire in December 1999. It has been extended to Socialist politicians, academics, journalists and prominent opponents of Eta.

The group has been blamed for 25 deaths in shootings and bomb attacks since the end of the ceasefire. The latest killing comes a week before regional elections are due to be held for the parliament in the northern Basque country.

Mr Aznar's PP hopes to wrest control of the regional government from the Basque Nationalist Party, which it accuses of being soft on separatists.

An opinion poll in yesterday's edition of the newspaper El Pais showed that the PP in the Basque country, which is led by the former interior minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja, is close to achieving enough votes to govern in coalition with the Socialists. Mr Mayor Oreja opposes negotiations with Eta.

webTitle: Son of samba

fields.headline: Son of samba
fields.standfirst: We've had their footballers and their supermodels. Now get ready for Brazil's DJs. Dom Phillips meets Sao Paolo's drum'n'bass posse
fields.trailText: We've had their footballers and their supermodels. Now get ready for Brazil's DJs. Dom Phillips meets Sao Paolo's drum'n'bass posse.
fields.body:
If it wasn't for the racetrack, Interlagos would just be another run down, dangerous suburb in Sao Paolo.

It's here that David Coulthard recently stole formula one victory, though the course is apparently unpopular with drivers, worried about the city's reputation for violence.

Tonight the fast engines have been usurped by the high-speed rhythms of electronic dance music for Skol Beats, a touring dance party that climaxes here after two nights in Curitiba and Rio de Janeiro.

Half a dozen marquees are packed with 20,000 or so people. Sub-genres such as trance and house get a big tent each and are jammed with white partygoers from Sao Paolo's significant middle class.

But in a huge tent hosted by the London club Movement, it's a different story. Here the faces are mostly brown and black, the clothes a clash of baggy hip-hop gear and futuristic ghetto chic, the music the rapid-fire rhythms and subsonic basslines of London-style drum'n'bass. Sporting Day-Glo dyed hair teased into sci-fi mohawks, pierced faces and flashing neon bracelets, these are the cyberpunks, a clean-living drum'n'bass clan from Sao Paolo's poorest suburbs. "This is a totally local movement," says writer and clubber Henrique Cury. "There's nothing like this in Rio."

Some of the crowd form circles so those skilful enough can dance in the middle, using a combination of moves from breakdancing, jazz and samba. Marcio takes his turn for a lewd courtship routine with a girl. He's on his knees, thrusting. The girl throws a handstand, brushes him dramatically off her hands and struts away.

Adelson is next, flinging his body through contortions. Where European audiences prefer to sway with drum'n'bass, the cyberpunks blur as they keep time with its 160-beats-per-minute drums.

"It's sort of a competition," explains Marcio, 21, grabbing a breather. He works in one of Sao Paolo's street markets. "A street dance," adds Adelson, who folds newspapers for a living. Both come from Suzano, a particularly rough southside suburb.

As the ferocious rhythms subside, a rolling breakbeat anthem that's half samba, half drum'n'bass, bristling with guitar licks and Portuguese chorus, crashes in. The crowd roar. The record, Sambassim, is a collaboration between the Sao Paolo DJ Patife and the Brazilian singer and composer Fernanda Porto. It's one of seven such tracks on the Brasil EP, just released by V Recordings and already causing a commotion on the London drum'n'bass scene, where Patife and his DJ partner Marky Mark have become stars.

According to the veteran DJ Bryan Gee, who runs London's V Recordings: "They've managed to capture the sound of Brazil, the sunshine, without making it too cheesy. This is the next sound for drum'n' bass. We're used to Brazilian footballers and supermodels. It's time to get ready for the first Brazilian DJ stars."

In the past decade acid house has flamed across the planet, but has remained under the control of European and American DJs and producers, with the rest of the world content to ape western clubs and import star DJs. South America is the last frontier for dance music and a key destination for British DJs, with Uruguay's swanky Punta Del Este resort touted as the "new Ibiza".

But the club scene here remains largely the preserve of the young middle classes. In Sao Paolo, though, hardnosed American techno first earned a fanatical following in the deprived suburbs, followed by drum'n'bass, mainly through the efforts of local boys such as Marky Mark (no relation to the Hollywood actor Mark Wahlberg's former rapper pseudonym). "People from high society, they don't go to watch drum'n'bass," says Marcio. His words are echoed by Ramilson Maia, leader of local drum'n'bass act Ram Science, who have just performed in the Movement marquee. "The cyberpunks are discriminated against. They're from the suburbs, they don't have much money and they don't take so many drugs as the trance people, because they can't afford it. It's about the music for them."

Max de Castro is a singer and multi-instrumentalist who collaborates on the Brasil EP. "I think the drum'n'bass beats sound like accelerated samba," he says. "If you start slowing down the beats, you get closer to bossa nova." There are social links, too, between drum'n'bass, born in London's inner-city council estates from a fusion of European hardcore techno, dub reggae and hip-hop, and samba - a combination of African drums, Cuban rhythms and European polka.

One of the first Brazilian musicians to combine syncopated African rhythms with European influences was the mulatta (mixed-race) Francisca "Chiquinha" Hedviges Ganzaga de Amaral, who struggled against all kinds of prejudice. As Gee explains, "This music comes from the underground and the underground is always found in the ghetto."

When Mark first appeared at Movement in London in 1998, his scratching abilities with high-speed drum'n'bass beats astounded people. He DJed like Brazilians play football. "Marky has made a big impact," says Gee. "He's brought a different attitude. DJs like me just go to the decks, cigarette in mouth. Marky is smiling, he's scratching."

The son of a jazz-loving policeman, Mark, 27, is a pioneer for drum'n'bass in Brazil - along with DJ Xerxes, the first producer to use samba licks. His father would have preferred it if he'd joined the police: "He's a little bit rude about it." Mark spent the 1990s building a reputation as Sao Paolo's leading hardcore and drum'n'bass DJ, working in a shop, DJing at a club and now hosting his own radio show.

For Patife, 24, DJing was an escape route from poverty. His wiry frame and rapper-style headscarf stand out in the smart restaurant where we all meet. When he grins, he reveals big braces on his teeth. He comes from one of Sao Paolo's roughest districts, Cidade A Demar.

His parents split when he was young; his mother now works as a cleaner at a tyre factory for £65 a month. Patife went to his first club when he was 11. "I started to work in pizza delivery, and all the money I got, I saved. When I was 13 I bought my first deck. Shit deck." In 1993, he went to a city centre record store where Mark wowed him with early jungle records. "I like the broken beats," he says, clicking out a rhythm with his tongue.

Patife and Mark first came to London in 1997. "It's my first time in London, and me and Patife see Goldie on the street," remembers Marky. "We say, 'Goldie! Goldie! Brazilians!' " Goldie gave them passes to his club Metalheadz, and they also went to Movement. Patife later borrowed the money to fly back to London with videos of their parties, records and flyers to convince Movement to let them franchise its name in Sao Paolo. Edo Van Dyne of Movement flew over to check it out and Mark got a contract straight away.

The release of the Brasil EP is going to up the stakes for Mark and Patife in both London and Sao Paolo. Tracks like the punishingly rhythmic Pra Voce Lembrar from Patife and De Castro take this fusion of urban samba and London jungle into new musical arenas. "It's a fresh flavour," says Mark. "New beats. It's cool."

De Castro is the son of Wilson Simonal, a famous Brazilian crooner of the 1970s, but with his loud shades, dreadlocks and diffident cool, he's clearly not following in his father's footsteps. Last year he released the Samba Raro album on the Trama label which won a critic's prize. "Mixing modern concepts with the best of Brazilian traditional music," he says. De Castro heard drum'n'bass some years ago and sought out DJs such as Mark in the rougher suburban clubs. Porto, 32, comes from the mainstream background of Brazilian popular music.

Classically trained, with a career that encompasses opera, writing soundtracks and playing violin, she first heard drum'n'bass in 1997 and was impressed enough to spend six weeks in London hanging out at drum'n'bass clubs. With her credentials, she is lifting drum'n'bass above the prejudice of the Brazilian critical establishment. "There's no reason why people shouldn't go for drum'n'bass.

It can be totally adapted for our culture," she says. In Sambassim, there's even a rare existential moment for drum'n'bass as she sings: "Is this really samba? Yes it is."

This couldn't have come at a better time for drum'n'bass. Five years ago, jungle, as it was called then, flamed into the mainstream, even hooking in stars such as David Bowie. But its thunder - and, importantly, its female audience - was stolen by the more melodic UK garage scene and drum'n'bass took a sullenly noisy direction. As Gee puts it, "The sex had gone out of the music, the feel-good. It did go up its own arse and get a bit nasty. Even my girlfriend wanted to go to garage parties."

Now Patife and Mark are part of a melodic new direction for the music.

Gee wanders back into the Movement tent, half bottle of Baileys in hand. Patife is on stage DJing, whipping the cyberpunks into a frenzy. Down in the throng, Marcio and Adelson are still dancing. Maybe playing records will join football as an escape strategy from Brazilian poverty. If not, there's always five minutes of glory in the circle. "When you are dancing, people are clapping, it's great," says Marcio. "We can feel like a DJ."

 The Brasil EP is out now on V Recordings.

webTitle: Time to tackle the deficit

fields.headline: Time to tackle the deficit
fields.trailText: Over the next four weeks, you will hear three views of the economy. The Tories will say Gordon Brown has squandered a golden inheritance through overtaxing, overspending and overregulation. The Liberal Democrats will say that far from being a spendthrift, Brown has been a skinflint and damaged the economy by allowing the pound to remain too high. And Labour will say that we've never had it so good.
fields.body:
Over the next four weeks, you will hear three views of the economy. The Tories will say Gordon Brown has squandered a golden inheritance through overtaxing, overspending and overregulation. The Liberal Democrats will say that far from being a spendthrift, Brown has been a skinflint and damaged the economy by allowing the pound to remain too high. And Labour will say that we've never had it so good.

None of this matters. Labour will win because it gives the impression of being relatively competent and the Conservatives give the impression of being a disorganised rabble. Despite what the pundits say, the actual state of the economy tends to be unimportant in deciding the outcomes of elections, and this will be no exception. The economic records of the past two governments have been one long continuum in which there has been steady growth falling unemployment and low inflation.

The Tories were dumped in 1997 because Black Wednesday was a political disaster momentous even by Britain's own egregious standards. Labour has avoided its usual mauling at the hands of the markets by doing very little to the macroeconomy; even independence for the Bank of England was less significant than the adoption of an explicit inflation target after Britain left the exchange rate mechanism.

Labour's record is unspectacular but solid. From 1997 to 2000, the economy grew 2.8% a year on average, slightly above Britain's long-term average. The Conservatives argue that the robust expansion in 1997 was the legacy of their government, and there is some truth in this. On that basis, growth was 2.6% in the three years when Labour's decisions counted. How does that compare with John Major's administration? Badly, say the Tories, because from 1993 to 1997 growth averaged 3.1% a year. But the Conservatives' growth record looks less good when 1992 (the first year of the 1992-7 parliament) is included, as it should be. The economy grew 0.1% in 1992, so the average for 1992-97 is 2.6%, the same as Labour's in the past three years. Moreover, the deep recession of the early 1990s meant the economy had oodles of spare capacity, allowing for rapid growth and rapidly falling unemployment without inflationary pressure.

Labour's record on inflation is good. Measured by the retail prices index excluding mortgages, it is down from 2.8% in May 1997 to 2.1% in 2000, while using the the harmonised index to compare different countries, Britain has the low est inflation rate in Europe. Much will be made of this over the coming weeks, particularly since the expectation that inflation will remain low has driven down long-term interest rates, so that borrowers in Britain are no longer at a disadvantage compared to borrowers in the rest of Europe. When Labour came to power, long-term interest rates were 7% in Britain and 6% in the countries that now make up the eurozone. Last year, the rates were identical at 5.5%. Where the Conservatives do have a point is with their argument that real interest rates - nominal interest rates minus inflation - are higher not lower than they were in the mid-1990s.

The Tories are also right to say that the tax burden is higher now than it was in 1997, but real incomes have been rising, consumer confidence is relatively strong, house prices are going up. The economy is now slowing down pretty rapidly and the data over the next few months - affected by the travails of the US and foot and mouth - will be weak. Even so, Labour will have a second term to deal with some of the problems left over from the first.

One of these is Britain's poor productivity record, explored elsewhere in this section. The real time bomb is the increasingly lopsided state of the economy, with boom in some protected domestic sectors and impending bust in the bits that trade. The chart shows that the problem stems from Britain's over-valued real exchange rate, which adjusts for changes in relative unit labour costs between countries. The exchange rate has been higher for longer than it was during the manufacturing slump of the early 1980s, and what's surprising is not that some parts of industry have been suffering, but that the distress has not been greater.

It may be that industry has been transformed over the past two decades, making it more resilient, and the fact that Britain is increasing its market share of European inward investment suggests that the UK is seen as a good place to do business. Alternatively, it could be the underlying problems caused by the exchange rate have been masked by the buoyancy of global demand and will surface as a result of the global economic slowdown. Already, Britain is losing market share of global exports.

It is tempting at this juncture to point to Germany as a country that has survived and thrived despite having a high real exchange rate, but Germany's sluggish record of the past decade suggests that sooner or later even the most efficient of economies can be hobbled by an overvalued currency, a weakness exacerbated by joining the euro at a rate 20% too high against the French franc.

Britain's recent experience mirrors that of the US. Optimism about the UK meant capital flowed into the country, boosting sterling. A high pound depressed inflation, even at a time of robust domestic demand, leading to lower interest rates. Cheaper money boosted growth prospects, which attracted even more capital. And so it goes on.

Warning signs

The current account is already flashing warnings signals, though it is something of a paradox that the overvaluation of sterling has been greatest against the euro, while the deterioration in the trade figures has been most pronounced against non-EU countries. Britain's deficit in goods is likely to hit £3bn a month before long if further cuts in interest rates add to consumer demand at a time when manufacturing is in recession, and business services and tourism are heading the same way. At some stage, the Bank will be proved right and sterling will fall so that the current account deficit can be reduced. The longer this process is delayed the more painful the adjustment will be. Over the next four weeks, this will not matter. But over the next four years it will.

Much will be made of this over the coming weeks, particularly since the expectation that inflation will remain low has driven down long-term interest rates, so that borrowers in Britain are no longer at a disadvantage compared to borrowers in the rest of Europe. When Labour came to power, long-term interest rates were 7% in Britain and 6% in the countries that now make up the eurozone. Last year, the rates were identical at 5.5%. Where the Conservatives do have a point is with their argument that real interest rates - nominal interest rates minus inflation - are higher not lower than they were in the mid-1990s. The Tories are also right to say that the tax burden is higher now than it was in 1997, but real incomes have been rising, consumer confidence is relatively strong, house prices are going up. The economy is now slowing down pretty rapidly and the data over the next few months - affected by the travails of the US and foot and mouth - will be weak. Even so, Labour will have a second term to deal with some of the problems left over from the first. One of these is Britain's poor productivity record, explored elsewhere in this section. The real time bomb is the increasingly lopsided state of the economy, with boom in some protected domestic sectors and impending bust in the bits that trade. The chart shows that the problem stems from Britain's over-valued real exchange rate, which adjusts for changes in relative unit labour costs between countries. The exchange rate has been higher for longer than it was during the manufacturing slump of the early 1980s, and what's surprising is not that some parts of industry have been suffering, but that the distress has not been greater. It may be that industry has been transformed over the past two decades, making it more resilient, and the fact that Britain is increasing its market share of European inward investment suggests that the UK is seen as a good place to do business. Alternatively, it could be the underlying problems caused by the exchange rate have been masked by the buoyancy of global demand and will surface as a result of the global economic slowdown. Already, Britain is losing market share of global exports. It is tempting at this juncture to point to Germany as a country that has survived and thrived despite having a high real exchange rate, but Germany's sluggish record of the past decade suggests that sooner or later even the most efficient of economies can be hobbled by an overvalued currency, a weakness exacerbated by joining the euro at a rate 20% too high against the French franc. Britain's recent experience mirrors that of the US. Optimism about the UK meant capital flowed into the country, boosting sterling. A high pound depressed inflation, even at a time of robust domestic demand, leading to lower interest rates. Cheaper money boosted growth prospects, which attracted even more capital. And so it goes on. Warning signs The current account is already flashing warnings signals, though it is something of a paradox that the overvaluation of sterling has been greatest against the euro, while the deterioration in the trade figures has been most pronounced against non-EU countries. Britain's deficit in goods is likely to hit £3bn a month before long if further cuts in interest rates add to consumer demand at a time when manufacturing is in recession, and business services and tourism are heading the same way. At some stage, the Bank will be proved right and sterling will fall so that the current account deficit can be reduced. The longer this process is delayed the more painful the adjustment will be. Over the next four weeks, this will not matter. But over the next four years it will. larry.elliott@theguardian.com

webTitle: Israeli raid crosses line drawn by Oslo pact

fields.headline: Israeli raid crosses line drawn by Oslo pact
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Akram Atallah's middle son counted 13 tank shells on the first morning in his new home yesterday.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Beit Jala, West Bank
fields.body:
Akram Atallah's middle son counted 13 tank shells on the first morning in his new home yesterday. The 14th tore through the red-tiled roof, leaving the three-storey building inches deep in water, soot and metal shards.

Yesterday's assault on the Christian town of Beit Jala was the first invasion of Palestinian-ruled territory in the West Bank since these lands near Bethlehem were awarded to Yasser Arafat's control under the Oslo peace accords five years ago.

The tanks roared in just before 8am, pushing several hundred metres into Palestinian land and pounding homes for several hours, as the Israeli government announced that it had freed the army's hand to crush the militias who have fired from here on a road which links Jerusalem to the illegal Jewish settlements to the south.

A militiaman, Mohammed Abayat, was killed in the battle that erupted, and some 20 other Palestinians were hurt, including an 11-year-old girl who was hit in the eye, and a smaller boy whose arm was nearly severed by shrapnel.

As clouds of acrid-smelling smoke rose above Beit Jala, designated under Oslo as Area A, or under full Palestinian control, the Israeli defence minister, Binyamin Ben Eliezer, said the army would no longer be bound by the divisions enshrined by the peace accords. "In principle, I have approved any entry to Area A, if that is necessary to guard our security," he told reporters.

The declaration follows several invasions of Palestinian-ruled areas of Gaza in the past few weeks. Their frequency has rendered such violations routine, and helped blunt international criticism. But there was immediate reaction from the EU yesterday. "We immediately call on Israel to withdraw from Area A," its envoy, Miguel Moratinos, said during a visit to Gaza.

The brief invasion of Beit Jala comes after several days of relative calm. But in the past Palestinian snipers have taken cover in the rocky hills to fire on Route 60, which leads to the southern Jewish settlements, or an illegal enclave abutting Jerusalem, built on land confiscated from Beit Jala.

The Israeli army said the brief invasion was in retaliation for a shooting attack earlier yesterday. But Palestinian officials said the incursion, and Israel's assassination of an Islamic Jihad militant south of Beit Jala on Saturday, had sabotaged local efforts to rein in the militias, or tanzim, in advance of a ceasefire.

"The situation was coming under our control," said Ibrahim Ramadan, the chief of Palestinian preventative security in the Bethlehem district. "For 10 days there was not a single bullet. We stopped because they said there would be a ceasefire agreement, so we told the tanzim: 'We will capture you if anyone shoots.' Nobody shot until yesterday when they killed that man."

Amid the recriminations, Mr Atallah could be sure of one thing. His £100,000 home was in ruins after his family had spent just one night there.

"The Israelis believe that the Palestinians don't deserve nice houses. Only the settlers should be able to build nice houses on the land they occupy from us," he said.

When the first of the three shells to hit their home landed, Mr Atallah took his three sons to shelter under the central stairwell. As Shaban, nine, counted the incoming shells - 30 within earshot - his wife tried to calm the other boys by telling stories.

On the other edge of Beit Jala, the tanks roared up the driveway of the al-Jundi family home, shelling it once and spraying it with machine-gun fire. The Israelis occupied the house, which has a commanding view of Route 60, for about five hours, thrusting the women and 10 children out into a firefight with militia men who left piles of bullet casings at the gate. Then the Israeli soldiers relented and let the al-Jundis shelter in their basement.

Yesterday's surge in violence came as Israel's hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, rejected a call from an international inquiry led by the former US senator, George Mitchell, to stop building Jewish settlements in the West Bank. Palestinians say the illegal settlements are at the core of the conflict.

Meanwhile, an Israeli woman was injured by a bomb placed in a rubbish bin near the central Israeli town of Petah Tikva.

webTitle: Foot and mouth setback over Exmoor cull plan

fields.headline: Foot and mouth setback over Exmoor cull plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: There was another setback to the easing foot and mouth crisis last night when the Ministry of Agriculture announced that livestock on Exmoor would be culled for the first time.
fields.body:
There was another setback to the easing foot and mouth crisis last night when the Ministry of Agriculture announced that livestock on Exmoor would be culled for the first time.

Almost 1,000 cattle on a connected group of farms in Dulverton, within the national park, face slaughter after Maff officials found that they were visited by a farmer at the centre of an outbreak in Wiveliscombe, Somerset, some 15 miles away.

More than a dozen other premises visited by the farmer, Rob Norman, in the past fortnight have also been traced, and some 5,000 livestock are being slaughtered or facing slaughter.

Last night vets were hoping to begin the cull on the farms on Exmoor immediately. "We obviously want to get in there as quickly as possible, but we just don't know exactly when at the moment," a Maff spokeswoman said.

But the owner of the livestock, Guy Thomas-Everard, and his retired father, Christopher, who contracted Mr Norman to do some dehorning, indicated that they would seek an injunction to stop this.

"It is 10 days since Rob Norman was here, and we have had a vet in ourselves and he told us all the animals are healthy," said Mr Thomas-Everard Sr. "We have an excellent solicitor, and we plan to fight this."

Farmers fear that the national park - whose tourist trade has already been seriously hit by restrictions imposed because of the disease - could be further devastated by the epidemic. "Every farmer on the moor is living in fear," said Oliver Edwards, chairman of Somerset National Farmers' Union, who farms in the centre of the moor.

"We thought that with the restrictions being lifted in Somerset the other day we were seeing the light at the end of the tunnel, so this has been a real blow."

A restaurateur, Judy Carless, who recently criticised Tony Blair on a visit to Exmoor for his handling of the crisis and has set up the pressure group Living Exmoor, added: "We had just started reopening roads when this infection came along, and now all the signs have gone up telling people to stay away.

"Everybody is so terrified of what could happen if it reaches open moor."

Elsewhere in Britain, sunshine and mild temperatures brought visitors flocking to areas previously shunned because of the disease.

People headed for the North Yorkshire moors, despite footpaths being closed, while the Yorkshire Dales and Northumberland national park also proved popular.

A spokesman for North Yorkshire moors national park, Mike Pratt, said: "Before this weekend, due to the foot and mouth problems, our visitor numbers were down by about half, but over this weekend it seems as if they are pretty much back to normal.

Ian Stewart, a spokesman for Northumberland national park, said: "The weather has been beautiful, and visitors levels are running at 70% of what they were - which isn't bad, considering."

webTitle: Screening plan after TB outbreak at jail

fields.headline: Screening plan after TB outbreak at jail
fields.standfirst:
Outbreak of TB at prison

Special report: prisons
fields.trailText: Health officials are considering screening all new prisoners for tuberculosis after an outbreak at Pentonville prison affecting 14 people - the first documented instance of the disease at a British jail.
fields.body:
Health officials are considering screening all new prisoners for tuberculosis after an outbreak at Pentonville prison affecting 14 people - the first documented instance of the disease at a British jail.

Seven, possibly eight, patients are thought to have caught TB in the north London prison and the others are believed to be friends, relatives or close social contacts.

Worried prison and health service officials are deciding whether countrywide measures for inmates and prison staff are needed to combat the threat from what is a relatively new strain of TB, resistant to a frontline drug normally used to treat the disease.

Wider checks on the past histories of new TB sufferers outside prison may also be considered, including whether patients have ever been inmates. Pentonville, a men's prison, has introduced screening for TB symptoms in new prisoners, supervision to ensure all those with TB follow treatment and screening of staff.

The outbreak, which started 16 months ago, is smaller than that linked to a Leicester secondary school where 62 cases have been diagnosed. But the issue is extremely sensitive. Jails elsewhere have provided huge breeding grounds for TB. In Russia, many prisoners are almost immune to conventional treatments because of multi-drug resistance.

British officials have stressed there was no comparison between the infrastructure of the health or prison services in Britain and the dilapidated systems in Russia. They also said the Pentonville outbreak only involved resistance to one drug rather than an armoury of treatments.

Those infected with TB spread the germ from their lungs through coughing, sneezing or spitting, but it usually requires close and prolonged contact with others for the disease to spread. Most patients stop being infectious within a couple of weeks of treatment.

The Home Office said: "The prison health policy unit is currently considering issuing further advice to prison service establishments about the care, management and treatment of prisoners with TB in conjunction with policy leads in the Department of Health. Occupational health requirements for staff are currently under review."

Authorities declined to say how many in the Pentonville outbreak were prisoners or staff, or whether women were among those outside the prison who had contracted the disease. The first case was a prisoner diagnosed in January last year, three months after becoming an inmate.

Five of the patients were in the prison for some of the time the first man was likely to be infectious. The onset of their symptoms ranged between two and nine months after contact with this person. Another was diag nosed through tracing the prison contacts of these five, and one was diagnosed when undergoing medical examination for symptoms unrelated to TB.

The outbreak accounts for nearly half the 31 instances of TB resistant to a drug called isoniazid identified in London since the beginning of last year. The first such patient in the capital was only recorded in 1995. There were two in 1998 and 15 in 1999. Three-quarters of the total of 49 are men. Two-thirds were born in Britain, whereas most new cases of TB in London were born abroad, and nearly half of them are white. Their average age is 28.

The total of drug-resistant cases is small compared with the overall number of TB cases in the capital, of which there 2,938 new reports last year, a 38% rise since 1995. But health authorities, who have increased the number of specialist TB nurses at chest clinics, are desperate to stop its spread through high-risk groups, including those in poor housing or dependent on drugs or alcohol.

webTitle: Post Office turns against rail

fields.headline: Post Office turns against rail
fields.standfirst:
'Catastrophically late' first class mail may be moved back to road or air

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The Post Office last night threatened to remove first class mail from rail and put it on the roads or even in the air because of a failure by the rail industry to help deliver millions of first class letters on time.
fields.body:
The Post Office last night threatened to remove first class mail from rail and put it on the roads or even in the air because of a failure by the rail industry to help deliver millions of first class letters on time.

The PO said it would take action unless the situation dramatically improved. Most of the 8m first class letters carried by rail each day are "catastrophically late" and there is little sign of improvement.

The PO said it was in discussions with English, Welsh and Scottish (EWS), the rail freight company which carries the mail, to see what improvements could be made. Of the 59 mail trains which operate each night, 20 or more are running 30 minutes late and miss vital connections with delivery vans for onward transmission to sorting centres.

The PO is under pressure from the industry regulator to improve first class mail deliveries. Last year it only achieved an 89.1% success rate and this year it has been instructed by the regulator to raise its performance to 92.1% or face financial penalties.

Yesterday the PO said: "This situation cannot go on indefinitely." It relies heavily on rail for its rail deliveries and its £50m contract with EWS is one of the most lucrative for the freight company, which is losing millions of pounds a year.

A spokesman for the PO, which has assumed the global name of Consignia, said EWS had consistently defaulted on its contract, which has a further five years to run. The PO could have taken legal action against EWS but has so far refrained from doing so.

The position has been made worse by the impact of the Hatfield rail crash in October last year. The crash paralysed the industry, which has still not fully recovered, but the effect on postal efficiency has been particularly severe.

Even in the 10 months before Hatfield, according to the PO, 95% of its mail trains were running late. Although there has been some improvement in the past few months, its services are still poor.

Its relationship with Railtrack is only beginning to heal after a clash at Christmas when Railtrack announced a closure of part of the network for signalling improvements. This was done without any consultation with the PO, whose services could have been severely restricted for 10 days. Railtrack only relented and restored some access to the PO after a strong protest from the company.

The PO is reluctant to pull out of rail. It has invested £200m in its own rail terminal at Willesden in north London, a hub from which its trains go to all parts of the country. This development had the effect of taking hundreds of PO vans off the roads, particularly in central London.

The Willesden terminal has been supplemented by several regional centres in Bristol, Manchester and Scotland.

Some members of the PO's board want the company to review its commitment to rail and revert to road. But this would require more investment and, with mounting congestion on the roads, might be counter-productive.

EWS admits that its performance has not been good but says it hopes to resolve its difficulties with the PO. It has introduced newer, faster trains to haul the PO's mail fleet at speeds of more than 100mph, but large-scale engineering works by Railtrack do not make them easy to test.
