Railtrack only relented and restored some access to the PO after a strong protest from the company. The PO is reluctant to pull out of rail. It has invested £200m in its own rail terminal at Willesden in north London, a hub from which its trains go to all parts of the country. This development had the effect of taking hundreds of PO vans off the roads, particularly in central London. The Willesden terminal has been supplemented by several regional centres in Bristol, Manchester and Scotland. Some members of the PO's board want the company to review its commitment to rail and revert to road. But this would require more investment and, with mounting congestion on the roads, might be counter-productive. EWS admits that its performance has not been good but says it hopes to resolve its difficulties with the PO. It has introduced newer, faster trains to haul the PO's mail fleet at speeds of more than 100mph, but large-scale engineering works by Railtrack do not make them easy to test.

webTitle: Witness appeal on Anna death inquiry

fields.headline: Witness appeal on Anna death inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Lord Laming, head of a public inquiry into the killing of eight-year-old Anna Climbié, last night appealed for witnesses to provide evidence that could lead to a fundamental overhaul of child protection in England.
fields.body:
Lord Laming, head of a public inquiry into the killing of eight-year-old Anna Climbié, last night appealed for witnesses to provide evidence that could lead to a fundamental overhaul of child protection in England.

In an interview with the Guardian, he opened up the possibility that her murderers might be invited to give public evidence on their perception of the service offered by social workers, doctors and police before her death.

And he disclosed advice from ministers that the girl's death could not be blamed on the misjudgment of individual staff, but looked as if it may have been the result of "a gross failure of the system".

The girl - named in trial reports as Anna, but known to the inquiry as Victoria Climbié - was murdered in London last year after months of abuse went unheeded by staff from the agencies that came into contact with her.

Her aunt, Marie Therese Kouao, 44, and her lover, Carl Manning, 28, were convicted of murder at the Old Bailey in January and jailed for life.

The girl had been brought to the attention of social services three times and was discharged from hospital twice since coming to Britain from the Ivory Coast in 1999. After her death, the marks of 128 separate injuries were found on her body.

Lord Laming, a former chief inspector of social services, said he was heading an unusually complex statutory inquiry into the lessons to be drawn. Although the terms of reference instructed his team to reach conclusions on "how such an event may, as far as possible, be avoided in the future", he would not be able to comment on defects in the system unless they were thrown up by the evidence of this case.

For that reason, he said, he was about to advertise an appeal for witnesses.

webTitle: News: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Labour battle in Hartlepool
fields.body:
Labour battle in Hartlepool

John Booth, who is fighting his former Labour party boss, Peter Mandelson, at the general election, yesterday hit back at his accusations of "sour grapes". Mr Booth, 54, faces expulsion if he opposes Mr Mandelson, the official candidate. Mr Booth intends to campaign in Hartlepool under the banner Genuine Labour.

British pair die in air crash

Rodney Moody, and his daughter, Erica, 25, died in a helicopter crash in Beaune, eastern France, the Foreign Office said last night. Mr Moody, 60, from Marlow, Buckinghamshire, was piloting the helicopter when it came down in bad weather on Saturday.

Ex-minister's bag snatched

Former Tory cabinet minister Sir Norman Fowler had his briefcase snatched on a train as he travelled to a weekend surgery in his Sutton Coldfield constituency surgery, it emerged yesterday. British Transport Police were last night investigating the incident.

North Pole trio break record

Three Britons arrived at the North Pole yesterday after a 56-day trek, having conquered the South Pole last year. Catharine Hartley and Fiona Thornewill are the first women to walk to both poles. Thornewill and her husband, Mike, became the first married couple to reach north and south.

Pet owners' risk of pampering

A survey published yesterday of 1,000 pet owners has revealed that many animal lovers treat their charges like humans by feeding them crisps and take-away meals. Research by pet food firm the Iams Company showed that 40% of owners jeopardize their pets by giving them unhealthy meals.

Two win lottery jackpot

Two people hit Saturday's National Lottery jackpot, each winning £3,814,026. The numbers were 1, 3, 16, 33, 46 47, and the bonus ball was 35. There was no Thunderball winner.

webTitle: Comment: European commission

fields.headline: Red flags flying
fields.standfirst:
Ian Black inside Europe
Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Ian Black inside Europe
fields.body:
No prizes for guessing that there will be some unease at the powwow of European socialist parties in Berlin today after the launch of Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's ambitious ideas about the future of the union - which Tony Blair frankly did not see as part of his own pre-election calendar.

But there is a view in Brussels that Blair has been too obsessively anxious about avoiding European minefields on the road to a second term. Leaving aside the smouldering question of the single currency, his path is clear. Tory central office has been planting lots of red warning flags, sending the shadow cabinet office minister, Andrew Lansley, over on the Eurostar to mark out the dangers. It wasn't very convincing, especially when he talked, though with an impressively straight face, about how William Hague and Francis Maude would be taking a robust Conservative message to the Gothenburg summit in mid-June - just days after their certain triumph at the polls.

Yet real hazards await after the election, especially if the great debate about the future of Europe gets caught up with a euro referendum. It's going to be hard enough to win that argument without getting tangled up in Heath Robinson complexities about the role of council, commission, a second parliamentary chamber, a charter of competences and budgetary powers. When eyes glaze over, those are the kind of Euro-words that do it.

And there are immediate dangers for Blair when the integrationist Belgians take over the EU's rotating presidency in July, with ideas like union-wide taxes and a stronger euro-group (the forum of 12 euro-zone finance minsters), where Gordon Brown - nothing personal, you understand - cannot be welcome.

The Belgians, incidentally, hailed Schröder's thoughts, but disliked those bits that called for some EU powers to repatriated - which went largely unmentioned in the usual "superstate" frenzy in the UK. The French loathed the lot. Hitman Pierre Moscovici, the Keith Vaz of the Quai d'Orsay, was wheeled out to rubbish them, boosting British hopes that talk of the revival of the Franco-German partnership after last December's bust-up at Nice had been exaggerated.

 The Swedes notched up a couple of successes for their presidency last week, when the prime minister, Goran Persson, managed to get North Korea's Kim Jong-il to loosen up, and pushed through a long-awaited EU deal on the sort of freedom of information rules that Scandinavians take for granted.

But they've had a hard time. Their Stockholm summit was a yawn and it was plain rude of the Belgians to launch their own 16-point plan a full two months early. And the Swedes are now seriously worried about how to manage the presence of George Bush at Gothenburg. Inviting him over seemed like a good idea, but with controversy raging over the Son of Star Wars missile defence scheme and the Kyoto global warming pact in shreds, what was planned as a showcase for transatlantic partnership could become a launching pad for embarrassingly public trouble with the Toxic Texan.

 I hadn't realised this before, but Her Majesty now has no fewer than four ambassadors in Brussels, which must say something about the sheer intensity of British engagement at the heart of Europe. Cognoscenti will work out easily that the EU certainly needs one of our top chaps, as does Nato, and of course Belgium.

Resisting the urge to launch a helpfully educational euro-quiz, I can reveal that the latest addition to the team is an affable and thoughtful diplomat who represents HMG on the new political and security committee, a key point in the spaghetti junction of institutions where - with or without Britain's great debate - governments are quietly, and routinely, starting to make foreign and security policy happen in Europe's name.

 Romano Prodi and team were dismayed to learn from the latest "Eurobarometer" poll that a third of European citizens believe most of the EU's budget is spent on buildings, salaries and perks. The drearier truth is that these add up to about 5% and that the vast bulk goes on the common agricultural policy and regional aid.

No one wants to be caricatured and disliked. But shouldn't the Eurocrats have been more concerned by the finding that enlargement -the single biggest project facing the union today - is deeply unpopular, with 50% against it in some countries?

On second thoughts, maybe the commission was right to challenge governments: if they dream up these big and costly ideas, they really must try harder to sell them to their voters.

webTitle: Family of four found dead after shooting at home

fields.headline: Family of four found dead after shooting at home
fields.trailText: Police last night were investigating the deaths of two children and two adults who were found shot dead in their home in Harrow, north-west London.
fields.body:
Police last night were investigating the deaths of two children and two adults who were found shot dead in their home in Harrow, north-west London.

A murder inquiry was launched, but police said they were not looking for anyone in connection with the deaths, which were believed to have followed a domestic dispute.

Officers called to the house yesterday morning found the bodies of a girl and boy of primary school age and of a man and a woman. They recovered a shotgun.

Police were trying to determine the sequence of the shootings, hoping for a hint of the motive behind the tragedy.

Local people gathered in the street, and some were in tears. Some said the family had been thinking of moving to Bournemouth, Dorset.

Mike Roper, 57, a newsagent, said the woman had worked part-time in Sainsbury's at South Ruislip: "She was lovely, often spoke to my wife, because we had thought of moving to Dorset as well.

"She had just bought a dart board from the shop for the boy, and was worried about the darts because she did not want him to come to any harm."

Detective Superintendent Nigel Mawer said police had been called after a friend visited the house and was unable to gain entry. "Formal identification is still awaited, but we believe they are the family resident at the address. A postmortem will be carried out tomorrow morning."

While police did not think anyone else was involved, he was "keeping an open mind".

webTitle: Medical scandals leave trust in doctors unshaken

fields.headline: Medical scandals leave trust in doctors unshaken
fields.trailText: They have suffered from a wealth of recent adverse publicity - from Harold Shipman, the GP-turned-serial-killer, to the Alder Hey organ retention scandal, and the Bristol babies' hearts tragedy.
fields.body:
They have suffered from a wealth of recent adverse publicity - from Harold Shipman, the GP-turned-serial-killer, to the Alder Hey organ retention scandal, and the Bristol babies' hearts tragedy.

Yet doctors are still viewed as the people the public most trust, research has revealed.

The Mori poll - which deliberately drew the public's attention to controversies such as Alder Hey, where some 3,000 childrens' organs were stored without their parents consent - found 89% of the public trust their doctors to tell the truth. This was a rise of 2% on last year when Harold Shipman was found guilty of murdering 15 female patients, and 7% on 1983 when Mori began polling on the issue.

Their trustworthiness rating, which comes as a national audit office (NAO) report revealed the NHS owes £3.9bn in compensation for medical negligence, places them above teachers, on 86%, and judges and the clergy, the latter of which have seen public trust slide from 85% in 1983 to 78%.

The police are trusted by 63% of an increasingly cynical public, but, at 17%, the least trusted of all remain politicians.

Perhaps surprisingly, given the second resignation of former Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson, government ministers are viewed as more trustworthy than back benchers, at 20%, and are seen as more credible than journalists, trusted by 18%.

The research, conducted for the British Medical Association (BMA), drew on interviews with nearly 2,000 people aged 15 and over in England, Scotland and Wales, which took place in late March - before the NAO report, or a hospital audit which last week revealed a third of all cervical cancer cases were undetected.

But the face-to-face interviews did occur against a backdrop of increasingly high-profile media coverage of medical blunders, including the harm wreaked by disgraced gynae cologists Rodney Ledward and Richard Neale, and the recent hospital deaths of 18-year-old Wayne Jowett - who died in February when a junior doctor injected a powerful drug into his spine instead of his vein - and three-year-old Najiyah Hussain, who died in January when a consultant gave her a fatal dose of laughing gas instead of oxygen.

Commenting on the results, which also found 89% of the public were fairly or very satisfied with the way doctors carried out their jobs, the BMA's chairman, Ian Bogle, said they belied fears of a crisis of public confidence in doctors.

"This shows that you should trust the public to make mature judgments based on their own experience," he said. "Patients read about high profile cases and they want action taken against individual bad doctors but they do not make false links between very different kinds of problems and they know that doctors are doing a good job in difficult circumstances.

"Doctors will take great heart from this evidence, and I hope that politicians, commentators and doctors themselves really do absorb the lessons of this poll.

He added: "There is a danger that if you keep saying that public confidence is eroded, it will become a self-fulfilling prophecy. That is not good for patients, for doctors or for the NHS."

% in 1983 2001

Doctors 82 89

Teachers 79 86

TV newsreaders 63 75

Professors n/a 78

Judges 77 78

Clergy 85 78

Scientists n/a 65

Police 61 63

Man on the street 57 52

Pollsters n/a 46

Civil servants 25 43

Union bosses 18 39

Business leaders 25 27

Government ministers 16 20

Journalists 19 18

Politicians 18 17

webTitle: Snack scheme aims to cut NHS wastage

fields.headline: Snack scheme aims to cut NHS wastage
fields.trailText: A 24-hour service of free snacks in NHS hospitals will be launched by ministers this week in a £40m programme to improve the quality of patients' food.
fields.body:
A 24-hour service of free snacks in NHS hospitals will be launched by ministers this week in a £40m programme to improve the quality of patients' food.

Alan Milburn, health secretary, will also unveil recipes for main meals that have been prepared by Loyd Grossman and other celebrity chefs. The minister ordered that meals must be tempting enough to cut the NHS bill for wasted food, which accounts for nearly 10% of its £500m annual culinary budget.

The snackbox service will be provided for patients who do not feel like a main meal or who miss one because of treatment or tests, and for patients arriving at any hour of the day or night when kitchen service is not available.

The choice will be:

 a standard snackbox of fresh fruit, crisps, cheese, butter, crackers, chocolate bar and fruit drink;

 a sandwich snackbox with a choice of white or wholemeal bread sandwiches, yoghurt, fresh fruit and fruit drink;

 a children's snackbox of fromage frais, cheese triangle and breadsticks, fresh fruit, milkshake, chocolate bar and crisps.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said the snackbox service would be "rolled out" to all NHS hospitals in England by the end of the year. It would not be available to patients who had a full meal and still felt peckish.

The NHS provides 300m meals a year at an average cost of £1.67 per meal.

"Our aim is to improve the standard and quality of hospital food. We want patients to have better food with less waste," she said.

 John Hutton, health minister, said Norwood Ravenswood, a leading child and family services charity, will be the preferred bidder to run an adoption register for England and Wales that is due to be launched in July. The register will tackle delays in finding suitable adoptive families for children when a local family cannot be found or the child needs to move away from the area.

webTitle: Comment: email Paul Brown @Tirana

fields.headline: email Paul Brown @Tirana
fields.trailText: There are more Mercedes on the streets of Tirana than any other capital city in Europe but 90% of them are stolen.
fields.body:
There are more Mercedes on the streets of Tirana than any other capital city in Europe but 90% of them are stolen. This illustrates the anarchy that has reigned in Albania since its peculiar brand of Chinese communism lost its iron grip 10 years ago.

Freedom simply got out of hand, the mayor, Edi Rama, says. "Even Mrs Thatcher would have been astonished at our success in embracing capitalism. There is no society. Private property is the only thing that matters. Everything else is not our concern."

The stolen Mercedes arrive daily on a special car ferry from Italy run by the mafia. Since Albania has no method of disposing of old cars, its roads are littered with wrecks. For a country that did not allow private car ownership until 1990 and then had only 20,000 cars, it is an extraordinary transformation.

Officially Albania is a very poor country, but drug trafficking, illegal immigrant networks and prostitution rackets have transformed the economy. Money is pouring in from 700,000 Albanians living and working in Italy, France and Germany. One woman in Tirana told me she had two brothers working in each of these countries and so she had no need to find work at home.

Emigrants, both legal and illegal, sending money home from all over Europe, account for one-third of Albania's annual income. Money laundering from drugs and prostitution adds to the flood of hard currency. All over Albania, mansions are being built by people who have no formal job or declared income.

Not that this helps the mayor much, because few pay any taxes. That's why Tirana has clean western-style houses with televisions and flowers, but outside the front doors are mountains of garbage, floods from blocked drains and potholed roads. Most electricity and water is stolen, and the city has 30,000 illegally built houses. It is hard to believe this is Europe.

Edi insists he is an artist, not a politician, but he likes the challenge that is Tirana. He felt a duty to his home city to stand for election last September on a ticket of trying to bring it back from the brink of disaster. In six months he has made a difference. Lorries daily attack the backlog of uncollected rubbish. Public buildings around the main square have been painted and potholes in the main streets have been filled.

About 100 illegal shops in the city's main park have been bulldozed. The mayor said they caused flooding because they blocked the main untreated sewage outfalls into the river.

The illegal houses are a different matter. Bulldozing is one option, but the threat of doing so is more effective. The mayor will declare a property legal in exchange for a land tax and payment for electricity stolen from the national grid and for water. This way the city's revenue has increased 250% in six months.

But that is only a beginning. Starvation in the countryside, after the collapse of collective farms and of the banks in the pyramid-selling scandal of 1997, led to a rush to the towns. webTitle: FA denies trying to strike secret deal over future of Wembley

fields.headline: FA denies trying to strike secret deal over future of Wembley
fields.standfirst:
Related special report
Wembley
fields.trailText: The Football Association last night gave full support to its chief executive Adam Crozier after he was accused of trying to mislead the public by attempting to secretly negotiate a deal with the government for the financing of the new Wembley stadium.
fields.body:
The Football Association last night gave full support to its chief executive Adam Crozier after he was accused of trying to mislead the public by attempting to secretly negotiate a deal with the government for the financing of the new Wembley stadium.

According to reports, Mr Crozier wrote to Chris Smith, the sports minister, two weeks ago asking the government to underwrite the £660m project and said news of the deal could be kept secret until after the general election to prevent any public or political backlash.

In his letter, Mr Crozier also requested that the government pay an initial £150m towards the Wembley project and £1m a month to maintain its expenses. He wrote: "The FA understands the difficulties the government will face in the political process of coming to a binding agreement but this must be done by May 23, although it can be kept under wraps until after the election."

The letter has caused anger within government circles with officials privately accusing Mr Crozier of gross political naivety and greed. Last week the FA announced that it was not willing to solely fund the construction of a new national stadium, plunging the project into crisis.

Last night the FA said the three-page letter was not an attempt to negotiate a secret deal and that there was no intention of a Wembley cover-up until after the election.

An FA spokesman said: "We have been in constant touch with the government on this issue. We were keen to bring the matter into the public domain ourselves and did so. It's never been our intention to cover anything up or prevent it from becoming publicly known.

"Everyone is aware that we are in a politically sensitive time and that was reflected in the correspondence. We always wanted a decision relatively quickly from the government and urged them to respond before the board meeting on April 26, which happened.

"There was and is no question of keeping anything under wraps. This is just another attempt to divert attention away from the fact that the government should support a national stadium. Adam Crozier has made it clear that people must stop playing politics on this issue and slinging mud at each other. He has called on everyone to work together."

A Downing Street spokesman said: "The whole thing has been completely blown out of proportion. We are not aware that he [Mr Crozier] was suggesting anything remotely improper.

"There's no acrimony between the government and the FA on this issue and the most important thing is to assume a viable way forward."

Meanwhile, officials involved in the project categorically denied reports at the weekend that they had been involved in negotiations to turn the old stadium into a shopping complex if funding for a new stadium could not be secured.

webTitle: West's troubleshooters rush to Macedonia

fields.headline: West's troubleshooters rush to Macedonia
fields.standfirst:
EU and Nato urge government not to ditch dialogue as fighting intensifies

Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: EU and Nato urge government not to ditch dialogue as fighting intensifies
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Nicholas Wood in Slupcane, Macedonia
fields.body:
The European Union sent Javier Solana, its foreign policy chief, to Skopje last night to urge the Macedonian government to try to keep a dangerously escalating situation under control, as fighting between ethnic Albanian rebels and security forces spread yesterday.

Nato's secretary general, Lord Robertson, joins him today as western countries scramble to contain the worsening crisis one of only two former Yugoslav republics to have been spared full-scale conflict.

Mr Solana will travel to Kosovo's capital, Pristina, today to urge its Albanian leaders to distance themselves from their rebel Macedonian kinsmen.

EU foreign ministers meeting in Nykoping, Sweden, urged the Macedonian government not to declare a state of war and to continue the inter-ethnic dialogue it promised with the country's Albanian minority.

Anna Lindh, the Swedish foreign minister, and the EU external relations commissioner, Chris Patten, are to go to the Macedonian capital, Skopje, later in the week to drive home the same message.

Last month the EU signed a landmark "stabilisation and association agreement" with Macedonia which the member states want to use as a carrot to encourage dialogue between Slavs and Albanians. It was the first time in the bloody 10-year history of the break up of Yugoslavia that the EU seemed to have a useful independent role to play.

Helicopter gunships, tanks and mortars were used to pound the villages of Slupcane and Vaksince again yesterday after the expiry of a deadline for civilians to leave the area.

The attack came as the rebels showed no sign of withdrawing from their positions in the north-west, where security forces bombarded them for a fourth day running. A senior rebel chief swore that his men would not leave the region, as rebel units had done near Tetovo more than a month ago when attacked by the army.

"We'll never let Tetovo happen again," said Commander Sokhu, speaking at his headquarters near Slupcane.

The International Committee of the Red Cross expressed serious concern for people living in the area. At least seven people - all civilians according to the rebels - have been killed in fighting since last Thursday.

A government spokesman said two police checkpoints were attacked by gunmen north of the city of Tetovo. Rebel chiefs said their forces clashed with the army near the village of Shatka, close to the Kosovo border, and explosions could be heard miles away.

The ongoing conflict has boosted support in government circles for a declaration of war. The prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, said he hoped the measure would give the security forces a free hand to deal with the crisis. The declaration would allow President Boris Trajkovski to form a new government and effectively rule by decree.

However, observers said that while the idea was being discussed, Mr Trajkovski was per sonally opposed to the move.

The declaration of a state of war would need a two-thirds majority in the Macedonian parliament and would be bitterly opposed by ethnic Albanian MPs, with whom the government has been negotiating to form a new coalition.

In Slupcane, villagers huddled in cellars as the bombardment began after the expiry of the deadline to evacuate.

Surrounded by up to 50 members of his extended family, Alidin Osmani, 50, said villagers had given up listening to the government's deadlines since his cousin, Rumsi Osmani, had been killed. "He was outside on Thursday afternoon and 10 minutes before the deadline was due to expire he was killed by a mortar," Mr Osmani said.

Outside the Osmani home, a stream of dried blood could be seen where he was killed. "They gave us an ultimatum and an hour after announcing it they started shelling us. What kind of ultimatum is that?" he said.

The government claims that the families remaining in the villages are being used as human shields by the rebels, but Mr Osmani said it was the fear of the Macedonian police that was keeping them from leaving the house. "Where can we go. If we go the Macedonians will be waiting for us. They will separate the men from the children," he said. "Here the women are afraid and the children are crying."

Out on the street not a single house was left untouched by the shelling. Two dead horses and a cow lay by the side of the road. The walls were pockmarked and any windows left uncovered were smashed. The fantails of mortar shells lay dotted along the road. One shell had blasted out the side of a house.

A rebel staff car, a Russian jeep with the letters UCK sprayed on its sides, shot by. The guerrillas claim to have 2,000 men in 12 villages around Kumanovo. Rebel checkpoints and bunkers can be seen at the entry to each village. They wear either black or khaki uniforms, all of them with a red badge bearing the group's initials.

Commander Sokhu said his men moved into the area from their bases near the border with Kosovo after the Macedonian army's offensive in Tetovo. Amid all the surrounding destruction and stress on the villagers he said his men could not be blamed for what was happening.

"I don't feel responsible because I'm not shelling the people, I'm trying to protect them," he said.

webTitle: Race divide in US cities gets wider

fields.headline: Race divide in US cities gets wider
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Nearly 40 years after the American civil rights movement brought an end to official racial segregation, children in the United States are growing up in less racially integrated neighbourhoods than they were a decade ago, researchers have found.
fields.body:
Nearly 40 years after the American civil rights movement brought an end to official racial segregation, children in the United States are growing up in less racially integrated neighbourhoods than they were a decade ago, researchers have found.

Last year's census has confirmed that America is now a more multiracial society than at any time in modern history, with non-Hispanic whites now a minority in several major cities.

But researchers at the State University of New York say the same census reveals that American cities are becoming more racially divided than ever, an impression which is difficult to miss in somewhere like Washington.

Over the past decade, cities such as Detroit, Chicago and Milwaukee have all become significantly more segregated than they were in 1990, the researchers found.

The reality today is that young black Americans are growing up in a black America, while young whites are growing up in a white America.

Social integration and even contact between the two races is rare and getting rarer, especially among school-age children. The problem diminishes once young people reach college, where integrated living accomodation is enforced.

Levels of racial segregation are especially marked in urban schools and in the use of urban community services, largely as a result of "white flight" from the cities to the suburbs, the researchers found.

Even when black middle-class parents flee the cities themselves, in search of the same improvements as white people, the result is the creation of largely black suburbs, rather than integrated ones.

The researchers calculated the extent of segregation by comparing census enumeration areas in different cities be tween 1990 and 2000. The results show that the five most segregated cities are, in order: Detroit, Milwaukee, New York, Newark and Chicago.

The most rapid increase in segregation since 1990 has been in Milwaukee, followed by Chicago, Detroit and Birmingham. In Milwaukee, black people now account for about one third of the city's inhabitants, but nearly two-thirds of the pupils in state schools.

"It's white flight and it's increasingly difficult to have any kind of meaningful desegregation or integration," a spokeswoman for the Milwaukee school system said.

The findings underscore the extent to which racial divisions remain an integral aspect of everyday life in modern America, in spite of the progress which has been made in achieving formal equality between the black and white communities over the past 40 years.

"It's a very big problem for white children who may think that they're experiencing diversity in the country, but they are only getting a taste of it," researcher John Logan told the New York Times.

"For minority children, they're growing up in neighbourhoods where they are the majority, and that's not the world they will live in," Mr Logan added.

The researchers found that the return of informal segregation is particularly strong in the northeast and the midwest of the US. But the picture is not uniform nationwide.

In cities such as Seattle and Portland, Oregon, in the northwest, the trend is towards more integrated neighbourhoods.

Several cities in the South - such as Norfolk, Charleston, Augusta, Greenville and Jacksonville - have relatively low levels of segregation, partly because they all have large, integrated military populations.

webTitle: Energis calls for Oftel action

fields.headline: Energis calls for Oftel action
fields.trailText: Telecoms firm Energis yesterday called for urgent action from regulator Oftel after talks with BT aimed at sharing the former monopoly's exchanges to provide high-speed internet connections to customers collapsed, writes John Cassy .
fields.body:
Telecoms firm Energis yesterday called for urgent action from regulator Oftel after talks with BT aimed at sharing the former monopoly's exchanges to provide high-speed internet connections to customers collapsed, writes John Cassy .

Energis blamed BT's reluctance to enter into "genuine negotiation" on a move that would have increased competition.

The talks are thought to have broken down over the wholesale cost at which BT was prepared to sell space to rivals.

Oftel is expected to conduct a market review into BT's pricing proposals which will take about six months to complete.

BT had been given until April 30 to agree terms for digital subscriber line (DSL) interconnection products that analysts expect to make broadband internet access cheaper and more widely available.

Oftel had set the deadline after receiving complaints from Thus and Energis over the proposed charges.

Energis is now thought to be prepared to go head to head with BT by setting up a consortium to lay a network of local connections to customers. It is thought to have held talks with rivals, including Cable & Wireless, about a network that would provide a service to customers and wholesale capacity.

Small and medium sized businesses are expected to be the first big customers once telecoms firms agree terms on widespread broadband roll-out.

Patricia Hewitt, the government's minister for e-commerce, has insisted that strong but fair regulation will speed up the roll out of broadband internet.

webTitle: Indian McAnger

fields.headline: Indian McAnger
fields.standfirst:
Hindus enraged over claims that French fries contain beef

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Hindus enraged over claims that French fries contain beef
fields.body:
McDonald's last night mounted a desperate attempt to salvage its battered reputation in India after protesters ransacked one McDonald's branch and disrupted another following claims that it secretly "laced" its French fries with beef. The company denies the claims.

In scenes reminiscent of the Indian Mutiny, when Indian soldiers revolted against the British after being issued cartridges greased with cow fat, rightwing Hindu demonstrators attacked one McDonald's outlet in Bombay, shouted slogans outside another, and picketed the multinational's Delhi office.

The protesters have called on India's prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee to close down immediately all McDonald's 27 branches in India. One nationalist group yesterday said it was now carrying out laboratory tests on the firm's French fries, and accused McDonald's of offending Hindu sentiments.

"They have betrayed the faith of millions of our countrymen by serving food cooked in beef fat. It is unpardonable," Shanka Gaikar, of the ultra-nationalist Bajrang Dal said. "If they don't close the outlets with immediate effect, we will be forced to take extreme steps," he added.

The row blew up when three vegetarian Hindu Indian businessman living in the United States last week filed a multimillion dollar lawsuit against McDonald's.

They alleged that the company had "fraudulently concealed the existence of beef in its French fries," which are ostensibly cooked only in vegetable oil. In the US, McDonald's appears to have reluctantly conceded that a small amount of beef extract has been used in its chips. But in India, where McDonald's serves neither beef nor pork, local franchise holders have issued denials that their product has in any way been contaminated.

"French fries in India do not contain any beef or any animal extract. We are extremely sensitive to our Indian culture and religion," McDonald's Delhi managing director Vikram Bakshi insisted yesterday.

Since coming to India five years ago, McDonald's has carved out a modest niche for itself serving its flagship Maharajah Mac (made from lamb) and tantalising McAloo Tikki burgers to middle-class customers. The firm recently opened its first drive-through branch, close to the Taj Mahal.

But critics have complained that its products are "expensive", "bad" and "unIndian".

"India has a very ancient food culture. McDonald's will never become part of mass culture here because most people can't afford to eat there," Dr Vandana Shiva, a leading Indian ecologist, complained recently.

Following the demonstrations over the weekend, police in Bombay arrested 30 Hindu activists before later releasing them on bail.

McDonald's yesterday said the protesters had caused £30,000 worth of damage, but said it had now taken "precautions" against further attacks. All branches remained open, it said.

In the US, McDonald's appears to have reluctantly conceded that a small amount of beef extract has been used in its chips. But in India, where McDonald's serves neither beef nor pork, local franchise holders have issued denials that their product has in any way been contaminated. "French fries in India do not contain any beef or any animal extract. We are extremely sensitive to our Indian culture and religion," McDonald's Delhi managing director Vikram Bakshi insisted yesterday. Since coming to India five years ago, McDonald's has carved out a modest niche for itself serving its flagship Maharajah Mac (made from lamb) and tantalising McAloo Tikki burgers to middle-class customers. The firm recently opened its first drive-through branch, close to the Taj Mahal. But critics have complained that its products are "expensive", "bad" and "unIndian". "India has a very ancient food culture. McDonald's will never become part of mass culture here because most people can't afford to eat there," Dr Vandana Shiva, a leading Indian ecologist, complained recently. Following the demonstrations over the weekend, police in Bombay arrested 30 Hindu activists before later releasing them on bail. McDonald's yesterday said the protesters had caused £30,000 worth of damage, but said it had now taken "precautions" against further attacks. All branches remained open, it said.

webTitle: Analysis

fields.headline: Grievances galore
fields.standfirst:
Public petitions are playing a surprisingly large and serious part in the life of the Scottish parliament.

Special report: devolution in Britain
Special report: Scottish parliament
fields.trailText: Public petitions are playing a surprisingly large and serious part in the life of the Scottish parliament.
fields.body:
Devolution was intended to produce a more open and participatory political process. Scotland's parliament was supposed to be the antithesis of Westminster with its remote decision-making and obscure procedure. And, yes, devolution has brought coalition, strong parliamentary committees, open consultation processes in advance of legislation, transparent parliamentary procedures, the creation of a new "civic forum" and the development of electronic democracy through use of the internet. But of all the innovations it has been the growth of a system of public petitions to parliament that has been most surprising.

Most parliaments have some form of petitions process. Indeed Westminster's has been in existence since 1571, and a right to petition the monarch dates from Magna Carta. At Westminster, though, the use of petitions to influence parliamentary activity has long fallen into disuse. Individuals and pressure groups still use the process but must route their petitions through MPs. MPs present them in the Commons briefly, before they disappear into the civil service bureaucracy to await replies from ministers many months later.

The new Scottish system could not be more different, particularly in its impact on the functioning of the parliament. If petitions have no impact on the functioning of Westminster, in Scotland they shape the activities, workload and behaviour of the parliament itself in a variety of ways. Scotland's system is open and accessible. There is a full-time committee of seven members of the Edinburgh parliament responsible for processing petitions, along with a committee clerk. So the process has a permanent and publicly accountable face to it. All petitions are discussed in the petitions committee and then sent to the parliament's subject committees for further discussion. They are all logged on a dedicated website, with titles, dates of progress, debates and outcomes. Petitions can also be sent by email.

The most encouraging thing about the process so far has been its popularity. Essentially, petitions are for little people - individuals and community groups - rather than the large, well-funded pressure groups and lobbying organisations. And, largely, it has been individuals and resource-poor community groups that have used the procedure. Individuals accounted for just over 50% of petitions in the parliament's first year. It has to be acknowledged that many of these are down to Scotland's one-man petitioning machine, a Glasgow pensioner called Frank Harvey. But when his numerous petitions are excluded, individuals account for 42.5%: easily the largest category. The chart shows the breakdown of petitions over the two years of the parliament's life by source.

Among the pressure groups, most are small-scale, local and single issue. The National Farmers Union and Friends of the Earth petitioned the parliament, but these stood alongside such groups as Troon Against Pollution and Save Weymss Ancient Caves Society: hardly the heavyweights of pressure group lobbying.

While process is important, outcomes matter more to whether petitioning works as a democratic device. After all, if the majority of petitions were considered by parliament but no action taken, there would be little point. In fact, out of the 241 petitions formally lodged with the parliament in 1999-2000, most led to some positive form of parliamentary activity. Indeed, 85 petitions - just over a third of the total - led to the parliament's committees actively pursuing the grievance raised.

Thirteen petitions led to the establishment of committee investigations into the issues raised; a further 29 were fed into existing investigations. Two petitions led to debates in the parliament sponsored by committees (one also in volved a major committee investigation); and a further two were subject to half-hour debates by MSPs' motions. Petitioners were not, in other words, fobbed off. Their pleas were debated and often had an impact on parliament itself, with committees picking some up and using them as the basis for inquiries.

Sure enough, there is a Westminsterish element to the petitions, with many sent on to ministers in the Scottish executive or to officials in quangos or to local authorities. However, these are sent with parliamentary authority and are pursued. Committees do not just write off to a minister then forget about it. There is considerable follow-through. Petitioners are kept informed of the minister's response and further discussions and activities may take place following a ministerial reply, sometimes with implications for executive legislation. The situation is the same for quangos and local authorities, with parliamentary committees championing the petitioner's cause with these organisations. Petitions do not just disappear into the system, as happens all too frequently at Westminster.

Overall, the popularity of the petitions process and its impact upon the Scottish parliament has been impressive. Not only have the "right" people used the process, but the committee system of the parliament has taken them seriously and petitioning has become another aspect of the "new politics" now associated with the parliament's work. In a modest way, this very traditional grievance mechanism has begun to restore what has become the missing link between political institutions and citizens. Is Westminster watching?

Peter Lynch and Steven Birrell are at Stirling University

webTitle: Gentlemen prefer spandex

fields.headline: Gentlemen prefer spandex
fields.trailText: Rod Stewart - Wine, Women And Song | Queer And Catholic | Stars In Their Eyes
fields.body:
Do you think I'm sexy? Actually, don't answer that. Not because I don't trust your judgment, but because, as Rod Stewart - Wine, Women And Song (BBC1, Sunday) revealed, it was originally If You Think I'm Sexy but it was changed at the last minute for a reason that wasn't entirely clear. Something about nuance, I think. I doubt Rod was sure either, since the women and the wine (or more accurately, the Bacardi and vodka) were proving quite a distraction for the wee lad. Listen, if Britt Ekland was applying your eye shadow, you'd be preoccupied too.

I never really liked Rod Stewart. Mostly, it was the scary clothes he used to wear. The leopard skin leggings and voluminous acid green shirts, the tight yellow trousers which showed off the contours of his bits far too closely and the scarf round his wrist (which could all too easily get caught in an escalator if he wasn't too careful). Partly my dislike of Rod The Mod was because I had to play Sailing, not a song I liked anyway, on the guitar at school. Not having a musical bone in my body, I couldn't do it and thus my hatred was born. Wine, Women And Song has endeared the old rocker to me slightly. Sailing is still a terrible song, though.

Anyway, this was an interesting, if gentle, biography which traced the life of the world's greatest living English Scotsman from his mum and dad's Highgate newsagents to his big white mansion, complete with library and a drive you can imagine Miss Marple toddling up. The selection of talking heads was judicious and impressive. The Faces added sweet details of life on the road (the band used to check into hotels from which they had been banned as Fleetwood Mac, so no prizes for guessing who was mistaken for Stevie Nicks in the dimly lit reception of a Holiday Inn), while Stewart's siblings provided a distinctly un-rock'n'roll perspective.

Stewart himself was pensive and funny. Still a lovable, if wrinkly, cad, the only blot on his copybook lately is a collaboration with The Corrs. Now there's a weird bunch. Aside from that, it does genuinely seem that some guys have all the luck.

Mark Dowd isn't one of those guys. Queer And Catholic (Channel 4, Saturday), he seems to be a glutton for punishment. For nearly 70 minutes, he wrung his hands and fretted over the crisis at the heart of the Roman Catholic Church: the preaching of homosexuality as an abomination by a clergy some estimate half of whom are gay.

"Homosexuality is a time bomb ticking in the church and it is going to explode", said one of the contributors, a kick-ass nun named Jeannine. "I think it may explode soon." This sounded very messy. It made me wonder how they'll get the gunk off the triptych.

"I still respect my church", Mark confessed. Like, hello? Never mind what the Catholic Church has done to gay people over the centuries, what about their treatment of women and Jews and black people and anyone else it didn't really like the look of? Jesus Christ indeed. If you're that desperate, go join a nice Christian church like the Metropolitan Community Church.

"One of the effects of original sin is that we tend to be blinded to the reality of life and our purpose in life", said the Bishop of East Anglia. "Often, we can go awry, we can go off in the wrong direction because we don't actually see clearly." Well, that certainly explains Stars In Their Eyes (ITV, Saturday) and this, the first of a new series, was a classic.

First through the spangly plywood doors was a Gloria Gaynor who worked in John Lewis. Then came a civil servant who bore such an uncanny resemblance to Pauline Quirke that when he said he was in a tribute band to the person he was being, it seemed clear: he was in Fat Wham! and tonight Matthew, he was going to be George Michael. That he became Sting was altogether unexpected.

A Nottingham estate agent was then transformed into Christina Aguilera; an engineer from Ayrshire became a very good Frank Sinatra; and because there's always one that nobody cares about since they can't remember what the original sounded like, a bloke from Manchester became Johnny Moore of The Drifters. He ended up looking a lot like David Suchet in one of Rod Stewart's tartan suits. Not nice.

webTitle: Radio review

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: Dawn to be wild in nocturnal Newcastle
fields.trailText: Tyneside Dawn
fields.body:
"Sometimes it takes a little explaining," says wildlife enthusiast Chris Watson, with admirable understatement. He is standing in the centre of Newcastle, in the middle of the night, as clubbers spill out on to the streets, surrounded by recording equipment including one of those very long, fluffy microphones. It doesn't take long for the local constabulary to spot him.

"We're making a radio programme," says Watson. "A CD?" says the policeman, revealing a promising future in avant-garde ambient music, perhaps, as a robin chirrups against a drunk, late, mad street soundscape. "No, a radio programme, for International Dawn Chorus Day, on Radio 4. Remember to listen," adds Watson, cheerily. The police back off, quickly.

Yesterday was that day and Watson began all the feathered fun with Tyneside Dawn (Radio 4), a portrait in sound of the nocturnal birdlife in Newcastle. Listening to this at 6.35am, bleary-eyed and clinging to tea, I soon realised that this is the middle of the day to birdsong enthusiasts. At 2.45am, Watson's out in his garden having been woken up by a blackbird: "The song thrush is singing right into the microphone! You can hear the sparrows! One of the frogs in my garden pond's started up!"

But the human interest aspects of all this charming, sweet, nocturnal strangeness weren't touched upon. Do Watson's neighbours watch him as he watches birds? Does he stand out there, thrilling at the sound of baby robins "foodbegging from their parents", like whispering pneumatic drills, in his pyjamas? Do birdsong people even bother with pyjamas? Instead, with Watson back on the streets, we heard blackcaps and willow warblers, skylarks and gulls, all chirruping away in the city, as trains thunder past and cars whizz by.

That's what the whole day of themed programmes gamely tried to capture, the secret worlds of other creatures, including the enthusiasts themselves. It meant lots of bad puns in programme titles (Sound Advice, Up with the Bark, Music to Our Ears) but it also meant some small, joyous moments. Bill Oddie sprinkled dawn choruses from all over the world through the day's schedule - Venezuelan giant otters, American brown thrashers and, my favourite, the Russian marsh frog chorus.

Oddie likes to hear the dawn chorus on Hampstead Heath, not as rarefied an activity as it might sound. He's been attacked by dogs and gets confused by people doing bird impersonations - "quacking like ducks, honking like geese."

Again, the human mystery is as alluring as the birdy one. If it's not Dom Joly, who is out there at 7am, quaking and honking for fun, putting Oddie off? We should be told.

webTitle: TV Pick of the day

fields.headline: TV Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Toy Story | High Society | Pulp Fiction | There's Something About Mary | The Abominable Dr Phibes
fields.body:
Films

Toy Story (John Lasseter, 1995) 10am, 4pm, Disney Channel
The Disney film that signalled a new age of computer-generated animation, courtesy of the cutting-edge Pixar studio. There's more to it than the thrill of the whizz-bang special effects, though: the tale of a boxful of abandoned toys struggling for survival is fast, funny, and thoughtful about issues of friendship and loyalty, particularly in the rivalry between long-time fastest gun in town Woody the cowboy and arrogant upstart astronaut Buzz Lightyear.

High Society (Charles Walters, 1956) 6.55pm, TCM
What a swell party this is. MGM's ebullient musical remake of The Philadelphia Story has a champagne-light Cole Porter score (True Love, Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, and of course, Well Did You Ever?) and slick cast, with Grace Kelly, Frank Sinatra and Bing Crosby.

Pulp Fiction (Quentin Tarantino, 1994) 10pm, FilmFour
Tarantino's follow-up to his stunning debut, Reservoir Dogs, is just as savagely amoral, but funnier. It takes three staples of the thriller genre - the gangster and the boss's wife; the pug's One Last Chance; the lovers' doomed heist - and interweaves them with giddy pace and complexity. The characters are vividly 90s-Runyonesque: Uma Thurman's icy femme, Mia; Harvey Keitel's Mr Wolf; Tim Roth's Pumpkin; and John Travolta is a revelation as gunman Vincent Vega, talking burgers and toe-jobs on the way to the hit with cool partner Samuel L Jackson. Plus a soundtrack to die for.

There's Something About Mary (Peter & Bobby Farrelly, 1998) 10pm, Sky Premier
Poor geeky Ben Stiller. The girl of his dreams (Cameron Diaz) is taking him to the high school ball, until a bloody accident with his zipper ends the romance before it starts. Years later he employs Matt Dillon's sleazy private eye to track her down, but the dick starts making moves on her himself. Add the shocking-the-dog-back-to-life sketch and the famous sperm-hair-gel scene, and it's clear that questions of taste are far from the Farrellys' minds. The funny thing is, it's so funny.

The Abominable Dr Phibes (Robert Fuest, 1971) 1.50am, Sci-Fi Channel Vincent Price runs amok as Phibes, facially challenged after a nasty accident, and mentally suspect, given his intention to bump off the 10-strong medical team he blames for his wife's death on the operating table. Hunched at his majestic old cinema organ, he's a phantom of the movies with attitude, and his trail of grisly carnage, modelled on the curses of the pharaohs, is full of macabre fun.

Sports

Live Football 2.30pm, Sky Sports 2
It's moneybags Fulham, who have the country's first all-professional squad, against Arsenal in the women's FA Cup final. The Cottagers have already won their league, although they are in the division below Arsenal, while the Gunners have wrapped up the League Cup and could yet win the treble. Probably the two best teams in the country, so this should be worth watching.

Plus a soundtrack to die for. There's Something About Mary (Peter & Bobby Farrelly, 1998) 10pm, Sky Premier Poor geeky Ben Stiller. The girl of his dreams (Cameron Diaz) is taking him to the high school ball, until a bloody accident with his zipper ends the romance before it starts. Years later he employs Matt Dillon's sleazy private eye to track her down, but the dick starts making moves on her himself. Add the shocking-the-dog-back-to-life sketch and the famous sperm-hair-gel scene, and it's clear that questions of taste are far from the Farrellys' minds. The funny thing is, it's so funny. The Abominable Dr Phibes (Robert Fuest, 1971) 1.50am, Sci-Fi Channel Vincent Price runs amok as Phibes, facially challenged after a nasty accident, and mentally suspect, given his intention to bump off the 10-strong medical team he blames for his wife's death on the operating table. Hunched at his majestic old cinema organ, he's a phantom of the movies with attitude, and his trail of grisly carnage, modelled on the curses of the pharaohs, is full of macabre fun. Sports Live Football 2.30pm, Sky Sports 2 It's moneybags Fulham, who have the country's first all-professional squad, against Arsenal in the women's FA Cup final. The Cottagers have already won their league, although they are in the division below Arsenal, while the Gunners have wrapped up the League Cup and could yet win the treble. Probably the two best teams in the country, so this should be worth watching.

webTitle: Grozny mayor gives shoot-to-kill order

fields.headline: Grozny mayor gives shoot-to-kill order
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: Russia's loyalist mayor of Grozny ordered the instant shooting of any ethnic Chechens at the weekend suspected of murdering Russian civilians in the lawless Chechen capital.
fields.body:
Russia's loyalist mayor of Grozny ordered the instant shooting of any ethnic Chechens at the weekend suspected of murdering Russian civilians in the lawless Chechen capital.

Bislan Gantamirov, a Chechen and a convicted embezzler, was appointed mayor of Grozny by the Kremlin. He announced that suspected Chechen murderers should be killed "without trial or investigation" after the mutilated corpses of three Russians civilians were found in the city at the weekend. The three, all members of one family, had been shot dead and then disfigured, officials said.

Mr Gantamirov's call, which flies in the face of President Vladimir Putin's repeated promises to restore "normal" civilian administration and the rule of law in the breakaway republic, came as the top Russian officials running the 19-month war pledged a new hard line in Chechnya, while implicitly acknowledging that the war was going badly.

Sergei Ivanov, the new Russian defence minister, announced a halt to Russian force withdrawals from Chechnya after only 5,000 of an estimated 80,000 troops had been taken out. This was despite Mr Putin's promises earlier this year to pull out more than half of the total number.

And confirming that Grozny was too perilous for the Russians, despite their massive military presence around the capital, the Russians also reversed a decision taken 10 days ago to relocate the loyalist Chechen government to the city.

The administration will now remain in Chechnya's second city, Gudermes, because the guerrillas have made it plain that the Russian administrators would be made to pay if they moved to Grozny, despite the fall of Grozny to the Russians more than a year ago. "Conditions for the government's safe work in Grozny have not yet been created," said Nikolai Patrushev, Mr Putin's successor as head of the FSB, the successor to the KGB.

"The move will be carried out when the necessary conditions for the work of the government are created, and when appropriate security has been provided so that the government can perform its functions."

Mr Patrushev is a close ally of Mr Putin and was put in charge of the war effort in January in what was effectively a vote of no confidence in the military's conduct of the conflict. But Mr Patrushev is also under pressure.

When Mr Putin announced he was handing control of the war over to the secret service, he also demanded that Mr Patrushev report to him by this month on what had been done to take control of the situation.

Three of Mr Putin's most trusted aides - Mr Patrushev, Mr Ivanov, who is also a former KGB officer, and the new interior minister, Boris Gryzlov, spent Friday and Saturday touring the northern Caucasus and consulting regional military and security officials. The reversals of the announced moves on troop withdrawals and the relocation of the Chechen government in Grozny indicated the intractable problems they face.

"We have completed the stage of reducing the troops and have accordingly withdrawn a little more than 5,000 servicemen, around 40 tanks and several hundred armoured personnel carriers," Mr Ivanov said. "As of today, there are no plans to reduce the number of troops further," he said.

For the umpteenth time, he promised better pay and conditions for the troops in Chechnya, but admitted cash problems.

A further sign of Russian desperation came when Mr Gryzlov said that the government was about to rush through a package of legislation on political extremism, terrorism, and a state of emergency through the Russian parliament. "It is essential that the government... work out a strategic set of laws, which must be passed quickly," he said.

The Chechen women of Grozny, meanwhile, disrupted Russian patrols in the battered city by erecting impromptu roadblocks in protest at the killing of a local teacher, apparently by Russian soldiers.

The timing of Mr Gantamirov's controversial statement on summary executions suggested he had come in for severe criticism from the Kremlin officials for failing to make Grozny safe for Russian civilians, the Russian administrators, and the Russian troops.

"The mayor has given orders that these people should be shot on the spot," Mr Gantamirov's spokesman said. "He will personally commend those who fulfil that order."

webTitle: Stephen Poliakoff's Perfect Strangers

fields.headline: Like nothing else
fields.standfirst: Stephen Poliakoff's Shooting The Past was a tough act to follow. But Perfect Strangers, his elaborate family saga, displays the sheer breadth of his talent
fields.trailText: Stephen Poliakoff's Shooting The Past was a tough act to follow. But Perfect Strangers, his elaborate family saga, displays the sheer breadth of his talent.
fields.body:
Although he's not yet 50, the writer Stephen Poliakoff was such a prodigy - he had a play professionally staged while still at school - that he's lived through three ages of television drama. When he first wrote for TV in the 70s, the original drama for television was a regular event. His scripts - including the brilliant Euro-rail bildungsroman Caught On A Train, repeated on BBC2 this weekend - were seen in fat strands of single plays: Play For Today, Playhouse, Screen Two, Screenplay.

In the 80s and early 90s, fashion and finance encouraged TV drama to copy its richer cousin: cinema. While television fiction concentrated on adaptations of classic novels, the original playwrights worked on hybrids intended for release on a few large screens before screening on the small one. Poliakoff wrote (and sometimes directed) impressive examples of these: notably Close My Eyes and Hidden City.

Then, at the very end of the century dominated visually first by cinema and then television, Poliakoff entered a third and remarkable phase of his screenwriting career. He now wrote serials which deliberately rejected the fast-cutting of movies and, though visually distinctive, foregrounded talk in the way that the television plays of yesterday had. (Caught On A Train was essentially a conversation piece between two people.)

After the award-winning Shooting The Past - about the mysteries hidden in a picture library about to be sold - comes Perfect Strangers (BBC2), which, once again, feels like nothing else in the schedules. Poliakoff is also given the rare accolade for a living writer of a tie-in documentary: Stephen Poliakoff: Shooting The Present (BBC2). This also marks a shift in television history. A Late Show-type project in the old Late Show slot, it stands, like the drama that inspired it, as a treat that would once have been taken for granted by the viewer.

Perfect Strangers might have been called The Family Reunion if TS Eliot hadn't got there first, although Poliakoff has thankfully chosen to use crisp vernacular dialogue rather than verse. Ernest (Peter Howell), an ageing paterfamilias, is rich enough to invite all his relatives for a weekend at a London hotel. Distanced from the family by financial failure, the patronisingly described "Hillingdon contingent" come out of curiosity and cussedness, led by the dyspeptic Raymond (Michael Gambon) and his son Daniel (Matthew Macfadyen.)

Within a simple framework of romantic drama - will Daniel succeed in his desire to leave his DNA inside his cousin, Rebecca (Claire Skinner)? - the three-part drama, neatly timed for our current cultural obsession with genetics, investigates private and public misunderstandings of the past.

Although Poliakoff has followed the vocation of playwright and director, two other professions vitally underlie his writing: architect and historian. Most dramatists leave the precise settings for the scenes to a location scout. Poliakoff, though, puts the poetic and appropriate places on the page himself. Unknown or unconsidered buildings fill his work. The film Hidden City moves through a warren of shut-down tunnels and abandoned structures around London.

Seeming to have taken some screenwriter's equivalent of the taxi-driver's Knowledge, Poliakoff builds up in his plays and films an alternative A-Z of cafes, bars, flyovers, motorways, casinos, shopping malls, houses and flats. Because the clan in Perfect Strangers is rich and snobbish, the crucial sites here are Claridge's Hotel and the mansion flats of Knightsbridge. In the unlikely event of playwrighting ever letting him down, you feel that Poliakoff could make his living as a tour guide or estate agent.

As well as being the most architectural of dramatists, he also has the mind of a historian. Growing up in a family with an odd foothold on history - as a child in his pyjamas the playwright's father witnessed the Russian Revolution in Red Square - Poliakoff has always had as a writer an eye for startling details of the past. His stage play Talk Of The City drew acutely and amusingly on the early history of broadcasting and a powerful section in Perfect Strangers dramatises another bizarre but true detail from his researches: war-time evacuees living wild in the woods as they head back to their family home from the rural safe houses where they are supposed to be.

But, although much of his inspiration comes from footnotes in books, the past, in a Poliakoff play, usually exists as a visual record. The setting of Shooting The Past in a picture library makes this theme most explicit but, in Hidden City, a film studies lecturer discovers black-and-white footage of a woman being led away by men who look like secret agents.

And, in Perfect Strangers, it's again photos which cause the plot to develop. The Gambon character is astonished by a picture of his stern father dancing ecstatically in a garden. His son is troubled by another snap, which shows him in fancy dress in a house he has no memory of ever visiting. Through encounters within the tense and fractured family, the meaning of these scenes is finally revealed.

This obsession with what pictures can tell us is entirely appropriate in a writer whose notable career as a writer for television has impressively demonstrated how visual images can capture the texture and mystery of time.

• Perfect Strangers, Thursday, 9pm, BBC2; Stephen Poliakoff: Shooting The Present, Tuesday, 11.20pm, BBC2.

webTitle: Country Diary

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Climb every mountain
fields.trailText: Climb every mountain
fields.body:
The Lake District

To the mountain man, now denied the fells, the delights of walking Morecambe or Grange promenades soon begin to pall; he wants something a bit more hilly. But, living on the fringe of Lakeland, we are more fortunate than most. At the back of my home is Kendal golf course - surprisingly still available for walking although sheep are grazing in adjoining fields - from which unsurpassed views of the Lakeland fells may be seen and, just across the river, is the pleasant hill, still open to walkers, on which stand the ruins of Kendal Castle, a splendid viewpoint. Several other minor heights encircling the town, from all of which the fells, so long denied us, may be studied in mouth-watering detail, can be tackled with surprisingly little expenditure of energy, and even road walking in this delectable area can be exhilarating.

The other morning, sunny and breezy, with needle-sharp views, we walked along the lovely road that traverses the flank of Hay Fell, and I thought I had never seen better views from so lowly a height, perhaps a mere 500ft or so above sea level. The whole of the valley of the Kent, with Kendal sprawled across its centre, lay stretched out below us, while the Lakeland hills, from the Coniston fells to High Street, with Crinkle Crags and the Scafells sticking up in the middle, crowded the horizon. Then, the other week, they reopened to walkers Orrest Head above Windermere, the hill from which the young Wainwright first saw the light. It is a simple walk, but from the top most of Lakeland may be seen - a hundred summits, the long length of Windermere far below and all the magic. The fells are not open yet but this is a start.

webTitle: Radio pick of the day

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Inventors Imperfect | Front Row | It's My Story
fields.body:
In America Benjamin Franklin is as well remembered for his highly efficient wood-burning stove (still being made) as for the Declaration of Independence. DH Lawrence couldn't stand him, denouncing him as "the worst kind of American". An insatiable tinkerer, Franklin could hardly be omitted from Adam Hart-Davies's catalogue of Inventors Imperfect (11.0am, Radio 4). Having devised an extraordinary range of useful gadgets, from the lightning rod to bifocal lenses, his encore was to dream up a glass armonica.

Fast approaching his 60th year, Paul McCartney has been spreading himself all over the shop in the past 12 months. His Beatles compilation has topped the charts in more than 30 countries; he has exhibited a selection of his paintings; and Blackbird Singing, his first volume of poetry, is available at all good bookshops. He surveys these crowded hours in Front Row (7.15pm, Radio 4), in an interview with John Wilson.

Every year about 150 British citizens are forced into a marriage they neither expected nor wanted. They are usually Moslem women, taken to Bangladesh for a family holiday and then confronted with an arranged marriage. The Foreign Office has a special unit to help such victims but, as reported in It's My Story (8.0pm, Radio 4), most of the rescue work is still carried out by an East London voluntary organisation, the Newham Bengali Community Trust.

webTitle: Fans killed as roof of stadium falls in Iran

fields.headline: Fans killed as roof of stadium falls in Iran
fields.trailText: Several football fans were killed and hundreds of others were injured yesterday when part of the roof of a stadium collapsed during a game in northeastern Iran, the official Islamic Republic News Agency (Irna) reported.
fields.body:
Several football fans were killed and hundreds of others were injured yesterday when part of the roof of a stadium collapsed during a game in northeastern Iran, the official Islamic Republic News Agency (Irna) reported.

Angry fans clashed with police trying to make their way into the Mottaqi stadium, where the accident occurred, Ali Ansarian, a player with Persepolis, Iran's most popular team, said by phone. He added that fans had started fires on the field.

"We are trapped in the locker room," Ansarian said. "There is such a thick crowd outside that we can't force open the door to the locker room. Through a window, I can see fighting outside between fans and the police. He said he had seen at least 30 people dead. State-run Tehran television showed fans wielding metal poles locked in battle with anti-riot forces trying to control the crowds at the stadium in the city of Sari, 150 miles northeast of Tehran.

One wall of the stadium had been torn down. Iron fences separating the stand from the pitch had been torn out. The field was packed with fans and police.

"The security forces are trying to direct the people out of the stadium," Tehran television said.

Irna reported that "hundreds" of fans had been injured and "several" killed. It did not give an exact number of casualties. It said there were about 20,000 fans were at the game.

A telephone operator at a hospital in Sari said many of the injured people were in a critical condition.

Persepolis was playing another local team, Shemooshak of Nowshahr, when the accident happened during the second half. AP

webTitle: Zambia's Chiluba will not seek third term

fields.headline: Zambia's Chiluba will not seek third term
fields.trailText: Zambia's president, Frederick Chiluba, has bowed to popular and parliamentary pressure and abandoned plans to amend the constitution so that he could run for a third term.
fields.body:
Zambia's president, Frederick Chiluba, has bowed to popular and parliamentary pressure and abandoned plans to amend the constitution so that he could run for a third term.

Mr Chiluba backed down amid a barrage of local and international condemnation of his attempt to extend his 10-year rule. Members of his own cabinet and party denounced his scheme to run for another five years as president, and parliamentarians moved to impeach him for abuse of power.

The South African and Botswanan governments pressed him not to amend the constitution. Foreign aid donors also expressed their displeasure.

Mr Chiluba said on Friday that he was not going to run again, but many Zambians did not believe him because he has said it before, and because he left open the possibility of calling a referendum to amend the constitution to allow a president - any president - to seek a third term.

After a fresh round of denunciations, in which Mr Chiluba was accused of duping ordinary Zambians, the president yesterday insisted he really does not intend to run for office again, but this time ruled out the possibility of a referendum.

"I'm not going to stand. I want to make it clear, clear, clear. I'm not standing for a third term," he said. "I also want to put it categorically that there will be no referendum. There can never be a referendum if I am not standing."

On Thursday, Mr Chiluba defied a high court order and dismissed his vice-president and eight other members of the cabinet from the ruling Movement for Multi-Party Democracy (MMD) after they opposed his successful attempt to amend his party's rules to permit him to be its candidate once again. The next step was to tamper with the constitution.

Mr Chiluba set about a purge of dissenters on Friday by dissolving his entire cabinet and promptly re-appointing the more loyal members. He said he will announce the rest of his ministers today.

The president's decision to clarify his intent followed a high-level meeting at which top officials warned that his attempt to extend his rule was likely to create widespread instability at home and harm Zambia's position overseas.

Violence broke out at a rally of the ruling party on Saturday, apparently provoked by the ambivalence of Mr Chiluba's position. The president described the clashes as an attempt by his "enemies" to create anarchy.

"The demonstration yesterday was against a non-existent constitutional amendment. It was very clear that the demonstration was pre-determined to cause anarchy in the country," Mr Chiluba said.

fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you
fields.body:
 You might recall general outrage a few months back when it was announced that the BBC had bought God, The Devil And Bob, a US cartoon satire about the war between good and evil. The Beeb, though, has taken the precaution of inviting church heads to a special screening, before it begins going on on BBC 2 on Tuesday. And they have given it, as it were, their blessing. So much for the days of gratuitous controversy...

 If the 1900 House and the 1940s House, weren't hardcore enough for you, you're in luck. On Thursday, BBC1 starts a series on surviving the iron age. If you thought living without central heating was bad enough, try doing it in an age before underwear was invented. Apparently it all starts off quite well with the group electing a leader and opting for "liberal democracy", but quickly decends into a real-life remake of Lord Of The Flies.

 Great news, finally, for those whose idea of great entertainment is watching gently perspiring middle-aged men sitting silently round a table. Yes, Late Night Poker will be returning to to Channel 4 later this year.
