webTitle: John Patterson: The Mummy is back

fields.headline: Curse is foiled again
fields.standfirst: The Mummy is back - but this time Rachel Weisz is ready for him. John Patterson takes his weekly look at the US releases
fields.trailText: The Mummy is back - but this time Rachel Weisz is ready for him. John Patterson takes his weekly look at the US releases
fields.body:
Every so often the suits at Universal Studios send some poor fool down a creaky staircase to the classic horror-movie archive to see if it's time to chivvy out the monsters for another big-budget remake. They're all lurking down there because the studio still owns the rights, having built its reputation and house style with its 1930s horror classics. There on the slab sleeps Dr Frankenstein's gentle monster; Dracula and his bride gaze palely from the shadows; the Invisible Man sits in his clean, white bandages; and the Mummy lies alongside him in his fetid 5,000-year-old ones.

They've all been given a day-pass over the past 20 years, in the hopes a remake might scare up some serious box-office receipts for Universal. The success rate has been pretty grim, though. We've had Francis Coppola's - I mean Bram Stoker's - Dracula, misleadingly marketed as his return to form. Then there was Kenneth Branagh's Frankenstein, featuring Robert De Niro's worst-ever performance as the compendium of corpse parts, and Franc Roddam's The Bride, in which a good director was lumbered with a bad Doktor (Sting), and the assemble-it-yourself fiancee turned out to be Jennifer Beals. It had one vital component missing: the talent. The Invisible Man and the werewolf have been less active of late, and although Paul Verhoeven's Hollow Man made a splash for invisibility last year, the last great werewolf movies were Wolfen and An American Werewolf in London, both nearly 20 years ago.

But it's the bandage-clad pyramid-dweller who's had the fewest outings since he was first played by Boris Karloff in 1932. Although Lon Chaney Jr made some ratty Mummy movies in the second world war and Christopher Lee climbed out of his sarcophagus for Hammer in 1959, until recently the word "Mummy" tended to make me think of Carry On Screaming. All that changed with Stephen Sommers' The Mummy in 1999. Backed by lots of Universal money, Sommers cunningly crossbred the Mummy tale with the kind of "Perils of Pauline" story architecture we know from Raiders of the Lost Ark. The recipe called for scary monsters, big action sequences, a lantern-jawed hero, a feisty leading lady, tons of clever effects, and a memorable piece of nastiness every so often. With Brendan Fraser and Rachel Weisz holding it together, The Mummy was the surprise hit of that summer. All they needed was a sequel.

Well, it's here, and much happiness was had by myself and the other people in the twilight matinee I attended, particularly during the opening sequence, as mighty armies of Egyptian warriors hacked each other up with giant battleaxes. The plot concerns the long-dormant Army of the Anibus, which will rise and serve whoever acquires a certain bracelet - now in the possession of Fraser and Weisz's eight-year-old son. The usually dependable Fraser seems to be having less fun than last time, but Weisz looks as if she's having much more. Half the time her plummy, Enid Blyton tones put me in mind of Angela Lansbury, the other half she's Lara Croft, emptying pump-action shotguns into the camera in a way that makes me weak at the knees. If the sequel is more calculated than the original, and has less heart, it's still almost as enjoyable.

I guarantee The Mummy Returns will be the biggest movie in America for the next couple of weeks. I know this not simply because I was turned away from two sold-out Friday afternoon shows, but also because when I did get in, the only seat I could find was in row two, right in front of a 70ft-wide screen. My neck still aches something rotten a day after seeing it.

webTitle: Being a gay teenager

fields.headline: Different for girls
fields.standfirst: Sylvia Brownrigg on first love and coming out way back when she was young
fields.trailText: Sylvia Brownrigg on first love and coming out way back when she was young
fields.body:
Being a gay teenager is not what it was. What a difference a couple of decades makes! A friend's child goes to a school whose walls have posters advertising the gay and lesbian student group. As a high-schooler in Oxford, I inhabited a cloistered place where you would nurture an unutterable fixation on the jolly captain of the volleyball team, amid classmates' hissed whispers about what the history teacher was getting up to with a sixth former (she was "the kind of person who sits too close to girls at picnics" in a tart phrase I learnt later). It was not until I was at university in the US that the door - not just to the closet, but to my imagination - swung wide open.

It was a transitional time, stylistically, when the defiant unshaved 70s were ceding ground to the shoulder-padded 80s. Coming out-wise, my timing was good: had I been a few years older, I probably would have had to have a spell living in a separatist house baking wholegrain bread for people called Morag and Joanie. As it was, I was free to develop crushes on women in turquoise pantsuits and mirrored shades who danced (it wasn't their fault, it was all they knew) to Bananarama and Soft Cell.

More to the point, the cultural climate was opening up in an important way. Gay boys have always been assumed to be interested in sex - we all knew that, even before Queer As Folk came along - but girls had drabber identities to fend off: we were supposed to be more drawn to sisterhood than to sex. In the 80s this began to change. One friend, eager to hasten my choices, gave me as a Christmas present an illustrated volume of The Joy of Lesbian Sex. As a proselytising act, it had mixed success: I remember tittering over the gentle line drawings and well-meaning, soft-focus suggestions: "Feathers can be fun."

Still, what you really need at that age is the suave older person who will inspire your unfettered attentions. In my novel Pages for You, I have created someone poised and fetching, a beautiful teaching assistant named Anne whose cool intelligence makes 17-year-old Flannery swoon. The two become enraptured and together transform the year into one of sensual discovery.

Reality was, inevitably, more cluttered than this. Yes, at my university there was a charismatic teaching assistant, who has gone on to become an eminent theorist on gender and the body, and certainly she was trailed by adoring women; but her incipient megalomania and unhappy resemblance to Michael Douglas ruled her out as a model for my heroine.

Then there was the woman who became my girlfriend, who seemed so vastly older than me (she was 21) that I could only congratulate myself on my sophistication in making such a catch. With the four years between us that felt like a decade, I was convinced I was in a May-December romance.

But what is important in the older figure is not so much the actual difference in age as the difference in authority and bearing. Someone's got to let you know how it all works. You need someone to introduce you to the pleasures of co-showering and to usher you into the delights of lovers cooking together; someone who will stay up all night with you and ease you into the first startlement of a morning shared with someone else.

Some have assumed this novel is dedicated to an ex-lover, as if the story were a transcription of actual events. It isn't. It was written for a much-loved friend, someone older than I am who I suspect (presumptuously) shares some of my sense of sexuality's complications; and whose own graces inform Anne's. Because being a gay teenager is not, of course, the whole story. As my own narrative ravels forward, there are new firsts and discoveries, and entirely unsuspected episodes that have made me feel blind as a 17-year-old. One such episode got me writing this book. It was surprising how easy I found it to slip into the mind of that youngster; I did not even need to reread The Joy of Lesbian Sex to recapture that mood of urgent curiosity.

 Pages for You is published by Picador at £12.99.

webTitle: The current crisis in Rape Crisis

fields.headline: Crisis? What crisis?
fields.standfirst: When a woman was raped on Coronation Street, you might have expected the TV company to run a Rape Crisis number at the end of the show. But they didn't. Anita Chaudhuri finds out why
fields.trailText: When a woman was raped on Coronation Street, you might have expected the TV company to run a Rape Crisis number at the end of the show. But they didn't. Anita Chaudhuri finds out why
fields.body:
Coronation Street, it has to be said, does not usually provide much useful commentary on feminist responses to sexual violence, not unless you have a very sophisticated reading of the marital squabbles of Jack and Vera Duckworth. Yet its recent storyline about the rape of teenager Toyah Battersby has, unwittingly, starkly highlighted the current crisis in Rape Crisis.

After the harrowing episodes, Granada TV failed to broadcast a single rape helpline number, preferring to direct viewers to its website where they could click on links to Victim Support, the Samaritans or a dead-end link to the Rape Crisis Federation, an administrative body which does not provide counselling.

The reason? It appears Rape Crisis, once a beacon of feminist solidarity and Reclaim the Night marches, is suffering from an image problem.

"We provided Coronation Street with advice about the storyline and stressed the importance of putting people in contact with us," says Julie Barnard, director of the Rape Crisis Federation. "What they're really saying to Rape Crisis is, you're OK to provide us with juicy storylines, but not to provide support afterwards. It was the same with Grange Hill and a recent BBC rape documentary."

Barnard says TV companies don't want to give out Rape Crisis numbers on air because they're frightened of saying the R word. "It's fine to show it, but not to say it," she points out.

"We didn't single out Rape Crisis because we didn't want to concentrate on rape, but on violent crime in general," a Coronation Street spokeswoman says, though they used Toyah's terrified face in dozens of trailers.

However, there is a much bigger reason why the TV companies, as well as many other public information bodies, are no longer confident about giving out Rape Crisis hotline numbers. Many of Britain's 65 centres have been reduced to offering a skeleton service of just two hours per week. There are long waiting lists, up to two years in some regions, without the added burden of TV advertising, and people outside the movement are beginning to hear about it.

"Most charities can't cope with caller demand, which is often 500 calls in the first half hour," says Donald Steele at the BBC. "So we give out our audience helpline." Is it staffed by trained rape counsellors? "No, not specifically, but they are used to dealing with people in extreme distress."

The most chilling example of the problems in Rape Crisis is in London, where one of the country's flagship centres opened its doors 25 years ago. It should be celebrating its continued success this summer; instead it has been forced to suspend the service.

The strength of Rape Crisis has always been that it offers women a way forward, to find some sense of peace in the weeks and years following their ordeal. Now women in London do not have that option. Most distressing of all, many victims, not realising the service is no longer running, leave their details on the answering machine still listed in the phone book.

This was the case with a 19-year-old woman who was last year raped, in broad daylight, in an alley just off London's Wardour Street. The incident received a lot of publicity because of the shocking truth that this could happen to someone just seconds away from a crowded street. "Afterwards I phoned Rape Crisis and left my number, but they never returned my calls," she says. "No one else ever offered me any counselling. They were the first place I thought to go because I'd heard of them. I felt very badly about that."

The big issue is cash. Before the last election, Tony Blair promised to give Rape Crisis core funding; New Labour's eventual solution was to channel money into safer, less politicised services, notably Victim Support who now receive £1m per year for rape counselling. It has recently given funding to the Rape Crisis Federation, but not for local centres.

"Victim Support doesn't have specially trained counsellors, it is still aligned with the police in many minds and it's not a service for women. We have heard of lots who have been sent to a male counsellor," Barnard says.

Rape Crisis, it seems, has been a victim of its own success. The movement was born of radically optimistic politics in the mid-70s, emerging out of consciousness-raising groups and new discussions about women's recovery process. There is no centralised funding programme, so to stay afloat, individual centres, run as charities, have to appeal to local councils, health trusts and private fundraising.

Sheila Coates has worked at South Essex Rape Crisis for 18 years. Despite the fact that it has won awards for its pioneering work, the centre will close in September if it doesn't get an injection of cash. It currently employs three counsellors - two funded by the health authority, one bankrolled by a mishmash of sources - plus five other full-time staff. The volume of work is fierce: thousands of calls per year and 800 ongoing face-to-face clients.

Then there are the calls from desperate women elsewhere in Britain, referred to South Essex because its phone lines are open longer. "We can't take them, we'd lose our funding," Coates says. "Everybody refers women to us - police, psychologists, social services - but no one wants to pick up the tab. We cover everything from giving evidence to HIV counselling and dealing with housing. It's a holistic approach that has been shown to work, not just here but in the US and Australia where Rape Crisis is treated seriously and funded properly."

Coates says there is a reluctance to believe a need exists for a Rape Crisis service. "GPs have said to me: 'We don't need this, I hardly ever see women who've been raped.' Councillors have said: 'Don't women tell lies? Surely they exaggerate?' Right now at South Essex we're involved in a murder trial and dealing with a woman so traumatised that she's cut her nipples off and flushed them down the loo. And what am I doing? I'm spending half my time chasing money when every moment I'm here I should be dealing with the real stuff."

She points out that there is a key misconception about the work Rape Crisis does. "People think it's just women talking to other women, and why should they give funding to that."

Dr Liz Kelly, of the Child and Woman Abuse Studies Unit at the University of North London, claims it was ever thus. "Rape Crisis has never had the funding or public sympathy that, say, the women's refuge network has. Also there has been a desire for independence and groups have been able to survive on very little."

Another problem when it comes to funding is that Rape Crisis is women-only. With increasing awareness of male rape, many people have shied away from what Rape Crisis stands for. "There has been an unwillingness to acknowledge the contribution, skill and expertise of the women's sector, and unease about the fact that Rape Crisis is women-only, rather than seeing that as one of its strengths."

Kelly agrees that Rape Crisis is suffering from an image problem. "It's associated with the kind of feminism that we're all supposed to be 'post' now. If we were 'post' the material conditions that required Rape Crisis, then I would be very happy. People say Rape Crisis is old-fashioned. I wish it were so because that would mean there weren't thousands of women in dire need of help."

We have heard of lots who have been sent to a male counsellor," Barnard says. Rape Crisis, it seems, has been a victim of its own success. The movement was born of radically optimistic politics in the mid-70s, emerging out of consciousness-raising groups and new discussions about women's recovery process. There is no centralised funding programme, so to stay afloat, individual centres, run as charities, have to appeal to local councils, health trusts and private fundraising. Sheila Coates has worked at South Essex Rape Crisis for 18 years. Despite the fact that it has won awards for its pioneering work, the centre will close in September if it doesn't get an injection of cash. It currently employs three counsellors - two funded by the health authority, one bankrolled by a mishmash of sources - plus five other full-time staff. The volume of work is fierce: thousands of calls per year and 800 ongoing face-to-face clients. Then there are the calls from desperate women elsewhere in Britain, referred to South Essex because its phone lines are open longer. "We can't take them, we'd lose our funding," Coates says. "Everybody refers women to us - police, psychologists, social services - but no one wants to pick up the tab. We cover everything from giving evidence to HIV counselling and dealing with housing. It's a holistic approach that has been shown to work, not just here but in the US and Australia where Rape Crisis is treated seriously and funded properly." Coates says there is a reluctance to believe a need exists for a Rape Crisis service. "GPs have said to me: 'We don't need this, I hardly ever see women who've been raped.' Councillors have said: 'Don't women tell lies? Surely they exaggerate?' Right now at South Essex we're involved in a murder trial and dealing with a woman so traumatised that she's cut her nipples off and flushed them down the loo. And what am I doing? I'm spending half my time chasing money when every moment I'm here I should be dealing with the real stuff." She points out that there is a key misconception about the work Rape Crisis does. "People think it's just women talking to other women, and why should they give funding to that." Dr Liz Kelly, of the Child and Woman Abuse Studies Unit at the University of North London, claims it was ever thus. "Rape Crisis has never had the funding or public sympathy that, say, the women's refuge network has. Also there has been a desire for independence and groups have been able to survive on very little." Another problem when it comes to funding is that Rape Crisis is women-only. With increasing awareness of male rape, many people have shied away from what Rape Crisis stands for. "There has been an unwillingness to acknowledge the contribution, skill and expertise of the women's sector, and unease about the fact that Rape Crisis is women-only, rather than seeing that as one of its strengths." Kelly agrees that Rape Crisis is suffering from an image problem. "It's associated with the kind of feminism that we're all supposed to be 'post' now. If we were 'post' the material conditions that required Rape Crisis, then I would be very happy. People say Rape Crisis is old-fashioned. I wish it were so because that would mean there weren't thousands of women in dire need of help."

webTitle: Wonders and blunders

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.standfirst:
12. Chris Wilkinson
Wonder: Media Centre, Lord's
Blunder: A&E centre, King's College Hospital, London
fields.trailText: 12. Chris Wilkinson
fields.body:
I really like the new media centre at Lord's cricket ground. The centre was designed by Future Systems and completed in 1999. It is an amazing piece of architecture, particularly in the effective way it uses different materials and structural elements.

The centre is an excellent example of design that combines an exciting expression of new technology with an emphasis on the quality of architecture. I think it works very well in its historic setting. It is a "building of today" and proves that buildings don't have to be traditional in format.

On the other hand, I often find hospital buildings to be lacking in imagination and good design. Design plays an important role in places where people are ill because the environment they are in can influence them in a positive way. It is a shame that most hospitals don't pay enough attention to the quality of architecture.

That's why I don't like the recent additions to King's College Hospital, particularly the accident and emergency centre. I find its appearance unpleasant in the way it harps back to Victorian times but at the same time attempts to express this in a postmodern way.

Hospital buildings should attempt to engage with the latest technology in the way they are designed. The A&E centre seems to have a vaguely engineered base but the structure fails to express its purpose in a strong and convincing way. The bright red colour of the steel components and the materials used do not complement the building at all.

webTitle: Michele Hanson: The secret life of a line manager

fields.headline: The secret life of a line manager
fields.trailText: Who invented line managers? Whatever are they for? I have never heard of a line manager who is any use.
fields.body:
Who invented line managers? Whatever are they for? I have never heard of a line manager who is any use. Now poor Rosemary has one. What a nuisance. Since hers was appointed, Rosemary has hardly been able to do a scrap of work. She isn't allowed to do anything until the line manager tells her to, but she can't get hold of the creature for love nor money.

Miss Line Manager started off by asking Rosemary strictly whether she knew where all the security alarms were, and then she vanished. Sometimes she could be glimpsed in the distance, whizzing down a corridor looking busy, but Rosemary could never catch her. Meanwhile people were eagerly signing lists and queuing up to join Rosemary's groups and classes, unaware that their lives were on hold until the line manager gave permission.

Last week, Rosemary at last spotted Miss Line Manager approaching. She flung herself in her path, crying: "At last! Please, please manage me! I beg you!"

But Miss LM didn't think Rosemary at all funny. We find that most line managers are no good at jokes. How can they be? Fielding's line managers must sneak along the corridors behind him, spying and scribbling information on a clipboard, without laughing. They need to be of a serious disposition.

Fielding has five in his school, all half his age. They like to audit, put people on databases and ask for bullet points, tend to be hatchet-faced fellows in suits with shiny hair and live in minimalist offices, rather like psychiatric clinics, with black floors, white walls and no plants. From these oases of efficiency, they step into the shambles of Fielding's classroom, where he probably displeases them.

"Secretly, I go out of my way to irritate the bastards," whispers Fielding. He fumbles with his electric register, makes a hash of lesson plans, or has no visible plans at all. But as the teaching profession is in desperate straits, they can line-manage him to the hilt and it will get them nowhere.

Oddly enough, my friend Mavis was once a line manager and explained it all. Line managers must collect the billion forms that nobody knows how to fill in, speak in a language that nobody understands, and they're in charge of the money, which everybody wants more of. Aaah! One almost feels sorry for them. But not quite.

webTitle: Pass notes: Gary Cooper

fields.headline: No 1,874 Gary Cooper
fields.trailText: What would Gary Cooper be doing if he were alive today? Scratching feebly at the inside of his coffin lid.
fields.body:
What would Gary Cooper be doing if he were alive today? Scratching feebly at the inside of his coffin lid.

I ought to shoot you like a goddam dog for that. Hold it, pardner. He would be 100 years old today. If he hadn't died in 1961, that is.

That's a mighty boring handle he's got there. So boring it can't be real. His real name was a rootin'-tootin' Frank Cooper. He changed it when he joined the actors' union. (His agent's hometown was Gary, Indiana).

So he grew up wrasslin' grizzlies and drinking sarsaparilla, then? Frankie did live on a Montana ranch when he was a kid. But his mother thought he was running wild so she sent him to public school in England.

So he spent most of the time dressed up like a million-dollar trouper? Super duper. In fact he went back to Montana when the first world war broke out and worked on the ranch. "Getting up at 5am and shovelling manure at 40 below ain't romantic," he said when he was a movie star.

So "Gary" Cooper must have worked. Dang right. Coop got into Hollywood as an extra in cowboy movies in the silent days, then got a break in 1926 and was handed a second lead role in The Winning of Barbara Worth. Paramount liked the brooding tough guy and gave him a $150-a-week contract.

There's gold in them thar Hollywood hills. In 1939 he was audited by the US treasury which said he was the best paid employee in the country - earning $480,000 (almost $6m today) that year.

So did all his swooning fans resent that then? America loved Coop so much, no one cared. His career actually got better in the subsequent years, with Meet John Doe, The Fountainhead, and the all-time ticking-clock classic High Noon.

Do say: "Quit pushin' me. I'm tired of being pushed."

Don't say: "Are you sure that's the right time?"

webTitle: What's in a name?

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.standfirst: Mavericks eat sandwiches in their leotards
fields.trailText: When John Humphrys doesn't interrupt on the Today programme you wake up and take notice. That's what happened last week. He was talking about the word maverick and was interviewing a man of that name who is descended from Samuel A Maverick (1803-1870), a Texas cattle-owner who let his calves roam free, unbranded. This information has been available in dictionaries for well over a century (the OED cites an 1867 example) but has evidently only just reached the BBC. At any rate John Humphrys was near dumbstruck.
fields.body:
When John Humphrys doesn't interrupt on the Today programme you wake up and take notice. That's what happened last week. He was talking about the word maverick and was interviewing a man of that name who is descended from Samuel A Maverick (1803-1870), a Texas cattle-owner who let his calves roam free, unbranded. This information has been available in dictionaries for well over a century (the OED cites an 1867 example) but has evidently only just reached the BBC. At any rate John Humphrys was near dumbstruck.

Meanwhile, the editor of the Today programme, Rod Liddle, in an article in the Spectator, speaks of gerrymandering. Doubtless Mr Humphrys will be hoping to speak to a descendant of Gerry Mander. He will be disappointed. There never was such a person. There was, however, in 1812 a governor of Massachussetts called Elbridge Gerry, and the legislature divided up the state in an electorally advantageous manner which formed a shape supposedly resembling that of a salamander.

Still, such mistakes are easily made. Take that robust piece of earth-moving equipment, the JCB. We admit we had assumed that, the way RSJ stands for rolled steel joist, JCB stood for - something or other. It was not till earlier this year, with the death of its inventor, Joseph Cyril Bamford, that we learned otherwise. (And, in fairness to Mr Humphrys and Today, this information is also in the OED.)

Where would we be without what has immortalised AM Ampère, Count Alessandro Volta, James Watt, Georg Simon Ohm and such great names as these? What would we wear on a bank holiday without wellingtons, cardigan and mackintosh? Bloomers perhaps, or the garment named after the French trapeze artiste Jules Léotard. Thus oddly attired, we sit down to a sandwich and a refreshing glass of kir (white wine and cassis). The mayor of Dijon, Canon Félix Kir (1876-1968), presumably left no descendants for John Humphrys to interview but it's unlikely that the same goes for John Thomas, whoever he was.

webTitle: Arts boards up in arms

fields.headline: Arts boards up in arms
fields.standfirst: Reform should not be imposed unilaterally
fields.trailText: On March 15, the Arts Council chairman, Gerry Robinson, gave the regional arts boards (RABs) six weeks to hand over all their assets and staff contracts. This was the corporate raider who had battled with Forte applying his tactics on the public service and, predictably, it has stirred up a bitter rebellion: eight out of the 10 RABs have refused to hand over anything.
fields.body:
On March 15, the Arts Council chairman, Gerry Robinson, gave the regional arts boards (RABs) six weeks to hand over all their assets and staff contracts. This was the corporate raider who had battled with Forte applying his tactics on the public service and, predictably, it has stirred up a bitter rebellion: eight out of the 10 RABs have refused to hand over anything.

What is now making the muddle difficult to resolve is that the tactics of surprise and speed have needlessly antagonised relations between the London-based Arts Council and the RABs. Furthermore, no one, including Gerry Robinson and his chief executive, Peter Hewitt, seems able to explain how the reforms outlined in the Prospectus for Change will actually work.

On the key issue of whether this is stealth centralisation or genuine devolution, the Prospectus specialises in pure doublespeak: more power is promised at the centre as well as in the regions. The repeated references to a "single voice" for the arts with regional offices across the country is being justifiably interpreted as incompatible with genuine regional devolution.

Amid the controversy, there is broad agreement that some reform is needed of the RABs (which were a product of the Thatcherite assault on local government in the mid-80s). The general theme is more devolution and less bureaucracy. But on the latter, an obviously laudable aim, the RABs indignantly insist that they are not to blame. Certainly, the Prospectus does not make it clear how it proposes to cut the form-filling (often demanded by Europe or other government departments). Meanwhile, some points are made very clear such as job losses, and the abolition of one region (Southern Arts) altogether, creating a mega-regional office responsible for a population of 8m.

This has proved a textbook case of how not to reform a public body. It will demoralise and paralyse arts administration in the regions for months. Publicly subsidised arts is a notoriously difficult area of government - it always arouses passionate controversy over who decides what is funded, and the value of their decisions. There appears to have been an attempt at the Arts Council to bypass that kind of healthy democratic debate by producing a reform proposal that defeats even experienced arts administrators' powers of comprehension, let alone the art-loving taxpayer.

webTitle: Bush threatens to slash spending on nuclear safety aid to Russia

fields.headline: Bush threatens to slash spending on nuclear safety aid to Russia
fields.standfirst:
US budget cut brings fears of trafficking and a scientific brain drain

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: US budget cut brings fears of trafficking and a scientific brain drain
fields.body:
The Bush administration is planning to slash spending on nuclear safety projects in Russia, raising fears that slacker controls on the porous Russian nuclear industry could bring an upsurge in the trafficking of radioactive materials.

Throughout the 1990s the US spent billions of dollars on various programmes in Russia aimed at securing nuclear stockpiles against theft, decommissioning weapons-grade uranium and plutonium or converting it for civilian use, and retraining and paying Russian nuclear scientists in order to discourage them from taking their expertise elsewhere.

The policy has been widely seen as one of the few relatively successful aid programmes to Russia and the Clinton administration had signalled a 50% increase in funds this year for the projects run mainly by the Pentagon and the US Department of Energy.

But White House budget plans from the Bush team have scrapped the proposed increases and instead cut the $800m (£571m) allocated to the energy department by around $100m or more than 12%.

"It seems that some projects will need to be scrapped," said Igor Kudrik, a Russian expert on his country's nuclear industry at the Bellona environmental watchdog in Norway.

The Republicans came to office in Washington fiercely critical of what they viewed as the Clinton government's failed economic and aid policies towards Russia. The proposed nuclear safety cuts are the first concrete evidence of reduced spending on Russia, though US and Russian experts predict the cuts will encounter strong resistance in Congress.

"There are prominent people in Washington, including Republicans, who want to restore and expand the spending, arguing that the nuclear problem is a threat to the US and not a favour to Russia," said Sergei Rogov, Moscow's top expert on the US.

Indeed, a recent US government sponsored report recommended that up to $30bn be spent on containing the Russian proliferation risk over the next decade.

Instead, under the Bush plans, experts say, key programmes could be eliminated, hastening a Russian brain drain and making it more tempting for Russian nuclear physicists to ply their trade in countries Washington views as rogue states.

A billion-dollar scheme to decommission 68 tonnes of weapons-grade plutonium, agreed by Presidents Clinton and Vladimir Putin in Moscow last year, is likely to be halted by the Bush administration, said Mr Kudrik.

A separate project promoting the development of hi-tech enterprises and retraining Russian nuclear scientists to work in them could also go. More than 2,000 Russian nuclear scientists are employed in such schemes. Employment is on offer from such US bugbears as Iraq, Iran, and North Korea.

In the eight years since the US energy department inaugurated its nuclear containment projects in the former Soviet Union, new security systems have been installed at 113 sites.

But this is a gargantuan work in progress, securing a mere fraction of weapons-grade material regarded as risky across Russia.

Apart from planning to cut the nuclear safety funding, the US is also threatening to suspend most other aid to Russia if it concludes that Russian sales of nuclear technology for power plants in Iran are helping the country build a nuclear bomb. Last week the US state department put Iran at the top of its league table of countries sponsoring terrorism.

"American officials are convinced both that Iran plans to use that reactor to develop nuclear weapons, and that Iran's possession of nuclear weapons threatens US national security and that of its vital allies," Celeste Wallander of the US Council on Foreign Relations wrote in an analysis last month of the Bush administration's policies on Russia.

But in the bout of tension between the Bush and Putin governments, says Mr Rogov, the Russians are pushing ahead with the Iranian contracts because they have concluded that there will be no reward from the West for good behaviour.

"We're damned if we do, and damned if we don't," he added.

webTitle: The church does stand up to Mugabe

fields.headline: The church does stand up to Mugabe
fields.trailText: While it is true that the Catholic church leadership belatedly offered a slap on the hand to Robert Mugabe with a rebuke of political violence (Face to Faith, May 5) there has been much courageous criticism by individual church leaders.
fields.body:
While it is true that the Catholic church leadership belatedly offered a slap on the hand to Robert Mugabe with a rebuke of political violence (Face to Faith, May 5) there has been much courageous criticism by individual church leaders. The Roman Catholic archbishop in Matabeleland, Pius Ncube, has been particularly clear, and has suffered death threats as a result. His case was recently under investigation by Amnesty International.

Visiting Matabeleland last week, I heard unequivocal criticism from the Anglican bishop of Mashonaland of those "whose actions crush the people and grind the face of the poor". Several priests I spoke to told me of the threats they had received and the danger they believed themselves to be in. One, who had been imprisoned during the fifth brigade incursion into Matabeleland in 1985, described himself as "very frightened indeed".

Tim Neill was vicar-general of Mashonaland (not Zimbabwe) and this is significant. Zimbabwe is essentially tribal, and the predominant Shona tribe of Mashonaland has sought to dominate the Ndbele tribe of Matabeleland. This has, at times, been reflected in both government policy and church leadership.

On the ground the churches are confronting the hunger faced by many of the poorest people in the townships. The so called "fast-track" policy of land redistribution promulgated by Mugabe's "war vets" has led to chaos in agriculture. Staple crops are not being planted, and the price of mealie flour, the basic food of the poor, has gone up tenfold in the past few months.

Unless the intimidation of schools, hospitals, businesses and churches as well as farms ceases, violence seems inevitable. webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: On January 22 we published an article quoting and paraphrasing a senior lecturer in linguistics at the University of East Anglia, KR Lodge, as saying that telephone text messaging was destroying standards of literacy, as he saw among his own students (Phone txt chat 'harms literacy', page 7).
fields.body:
On January 22 we published an article quoting and paraphrasing a senior lecturer in linguistics at the University of East Anglia, KR Lodge, as saying that telephone text messaging was destroying standards of literacy, as he saw among his own students (Phone txt chat 'harms literacy', page 7).

Our piece was based on reports supplied to us. Dr Lodge complains that his views have been misrepresented from the beginning. What he actually believes is that text messaging is fine, one of many ways of communicating which is no better or worse than any other. While he does encounter problems with university students' ability to write, he does not blame text messaging; for one thing, it is too recent as a mass phenomenon to have had this effect. If it were the only communication form people were exposed to, then it might reduce their ability to cope with a range of others, he says, but it is far too early to make any such assertion now.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 0845 451 9589 between 11am and 5pm Tuesday to Friday (all calls are charged at local rate). Mail to:

webTitle: Letter: Crude claim

fields.headline: Crude claim
fields.trailText: Allegations against politicians are sadly the stuff of politics these days, and in a world of spin and spite it is often wiser simply to ignore them (Top Tory at centre of sanctions busting claims, May 4).
fields.body:
Allegations against politicians are sadly the stuff of politics these days, and in a world of spin and spite it is often wiser simply to ignore them. In an otherwise carefully worded report (Top Tory at centre of sanctions busting claims, May 4), however, you overstepped the mark by specifically stating that I "earned an estimated £100,000 a year by delivering to South Africa about 15% of its imports". I did not.

I have never been responsible for any sale of Brunei crude oil to South Africa, and any such suggestion is totally untrue. Contrary to the impression given in the Guardian I in fact gave a full explanation to your reporter, albeit off the record, about these allegations. The same evidence has been hawked around journalists for about six years, and has been dismissed in the past by other newspapers.

I should be grateful if you would publish this letter in order to set the record straight.

Alan Duncan MP
Conservative trade and industry spokesman

webTitle: Letter: Ilisu: a glimmer of hope

fields.headline: Ilisu: a glimmer of hope
fields.trailText: The Guardian's coverage of the Balfour Beatty annual general meeting (Kurds threaten dam contractor, May 3) distorted the reality of Kurdish protest against the dam.
fields.body:
Over the past year, the Guardian has provided outstanding coverage of the international campaign to stop the proposed Ilisu dam in south-east Turkey. However, your coverage of the Balfour Beatty annual general meeting (Kurds threaten dam contractor, May 3) distorted the reality of Kurdish protest against the dam.

Rather than stating that the PKK guerrillas would take up arms against Balfour Beatty, as reported in your article, an individual Kurd who spoke at the meeting was actually expressing fears that the building of a large-scale dam in such a sensitive region as south-eastern Turkey posed a threat to the fragile peace brought about by the two-year guerrilla cease-fire.

At the meeting, Lord Weir, the Balfour Beatty chairman, in answer to a question I posed about ongoing human-rights abuses in the Kurdish area where the Ilisu dam is to be built, expressed his sensitivity to human-rights concerns in the region. Nearly 3m Kurds have been displaced over the past two decades as a result of the Kurdish-Turkish conflict. According to Dr Ayse Kudat, a former World Bank expert, the lives of an additional 78,000 Kurds could be affected if the Ilisu dam is built.

Given the extreme delicacy of the ceasefire situation and the failure of the Turkish government to properly consult the thousands of Kurds who stand to be affected by the dam, it is my greatest hope that Lord Weir and Balfour Beatty will follow their own human rights policy, which asserts that the company is not prepared to work in "countries where practices may still be so very far distant from the Universal Declaration of Human Rights' principles" and withdraw from the Ilisu project. Failure to do so poses the real risk of further devastating the lives of thousands of Kurds.
Kerim Yildiz
Chairman, Ilisu Dam Campaign mailto:khrp@khrp.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Obsessions
fields.trailText:
It is not the hapless Barry George who is "obsessed with guns and celebrities" (Dando trial man seen at her home, May 5) but the editors of our national newspapers and the BBC. This is not the time for eulogies to Jill Dando, but the time for a fair trial. In England (so we are led to believe) a man or woman is innocent until proven guilty.
Gerald Morgan
Dublin

webTitle: The way things were

fields.headline: The way things were
fields.trailText: Kate Holland (Letters, May 5) uses the jokey Yorkshire past tense construction "When I were a lass".
fields.body:
Kate Holland (Letters, May 5) uses the jokey Yorkshire past tense construction "When I were a lass". I am a southener myself, but my late wife (from Leeds) always insisted that no Yorkshire person ever said "I were". According to her what they say is "I wa' ", the "r" sound being inserted, mistakenly, by ignorant southeners.
Don Benlow
Wisbech, Cambs

 Robin Cook's view of a multicultural Britain has been vindicated. Ronnie Biggs wants to "be part of the English culture again" to "enjoy simple pleasures such as a pint of beer and a curry" (Porridge? Ronnie Biggs just wants curry and a pint, May 4). And this from a man who has been out of the country for 35 years.
John Sheldon
Warwick john.sheldon@ntlworld.com

 So Bryan Gould (No one seems to love this government, May 4) thinks that Labour can inspire the electorate to vote for them "as a matter of self-interest". Marvellous. How very New Labour.
Philip Bloomfield
Banbury, Oxon philbloomfield@aol.com

 Peter Grimsdale is entitled to defend Channel 4's coverage of Formula 1 on behalf of its fans (Letters, May 5). It's a pity he and his colleagues felt they had to break Channel 4's contract to screen Tour de France highlights, which were also watched by thousands of sports fans and, frequently, by those just as interested in the French countryside as in who was wearing the yellow jersey.
Bruno Clements
Devizes, Wilts

 Was there some mistake with the photograph used to illustrate the article on crime statistics (London 'is safer than most EU capitals', May 4)? Surely this was an installation by Tracy Emin. Perhaps police should now make victims aware of the potential value of their trashed homes.
Robin Walton
Hayling Island, Hants

webTitle: Nomura loses its highest flyer

fields.headline: Nomura loses its highest flyer
fields.trailText: Guy Hands, the City's highest paid person, is quitting his job with investment bank Nomura to start his own business.
fields.body:
Guy Hands, the City's highest paid person, is quitting his job with investment bank Nomura to start his own business.

Mr Hands, who was once paid £40m for a single year's work, plans to leave the Japanese bank after six successful years to launch a £2bn private equity fund.

During his time at Nomura the 41-year-old has spent more than £10bn buying and then securitising the cashflow from assets ranging from the William Hill bookmaking chain to the Ministry of Defence married quarters estates and Britain's largest portfolio of pubs.

His final deal for Nomura is likely to be the £1.85bn purchase of the Le Méridien hotel chain for which he last week secured preferred bidder status.

Several investment banks are willing to back Mr Hands, though it may be a couple of months before the terms of his departure from Nomura are finalised. The talks are said to be amicable but remain sensitive because it is thought Mr Hands is owed several million pounds of unpaid bonuses for his work which has seen him make about £1bn in profit for the bank.

When he arrived at Nomura from US investment bank Goldman Sachs he is said to have negotiated a deal whereby he was entitled to 10% of any profits he made. While he has been richly rewarded for his work it is thought he is still owed large sums in back pay.

Sources close to Nomura yesterday indicated that the decision to let Mr Hands go had been a "tough but sensible" one. "In reality Guy has got too big for the bank," said one source.

Mr Hands' Principal Finance Group has absorbed about £2bn of Nomura's £10bn in investment funds. It is rare for an investment bank to have such a large proportion of its cash exposed to one business.

He wants to carry on doing bigger deals but Nomura feels it cannot match his ambitions. However, it may become an investor in his new fund.

A close friend of Tory leader William Hague, Mr Hands has become one of the City's highest profile figures after pulling off a series of deals that have transformed the way that big banks fund acquisitions.

An individual who friends say has an incredible ability to analyse complex figures despite being dyslexic, he tends to raise money in the bond markets, securing it against the cashflow generated from the assets he plans to buy.

He has built up a team of 60 highly paid whiz-kids, based in an office called the Data Centre, who work long hours pouring over financial projections in detail. Many of those staff are expected to join him at his new fund.

Mr Hands has amassed a £150m personal fortune. He, his wife Julia and their four children will in a few weeks move into a new £10m home in Sevenoaks in Kent, once owned by Winston Churchill, which comes complete with a £3m fitness centre, a den devoted to his passion of heavy metal rock music, tennis court, stables and croquet lawn.

webTitle: Letters: GPs present a host of complaints

fields.headline: GPs present a host of complaints
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee claims (Doctors may protest but they've never had it so good, May 2) that "things look set to get much better in the NHS".
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee claims (Doctors may protest but they've never had it so good, May 2) that "things look set to get much better in the NHS". Anyone working in the health service (which I left 15 years ago) will tell of precipitously falling standards of hygiene and service and widespread absence of adequately qualified or experienced staff.

For example, a staff nurse I know in a Huntingdon hospital recently searched for 20 minutes for a thermometer. My mother, who has been diagnosed with incipient glaucoma by her optometrist, has been told waiting lists to see an ophthalmologist are closed at six months at the local hospital. The GP has received a letter asking for no more eye referrals to be sent.

I work in the insurance industry, escorting sick holidaymakers back from hospitals in Spain, France, Italy and other countries, where standards are conspicuously better. I can only advise the patients I meet to have their treatment overseas.

It has come to the point where the NHS is not just in crisis, it is being surreptitiously downgraded and dismantled. Soon it will become the threadbare safety net that is the public health system in the United States and, as there, everyone that can afford it will be paying private health insurance.
Dr Stephen Coombs
London

 I am a GP and, frankly, I am insulted by Polly Toynbee's implication that we are obsessed with making money. The BMA has not always opposed changes, as she seems to believe. Changes have been going on for the last 10 years and the BMA has worked with successive governments often, in my opinion, to the detriment of the doctors whom it is supposed to represent. At last the BMA is making a stand; let us hope it is not to late.
Dr H Cox
Bingley, West Yorkshire

 I fear Polly Toynbee has allowed herself to be misled by spin doctors rather than real doctors. More and more is expected of GPs and there are major problems of recruitment and retention. Is there any other profession whose members are personally and individually responsible for ensuring the provision of care 24 hours a day, 365 days a year?
Dr Tony Stanton
London Local Medical Committees

 Our practice has been recognised as a "beacon" and has adopted a local contract and I sit on the primary care group board, so we are not averse to change. Most of all we enjoy our job and want to do it properly.

Unfortunately, there are not enough of us. It is impossible to deal with more complex cases thoroughly without spending more time with the patient. However, to meet access targets we will be forced to compromise on quality and potentially safety. Exhortations to work "smarter" do not square the circle and this is the major cause of our anger and, in many cases, despair.

The situation is made worse in my area where all the "extra" resources have been swallowed up paying off hospital debt, with virtually no growth for primary care. Meanwhile, GPs on the board are as much "in control" as Canute was of the sea, and NHS Direct find they've underestimated the number of calls - so guess who they pass them back to?
Dr Tony Rimmer
Warrington tonyrimmer@doctors.org.uk

 To suggest that 26 hours of NHS patient contact is all the work a GP does is like saying a firefighter's working hours should be judged by the time spent actually putting out fires. The increase in work is not only in unnecessary paperwork and monitoring but also in totally appropriate meetings around primary care teams, education, and administration around the needs of patients now so much more care has been transferred from hospital to general practice.
Dr Anna Livingstone and Dr Kambiz Boomla
London

 No Polly, it was the consultants' mouths that were "famously" stuffed with gold to get them to join the nascent NHS in 1948. General practice was seriously neglected and it sank into a near terminal state until revitalised in the early 1960s by the GP Charter. What forced its introduction? The threatened mass resignation of most of the GPs in the country. It may be needed again.
Dr Mark Sullivan
Truro, Cornwall marksullivan@doctors.org.uk

 If the job is so good, why are so many GPs retiring early, sick and fed-up, while so few are prepared to join the profession? It is indisputable that the work has become more complex and demanding, but the resources have not been made available to primary care to carry out the tasks. Things may "be set to get better" but promises for a second Labour term cannot disguise failures to deliver in the first.

The GP contract needs modernising, but the open-ended nature of it has been a bargain for the government at a price other health care systems in the developed world cannot match. In our practice we protested last week by offering our patients 15 minute appointments, the minimum we consider necessary these days for an adequate consultation. When are we going to be resourced to do this as a matter of course?

Blaming doctors is not new. Ask teachers how useful it is.
Dr Robert Mayer
London

webTitle: BT prepares to bite bullet

fields.headline: BT prepares to bite bullet
fields.standfirst: Life-saving plans include £5bn rights issue, sale of Wireless, and scrapping dividend
fields.trailText: Life-saving plans include £5bn rights issue, sale of Wireless, and scrapping dividend
fields.body:
BT is this week expected to announce its long-awaited radical shake-up aimed at shoring up its finances. The plan will include a £5bn rights issue, a full demerger of its BT Wireless mobile phone business and the scrapping of its final dividend.

The far-reaching overhaul is likely to be confirmed alongside results showing that profits have plunged by £1bn over the past year.

The decision not to pay a dividend will be the clearest signal yet to BT's millions of small investors that the world-class company that many of them bought into when it was privatised is now in urgent need of some remedial care.

The radical steps are being taken to cut the £30bn of debt BT has built up, largely by bidding for licences for the next generation of mobile phone networks. The planned £5bn rights issue will be the biggest in British corporate history, exceeding a £3bn fundraising by Vodafone last week.

The scrapping of the dividend will save about £1.4bn. Alongside that BT is expected to announce the £3bn sale of its directory business, Yell.

The unit, which includes the Yellow Pages directory, is expected to be bought by a consortium of private equity firms made up of Apax Partners and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst.

The demerger of BT Wireless, which includes mobile phone firm BT Cellnet, is likely to see shareholders in BT offered one BT Wireless share for every BT share they own.

Executives had previously planned to float off just 25% of BT Wireless but a full demerger is likely to happen as a result of shareholder pressure. Wireless will take some of BT's substantial debt with it.

Big City investors insist that there must be greater stock market visibility of the fast-growth parts of BT's business and those revolve around wireless. BT Wireless is estimated to be worth £20bn but its valuation will remain volatile while stock market analysts reassess the earnings potential of mobile phone firms following their heavy investment in new networks.

City shareholders have already forced senior management change at the company, with Sir Christopher Bland last week being headhunted from the BBC to take over from Sir Iain Vallance, BT's long-standing chairman.

Sir Peter Bonfield, the chief executive of BT, is also in the firing line, with the company reportedly ready to replace him if a suitable candidate can be found.

However, Sir Peter has been active in the past week selling off stakes in overseas firms that BT bought at a time when it was not crippled by debt. A much vaunted investment in Japan Telecom was sold to Vodafone for £3bn, while its stake in Spain's Airtel is also likely to be sold to the mobile operator.

On Friday it sold its stake in Maxis Communications, a Malaysian mobile phone oper ator, for £350m, bring the total value of the week's disposals to more than £5bn. That cash will be used to cut debt. BT is also moving out of its central London headquarters.

This week's results announcement and strategy shake-up will be the first public opportunity Sir Christopher has had to present himself as the new broom ready to sweep away BT's troubles.

However, many analysts fear that BT's problems go far deeper than the senior management troubles. They point to a culture of bureaucracy that extends far below board level.

Profits for the year to March 31 are expected to decline from £2.9bn last year to £1.95bn or so.

webTitle: Utility bills fall by £130 a year

fields.headline: Utility bills fall by £130 a year
fields.trailText: Householders are saving nearly £130 a year on their gas, telephone, water and electricity bills compared to the cost of the same utilities five years ago.
fields.body:
Householders are saving nearly £130 a year on their gas, telephone, water and electricity bills compared to the cost of the same utilities five years ago.

Research by the Department of Trade and Industry shows that where consumption is unchanged, households are paying less for their gas, electricity and telephones, but the full benefits of those savings are being offset slightly by increases in water bills over the period.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said that two years on from the full opening up of competition in the gas and electricity markets, the research proved that consumers were benefiting from real rivalry between firms.

In the last two years, electricity companies have started to offer gas services and vice versa. Several companies have ambitions to become multi-utilities. There has also been substantial growth of competition in the telecoms market, from both fixed-line and mobile operators. Consumers, however, are not free to choose their water provider.

The biggest price falls have been in telephone charges, where consumers who use their phones in exactly the same way as they did five years ago are now paying 19% less.

Gas and electricity prices have fallen by 13% and 11%, while water charges have increased by 5% over the period. However, water prices did tumble last year. In 1999 water bills were 16% ahead of 1996 levels.

fields.trailText: Sunday Times
fields.body:
Sunday Times

Canary Wharf, the property firm that owns a large office complex in the Docklands in east London, is preparing to raise £800m in the bond market in the next two weeks. The company plans to securitise the income on three of its largest buildings, returning £300m of the funds raised to investors, and using the rest to reduce a construction loan.

The cost of red tape to British businesses is estimated at £15bn in the last four years, according to a study to be published this week by the British Chambers of Commerce. Employment legislation and EU data protection are said to have helped increase costs.

Steven Cain, the former Carlton chief executive, is preparing a £400m bid for Halfords, the bicycle and car accessories' group owned by Boots, the Chemist. Mr Cain is thought to have private equity backing for the bid.

IoS

Sir Anthony Tennant, the former chairman of auction house Christie's who was the subject of a US arrest warrant last Wednesday, has received the support of French bank BNP Paribas. Sir Anthony, a director of the UK holding company for the bank, has been resisting attempts by US prosecutors to make him travel to the US to answer charges of collusion with his opposite number at Sotheby's to fix prices.

James Crosby, the chief executive-elect of HBOS, has said he will not spend more than one day a week at the new bank's Edinburgh headquarters. Mr Crosby denied that the merger was a takeover, saying that four of the seven senior executive posts would be held by BoS directors.

Sunday Business The Department of Trade and Industry investigation into the Mirror share-dealing affair is thought to recommend that no action be taken against the journalists involved. The DTI report into the actions of editor Piers Morgan and former "City Slickers" Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell is understood to be finished, though it will not be published.

Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Mobile is near to striking a deal with US firm Sprint , as part of its proposed $1bn (£694m) move into the US telecoms market.

Observer

A host of multinational companies, are considering lawsuits against the British government after the European court of justice ruled elements of the UK advance corporation tax laws discriminated against overseas firms. BMW, Deutsche Bank and Total Oil are among 40 companies who have launched claims, which could cost Gordon Brown billions of pounds in refunds.

NTL , the heavily indebted cable television company, is to make more than 3,000 workers redundant this year, with most job cuts likely to come from its 22,000 workforce in Britain.

Sunday Telegraph

Sir Michael Richardson, the former head of corporate finance at NM Rothschild , is thought to have been found guilty of breaching rules governing the financial markets. The securities and futures authority is reported to have sent him its findings relating to the alleged improper use of headed notepaper from National Westminster Bank. Tesco could face strike action in Ireland, its second largest market outside Britain. Chief executive Terry Leahy was last week in talks with unions who are complaining about pay among the 9,000 staff.

webTitle: European touch for M-way services

fields.headline: European touch for M-way services
fields.trailText: Granada motorway service stations are to receive a continental-style makeover as part of plans by their new owner, Compass, to transform roadside facilities.
fields.body:
Granada motorway service stations are to receive a continental-style makeover as part of plans by their new owner, Compass, to transform roadside facilities.

The 28 service stations, bought following a demerger of the chain from Granada earlier this year, are to lose their present brand identity.

Compass is reported to want a more European image, and has produced a shortlist of two potential names. A decision on the brand name is expected when the company reports its results later this month.

Compass chairman Francis Mackay and chief executive Michael Bailey also plan to extend the service station chain into Europe. They expect to win contracts for a number of the 200 continental stations due to come up for auction in the next five years .

As well as rebranding and expansion, Compass has planned a range of measures to increase revenue from its existing British service stations, which attract more than 70m motorists a year. It is already introducing Upper Crust sandwich bars on its sites and is thought to be considering establishing more extensive shopping facilities.

Under the plan, food and clothes retailers would be encouraged on to the sites - though the idea is likely to meet with resistance from the highways agency.

Compass hopes that the makeover will reverse the 20% fall in its share price since its deal with Granada was announced last year.

webTitle: Banham to quit Kingfisher

fields.headline: Banham to quit Kingfisher
fields.trailText: Sir John Banham, chairman of the B&Q, Comet and Woolworths retail chain Kingfisher, is to quit the company later this year.
fields.body:
Sir John Banham, chairman of the B&Q, Comet and Woolworths retail chain Kingfisher, is to quit the company later this year.

His decision to retire was confirmed yesterday after weekend speculation about mounting tension between Sir John and Kingfisher's chief executive, Sir Geoff Mulcahy.

The timing of his departure announcement is unusual. Kingfisher is attempting to split its activities by selling off or demerging Woolworths and Superdrug to focus on its trans-European DIY and electricals businesses.

Sir John explained that both he and Sir Geoff were approaching retirement age and that they did not want to leave at the same time. But yester day Kingfisher said it had asked Sir Geoff to stay on for a further three years. The 59-year-old chief executive is a very hands-on boss and has no obvious successor.

Sir John said: "I am delighted that Geoff will continue to direct the group's progress."

The separation process, announced last September, has been exceptionally tortuous and City analysts have become increasingly exasperated with the lack of progress.

Sir Geoff first favoured a float of the general merchandise businesses, and was then persuaded to consider a sale to trade or financial buyers. At least four buyers emerged for Superdrug, and Dutch group Kruidvat was considered favourite. But they have so far failed to offer the sort of price Sir Geoff wants and he has now moved back to favouring a demerger.

In the meantime the two Kingfisher executives he had lined up to run the newly floated business have quit and he has brought in former Railtrack chief Gerald Corbett as chairman of Woolworths.

On Friday Kingfisher issued a statement saying the split was still on course, but there was no mention of Sir John's imminent departure.

Sir John, who is also chairman of Whitbread, the restaurants and hotels owner, insisted that he had had no disagreements with his chief executive. Sir John took the job five years ago when Sir Geoff, who previously held both positions, was made to give up the chairman's role by shareholders.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 12 miners killed in Ukraine
fields.body:
12 miners killed in Ukraine

Nine miners died and another was missing after a blast on Saturday caused by a gas leak in a mine in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, the emergencies ministry said. They were working 110 metres underground.

Three other miners were killed while working deep underground in two separate accidents in the Donetsk and Lugansk regions. AFP, Kiev

Jewel thieves in grenade raid

About 40 people were wounded yesterday when thieves exploded a grenade while robbing a jewellery shop in a mall in a Manila suburb. Police blamed the Hammer Gang, who wounded 36 people last week in a similar robbery.

The blast occurred just before President Gloria Arroyo said she was lifting a state of rebellion imposed after protests by backers of the ex-president, Joseph Estrada. Reuters, Manila

Staff crisis hits Pope's guard

The Pope's private army, the Swiss Guard, is to advertise for recruits after a fall in volunteers as the Swiss economy surges. The force is supposed to be 120 strong, but yesterday's swearing in of 26 men left 13 places unfilled.

Complaints about low wages, boredom and a ban on living outside the Vatican have been blamed. Rory Carroll, Rome

webTitle: Germans are sick of atoning for Nazis

fields.headline: Germans are sick of atoning for Nazis
fields.trailText: An overwhelming majority of Germans are sick of atoning for the crimes of the Nazi era, according to an opinion poll published today. Six out of 10 Germans said they felt no guilt or responsibility for the Nazi era, while 61% said they were fed up with the continual "digging at old wounds".
fields.body:
An overwhelming majority of Germans are sick of atoning for the crimes of the Nazi era, according to an opinion poll published today. Six out of 10 Germans said they felt no guilt or responsibility for the Nazi era, while 61% said they were fed up with the continual "digging at old wounds".

In the survey in today's issue of the magazine Der Spiegel, 45% of the 1,000 Germans questioned agreed with the statement: "I am fed up hearing about the Third Reich and I don't want to hear any more." Only 6% said they felt some guilt for the war, while 32% said they considered themselves partly responsible.

More than half said that there should be room for forgiveness towards old Nazis, "as you don't know how you might react in such a situation".

Almost 28% of those polled believed that Hitler would have been a great statesman had he not instigated the war and the Holocaust.

The survey comes at a time when what have been dubbed the last trials of alleged Nazi criminals - now very elderly men - are taking place or are about to come to court in Germany.

Analysts say the results of the poll suggest that the country is keen to move on and be freed from the shackles of its past.

It also comes as Germany is seen to be entering a new era of boldness. The chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, tried last week to redefine Germany's position at the centre of Europe with his radical proposal to turn the European commission into a fully fledged government. If the Schröder plan is taken up, Germany will certainly be at the EU's helm.

The country's new self-confidence is seen to be perfectly embodied in the vast new chancellery in Berlin, into which Mr Schröder moved last week. But a survey in the newspaper Welt am Sonntag shows that 61% of Germans believe that the building is too big and a sign of arrogance.

webTitle: Obituary: Billy Higgins

fields.headline: Billy Higgins
fields.standfirst: Drummer whose inspirational playing made him a jazz legend
fields.trailText: Drummer whose inspirational playing made him a jazz legend
fields.body:
A desk editor on this very newspaper - a long time ago, and in a different climate - once challenged a proposed jazz feature of mine with the incredulous query: "How can you possibly write 500 words about a drummer?" The objection was coming from the incredulity of high culture as to the place of musical bit-part players, but it could just as easily have been popular culture incredulity too. Gags about drummers - their presumed crassness, unmusicality and general absurdity - have been amiably prevalent in the rock and pop world too.

Billy Higgins, the Los Angeles-born drummer who has died of kidney failure aged 64, was the kind of performer who despatched all that dismissive mythology single-handed - and he could deliver some thoroughly dazzling percussion information single-handedly too, though pyrotechnical displays were not his idea of a good time. When Higgins is described, words like "warmth", "love" and "joy" often wing by . These were not fanciful associations but occasioned as much by Higgins' appearance on a bandstand as by the astonishingly light, airy, dancing manner of his playing.

Few jazz drummers have ever looked as relaxed onstage or as much in their element as Higgins. A lithe, graceful man, he appeared to play almost unconcernedly, arms moving in arcs, the blur of the sticks on the cymbals taking on a plastic malleability. His fluid, caressingly subtle cymbal beat, a soft surge of sound that on its own would confound every cliche about unsubtle drummers, and which could lift the most laggardly of soloists into inspiration, was legendary on the jazz circuit for 40 years. Coleman began private workshop sessions with Higgins, trumpeter Don Cherry and bassist Charlie Haden; explorations which led to the birth of the Ornette Coleman Quartet.

The partnership with Walton continued into the 1990s, when Higgins' health problems began to disrupt it.

Through the 70s and 80s, Higgins was a popular drum choice for a wide variety of jazz leaders, from Milt Jackson, Art Pepper and JJ Johnson to Pat Metheny. With all of them, and as long as he was making good music, he usually looked like a man in paradise while seated at the drums.

He is survived by four sons and two daughters.

Val Wilmer writes: Billy Higgins played music with love. As he told me when we first met: "You're not supposed to rape the drums, you make love to them as far as I'm concerned."

The Brooklyn house where he lived in the early 1970s was one of my first ports of call in New York. The huge room, decorated with pictures of Malcolm X and African women, was always sunny and welcoming and so was he.

I generally arrived with a bottle of vodka. That wasn't for Billy, he was cleaning up his system, it was for me and the gang - women neighbours, saxaphonists Claude Bartee and Hank Mobley, bassist Wilbur War and a dynamic blind pianist named Chris Anderson. Sometimes my friend Terri Quaye came with me - she would play Billy's drums while he played the bass - and as the music and banter flowed I've never had such fun in my life.

webTitle: Obituary: Sir Patrick O'Connor

fields.headline: Sir Patrick O'Connor
fields.standfirst: Appeal court judge who rejected the appeal of the Birmingham Six
fields.trailText: Appeal court judge who rejected the appeal of the Birmingham Six
fields.body:
It is said that if judges were infallible, what then would be the point of the court of appeal. Unfortunately, as has been shown repeatedly in recent years, the court of appeal can be just as wrong, particularly in criminal cases.

Sir Patrick O'Connor, who has died aged 86, had the misfortune to be one of the judges in the second Birmingham Six appeal in 1988. Many observers believed that the convictions of the men for the bombing of a pub in Birmingham in 1974 would be quashed, but Lord Justice Lane said that the longer the proceedings had continued, the more the court had become convinced of the guilt of the men. Sir Patrick added that simply by reading the transcripts of evidence relating to alleged confessions, it would have been surprising had the jury not decided that the defendants had been lying but also that they had "jointly concerted their lies". It was not until 1991 that the convictions were finally quashed. At this point there was some criticism of Lord Lane and Sir Patrick but it was partially explained away by the fact that the 1991 court looked at different scientific evidence.

The son of a doctor, O'Connor was born into a Catholic family in India. He was sent to Downside and then, to Merton College, Oxford, of which he was made an honorary fellow in 1987. At the beginning of the war he was called to the Bar, joining Inner Temple (of which he was appointed a master of the bench in 1966). His pupillage was taken in the very strong civil set at 2 Crown Office Row, headed by Ronnie Armstrong-Jones, and which included the future Lord Justices of Appeal, Sir Edward Eveleigh and Sir Hugh Griffiths.

As a young man, ill health prevented him being accepted into the Royal Navy during the war and he combined his practice with wartime fire-watching. For six years from 1954, until he took silk, he was junior counsel to the post office, during which time he developed a strong general practice with an emphasis on libel.

Perhaps his best remembered case as a barrister - and certainly one which has had major repercussions for the Bar and its clients - came in 1966 when he appeared for Norbert Rondel. The former wrestler and strong-arm man for the slum landlord Peter Rachman sued his previous barrister claiming that he had been negligently represented in a criminal case. It was a case - which so far as the Bar was concerned - O'Connor fortunately lost. Clients could not sue their barristers for their actions in court. Rondel was not happy and, representing himself, took the case to the House of Lords where the decision was upheld. Nearly 40 years later, he is still trying to re-open the case.

O'Connor's judicial career followed the then traditional lines. He was the recorder of King's Lynn from 1959-61 and then of Southend for five years, until 1966, when he was appointed to the high court joining the Queen's bench division. He was also the deputy chairman of the Isle of Wight quarter sessions from 1957 until their abolition in 1971 following the Beeching Report.

The year after his appointment to the bench, O'Connor presided over the trial of Dennis Stafford and Michael Luvaglio who were accused of murdering Angus Sibbett in a quarrel over gaming machines in the north-east. Their convictions, perhaps not on the strongest of prosecution cases, have also led to a long-running and continuing series of appeals and efforts to prove their innocence.

That same year he sentenced the south London gang leader Charles Richardson to 12 years for attempting to get at the jury in a trial involving Richardson's younger brother, Eddie. Explaining why he considered an exemplary sentence was required, O'Connor said he considered there were few more serious offences than conspiracy to pervert the course of justice.

In his time on the bench he presided over a number of high-profile libel cases involving, among others, the one-time Manchester United manager, Tommy Docherty, who was complaining about remarks over his managership by the Scottish international Willie Morgan. Docherty dropped the case on the third day. O'Connor was also the judge when singer Dorothy Squires sued for libel over the oblique remark in Cosmopolitan that a pop star was "Britain's most famous wreck since Dorothy Squires."

Other actions he handled included Harold Evans's successful claim against Private Eye and the case that poet Pam Ayres brought against the Sunday Express. Back on the sporting field, he and others quashed the damages awarded to former Welsh rugby international JPR Williams after the Daily Telegraph had accused him of shamateurism. In 1989 he also was one of the judges who rejected the claim of a schoolboy severely injured in a rugby match, holding there was no duty of care for a school to insure its pupils.

He was then part of the court which criticised unregulated and unsupervised powers to the social security secretary. Nevertheless, the court upheld a high court decision ruling that an unemployed father of six was not entitled to a grant which would have allowed him to take a place on a government-sponsored employment training scheme.

O'Connor retired from the bench in 1989. Throughout his life he maintained his links with Downside, and as a practising Catholic was instrumental in reviving the custom of the traditional Easter retreat for former pupils. On a more secular note, this very companionable man - he was a keen sailor and golfer - was also devoted to St Patrick's Day.

His wife Mary, whom he married in 1938, died in 1984. He is survived by their two sons and two daughters.

 Rt Hon Sir Patrick McCarthy O'Connor, judge, born December 28 1914; died May 3 2001
