webTitle: Letters: the late Rita Hunter and the late Peggy Dear

fields.headline: Letters: Rita Hunter and Peggy Dear
fields.trailText: Megan Gardiner writes: I was quite miffed when I read the obituary by Tom Sutcliffe (May 2) about Rita Hunter, one of the finest Brunnhildes ever.
fields.body:
Megan Gardiner writes: I was quite miffed when I read the obituary by Tom Sutcliffe (May 2) about Rita Hunter, one of the finest Brunnhildes ever. I am an ardent fan of strong women, who are not afraid of their talents, their physical stature or of small-minded, narrow people. So what if she was a larger-than-average figure? There are enough of the slight and wispy women pushed into the spotlight, who have some talent but not the voice needed to sustain the truly big operatic roles. Hunter needed her larger stature to support her wondrous voice, and that was part of what made her such a character in the operatic world. Maria Callas' voice was never as good as it was when she was a bigger woman - she may have been a slim beauty, but the voice lost that touch that made it spectacular. Something Hunter's voice never lost, despite Sutcliffe's claims to the contrary.

David Ayliff writes: Peggy Dear (obituary April 20) was, indeed, a pioneer of women in stage management. However, the first woman stage manager in this country was Maud Gill, who took over the post at the Birmingham repertory theatre in 1917. She left a fascinating and entertaining account of her experiences in her autobiography See the Players. She was told that a woman ought not to be put in charge of stagehands because "working men" would not take orders from her, but she decided that, since mothers had been keeping order in the home since the beginning of time, the way to go about it was to treat them as a mother would treat her family. It worked.

webTitle: Debate: Holistic approach to success

fields.headline: Holistic approach to success
fields.trailText: As Tiger Woods basks in the glory of achieving what many people thought was impossible - holding all four major golf championships at once - golfers worldwide are looking to North America to see how he did it.
fields.body:
As Tiger Woods basks in the glory of achieving what many people thought was impossible - holding all four major golf championships at once - golfers worldwide are looking to North America to see how he did it.

For some time Gordon Brown, too, has been looking enviously across the Atlantic to see what he could glean from the performance of the US economy, particularly the stellar rise in productivity in the second half of the 1990s. But in order to learn more from America it is crucial to address all the factors at play.

A recent study by the Engineering Employers' Federation (EEF) has looked at the reasons behind the strong productivity performance of US manufacturers.

There are logical reasons behind the US advantage in golf and manufacturing. The sheer number of people playing golf and the money that goes into the game gives the US an inherent advantage.

Size also matters to the manufacturers there who have a homogenised, more protected domestic market six times bigger than that of the UK. This allows them to benefit from economies of scale and fewer demands for variations of their final product.

The US also benefits from a larger IT manufacturing base, which performed exceptionally well.

Irrespective of some of the "natural" advantages that the US enjoys there is still plenty we can learn from Uncle Sam. The attention that is paid to every aspect of Tiger Woods's game and the continued pursuit of perfection has to be applauded. Similarly we can learn from the experience of US manufacturers that have applied lean manufacturing (removing waste from all aspects) so intensely and with single-minded pursuit of continuous improvement.

Firms have profited from these techniques by marrying their implementation with the use of IT, enabling them to get detailed information on their performance. Many British firms have dabbled in these lean techniques but have failed to replicate the intensity and the end results of their US counterparts.

Higher rewards are on offer in US golf in terms of prize money and sponsorship. Similarly, in US manufacturing average earnings in the late 1990s were 20% higher than in the UK when adjusted for the greater purchasing power of the dollar. US firms have also made much more use of performance and profit-related pay, offering greater incentives to their employees.

By contrast, in the UK at tempts to improve productivity meet with more resistance given their association with job losses and retrenchment.

The close knit team of Tiger, his father Earl and coach Butch Harman has been behind his rise to fame. American manufacturers also appear better at working together as a team. Two-way communication between US managers and employees is freer flowing, with the end results that our firms are less effective at implementing change and US firms benefit from more employee involvement.

Employers are instrumental in tackling most of these issues. However, this does not let the government off the hook. Just like America's investment in all aspects of golf has paid off, our research pinpointed high investment and R&D as key factors in the success of US manufacturing. Sterling's volatility (and recent overvaluation) and a greater risk averse investment culture in North America have com bined to give firms a larger and newer capital stock.

Gordon Brown must recognise that government action is needed to give manufacturing the impetus to break into the US cycle of higher investment, productivity, earnings and profitability.

The chancellor's approach has limited itself to encouraging greater investment in IT by small firms. One area where the chancellor could act promptly is by extending capital allowances to cover investment in IT.

Tiger Woods would struggle to beat the rest of the world if he was forced to play with one hand tied behind his back. Yet many manufacturers are expected to do just that as they are bound up with more and more government red tape. The chancellor has failed to realise that his goal of increasing productivity does not go hand in hand with the increasing burden of regulation. Similarly, it is the government's responsibility to ensure planning permission is easier and cheaper to obtain.

Past victories in the Ryder Cup show that through teamwork we can overcome the golfing gap with the US. If employers, trade unions and the chancellor can work together to remove the barriers to productivity improvement they too would make a formidable combination. Employers must take their share of the responsibility, but Gordon Brown must also ensure that the government adopts a more comprehensive approach to overcome the productivity gap.

Dougie Peedle is deputy chief economist at the Engineering Employers' Federation
